headline: A Better Year for Trump’s Family Business (Last Year, That Is)
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Company Reports']
abstract: In 2019, the Trump Organization showed improvement over the previous year. But the company’s minimum reported revenues still fell short of the president’s first year in office, his new financial disclosure shows.
lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus ripped through the country, upending President Trump’s family business and the broader hospitality industry, the company last year showed modest gains, according to Mr. Trump’s annual financial disclosure report released late Friday.

headline: Court Frees Michigan Teen Who Was Held for Skipping Online Schoolwork
abstract: The release came more than a week after a judge ruled that the girl, who violated the terms of her probation by skipping coursework, should remain at the juvenile facility.
lead_paragraph: The Michigan Court of Appeals on Friday freed a 15-year-old suburban Detroit girl whose detention at a juvenile facility drew widespread criticism after a county judge ordered that she be held for failing to complete her online schoolwork.

headline: Federal Agents Don’t Need Army Fatigues
abstract: If you’re an officer of the law, dress like one. Leave the soldiering to soldiers.
lead_paragraph: Masked men, clad indistinguishably from soldiers, yanking civilians off the street in the dead of night and throwing them into unmarked cars is the modus operandi of totalitarian regimes — or the stuff of dystopian fiction.

headline: Canada’s Key Role in Creating a Once Awaited Vaccine
abstract: An American researcher created the polio vaccine, but a Toronto lab and a pioneering female scientist made its mass production possible.
lead_paragraph: Canadians don’t have to go back to 1918 and the start of the Spanish flu pandemic to find an analogy to today. For decades, waves of polio outbreaks gripped the country with fear, death and uncertainty, as recently as the 1950s.

headline: Quotation of the Day: China Wields Its Security Law to Crush Hong Kong Dissent
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 1, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “They are running short of confidence to face the people, to face the people’s choice, to face the people’s demands. It’s fear.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 1, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 1, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 10 about the Netflix documentary series “Last Chance U” refers imprecisely to coach John Beam. He identifies as multiracial, not white.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Seeing America With Megan Rapinoe’ and ‘The Last Narc’
abstract: The soccer star and activist leads a discussion on HBO, and an Amazon docuseries looks back on the murder of a D.E.A. agent.
lead_paragraph: SEEING AMERICA WITH MEGAN RAPINOE 10 p.m. on HBO. Megan Rapinoe may be one of the biggest stars in sports following the United States women’s national soccer team’s 2019 World Cup victory. But she’s also an outspoken activist for equal pay, racial justice and L.G.B.T.Q. issues. On this special, Rapinoe engages in a discussion with Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the comedian Hasan Minhaj and the New York Times journalist Nikole Hannah-Jones for a wide-ranging conversation about the upcoming election and societal issues the country is currently facing.

headline: A School Reopens, and the Coronavirus Creeps In
abstract: As more schools abandon plans for in-person classes, one that opened in Indiana this week had to quarantine students within hours.
lead_paragraph: One of the first school districts in the country to reopen its doors during the coronavirus pandemic did not even make it a day before being forced to grapple with the issue facing every system actively trying to get students into classrooms: What happens when someone comes to school infected?

headline: Edmonton, ‘City of Champions,’ Readies for a Hockey Marathon
abstract: The N.H.L. chose the small-market, hockey-mad city as one of two “hub cities” — along with Toronto — to host its playoffs.
lead_paragraph: EDMONTON, Alberta — It is said that hockey is the heartbeat of Alberta’s capital city. If that’s so then the 2020 N.H.L. playoffs are like a defibrillator that has shocked the city’s rhythm back to life.

headline: Yasmin Monet Prince, a New Action Heroine
abstract: The young British actress stars in “Hanna,” the action drama on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: Name: Yasmin Monet Prince

headline: Trump’s Approval Rating, Biden V.P. Search: The Latest in the 2020 Race
abstract: President Trump’s more sober messaging on the coronavirus crisis didn’t last long. For Joe Biden, the search for a running mate may last a little longer.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.

headline: Make Pizza … On Your Grill
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Pizza', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Bear with us. We know this sounds bonkers, but it really does work.
lead_paragraph: Homemade pizza is great. A 500-degree oven in August is not.

headline: How Woody Vines Do the Twist
abstract: Slowly, scientists are learning how lianas quickly climb.
lead_paragraph: Wood is typically thought of as stiff and rigid, but some wood, in the race upward to access the best sunlight, twists. Lianas, or woody vines, are concentrated in tropical forests; they possess a narrow stem that lets them climb to the top of the canopy, more than 100 feet above the ground, as quickly as possible by twisting their way around tree trunks. Basking in the sun at the top, these vines flower, fruit and lay out new leaves as they photosynthesize.

headline: The Little Fraught Schoolhouse
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Children and Childhood', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Second Homes and Non-Primary Residences']
abstract: New York parents of means are seeking less congested classrooms near their second homes in the Hamptons and Hudson Valley. Not everyone is happy about this.
lead_paragraph: Carlie Lawrence, 42, a fashion executive and mother of two from Manhattan, was facing the same fear that seemingly every parent of school-age children has these days: what if schools don’t open in the fall?

headline: Why a Data Breach at a Genealogy Site Has Privacy Experts Worried
keywords: ['Genealogy', 'Forensic Science', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Computer Security', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Nearly two-thirds of GEDmatch’s users opt out of helping law enforcement. For a brief window this month, that didn’t matter.
lead_paragraph: The peculiar matches began early on a Sunday morning. Across the world, genealogists found that they had numerous new relatives on GEDmatch, a website known for its role in helping crack the Golden State Killer case.

headline: Can Humans Give Coronavirus to Bats, and Other Wildlife?
abstract: Federal agencies suggest caution in U.S. bat research to avoid transmitting the novel coronavirus to wildlife.
lead_paragraph: Many people worry about bats as a source of viruses, including the one that has caused a worldwide pandemic. But another question is surfacing: Could humans pass the novel coronavirus to wildlife, specifically North American bats?

headline: Law to Reduce Crack Cocaine Sentences Leaves Some Imprisoned
keywords: ['Mandatory Sentencing', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Criminal Justice', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Law and Legislation', 'Probation and Parole', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: Critics say the First Step Act is being applied too arbitrarily by judges who are taking a hard line when it comes to revisiting nonviolent drug sentences.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lazelle Maxwell, 48, is nearly 12 years into a 30-year sentence for a nonviolent crack cocaine charge, a penalty exacerbated by previous run-ins with law enforcement that led to his designation as a career offender.

headline: The War on Frats
keywords: ['Fraternities and Sororities', 'Colleges and Universities', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Social Media', 'your-feed-selfcare']
abstract: Groups of fraternity brothers and sorority sisters are working to kick their organizations off campus.
lead_paragraph: In the past month, hundreds of students have dropped out of their fraternities and sororities at Vanderbilt University. They have gathered, digitally, using group-run Instagram activist pages. They have written searing op-eds condemning their own organizations for the student newspaper, The Vanderbilt Hustler.

headline: ‘Cocktails and Masks Don’t Really Go Together’
abstract: Young Russians are partying again, seeking a return to normal life and willing to risk a coronavirus surge. “We are people, not robots, and want to have a life,” said a bar patron (and doctor).
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When Nest, a cramped Moscow cocktail lounge, reopened for business in late June after more than two months of lockdown, it offered free masks and antiseptic lotion at the entrance to help calm any fears drinkers might have about sitting just inches from each other around tiny round tables.

headline: Like Old Hollywood Movies, Video Games Get a Polish for New Audiences
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'PlayStation (Video Game System)']
abstract: Game publishers are digging through their vaults to remake or remaster popular titles in a bid to kindle players’ nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: Nostalgia has always been a powerful source of revenue for Hollywood. Turns out, it’s equally lucrative for video games.

headline: Body Bags and Enemy Lists: How Far-Right Police Officers and Ex-Soldiers Planned for ‘Day X’
keywords: ['Neo Nazi Groups', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Germany has woken up to a problem of far-right extremism in its elite special forces. But the threat of neo-Nazi infiltration of state institutions is much broader.
lead_paragraph: GÜSTROW, Germany — The plan sounded frighteningly concrete. The group would round up political enemies and those defending migrants and refugees, put them on trucks and drive them to a secret location.

headline: Tammy Duckworth Is Nothing and Everything Like Joe Biden
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Despite their disparate backgrounds, the Illinois Democrat has carved out a public life most evocative of the man she could join on the presidential ticket.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tammy Duckworth, like the man she might serve as vice president, prizes loyalty in her ranks and occasional mischief in her workplace.

headline: 12 People in a 3-Bedroom House, Then the Virus Entered the Equation
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality', 'Service Industries', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Overcrowding, not density, has defined many coronavirus hot spots. Service workers’ quarters skirting Silicon Valley are no exception.
lead_paragraph: It was not surprising when three-quarters of the house tested positive. There were 12 people in three bedrooms, with a bathroom whose door frequently required a knock and a kitchen where dinnertime shifts extended from 5 p.m. well into the evening.

headline: This Sledding Team Trained Hard for Gold in 2010. Some Members Regret It.
keywords: ['Skeleton (Sport)', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'Concussions', 'Olympic Games (2010)', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: In skeleton, the headfirst Olympic sledding sport, the opportunity for unlimited training on the track can be a huge advantage. But Canadian Olympians who had such access believe it was bad for their brains.
lead_paragraph: The chance to host the 2010 Winter Games was supposed to be a godsend for Canadian athletes who compete in skeleton, the headfirst sled run down a twisting track.

headline: Indian Billionaires Bet Big on Head Start in Coronavirus Vaccine Race
abstract: The world’s largest vaccine producer, the Serum Institute, announced a plan to make hundreds of millions of doses of an unproven inoculation. It’s a gamble with a huge upside. And huge risks.
lead_paragraph: PUNE, India — In early May, an extremely well-sealed steel box arrived at the cold room of the Serum Institute of India, the world’s largest vaccine maker.

headline: The Strange Lives of Objects in the Coronavirus Era
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Design', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Museums', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: The pandemic has inspired a flurry of new and novel items — and given ordinary ones new meanings.
lead_paragraph: Plastic bubbles that hover over restaurant tables. Rods for contactless elevator-button-pushing. Portable seats that attach to lampposts, for shoppers waiting outside crowd-controlled stores. Dresses with skirts that have a six-foot radius. Podlike enclosures to keep gym-goers separate. A plastic sleeve that enables hugging at nursing homes. Masks in every imaginable form.

headline: Iran Will Expand Nuclear Program and Won’t Talk to U.S., Ayatollah Says
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: In a televised speech, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said that negotiating with Washington over his country’s nuclear program would only help President Trump get re-elected.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has said in a televised address that Iran will expand its nuclear program and will not negotiate with the United States, doubling down on his defiance of the Trump administration’s “maximum pressure” policy.

headline: Infections Swamp the U.S., Which Recorded 42% of All Its Coronavirus Cases in July
abstract: Thousands in Berlin protest Germany’s coronavirus measures. The virus is picking up speed in the Midwest. A summer camp in Georgia apologizes for hosting a retreat after hundreds who attended were infected.
lead_paragraph: Read our live Coronavirus Pandemic coverage here.

headline: Italy Draws a Line Under Genoa Tragedy, Shunting Aside the Benettons
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Privatization', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Tolls', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The government has leveraged anger over the collapse of Genoa’s Morandi Bridge to take back control of the nation’s highways. But critics say the deal sends a troubling message to investors.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Less than two years after the collapse of the Morandi Bridge in Genoa killed 43 people, Italy will draw a line under the tragedy on Monday when it inaugurates a replacement. But that public celebration has been accompanied by a behind-the-scenes deal that will reshape the running of Italy’s highways as it exacts retribution on the former bridge’s managers.

headline: Isaias Churns Toward Florida After Hitting Bahamas
abstract: The tropical storm is expected to be upgraded to a hurricane again overnight and may hit Florida’s coast, further testing a state that has been battered by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The Magic of Baked Feta
abstract: Yasmin Fahr’s sheet-pan baked feta, Angela Dimayuga’s black cherry-pistachio salad, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include Yasmin Fahr’s sheet-pan baked feta with broccolini, tomatoes and lemon (above), Angela Dimayuga’s black cherry-pistachio salad with charred scallion vinaigrette and Yewande Komolafe’s spicy cucumbers with yogurt, lemon and herbs. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: Robert Gnaizda, Lawyer Who Fought for Social Justice, Dies at 83
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Legal Profession', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: He challenged redlining banks, employers who discriminated in hiring and, early in his career, Southern counties that thwarted Black voters.
lead_paragraph: Robert Gnaizda, a lawyer who gained a national reputation defending the civil and economic rights of the poor and minority groups so successfully that lawsuits against their adversaries often proved unnecessary, died on July 11 in San Francisco. He was 83.

headline: Ethiopian Workers Are Forced to Return Home, Some With Coronavirus
abstract: Stigmatized, out of work and facing dangers, migrant laborers are returning by the thousands — and may be fueling a growing outbreak in Ethiopia.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — Unemployed and shunned as possible coronavirus carriers, Ethiopian migrant laborers are returning home by the thousands, placing a huge strain on Ethiopia’s poorly equipped medical system.

headline: Spend Time with Shakespeare’s Family and Try a Taste Test
abstract: As August arrives, you can learn how an author conjured Elizabethan England and engage your children’s five senses in a mystery game.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: How Do I Get My Landlord to Follow Covid-19 Rules?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: New York issued guidelines for how residential buildings should safely operate — but there no consequences for failing to comply.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a Manhattan rental building and staff aren’t wearing masks anymore, much less screening visitors. The building has been lax the whole pandemic, but it’s gotten particularly bad in the last two weeks. I can’t force our neighbors to wear masks, but I am often on the elevator with three or four people, without enough room to safely socially distance. In response to an email, management said, “We can’t enforce anything,” and ignored my second email. I am feeling very unsafe. What can I do?

headline: Under Pressure, Brazil’s Bolsonaro Forced to Fight Deforestation
abstract: After fending off international criticism on rainforest destruction, President Jair Bolsonaro caved to pressure and took steps to curb deforestation and forest fires.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A year ago, as fires engulfed the Amazon, President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil reacted to criticism from abroad with indignation: “The Amazon is ours,” he said, arguing that the fate of the rainforest was for his country to decide.

headline: Alienated by Trump, Suburban Voters Sour on G.O.P. in Battle for the House
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Suburbs']
abstract: House Republicans are on the defensive in suburban strongholds as voters reject President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: BALLWIN, Mo. — For Heather Vaughn, a substitute teacher and graduate student, the decision last month to place the black sign with colorful lettering in her front yard — the one that said, “Black Lives Matter” and “Science is Real” — felt like an act of courage.

headline: After Plummeting, the Virus Soars Back in the Midwest
abstract: States like Missouri, Illinois and Wisconsin are riding a frustrating seesaw during the pandemic, with new coronavirus cases rising again after apparent progress.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — First, the Pacific Northwest and the Northeast were hit hardest as the coronavirus tore through the nation. Then it surged across the South. Now the virus is again picking up dangerous speed in much of the Midwest — and in states from Mississippi to Florida to California that thought they had already seen the worst of it.

headline: ByteDance Said to Offer to Sell TikTok’s U.S. Operations
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Mobile Applications', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Trump administration has said the video app poses security concerns because of its Chinese ownership.
lead_paragraph: ByteDance, the Chinese internet giant that owns TikTok, has offered to sell all of the popular video app’s American operations as a way to save the business from being banned by the Trump administration, a person with knowledge of the matter said on Saturday.

headline: Dr. Eddie Negrón, a Physician Full of Fun, Is Dead at 69
abstract: Friends remember his jokes and his dancing as well as his medical care. He died of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, what should we call an erudite brace of acrostic constructors?
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage concerns one of my favorite language categories: collective or group nouns, also known as “terms of venery.” Apparently, many of them were coined centuries ago as hunting terms, and the Latin root ven-, from Venus, applies to the thrill of the chase, be it for love or, well, death.

headline: W.N.B.A. Rookie Showdown Halted by Ionescu Injury
abstract: Sabrina Ionescu, who was selected with the top draft pick by the Liberty, sprained her left ankle in a game against the Atlanta Dream.
lead_paragraph: Sabrina Ionescu accidentally stepped on Betnijah Laney’s foot near midcourt, then dropped to the floor after rolling her left ankle.

headline: More Games Postponed With 4 More Coronavirus Cases for Cardinals
abstract: Three staffers and one player for the St. Louis Cardinals tested positive for the virus, prompting the postponement of a game Saturday and a doubleheader Sunday against the Brewers in Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball’s sputtering effort to play in a pandemic took another discouraging turn on Saturday when one St. Louis Cardinals player and three team staffers tested positive for the coronavirus, forcing the postponement of their weekend series in Milwaukee.

headline: In Trumpworld, the Grown-Ups in the Room All Left, and Got Book Deals
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A large club of Trump administration evictees have turned their bracingly bad experiences into a new genre: political revenge literature.
lead_paragraph: It was the summer of 2016, and the Republican Party was about to nominate Donald J. Trump for president. Until then, many party members had aggressively opposed his candidacy. “I think he’s crazy,” Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, said earlier that year. “I think he’s unfit for office.”

headline: Protecting the Rights of Those With Disabilities
abstract: Readers discuss a series of articles about the impact of the Americans With Disabilities Act, passed 30 years ago.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Turn the News Into a Rose
abstract: You can make paper flowers as elaborate or a simple as you’d like. A simple bloom is a good place to start.
lead_paragraph: Paper flower-making is a popular craft that can result in blooms as complex and realistic as you want, from dahlias with 100 or more hand-cut, hand-curled crepe petals to coffee filter pom-pom carnations.

headline: Celebrating Eid al-Adha Amid a Pandemic
abstract: With socially distanced gatherings now the norm, we talked to a few people about how they planned to celebrate one of Islam’s holiest days.
lead_paragraph: Most countries observed Eid al-Adha on Friday, and so a belated Eid Mubarak to all who celebrated one of the holiest days in Islam. It is meant to remind Muslims of their faithfulness to Allah and each other, through Zakat, one of the five pillars of the religion that focuses on charity.

headline: For Two Teenagers on Election Day, the Political Gets Personal
abstract: In Brandy Colbert’s “The Voting Booth,” a girl who’s been speaking out since age 7 helps a drummer make his voice heard.
lead_paragraph: I was an adult the first time I volunteered for a presidential campaign. It was in 2008 for Barack Obama. As naïve as it sounds, I felt I was helping America begin to fulfill its promise: to be a place where “all men are created equal.” Fast-forward to today, when America has never seemed farther away from keeping that promise. In a world with so much injustice, how do we maintain hope and a willingness to fight, without burning out, or simply giving in to the easier option of looking the other way?

headline: Tank Tops and Short Shorts and Bears, Oh My!
abstract: In Carrie Firestone’s “Dress Coded,” a middle school’s sexist dress code is more terrifying than the bears wandering through its woods.
lead_paragraph: The Connecticut town where 14-year-old Molly Frost is surviving the end of her eighth-grade year has a bear problem. Bears have taken to wandering into people’s backyards and through the woods near the middle school, forcing the local school board to address the issue and prompting Molly, the main character in Carrie Firestone’s DRESS CODED (Putnam, 320 pp., $17.99; ages 10 and up), to sometimes carry a bear stick for protection.

headline: James Silberman, Editor Who Nurtured Literary Careers, Dies at 93
abstract: At Random House and elsewhere, including his own Summit imprint, he worked with James Baldwin, Marilyn French, Hunter S. Thompson and many others.
lead_paragraph: James Silberman, a revered book editor whose meticulousness, intuition and patience helped propel the publishing careers of a distinguished roster of authors, including James Baldwin, Marilyn French, Hunter S. Thompson and Alvin Toffler, died on July 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner Report Income of at Least $36 Million in 2019

abstract: The couple’s investments, mostly in real estate, were worth at least $204 million and as much as $783 million.

headline: Voting by Mail Is Crucial for Democracy
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: Especially amid the pandemic, it’s the surest path to a more inclusive, more accurate and more secure election.
lead_paragraph: For a man who votes by mail himself, Donald Trump is strangely obsessed with the idea that it is the most dangerous method of casting a ballot.

headline: Red Onions Linked to Salmonella Outbreak, Officials Say
abstract: More than 500 cases and at least 75 hospitalizations have been reported in the United States and Canada, the health authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Red onions grown in California have been traced as the potential source of a salmonella outbreak that has infected more than 500 people in the United States and Canada, health officials said.

headline: Homeland Security Reassigns Official Whose Office Compiled Intelligence on Journalists
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'News and News Media', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Brian Murphy’s office compiled reports of protesters and journalists who were covering the Trump administration’s response to unrest in Portland, Ore., last month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the Department of Homeland Security’s intelligence branch was removed from his position after his office compiled reports about protesters and journalists covering the Trump administration’s response to unrest in Portland, Ore., last month.

headline: More Than 1,000 Companies Boycotted Facebook. Did It Work?
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Online Advertising', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Boycotts', 'Media', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Small Business', 'Hate Speech']
abstract: Major advertisers on Facebook reduced their spending by millions of dollars in July, but not enough to significantly damage the platform’s revenue.
lead_paragraph: The advertiser boycott of Facebook took a toll on the social media giant, but it may have caused more damage to the company’s reputation than to its bottom line.

headline: Army Officer Who Clashed With Trump Vows to Speak Out on Security Issues
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Impeachment', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry']
abstract: Lt. Col. Alexander S. Vindman’s retirement from the Army after more than 21 years of service took effect on Saturday, the same day his sharply critical op-ed of the president was published.
lead_paragraph: An Army officer who was a key witness during the impeachment inquiry into President Trump last year and later retired after what he called a campaign of bullying and intimidation by the president and his allies, sharply criticized the administration on Saturday and said he would use his new civilian status to champion national security issues ahead of the elections in November.

headline: How to Stay Safer on Mass Transit
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Transportation', 'Commuting', 'Transit Systems', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Subways', 'Buses']
abstract: Timing your trip strategically, using contactless payments and not eating onboard are some of the things to keep in mind.
lead_paragraph: In cities across the country, ridership on public transportation has dropped precipitously as people have stayed home to help prevent the spread of the coronavirus. But for some, continuing to take mass transit was never optional. Many essential workers who cannot work remotely or don’t drive have continued to ride buses, trains and ferries; they are disproportionately people of color and the earners of lower incomes.

headline: Trader Joe’s Defends Product Labels Criticized as Racist
keywords: ['Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Customer Relations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The company had previously said the names of international-themed products that were intended to promote inclusiveness, such as Trader José and Trader Ming’s, “may now have the opposite effect.”
lead_paragraph: Weeks after admitting that some of its international-themed product labels might have fallen short of an “attempt at inclusiveness,” the grocery store chain Trader Joe’s is rejecting criticism of the labels — some with names like Trader José and Trader Ming’s — as racist.

headline: Puzzlin’
abstract: Did David Levinson Wilk keep you up with his sparkling grid?
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — David Levinson Wilk has constructed for the Times since 1996, although it’s been a bit since we’ve seen one of his Sundays. He’s been busy: He was a head writer for the recent television iterations of the “$100,000 Pyramid” and “Cash Cab,” and he wrote for “Who Wants to be a Millionaire” for nine years. Those impressive trivia chops come into play today in the fill, and the theme is good wordplay.

headline: Connie Culp, First Face Transplant Recipient in U.S., Dies at 57
abstract: Her near-total transplant in 2008 was at the time the most complex one ever performed. She was the fourth patient in the world to undergo such a procedure.
lead_paragraph: Connie Culp, the first patient in the United States to receive a face transplant, died on Wednesday at the Cleveland Clinic, where her procedure was performed in 2008. She was 57.

headline: Víctor Víctor, Known for the Hit ‘Mesita de Noche,’ Dies at 71
abstract: A singer, songwriter and producer, Mr. Víctor also worked to bring theater, music and dance lessons to underprivileged communities. He died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: U.A.E. Becomes First Arab Nation to Open a Nuclear Power Plant
abstract: The launch is raising concerns about the growing number of nuclear programs in the volatile Middle East.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Arab Emirates became the first Arab country to open a nuclear power plant on Saturday, raising concerns about the long-term consequences of introducing more nuclear programs to the Middle East.

headline: Lady Red Couture, ‘Mother Hen’ of a Drag Scene, Dies at 43
abstract: A fixture in Los Angeles clubs who stood 7-foot-2 in heels, she also co-hosted the L.G.B.T.Q. talk show “Hey Qween!”
lead_paragraph: Lady Red Couture, a comedian, singer and talk-show host who called herself “the largest live-singing drag queen in captivity,” and who became a mentor to younger drag performers, died on July 25 in Los Angeles. She was 43.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Law to Cut Drug Sentences Is No Help for Some Inmates
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 2, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like the luck of the draw. You’ve got people sitting in prison during a pandemic, and it’s not supposed to come down to who your judge is. It’s supposed to come down to the law.”

headline: Wilford Brimley, ‘Cocoon’ Star and Quaker Oats Pitchman, Is Dead at 85
abstract: Recognizable by his walrus mustache, the actor specialized in playing cantankerous characters in “Absence of Malice,” “The Natural” and other films.
lead_paragraph: Wilford Brimley, a portly actor with a walrus mustache who found his niche playing cantankerous coots in “Absence of Malice,” “The Natural,” “Cocoon” and other films, died on Saturday in a hospital in St. George, Utah. He was 85.

headline: NASA Astronauts in SpaceX Capsule Make First Water Landing Since 1975
keywords: ['Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Private Spaceflight', 'Motion Sickness', 'International Space Station']
abstract: Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley splashed down on Sunday in the Gulf of Mexico in the Crew Dragon spacecraft.
lead_paragraph: The first astronaut trip to orbit by a private company has splashed down safely in the Gulf of Mexico. Two astronauts dropped out of orbit in what was the first water landing by NASA since 1975, when the agency’s crews were still flying in the Apollo modules used for the historic American moon missions.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Connected’ and the SpaceX Landing
abstract: “Radiolab” journalist Latif Nasser hosts a new show on Netflix, and the SpaceX craft makes its return to Earth.
lead_paragraph: CONNECTED Stream on Netflix. As the director of research for “Radiolab,” Latif Nasser has covered all sorts of fascinating stories for the science podcast, like that of a Guantánamo Bay detainee who shares his name, or what the 2016 N.H.L. All-Star Game can teach us about democracy. Now, as the host of this new Netflix show, Nasser will uncover the surprising ways humans are connected to one another, the world and the universe at large. It’s a fascinating topic — one that highlights how a law of numerical probability applies to classical music, social media and tax fraud, or how a shipwreck laid the ground work for weather forecasting and cloud computing.

headline: To Break a Horse, and a Woman
abstract: How do prey animals stay safe in a world out to get them? And how would I?
lead_paragraph: Horses talk, but not like Mr. Ed. A horse may be trained to respond to “whoa” and “giddy up,” but if you speak to a horse, you’re not speaking in horse. They converse mostly through body language, and their most visible correspondence is a sign language of ears.

headline: ‘As I Started to Walk Away, the Second Man Reached Out His Hand’
abstract: Giving directions, a noisy Chinatown dining room and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

abstract: New studies in Europe and Asia suggest that riding public transportation is not a major source of transmission for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: Five months after the coronavirus outbreak engulfed New York City, riders are still staying away from public transportation in enormous numbers, often because they are concerned that sharing enclosed places with strangers is simply too dangerous.

headline: Florida’s Summer of Dread
abstract: The coronavirus had entrenched itself in communities from Pensacola to Key West, killing more than 7,000 Floridians. Then came Tropical Storm Isaias.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The crowded grocery stores, empty shelves and barren streets of South Florida in the dawning days of the coronavirus pandemic felt unsettlingly familiar: They resembled the rush of preparations and then the tense silence that precede a hurricane.

abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Less Sex, More Viewers: Pandemic Boosts Mexico’s Flagging Telenovelas
abstract: Dismissed as too old-fashioned to compete with streaming services, the melodramas have seen viewership surge from Mexicans seeking the familiar in a distressing time.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s love affair with melodrama was over.

headline: Driving Across the Globe to Fight Child Trafficking
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Philanthropy', 'Children and Childhood', 'Human Trafficking', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Automobile Racing']
abstract: Renée Brinkerhoff has been on a quest, on almost every continent, to use racing “as a platform to do something about” a global scourge. Next stop, Antarctica.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t until Renée Brinkerhoff’s last of four children departed for college that her life changed forever.

lead_paragraph: A Conservative lawmaker in Britain was arrested this weekend after a former parliamentary employee accused him of raping her, according to British news reports.

abstract: “I used to insist I didn’t get angry. Not anymore.”

headline: Storm Grazes Florida and Takes Aim at the Carolinas
abstract: Storm watches have been extended as far north as New England. Tropical Storm Isaias is on a track to reach land on Monday, with heavy rain and the potential for damaging floods.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended.  Follow our Live Hurricane Isaias tracker and updates.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Make Colu Henry’s white bean caprese salad, Yewande Komolafe’s baked tofu with peanut sauce, or the chef Rawlston Williams’s stew chicken.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Life during the pandemic offers its pleasures only fitfully, but there’s a good tomato getting ready for harvest on my solitary compound-bucketed plant and I’ve been looking forward to it all week. I’m planning on eating it sun-warm and cut into shingles between slices of toast, with a little salt and a bunch of mayonnaise. That’s summer’s greatest sandwich. I can almost taste it now.

headline: Baseball Is Playing for Its Life, and Ours
abstract: An outbreak of infections soon after reopening has struck a blow at more than just the Marlins.
lead_paragraph: In 1996, my rookie year in the major leagues with the Chicago Cubs, our manager Jim Riggleman often reminded us that we should play for the name on the front of our uniforms, not the name on the back. It was a noble idea — team before self — reinforced by the power big league athletes can feel when they realize they are representing entire cities, states, even countries, and taking a place in a long history of the sport they are so passionate about.

headline: Women Doctors Ask: Who Gets to Decide What’s ‘Professional’?
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Doctors', "Women's Rights"]

lead_paragraph: — Carmen Simmons, 27, a fourth-year medical student

headline: The Calm Voice Asking Thorny Questions in ‘Death, Sex & Money’
abstract: In her podcast, Anna Sale inspires her guests to share their darkest thoughts and deepest secrets. The intimate conversations feel more urgent than ever.
lead_paragraph: If you want to know what it feels like to be listened to, if, in our moment of detachment and division, you’ve forgotten the basic pleasure of revealing something delicate about yourself to another person, and of having that person respond by taking a sincere and sustained interest, allow Anna Sale to remind you.

lead_paragraph: The billion-dollar bailout of one of Ohio’s biggest utilities seemed suspicious from the start. It turns out the F.B.I. was paying attention, too.

headline: As Genoa Inaugurates New Bridge, the Feeling Is Bittersweet
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Politics and Government', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Viaducts']
abstract: Built in less than two years to replace the collapsed Morandi bridge, the new span is already a point of pride for Italy. But residents fear it will not be enough to revive their aging port city.
lead_paragraph: GENOA, Italy — Since the dramatic and deadly collapse of the Morandi bridge over the Italian port of Genoa two years ago, builders have worked around the clock, through a judicial investigation and the coronavirus pandemic, so a new bridge could open on time.

headline: U.S. Small Business Bailout Money Flowed to Chinese-Owned Companies
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Small Business', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Corporations', 'Social Media']
abstract: Millions of dollars of Paycheck Protection Program loans went to China-backed businesses in critical sectors, a study found.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has blamed China for the coronavirus pandemic and the ensuing economic crisis, but as the White House looks to stabilize small businesses in the United States, the rescue effort has had an unintended beneficiary: Chinese companies.

headline: Why Did Hong Kong Delay Its Election — by a Year?
keywords: ['Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Constitutions', 'Secession and Independence Movements', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Freedom of Assembly']
abstract: The government blames the pandemic. More likely, it was afraid to lose.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — And now, it’s election fraud.

headline: Britain Tried to Bring Fans Back to Indoor Sports. That Lasted a Day.
abstract: The world snooker championship welcomed spectators last week, part of a pilot program that offered hope to other events eager to follow suit. A few hours later, the government pulled the plug.
lead_paragraph: SHEFFIELD, England — The 2020 world snooker championship, which began on Friday, had a familiar feel. The stage of the intimate Crucible Theatre, the event’s home for more than 40 years, was bathed in klieg lights, the green cloth of the snooker tables and the red carpeting so brightly illuminated it was like stepping inside a Skittles bag. Judd Trump was back to defend his title, and for the first time in months, there were fans in the seats.

headline: Lady Macbeth in Appalachia, and Other Tales by an American Master
abstract: With a new collection, “In the Valley,” Ron Rash revisits the monstrous protagonist of “Serena” and plumbs the depths of Southern hearts.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half of Ron Rash’s mesmerizing new story collection is devoted to the eponymous “In the Valley,” a sequel to his 2008 novel “Serena.” If you’ve read that book, you surely remain haunted by its mythic powers. Nominally the Depression-era story of a North Carolina logging heir who returns home from Boston with a daunting new bride, it invested the power-mad Serena Pemberton with otherworldly malign qualities and gave her a big swath of North Carolina’s Appalachian logging country to despoil.

headline: Elizabeth Warren’s Evolution on Race Brought Her Here
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Ms. Warren, a racially progressive politician, is one of a handful of white women still under serious consideration to become Joe Biden’s running mate.
lead_paragraph: When Liz Herring arrived at George Washington University as a freshman in 1966, she entered a capital city in the throes of the civil rights movement. Just three years after a quarter-million people had crowded the National Mall to hear the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Congress was debating civil rights legislation as violent protests continued across the country.

headline: Birx Says U.S. Epidemic Is in a ‘New Phase’
keywords: ['Masks', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Medicine and Health', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare', 'Disease Rates']

lead_paragraph: Dr. Deborah L. Birx, the Trump administration’s coronavirus coordinator, said on Sunday that the nation was in a “new phase” of the coronavirus epidemic that was much more sprawling across the country than last spring’s outbreaks in major cities like New York and Seattle.

headline: ‘Immigration Nation’ Review: The Banality of Deportation
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Foreign Workers', 'Television', 'Deportation', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: This Netflix documentary looks at the bureaucracy of immigration enforcement — an intriguing investigation that probably won’t change any minds.
lead_paragraph: If you watch only one documentary about immigration, then by all means make it “Immigration Nation,” a six-hour Netflix series that mixes reporting with an impressive amount of vivid ride-along observation.

headline: Kayleigh McEnany Heckles the Press. Is That All?
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Trump does not always watch her briefings, and even his allies say she risks being known more for “hitting the press with a two-by-four” than advancing his priorities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the first half of his term, President Trump treated the White House press briefing as must-see television. From his small dining room off the Oval Office, he kept close watch over his first two press secretaries as they battled with journalists, defended his performance and often tried to rewrite history.

headline: U.S. Identifies Some of the Mysterious Seeds Mailed From China
keywords: ['Seeds', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Invasive Species', 'Herbs', 'Gardens and Gardening']
abstract: The 14 varieties identified include common ones, such as hibiscus, morning glory and lavender. Still, experts warned recipients not to plant them.
lead_paragraph: A federal agency said it had identified 14 types of plants from unsolicited packages of seeds that appeared to have been mailed from China, revealing a “mix of ornamental, fruit and vegetable, herb and weed species.”

headline: Mets’ Yoenis Cespedes Opts Out of 2020 Season
abstract: Cespedes had failed to show up to the ballpark in Atlanta for the Mets’ game against the Braves on Sunday, and the team did not know his whereabouts. After the game, they announced his decision to opt out.
lead_paragraph: When Mets Manager Luis Rojas realized Yoenis Cespedes, one of his most powerful hitters, was not at the ballpark in Atlanta on Sunday morning, he sent his outfielder a text message and followed with a phone call. Cespedes did not reply.

headline: Apple Fire Leads to Evacuation Order for 7,000 in California
abstract: The wildfire, near the San Bernardino National Forest east of Los Angeles, was burning out of control on Monday.
lead_paragraph: A wildfire that burned more than 20,000 acres 75 miles east of Los Angeles over the weekend continued to spread on Monday, forcing thousands of residents to evacuate, the authorities said.

headline: Relief Package Deal Remains Elusive as Impasse Over Jobless Benefits Persists
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Unemployment Insurance']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top Trump administration officials and lawmakers cautioned on Sunday that a deal over a new relief package to help people and businesses weather the coronavirus crisis remained elusive even as the debate over the details of the aid was set to take center stage in the coming week.

headline: Militants Attack Afghan Prison as Brief Cease-Fire Expires
abstract: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for an assault at a time when releasing insurgents from prisons has become a major issue in the Afghan peace process.
lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — Militants attacked a major prison in eastern Afghanistan on Sunday, detonating a car bomb and waging a gun battle against guards for hours, as dozens of inmates managed to escape, Afghan officials said.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']

lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank has opened an internal investigation into the longtime personal banker of President Trump and his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, over a 2013 real estate transaction between the banker and a company part-owned by Mr. Kushner.

keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Discrimination', 'Sheriffs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The polarizing former sheriff of Maricopa County, a stylistic doppelgänger to President Trump, is running for his old office in a state where approval of both men has slid.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — After 24 years of doling out his punitive brand of justice in Arizona’s most populous county, Joe Arpaio, who billed himself as “America’s toughest sheriff,” suffered a landslide defeat in 2016, largely because of his hard-line immigration stances and his own pugnacious defiance, which earned him a criminal conviction for contempt of court.

headline: Where a Little Mortgage Goes a Long Way
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Finances', 'Affordable Housing', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: Affordable homes can be hard to buy because lenders don’t make much money on small loans. But programs to encourage homeownership can help buyers build wealth.
lead_paragraph: The Shawnee neighborhood in Louisville, Ky., is a paradox: The houses are affordable, but they can be difficult to buy. The prices are so low that most banks and lenders will not bother writing mortgages for them.

headline: Covid Tests and Quarantines: Colleges Brace for an Uncertain Fall
abstract: Colleges are racing to reconfigure dorms, expand testing programs and establish detailed social distancing rules. And then, what to do about sex?
lead_paragraph: This month, many colleges around the country plan to welcome back thousands of students into something they hope will resemble normal campus life. But they face challenges unlike any other American institution — containing the coronavirus among a young, impulsive population that not only studies together, but lives together, parties together, and, if decades of history are any guide, sleeps together.

headline: Russia Sets Mass Vaccination for October After Shortened Trial
keywords: ['Clinical Trials', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Sovereign Wealth Funds']
abstract: The announcement raised concerns that Russia would begin inoculations and declare victory in the race for a coronavirus vaccine without fully testing its product.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia plans to launch a nationwide vaccination campaign in October with a coronavirus vaccine that has yet to complete clinical trials, raising international concern about the methods the country is using to compete in the global race to inoculate the public.

headline: Nordstrom Uses Influencers to Promote Safety and Draw Anxious Shoppers
abstract: Some retailers are turning to popular social media personalities to detail post-pandemic protocols and boost the allure of visiting their stores.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Nguyen, a fashionable Instagram personality with 1.1 million followers, is regularly tapped by retailers like Macy’s and Banana Republic to promote their wares on social media. They typically want her to take a stylish photo in their apparel and enthuse about their brand and any upcoming sale or product line.

headline: Theatrical Sort
abstract: Eric Bornstein’s debut puzzle puts us all in a state.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — This is a fun debut from Eric Bornstein with some little patterns sprinkled throughout. I know people realize this, but it’s certainly not easy to construct an easier puzzle. Today is a good example: Notice the precise setup, with straightforward clues for difficult entries and funnier clues for easier words, and the way that difficult and more accessible entries overlap, to give us fewer ways to get locked out of the solve.

headline: Mexico Seizes Crime Boss El Marro, Under Pressure to Cut Violence
abstract: While the arrest of José Antonio Yépez delivers a major blow to a cartel, analysts say officials lack a cohesive strategy against debilitating crime.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican federal authorities captured José Antonio Yépez, the criminal boss known as El Marro, on Sunday, landing a major blow against a cartel whose struggle for control helped spur record violence in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: A Group of Pac-12 Football Players Threaten to Opt Out of the Season
abstract: The athletes from 10 schools said they were dissatisfied with how their universities were handling the coronavirus, an approach they say prioritizes money over safety.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen Pac-12 Conference football players threatened Sunday to opt out of the coming season, saying they would not play until systemic inequities that have been highlighted by college athletics’ response to the coronavirus pandemic were addressed.

headline: Arrests Over Illicit Party Boat With 170 Guests Cruising Around N.Y.C.
abstract: It was yet another symbol of reckless socializing during the pandemic: The Liberty Belle was dinged for violating distancing rules, and its owners were accused of running an unlicensed bar, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The Liberty Belle, a riverboat with four bars, three outdoor decks and space for 600 guests, has been touted by its operators as a “favorite venue” of New Yorkers who hold parties, fund-raisers and other trendy events on the water.

headline: Several Private Boats Encroach on SpaceX Landing Zone
abstract: Onlookers circled the SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule as it bobbed in the water after its return to Earth, raising concerns about their possible exposure to toxic propellant fumes from the spacecraft.
lead_paragraph: Onlookers circled the SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule as it bobbed in the water after its return to Earth, raising concerns about their possible exposure to toxic propellant fumes from the spacecraft.

headline: In St. Louis, Testing Liberal Might Against a Democratic Fixture
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Cori Bush, an activist backed by the progressive group Justice Democrats, is trying to unseat 10-term Representative William Lacy Clay in a bid to turn protest-movement fervor into hard political power.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — As an activist who jumped into the political arena after the police shooting of Michael Brown here six years ago, Cori Bush is accustomed to hard fights. She has been maced, shot at with rubber bullets and cloaked in tear gas at so many protests against police brutality that they have blurred together.

headline: How the Media Could Get the Election Story Wrong
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Absentee Voting', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: We may not know the results for days, and maybe weeks. So it’s time to rethink “election night.”
lead_paragraph: Picture this Thanksgiving: turkey, football (maybe), tenser-than-usual interactions with relatives. And perhaps a new tradition: finding out who actually won the presidential election.

headline: Guyana Swears In New Leader, Resolving Struggle Over Oil Wealth
abstract: Mohamed Irfaan Ali will manage the flow of billions in new oil revenues, which are reshaping the small South American country and heightened a standoff after elections in March.
lead_paragraph: GEORGETOWN, Guyana — Guyana’s opposition party has won a bitterly contested general election, ending a prolonged political standoff that had crippled investment and heightened ethnic tensions in the small South American nation.

headline: As Federal Agents Retreat in Portland, Protesters Return to Original Foe: Local Police
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: While protests around the federal courthouse have remained calm for three consecutive nights, Portland police officers chased demonstrators through the streets near a local precinct.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Late on Saturday night, with protests in Portland continuing into their third month, one crowd of demonstrators gathered yet again in front of the city’s fortified federal courthouse while another group traveled miles east to a precinct used by local law enforcement.

headline: Biden’s Quietly Radical Care Plan
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Elder Care', 'Child Care', 'Home Health Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The candidate is talking about child care and elder care in the same breath, and making them part of his economic package. Both changes are long overdue.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden’s recent policy proposal to address the country’s crisis of care didn’t garner major headlines. There were no haphazardly capitalized Trump tweets in response, nor congressional Republicans denouncing it as socialism. But make no mistake: His plan is quietly radical in both its comprehensiveness and its framing.

headline: Why Are So Many People on Capitol Hill Getting Infected?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: Lawmakers are essential workers. They should start acting like it and protect themselves and the other people who work for Congress.
lead_paragraph: Representative Louie Gohmert, Republican of Texas, is not the first member of Congress to test positive for the coronavirus. At least 14 lawmakers, hailing from both parties and both chambers, are known to have either tested or been presumed positive for the coronavirus.

headline: Israeli Court Rebukes Prime Minister’s Son Over Harassing Protest Leaders
abstract: Yair Netanyahu tweeted the addresses and phone numbers of three men who led protests against his father’s administration. All three said they later received death threats.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — An Israeli court on Sunday ordered Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s older son to stop harassing three people helping to lead protests against his father’s administration after he tweeted out their home addresses and cellphone numbers.

headline: ‘Everyone Can Do Better’: Baseball Searches for Blame Amid Outbreaks
abstract: Major League Baseball’s commissioner put the onus on players to behave more responsibly, but some players and health experts see weaknesses in the league’s safety protocols.
lead_paragraph: With the Major League Baseball season becoming more precarious seemingly by the day amid a slow but steady stream of new coronavirus cases among the teams, the league’s commissioner, Rob Manfred, issued something of a rallying cry.

headline: From Minecraft Tricks to Twitter Hack: A Florida Teen’s Troubled Online Path
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Bitcoin (Currency)']
abstract: The teenage “mastermind” of the recent Twitter breach, who had a difficult family life, poured his energy into video games and cryptocurrency.
lead_paragraph: For Graham Ivan Clark, the online mischief-making started early.

headline: Tropical Storm Isaias, Grazing Florida, Takes Aim at Carolinas
abstract: The Florida coast was spared severe damage on Sunday, but much of the Eastern Seaboard is threatened with flooding rains.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Tropical Storm Isaias buffeted Florida’s eastern edge on Sunday with more heavy rainfall and powerful winds as it skirted the Atlantic Coast, leaving many people bracing for the threat of flash floods, storm surges and even tornadoes as the storm made its way north.

headline: ‘Clean Up This Mess’: The Chinese Thinkers Behind Xi’s Hard Line
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Law and Legislation', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)']
abstract: Chinese academics have been honing the Communist Party’s authoritarian response in Hong Kong, rejecting the liberal ideas of their youth.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When Tian Feilong first arrived in Hong Kong as demands for free elections were on the rise, he said he felt sympathetic toward a society that seemed to reflect the liberal political ideas he had studied as a graduate student in Beijing.

headline: Microsoft Says It’ll Continue Pursuit of TikTok
abstract: The announcement came after the company consulted with President Trump, who has threatened to ban the app and expressed national security concerns about it in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Sunday that it would continue to pursue the purchase of TikTok in the United States after consulting with President Trump, clearing the way for a potential blockbuster deal between the software giant and the viral social media phenomenon.

headline: Lord & Taylor Files for Bankruptcy as Retail Collapses Pile Up
abstract: The department store, which traces its roots to 1826, was struggling before the coronavirus hit. Its owner, the clothing rental start-up Le Tote, also filed for bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: Lord & Taylor, the floundering department store company that traces its roots to 1826, on Sunday became the latest retailer to file for bankruptcy protection as the coronavirus outbreak accelerates the demise of chains that were already teetering.

headline: Leon Fleisher, 92, Dies; Spellbinding Pianist Using One Hand or Two
abstract: Unable to use his right hand, he performed pieces written for left hand only, conducted and taught. Years later, he made a triumphant two-handed comeback.
lead_paragraph: Leon Fleisher, a leading American pianist in the 1950s and early ’60s who was forced by an injury to his right hand to channel his career into conducting, teaching and mastering the left-hand repertoire, died on Sunday in Baltimore. He was 92.

lead_paragraph: It was a weekend of chaos on TikTok — unleashed on Friday night when President Trump said, while aboard Air Force One, that he might ban the video app.

headline: Marathon Is Selling Speedway Gas Stations to 7-Eleven’s Parent for $21 Billion
abstract: The largest U.S. independent refining company will get cash, and 7-Eleven will add 4,000 convenience stores.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Marathon Petroleum, the largest U.S. independent refiner, announced on Sunday that it had sold its Speedway gas station chain to the Japanese retail group Seven & I Holdings for $21 billion in cash.

abstract: Operation Warp Speed has moved along at a rapid clip. But some people involved in the process fear pressure to deliver an October surprise for President Trump.
lead_paragraph: In April, with hospitals overwhelmed and much of the United States in lockdown, the Department of Health and Human Services produced a presentation for the White House arguing that rapid development of a coronavirus vaccine was the best hope to control the pandemic.

headline: Private Boats Enter SpaceX Splashdown Area, Raising Concerns
abstract: “We need to do a better job next time” of securing the area, the NASA administrator, Jim Bridenstine, said.
lead_paragraph: Two American astronauts were greeted by a group of private boats on Sunday as their SpaceX capsule splashed down safely in the Gulf of Mexico, an encroachment that distracted from an otherwise triumphant milestone for the country’s resurgent space program.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s choice to fill the Pentagon’s top policy job withdrew his name from consideration on Sunday after senators from both parties voiced opposition to the official’s nomination, largely because of his history of inflammatory comments.

headline: Microsoft Can Save TikTok — if Trump Doesn’t Mess It Up
abstract: Microsoft wants to buy the Chinese app, and the administration needs to get out of the way.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Immigration Nation’ and ‘Dora and the Lost City of Gold’
abstract: A six-part docu-series about the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency is on Netflix. And a live-action adaptation of “Dora” arrives on Hulu.
lead_paragraph: IMMIGRATION NATION Stream on Netflix. Leaders of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency granted behind-the-scenes access to Christina Clusiau and Shaul Schwarz to film this documentary series in 2017. But the filmmakers claim that when the project was nearly completed, government officials fought to censor it and delay its release. (Jenny L. Burke, the ICE press secretary, has disputed the accuracy of these statements.) Now viewers can see for themselves, in the six-part series that offers a candid look at the agency’s operations and tells the stories of some of the immigrants involved. “Part of what makes the film unique is that the creators were allowed not only to enter certain detention facilities but to interview people inside and then follow their cases through the labyrinthine immigration system,” The New York Times reported.

headline: Men’s Wearhouse Owner Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Tailored Brands, known for its clothing chains Men’s Wearhouse and JoS. A. Bank, struggled as the pandemic shut stores and consumer demand for office attire dropped.
lead_paragraph: The owner of Men’s Wearhouse and JoS. A. Bank, which once dominated the market for affordable men’s suits, filed for bankruptcy protection late Sunday, as demand plummeted for its corporate clothing with the coronavirus pandemic keeping America’s office workers at home.

headline: Is Telemedicine Here to Stay?
keywords: ['Telemedicine', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Elderly', 'Medicare', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Doctors', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: The answer largely depends on whether Medicare and private health insurers will adequately cover virtual doctor visits once coronavirus outbreaks subside.
lead_paragraph: Telemedicine is having its moment. Over the last few months, millions of people have relied on video or telephone calls to talk to their doctors. But as the pandemic moves across the United States, and eventually recedes in some places, how long will the moment last?

headline: Abductions, Censorship and Layoffs: Pakistani Critics Are Under Siege
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Political Prisoners', 'Unemployment', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Recent abductions of a journalist and an activist have underscored Pakistan’s worsening rights conditions as the country’s security forces pressure the news media and human rights groups.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Imran Khan boasted last year that Pakistan had one of the “freest presses in the world,” journalists were quick to object, saying that intimidation of reporters across the country was intensifying. It has only gotten worse since.

headline: Why the Botched N.Y.C. Primary Has Become the November Nightmare
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Nearly six weeks later, two congressional races remain undecided, and officials are trading blame over the mishandling of tens of thousands of mail-in ballots.
lead_paragraph: Election officials in New York City widely distributed mail-in ballots for the primary on June 23, which featured dozens of hard-fought races. The officials had hoped to make voting much easier, but they did not seem prepared for the response: more than 10 times the number of absentee ballots received in recent elections in the city.

headline: In Showdown Between China and the West, HSBC Gets Caught in the Middle
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States International Relations', '5G (Wireless Communications)', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Global businesses are increasingly being asked to pick political and legal sides in the confrontation between the world’s two biggest economies.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Like Hong Kong, HSBC has long sat at the crossroads between East and West, a big global bank based in Britain that has reveled in and profited from its deep relationship with China. And like Hong Kong, it is now caught in the middle of a new era of confrontation between Beijing and major Western governments.

headline: After 100 Podcasts, JJ Redick Widens His Range
abstract: The New Orleans Pelicans shooter is starting a new show and a production company to develop more podcasts.
lead_paragraph: JJ Redick of the New Orleans Pelicans came prepared.

headline: Why One Team Named the Indians Won’t Be Changing Its Name
abstract: A minor league team in Spokane, Wash., has steadfastly stood by its nickname with the support of the local Native American community.
lead_paragraph: Many sports teams using names and mascots invoking Native Americans do so over the longstanding and strenuous objections of people who say it is racist. Some teams, after years of stubborn refusal, have recently relented, like the Washington Football Team of the N.F.L., which abandoned its nickname last month.

headline: Gymnasts Worldwide Push Back on Their Sport’s Culture of Abuse
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Gymnastics', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Corporal Punishment', 'Women and Girls', 'Social Media', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: On Instagram and other social networks, gymnasts have tagged posts with #GymnastAlliance to share their own experiences in the wake of a new documentary that highlights verbal and physical abuse by coaches.
lead_paragraph: A culture in gymnastics that has tolerated coaches belittling, manipulating and in some cases physically abusing young athletes is being challenged by Olympians and other gymnasts around the world after an uprising in the United States.

headline: Can’t Find It at the Store?
abstract: How to make sure everyone gets what they need — and feels good about it.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus pandemic hit, Kate Coffman, who works at Alliance Brewing Company in Knoxville, Tenn., knew cash was going to be tight for a while. Although her brewery has stayed open for takeout, she has worked fewer hours and business is down. When a friend, Angie Ervin, started a local bartering group on Facebook, Ms. Coffman was eager to join.

headline: 29 Dead After ISIS Attack on Afghan Prison
abstract: The 20-hour gun battle left officials scrambling to recapture hundreds of prisoners, including many from the Islamic State and the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — A militant assault on a prison complex in eastern Afghanistan ended on Monday after a 20-hour gun battle, leaving 29 people dead and officials scrambling to recapture hundreds of prisoners, including many from the Islamic State and the Taliban.

abstract: “There’s such a laziness about reaching for the thing that is most familiar.”

lead_paragraph: UNCONDITIONALThe Japanese Surrender in World War IIBy Marc Gallicchio

headline: The Benefits of Talking to Strangers
abstract: Casual connections with people we encounter in the course of daily life can give us the sense of belonging to a community.
lead_paragraph: I’m a lifelong extrovert who readily establishes and relishes casual contacts with people I encounter during daily life: while walking my dog, shopping for groceries, working out at the Y, even sweeping my sidewalk. These ephemeral connections add variety to my life, are a source of useful information and often provide needed emotional and physical support. Equally important, they nearly always leave me with a smile on my face (although now hidden under a mask!).

headline: How to Ace an Online Job Interview
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Telecommuting', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: A handful of classic techniques and some tips unique to the work-from-home era can help you land that next job.
lead_paragraph: The in-person job interview went away when offices emptied this spring because of the coronavirus pandemic. On the plus side, no more flying out to company headquarters and staying at a hotel, just to spend a day of meetings in an uncomfortable suit and then heading right back home. On the downside, common technical snafus and fewer body language clues can make the online process feel fraught. To successfully make the jump to team member from virtual job seeker, brush up on classic interview techniques and adapt them to the new world of internet interviews.

headline: In This Pandemic Summer, Don’t Forget About Kids’ Other Risks
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Summer (Season)', 'Heatstroke', 'Drownings', 'Sports Injuries', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Trampolines', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Reinforcing summer safety with some of the special twists and dangers of this dangerous and twisty time.
lead_paragraph: I’m not sure whether to call this the good news or the bad news, but Covid-19 is not the only thing that parents need to think about right now.

headline: We Lebanese Thought We Could Survive Anything. We Were Wrong.
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'Currency', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The myth of their resilience helped the Lebanese function despite a miserably corrupt and inept state. No longer.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT — Anyone who knows Lebanon has heard this: The Lebanese are resilient. A reputation earned by weathering an outsize list of challenges over the years: a 15-year civil war, political tensions with Syria, wars with Israel and a collapsing public service infrastructure.

headline: One-Third of New York’s Small Businesses May Be Gone Forever
abstract: Small-business owners said they have exhausted federal and local assistance and see no end in sight after months of sharp revenue drops. Now, many are closing their shops and restaurants for good.
lead_paragraph: In early March, Glady’s, a Caribbean restaurant in Brooklyn, was bringing in about $35,000 a week in revenue. The Bank Street Bookstore, a 50-year-old children’s shop in Manhattan, was preparing for busy spring and summer shopping seasons. And Busy Bodies, a play space for children in Brooklyn, had just wrapped up months of packed classes with long waiting lists.

headline: Death of a Cat
abstract: For weeks, I have been trying to understand my own tears in the presence of a dying creature I did not love.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — I first saw it in bits — two paws here, the tip of a tail there — on grainy, black-and-white images taken by our backyard trail camera. Normally that device captures only the wild animals you’d expect to find in a first-ring suburb: opossums, mainly, but also rabbits and raccoons and rat snakes, sometimes an owl, now and then a fox. I once saw a bobcat slink across our street, but it’s never shown up in the trail-cam photos. My heart lifted when I first saw a clearly feline haunch in one of the pictures, but the scale was all wrong for a bobcat. It was just an ordinary house cat, prowling in my backyard.

headline: I’d Need Evidence Before I’d Get a Covid-19 Vaccine. It Doesn’t Exist Yet.
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Immune System', 'Research', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Scientists need to show us the data. And that’s exactly what they’re working on.
lead_paragraph: Coronavirus vaccines are rapidly advancing through the development pipeline. The University of Oxford’s vaccine is in large trials in Britain, Brazil and South Africa. In the United States, researchers just began enrolling around 30,000 volunteers to test Moderna’s vaccine, and more trials are starting every day. Operation Warp Speed has set an ambitious goal of delivering 300 million doses of a safe, effective vaccine by January.

keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Roommates', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']

lead_paragraph: Most people spent the spring trying to stay as far away from strangers as possible. But for renters like Elizabeth Merritt and Michael Daly, who needed to find roommates in the midst of the pandemic, moving in with someone they had never met was part of the reality of living in New York, global health crisis or not.

headline: A Hospital Forgot to Bill Her Coronavirus Test. It Cost Her $1,980.
keywords: ['Tests (Medical)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
