headline: ‘Boxed Into a Corner,’ Sturgis Braces for Thousands to Attend Motorcycle Rally
abstract: The annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally may attract 250,000 people even though South Dakota’s coronavirus cases have been rising.
lead_paragraph: For most of the year, Sturgis, S.D., is a relatively quiet city of 7,000 residents tucked beside a 1.2 million-acre forest, with a motorcycle museum as its signature attraction. But each summer, Sturgis transforms as bikers descend for a massive motorcycle rally.

headline: Poem: i want to speak of unity
abstract: A poem that testifies to the deepest parts of the American dream  from the times when hope was bright.
lead_paragraph: Each of us carries a cord of hope through all our wandering days. Where it begins, when we found ourselves leaving home — so many homes; or when we arrived, when consciousness widened to possibilities of community — the cord grows stronger or frays. Juan Felipe Herrera’s magnificent new poems in “Every Day We Get More Illegal” testify to the deepest parts of the American dream — the streets and parking lots, the stores and restaurants and futures that belong to all — from the times when hope was bright, more like an intimate song than any anthem stirring the blood. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: Don’t Fall for Trump’s Census Bait-and-Switch
keywords: ['Census', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Latinos should not let the president intimidate them into not being counted.
lead_paragraph: Last month, President Trump ordered the Commerce Department to do what it legally could to exclude undocumented immigrants from the census count used to redraw congressional districts. Then on Monday, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross announced that the constitutionally mandated 2020 census would end a month early.

headline: The Teenage Tinkerer Behind an E-Bike Revolution
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: Mike Radenbaugh dreamed up Rad Power Bikes over a decade ago in his family’s garage and now sets the pace for affordable battery-propelled bicycles.
lead_paragraph: The residents of Garberville, Calif., didn’t know what to make of 15-year-old Mike Radenbaugh and the odd motorized bikes he was concocting in his family’s garage.

headline: The Real Reason the American Economy Boomed After World War II
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Whites', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Income Inequality', 'Women and Girls', 'Unemployment', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: How expanding opportunity for women, immigrants and nonwhite workers helped everyone — and why we need to do so again.
lead_paragraph: The United States long reserved its most lucrative occupations for an elite class of white men. Those men held power by selling everyone else a myth: The biggest threat to workers like you are workers who do not look like you. Again and again, they told working-class white men that they were losing out on good jobs to women, nonwhite men and immigrants.

headline: Congress’s Ideological Divide Has Stymied Aid for Pandemic-Stricken Schools
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Republicans and Democrats agree that schools need billions of dollars to reopen, but policy fights have the parties at loggerheads, with educators growing desperate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans and Democrats in Congress say they agree that a new stimulus package must include billions of dollars to help schools struggling financially and logistically to resume education this month and next.

headline: ‘Out Stealing Horses’ Review: Old Man, Take a Look at Your Life
abstract: But the protagonist of this film, based on a Norwegian novel, would prefer to forget the past.
lead_paragraph: Adapted from the highly acclaimed 2003 novel by Per Petterson, “Out Stealing Horses,” written and directed by Hans Petter Moland, is an ambitious film that examines memory and consciousness through the perspective of an older man who’s determined to escape from memory and to constrict his lived experience.

headline: Mike Fiers Is Moving On, Just Like He Always Has
abstract: Fiers revealed the cheating scheme by the Houston Astros, his former club, but he has fended off attention ever since. “He wants the game to be straightaway,” his father said.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t exactly the 2020 debut Mike Fiers had spent an interrupted spring training and abbreviated summer camp envisioning. When he finally got on the mound for a real game on Major League Baseball’s opening weekend, Oakland’s right-handed pitcher allowed seven hits and four runs — three of them on a mighty home run by Mike Trout. Despite his ordinary performance, the Athletics still beat the Los Angeles Angels, 6-4.

headline: ‘Racism Makes a Liar of God’
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: How the American Catholic Church is wrestling with the Black Lives Matter movement.
lead_paragraph: In 1963, when 250,000 demonstrators gathered at the Lincoln Memorial and heard the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I have a dream” speech, they did so under the prayerful invocation of Archbishop Patrick O’Boyle of Washington. He called for the Holy Spirit to open the eyes of Christians to the injustice of racial discrimination, condemned violence and praised the activists who had possessed the courage to go forth, like Moses, in search of a beautiful country.

headline: Classical Music Attracts Older Audiences. Good.
abstract: Especially during a pandemic, the graying of audiences has been seen as a sign of precariousness. But maybe these older listeners are a lifeline.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic poses a grave challenge to all of the performing arts. There are few ways to mitigate the risk from packing performers and audiences tightly together without fundamentally altering the experience of these art forms, which thrive on crowds.

headline: Who Was Behind the Largest Mass Arrest in U.S. History?
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Vietnam War', 'National Mall (Washington, DC)']
abstract: Washington’s police chief took the blame. But Nixon was behind the decision.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1971, Richard Nixon found himself in a situation not unlike President Trump’s. His approval rating was falling — in Mr. Nixon’s case, to a first-term low — just as an energetic social movement was hitting the streets. Like Mr. Trump, Mr. Nixon was tempted to use military force to counter those dissenters. And like the current president, Mr. Nixon and his aides found a way around the Pentagon’s resistance.

headline: White Customers, Black Fabrics
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Textiles', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: Black-owned businesses make amazing clothing inspired by African patterns. What happens when, inevitably, everyone else starts buying them?
lead_paragraph: The recent outpouring of support for Black-owned businesses has brought attention to fashion labels that work with African prints. The labels, many of them founded by West African designers living in the United States and Britain, are turning the traditional patterns of West African fabric into contemporary American silhouettes.

headline: ‘It’s Kitchen Sink Time’: Fast, Less-Accurate Coronavirus Tests May Be Good Enough
keywords: ['Tests (Medical)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shortages', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Research', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Experts are revising their views on the best methods to detect infections, setting aside long-held standards so that the spread of the virus can be more quickly tracked and contained.
lead_paragraph: For months, the call for coronavirus testing has been led by one resounding refrain: To keep outbreaks under control, doctors and researchers need to deploy the most accurate tests available — ones reliable enough to root out as many infections as possible, even in the absence of symptoms.

headline: A Family Cries ‘Justice for Hannah.’ Will Its Rural Town Listen?
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Rural Areas']
abstract: People in rural areas are killed in police shootings at about the same rate as in cities, but victims’ families and activists say they have struggled to get justice or even make themselves heard.
lead_paragraph: SEDALIA, Mo. — Seven weeks had passed, and still there were no answers. So once again, a small cluster of friends and family gathered in the leafy courthouse square and marched for Hannah Fizer, an unarmed woman shot and killed by a rural Missouri sheriff’s deputy during a traffic stop.

headline: Self-Publishing Is a Gamble. Why Is Donald Trump Jr. Doing It?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Writing and Writers', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: His next book, “Liberal Privilege,” comes with an unusual distribution plan and no publishing house behind it, making it something of a curiosity in the industry.
lead_paragraph: There is a lot about Donald Trump Jr.’s second book that is unusual.

headline: ‘It’s Time for a Change’: Workers Idled by the Virus Try New Careers
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Careers and Professions', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Quarantines', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Unemployment', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Facing a loss of hours, unsecured wages and slow reopenings, some unemployed Britons are reconsidering their livelihoods.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — As a national lockdown was imposed in March, a food deliverer, Hanna Scaife, watched her weekly hours plummet from 30, to five, then to zero as restaurants across Teesside, in northeast England, shut their doors.

headline: Witnessing Nuclear Carnage, Then Devoting Her Life to Peace
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Nobel Prizes']
abstract: Setsuko Thurlow, a survivor of the atomic bombing in Hiroshima 75 years ago, has used the power of her personal story to try to rid the world of nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Aug. 6, 1945, Setsuko Thurlow, then just 13, reported for her first full day of duty in Japan’s increasingly desperate war effort. Together with 30 other girls, she had been recruited to assist with code breaking at a military office in Hiroshima.

headline: ‘Motorcycle of Tomorrow’ Is Heavy on Flair and Light on the Environment
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Automobiles', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Pineapple “leather,” flax seed instead of plastic: Tarform, based in Brooklyn, aims to set a standard with its retro-futuristic cafe racer.
lead_paragraph: Metal. Rubber. Leather. When it comes to motorcycles, the materials used to make them are as elemental as the experience of riding them.

headline: Anatomy of a Public Pool in a Pandemic
abstract: Reopenings around the country have varied, but one thing is consistent: Summer crowds are not allowed.
lead_paragraph: The timeless soundtrack of a public pool in summer is largely silent this summer. No shrieking children, no splashy entrances or periodic whistle blasts and curt admonitions from lifeguards (“Walk! Don’t run!”), little of the buzzy hum of happy people chatting in and around the water.

headline: The Unique U.S. Failure to Control the Virus
abstract: Slowing the coronavirus has been especially difficult for the United States because of its tradition of prioritizing individualism and missteps by the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every country has struggled to contain the coronavirus and made mistakes along the way.

headline: Water, Sand and Plenty of Elbow Room on 8 Wild, Protected Coastlines
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: From California to Cape Cod, these national seashores and lakeshores offer everything from bird-watching to boating to basking in the sun.
lead_paragraph: The grandmother of American conservation, Mardy Murie, once called the national parks our “best idea.” And this year, with foreign travel all but canceled, some of these celebrated domestic destinations have reached new heights of jam-packed popularity — and that, of course, presents challenges during a pandemic.

headline: New York’s Sidewalk Prophets Are Heirs of the Artisans of France’s Lascaux Caves
abstract: A critic’s tour deciphers the signs and symbols of the street art adorning boarded-up storefronts. What it tells us about our shared political realities and the ways our stories are connected.
lead_paragraph: About 17,000 years ago, in the caves of Lascaux, France, ancestors drew on grotto walls, depicting equines, stags, bison, aurochs and felines. They wanted to convey to other humans a political reality crucial to their survival: They shared their environment with other beings that looked and behaved differently from them.

headline: ‘Luster,’ by Raven Leilani: An Excerpt
abstract: An excerpt from “Luster,” by Raven Leilani
lead_paragraph: The first time we have sex, we are both fully clothed, at our desks during working hours, bathed in blue computer light. He is uptown processing a new bundle of microfiche and I am downtown handling corrections for a new Labrador detective manuscript. He tells me what he ate for lunch and asks if I can manage to take off my underwear in my cubicle without anyone noticing. His messages come with impeccable punctuation. He is fond of words like taste and spread. The empty text field is full of possibilities. Of course I worry about IT remoting into my computer, or my internet history warranting yet another disciplinary meeting with HR. But the risk. The thrill of a third pair of unseen eyes. The idea that someone in the office, with that sweet, post-lunch-break optimism, might come across the thread and see how tenderly Eric and I have built this private world.

headline: Real Life Horror Stories From the World of Pandemic Motherhood
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Women and Girls', 'Family Leaves', 'Child Care', 'Discrimination', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Parenting']
abstract: ‘I have been given two options: either resign or get fired.’
lead_paragraph: Employers are using the pandemic to get rid of mothers, and our attempts to protect them are failing.

headline: Hours of Talks on U.S. Coronavirus Relief End With No Deal
abstract: Ohio’s governor tested positive before a planned meeting with President Trump, but a second test was negative. India hit two million cases. China’s exports rose last month at their fastest pace of the year.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read live coronavirus updates here.

headline: After Isaias, When Will Power Be Back?
abstract: Tropical Storm Isaias tore across the region on Tuesday. Two days later, many households and businesses are still without power.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Idled by the pandemic, workers in Britain try new careers.
abstract: The economic collapse caused by the coronavirus has put millions of economic futures in doubt. More than nine million people have been furloughed in Britain, or 29 percent of the country’s work force, and 2.8 million have filed unemployment claims.
lead_paragraph: The economic collapse caused by the coronavirus has put millions of economic futures in doubt. More than nine million people have been furloughed in Britain, or 29 percent of the country’s work force, and 2.8 million have filed unemployment claims.

headline: A majority of travelers are not willing to get on planes, a new survey shows.
abstract: More than half of Americans who flew in the past year are not ready to do so again, according to a new survey, underscoring the difficulty airlines face in convincing people it is safe for them to get back on planes.
lead_paragraph: More than half of Americans who flew in the past year are not ready to do so again, according to a new survey, underscoring the difficulty airlines face in convincing people it is safe for them to get back on planes.

headline: China’s Offer to Help With Virus Testing Spooks Hong Kong
abstract: Infections have surged in the city, and its labs have been going at full speed. But wariness of the Chinese Communist Party runs deep.
lead_paragraph: The offer was presented as a favor to Hong Kong, a city struggling with a surge in coronavirus infections: a team of 60 medical officials from mainland China who would help expand testing across the city.

headline: Britain’s economy won’t fully recover till end of 2021, its central bankers said.
abstract: The Bank of England presented both a better and worse outlook for the British economy on Thursday. As the central bank left its monetary policy stance unchanged, policymakers said that they expected the British economy to contract by 9.5 percent this year, a less severe downturn than they indicated a few months ago, and the unemployment rate would peak at 7.5 percent at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England presented both a better and worse outlook for the British economy on Thursday. As the central bank left its monetary policy stance unchanged, policymakers said that they expected the British economy to contract by 9.5 percent this year, a less severe downturn than they indicated a few months ago, and the unemployment rate would peak at 7.5 percent at the end of the year.

headline: America Stands Alone
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every country has struggled to contain the coronavirus. But only one affluent nation has suffered a severe, sustained outbreak for more than four months: the United States.

headline: Episode Three: ‘This Is Our School, How Dare You?’
abstract: How white parents can shape a school, even when they aren’t there.
lead_paragraph: Chana Joffe-Walt explores how white parents can shape a school — even when they aren’t there.

headline: The Day That Shook Beirut
abstract: Our reporter in the Lebanese capital was injured in the huge blast. This is what happened to her when “everything seemed to come apart.”
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Restricting Beach Access to Residents Only
abstract: Fearing the spread of Covid-19, some cities in Connecticut and Long Island are trying to keep nonresidents off the sand, butting up against legal mandates that require them to maintain public access.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut and New York residents who don’t live along the coast are likely feeling the heat more than usual this summer, as one town after another has closed off its beaches to everyone except locals.

headline: ‘The Secret Garden’ Review: It’s as Lovely as You Remember
abstract: This version, featuring Colin Firth as the haunted uncle, hits the same notes as the 1911 novel and previous films, and that’s fine for this uncertain moment.
lead_paragraph: In a year defined by surprise, the predictability of “The Secret Garden” — a new film adaptation of Frances Hodgson Burnett’s beloved 1911 novel — proves more charming than tedious.

headline: ‘Waiting for the Barbarians’ Review: An Aestheticized Fable of Colonialism
abstract: Mark Rylance, Johnny Depp and Robert Pattinson star in this Ciro Guerra film adapted from a J.M. Coetzee novel.
lead_paragraph: The stark sight of a western-style military outpost in the middle of a whole lot of desert nothingness, where “Waiting for the Barbarians” begins, may remind cinephiles of the 1976 Valerio Zurlini film “The Desert of the Tartars.” It’s unclear whether the director of this picture, Ciro Guerra, meant the scene as a homage to Zurlini’s film, but he didn’t even need to. As it happens, J.M. Coetzee, whose novel of the same name inspired this film, was likely influenced by Dino Buzzati’s book “The Tartar Steppe,” the source for “Tartars.”

headline: ‘Song Without a Name’ Review: A Tragedy in the Peruvian Hillside
abstract: Melina León’s beautifully composed film follows a woman whose baby was stolen from her after child birth.
lead_paragraph: The Peruvian film “Song Without a Name” sets a dramatic mood with gorgeous black-and-white photography and an original guitar score. The story, loosely based on true events, begins in 1988 with Georgina (Pamela Mendoza), a Quechua woman who sells potatoes in the outer limits of Lima. She responds to a notice for a clinic that helps pregnant women like herself deliver babies. But in the moments after she gives birth, her child is taken from her.

headline: ‘River City Drumbeat’ Review: A Community’s Pulse Proves Strong
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Children and Childhood', 'Music']
abstract: At the heart of this documentary from Marlon Johnson and Anne Flatté is a drum line in Louisville, Ky., that offers children a chance to engage with Black art and history.
lead_paragraph: Early on in the beautiful documentary “River City Drumbeat,” two leaders from the River City Drum Corp teach elementary school students in Kentucky a drum lesson. Albert Shumake, a new father who has been involved with the corp since his childhood, inspires students by bringing them back to their elemental beginnings. He reminds the class that the first sound they heard was their mother’s heartbeat. As he speaks, his mentor Nardie White accompanies him on a drum, following Shumake’s lead with a solid and simple beat.

headline: ‘Psychomagic, a Healing Art’ Review: Introducing Surrealist Therapy
abstract: In this documentary, Alejandro Jodorowsky compares Freud’s “science” to his own “magic” and chronicles aiming for cures with methods resembling performance art.
lead_paragraph: For almost 70 years, the Chilean-born artist Alejandro Jodorowsky has been the utility infielder of lowercase-“s” surrealism. He’s a performer, graphic novelist, poet and, most prominently, a cult filmmaker. With the documentary “Psychomagic, a Healing Art,” he introduces the world to the work he has been involved in since the ’70s.

headline: ‘Howard’ Review: A Lyricist’s Life Cut Short
abstract: A new documentary looks at the prodigious talent of Howard Ashman, one half of the musical team behind “The Little Mermaid” and others, before he died of AIDS at 40.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, T: The New York Times Style Magazine published the photographs of more than a hundred of the city’s artists who had died of H.I.V./AIDS — a shocking record of creativity cut short and careers unrealized.

headline: Money for the Postal Service? The Check’s in the Mail
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Democratic National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Congress still can’t agree, and Democrats plan a virtual convention: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: Democrats fight to fund the Postal Service, as Chicago becomes the latest city to decide students shouldn’t return for in-person classes. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: House Democrats seek better rates on loans to cities and states.
abstract: Rashida Tlaib, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and other House Democrats signed on to a letter urging the Federal Reserve to do more to support state and local governments, adding to criticism that the central bank is being too cautious in some of the programs it set up to help the economy during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Rashida Tlaib, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and other House Democrats signed on to a letter urging the Federal Reserve to do more to support state and local governments, adding to criticism that the central bank is being too cautious in some of the programs it set up to help the economy during the pandemic.

headline: As French President Visits Beirut, Lebanese Ask Where Their Leaders Are
abstract: It was a day of funerals and fury in Beirut as residents cleared the rubble from their streets and homes, and vented anger at their government.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Visiting a neighborhood ravaged by this week’s giant explosion in Beirut’s port, the president looked residents in the eye, vowed to send food and pursue a new political initiative, expressed sorrow for the lives lost and shoved aside a bodyguard to give a woman a hug.

headline: In Tennessee, Bill Hagerty Wins Senate Primary
abstract: President Trump’s request for an earlier presidential debate was denied. Polls show tight Senate races in Maine, South Carolina and Kentucky. And Kanye West said he’s “not denying” that his bid to enter the 2020 race is meant to harm Joe Biden.
lead_paragraph: [Follow the DNC Live: Biden’s speech, schedule, start time, streaming and more.]

headline: In Richmond, Black Dance Claims a Space Near Robert E. Lee
abstract: Black dancers, musicians and artists have invigorated what had long been considered a whites-only space.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Janine Bell lived in Richmond for 35 years without visiting Monument Avenue. But that changed in July, when Ms. Bell threw a gathering honoring Emmett Till under the shadow of a statue of Robert E. Lee.

headline: Lawmakers Aim to Prevent Trump From Bypassing Ban on Armed Drone Sales
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Senators from both parties say President Trump cannot be allowed to help drone technology proliferate, and they want it to be kept away from Saudi Arabia in particular.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bill that Democratic and Republican senators introduced on Thursday would ban the sale of advanced armed drones to any nation that is not a close ally of the United States, according to lawmakers and congressional aides.

headline: Hawa Abdi, Doctor Who Aided Thousands in Somalia, Dies at 73
abstract: Dr. Abdi turned her family’s land into a hospital and camp that treated and supported legions of people displaced during a civil war.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Hawa Abdi, a doctor and human rights activist who safeguarded the lives of tens of thousands of Somalis during years of war, famine and displacement, died on Wednesday at her home in Mogadishu, the Somali capital. She was 73.

headline: For many workers, getting traction in the job market may require new skills.
abstract: With rising concerns that temporary layoffs are turning into permanent job losses, economists worry what this will mean for workers at the bottom rungs of the labor market — those with the fewest skills and the lowest pay.
lead_paragraph: With rising concerns that temporary layoffs are turning into permanent job losses, economists worry what this will mean for workers at the bottom rungs of the labor market — those with the fewest skills and the lowest pay.

headline: As unemployment benefits began to run out, a freelance job came just in time.
abstract: For Curtis Hoover, the freelance designing gig came just in time. His regular state unemployment benefits had run out, as had the weekly $600 supplement that Congress approved to help jobless workers make it through the pandemic. He was still eligible for payments under an emergency extension of benefits for 13 weeks, but the clock was ticking on that assistance as well.
lead_paragraph: For Curtis Hoover, the freelance designing gig came just in time. His regular state unemployment benefits had run out, as had the weekly $600 supplement that Congress approved to help jobless workers make it through the pandemic. He was still eligible for payments under an emergency extension of benefits for 13 weeks, but the clock was ticking on that assistance as well.

headline: My Name Is Karen. What Can I Do About the Meme?
abstract: I try not to be “a Karen,” but I think this joke has gone too far.
lead_paragraph: I am one of the many women who now find our name used as an insult or shorthand for an obnoxious, entitled, occasionally racist creature who demands to speak to the manager or calls the police for no good reason. I know this is not the biggest problem. But it really hurts me, especially since I try not to exhibit the behaviors associated with the insult. How should I respond when I hear someone being called “a Karen”? Ignore it, defend myself or change my name?

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Paintings by Toyin Ojih Odutola, Hawaiian pastries — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: He Spent 26 Years in a Chinese Prison. Then He Was Cleared of Murder.
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: A court in eastern China convicted Zhang Yuhuan in 1995 for the murder of two boys. His exoneration has grabbed headlines, though legal reforms have been sluggish.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese court on Wednesday exonerated a man who had spent more than 26 years in prison for the murder of two boys, a striking sign of the deep flaws in China’s criminal justice system, and new, if halting, efforts at reform.

headline: Organizing Your Face Masks
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Masks', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Orderliness and Clutter', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Since masks are going to be part of our lives for the foreseeable future, here are some ways to store and display them.
lead_paragraph: Roughly 80 percent of Americans say they wear face masks when they expect to be within 6 feet of other people, according to recent national surveys. That’s a lot of face masks.

headline: Video Shows Beirut Bride at the Moment of the Blast
abstract: Just as Israa Seblani was posing for her wedding video, an explosion tore through the city — leaving more than 135 dead and thousands injured.
lead_paragraph: Just as Israa Seblani was posing for her wedding video, an explosion tore through the city — leaving more than 135 dead and thousands injured.

headline: Snap will make a major effort to register first-time voters.
abstract: Snap, the company behind the popular social media app Snapchat, is planning a major push to register first-time voters within its app and to guide them through the ballot process ahead of the election on November 3.
lead_paragraph: Snap, the company behind the popular social media app Snapchat, is planning a major push to register first-time voters within its app and to guide them through the ballot process ahead of the election on November 3.

abstract: It didn’t just seem like everyone spent their lockdown playing Animal Crossing — they really were.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t just seem like everyone spent their lockdown playing Animal Crossing — they really were.

headline: Sweatpants Forever: How the Fashion Industry Collapsed
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Even before the pandemic, it had started to unravel. What happens now that no one has a reason to dress up?
lead_paragraph: Even before the pandemic, it had started to unravel. What happens now that no one has a reason to dress up?

headline: In Poland, the Rainbow Flag Is Wrapped Up in a Broader Culture War
abstract: Three activists were arrested and charged after hanging banners on Warsaw monuments, while opposition lawmakers wore multicolor clothing and masks in a protest in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: When President Andrzej Duda of Poland was sworn in on Thursday for a second term in office after a bitterly divisive campaign in which he rallied support by targeting homosexuality as a threat to the nation, he looked out over the floor of Parliament to find a sea of color.

headline: Dozens Charged in Hong Kong for Taking Part in Tiananmen Protest
abstract: The charges against 24 people for attending an annual vigil are the latest signs of an intensifying crackdown on the pro-democracy movement.
lead_paragraph: Two dozen democracy advocates in Hong Kong were charged on Thursday with taking part in an annual vigil honoring the victims of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests, the latest sign of the aggressive clampdown on dissent in the semiautonomous Chinese territory.

headline: Credit card debt plunges, driving a decline in overall household debt.
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Credit Cards', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Household debt fell in the second quarter as consumers stuck at home because of the coronavirus pandemic spent less on their credit cards, based on a new report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
lead_paragraph: Household debt fell in the second quarter as consumers stuck at home because of the coronavirus pandemic spent less on their credit cards, based on a new report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: Gannett and Tribune newspaper chains see subscriber growth amid plunging advertising.
abstract: Gannett and Tribune Publishing, two of the last remaining publicly traded newspaper chains, both reported impressive subscription growth alongside plummeting advertising sales during the second quarter of this year, which was dominated by the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Gannett and Tribune Publishing, two of the last remaining publicly traded newspaper chains, both reported impressive subscription growth alongside plummeting advertising sales during the second quarter of this year, which was dominated by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: This Year’s Must-Have Back-to-School Item: Masks for Children
keywords: ['Masks', 'Children and Childhood', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Education (K-12)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Parenting', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Crayola, Old Navy and Disney are among the brands making colorful masks for children. Child psychologists see this as a positive step toward “normalcy.”
lead_paragraph: Fall is drawing near, and right on schedule, ads offering discounts on backpacks, notebooks and pencils are beginning to pop up on television and online.

headline: Ava DuVernay Wins the Gish Prize
abstract: The writer, producer, filmmaker and activist will receive a cash award of about $250,000.
lead_paragraph: The Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, one of the most generous arts honors in the United States, has been awarded to the filmmaker and activist Ava DuVernay, who has worked to amplify the voices of women and people of color in Hollywood.

headline: ‘The Tax Collector’ Review: Street Gangs and Family Values
abstract: David Ayer’s generic gangland thriller presents a cartoonishly exaggerated showdown between good and evil.
lead_paragraph: Love. Honor. Loyalty. Family. “The Tax Collector” would have you believe it’s about all these things, as if slapping nouns on the screen (partly in cursive, no less) will convince us there’s a higher purpose to the bloodletting and viciousness that follow. But we’ve all seen “The Sopranos,” and we won’t get fooled again.

headline: Even Asymptomatic People Carry the Coronavirus in High Amounts
abstract: Researchers in South Korea found that roughly 30 percent of those infected never develop symptoms yet probably spread the virus.
lead_paragraph: Of all the coronavirus’s qualities, perhaps the most surprising has been that seemingly healthy people can spread it to others. This trait has made the virus difficult to contain, and continues to challenge efforts to identify and isolate infected people.

headline: What Is a Museum? A Dispute Erupts Over a New Definition
abstract: An international effort to update the definition of what museums are has been met with resignations and political intrigue.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Museums are having an identity crisis.

headline: ViacomCBS takes a pandemic hit, with ad revenue falling 27 percent.
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic wiped out a large portion of ViacomCBS’s advertising business and its box-office take in the second quarter, the company reported Thursday. ViacomCBS owns CBS, Nickelodeon, MTV, Showtime and the Paramount film studios. The company’s ad revenue in the United States fell 24 percent to $1.7 billion, and its theatrical business dropped a staggering 98 percent from the same time last year, to $3 million. Total sales fell 12 percent to $6.2 billion, and profit was halved to $478 million.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic wiped out a large portion of ViacomCBS’s advertising business and its box-office take in the second quarter, the company reported Thursday. ViacomCBS owns CBS, Nickelodeon, MTV, Showtime and the Paramount film studios. The company’s ad revenue in the United States fell 24 percent to $1.7 billion, and its theatrical business dropped a staggering 98 percent from the same time last year, to $3 million. Total sales fell 12 percent to $6.2 billion, and profit was halved to $478 million.

headline: She Was Pregnant With Twins During Covid. Why Did Only One Survive?
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Income Inequality', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Telemedicine', 'Hospitals', 'Babies and Infants', 'Midwives and Doulas', 'Discrimination', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Maternal Mortality', 'Infant Mortality']
abstract: Why being Black and giving birth in New York during the pandemic is so dangerous.
lead_paragraph: In March, with the coronavirus lockdown in full swing, Chrissy Sample was feeling anxious. Furloughed from her job and stuck at home with her 8-year-old son, she was also pregnant with twins, who were due in mid-July. Although she often felt immobilized by an intense pain in her legs and lower abdomen, her doctor regularly told her these feelings were normal.

headline: New York Attorney General Sues N.R.A. and Seeks Its Closure
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Gun Control', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Tax Evasion', 'Attorneys General', 'Embezzlement', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Letitia James seeks to dissolve the National Rifle Association, which was founded in New York, amid corruption allegations.
lead_paragraph: New York’s attorney general issued an existential challenge to the National Rifle Association on Thursday, arguing in a lawsuit that years of runaway corruption and misspending demanded the dissolution of the nation’s most powerful gun rights lobby.

headline: Whatever Happened to Arda Turan?
abstract: For months, Barcelona paid the finest player Turkey has ever produced not to play soccer. Why?
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — In the end, the question feels inappropriate. A little ridiculous, even. Arda Turan is sitting on the terrace of an impossibly lavish hotel, picking at a platter of fat grapes and sweet oranges and slices of fresh watermelon. The Bosporus shimmers a perfect blue. The sky is bright and glorious and it stretches all the way to Asia.

headline: ‘Now You Are Going to Die’: Beirut Bride Recounts Moment of Blast
abstract: Israa Seblani was posing for her wedding video when the camera captured the instant a deadly blast tore through the city.
lead_paragraph: Israa Seblani’s long white veil trailed behind her. She gazed downward as the camera captured her smile and panned to her train, draped around her feet in a lacy circle. She was just hours away from her wedding ceremony.

headline: NBCUniversal Pushes Out Chairman of NBC Entertainment
keywords: ['Television', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Cable Television', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Paul Telegdy leaves the network ahead of a pending investigation into his workplace behavior.
lead_paragraph: NBCUniversal, the media giant owned by the cable operator Comcast, has pushed out the leader of its network entertainment group amid a pending investigation into claims of workplace harassment.

headline: Diana Russell, Who Studied Violence Against Women, Dies at 81
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Writing and Writers', 'Sex Crimes', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: She popularized the term “femicide,” to highlight the killing of women “because they are women” and to distinguish these killings from other homicides.
lead_paragraph: Diana E.H. Russell, a leading feminist activist and scholar who popularized the term “femicide” to refer to the misogynist killing of women, and to distinguish these killings from other forms of homicide, died on July 28 at a medical facility in Oakland, Calif. She was 81.

headline: A Prominent News Media Critic Is Starting a News Outlet of His Own
abstract: For years, media insiders turned to Ken Doctor for advice. Now he plans to compete against a hedge-fund-owned paper in Santa Cruz.
lead_paragraph: Over the last 15 years, Ken Doctor has made his living as a critic of the news industry. A onetime media executive who started out as a publisher and editor of an alt weekly, Mr. Doctor regularly warns against hedge-fund ownership of news outlets in a column he writes for Harvard University’s Nieman Journalism Lab. Media companies hire him as a consultant, and he is often quoted in articles on the dismal state of local news coverage in America.

headline: The Fed moves closer to a new way to get people their money faster.
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board has unanimously approved a system to support instant payments that could help cash-strapped consumers receive money transfers more quickly, allowing them to avoid overdrafts and payday-lender borrowing.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve Board has unanimously approved a system to support instant payments that could help cash-strapped consumers receive money transfers more quickly, allowing them to avoid overdrafts and payday-lender borrowing.

headline: Wine Joins the 2020 Debate Over Privilege and Justice
abstract: An accusation involving migrant labor in Puglia leads to self-examination and, perhaps, new awareness of the treatment of agricultural workers.
lead_paragraph: In this topsy-turvy year of the Covid-19 pandemic and a national uproar over politics and racial injustice, few things are immune from the widespread cultural re-evaluation.

headline: Iran Envoy Brian Hook, a ‘Survivor’ on Trump’s Team, to Quit
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The exit of Brian Hook, the State Department’s special envoy for Iran, most likely rules out nuclear diplomacy with Tehran before November.
lead_paragraph: Brian Hook, the State Department’s special envoy for Iran and one of the few national security officials to survive the turmoil in the foreign policy team through most of President Trump’s term, is stepping down from his post, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced on Thursday.

keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Weather', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Floods']
abstract: Scientists at NOAA updated their prediction for the 2020 hurricane season, and now expect as many as 25 named storms.
lead_paragraph: Following a record number of Atlantic Ocean storms over the past two months, including five that struck the United States, government scientists on Thursday updated their forecast for the remainder of the hurricane season, saying it was likely to be extremely active.

headline: The Cult of the Tech Genius
abstract: It’s time to rethink how we treat and enable these brilliant — but damaging — tech personalities.

headline: Capital One will pay $80 million over hack.
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Computer Security', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: In 2019, a software engineer stole information relating to millions of customers. Regulators say the bank should have had better protections.
lead_paragraph: Capital One has agreed to pay $80 million to settle federal bank regulators’ claims that it lacked proper cybersecurity protocols, more than a year after a Seattle-based software engineer hacked into a cloud server and stole customers’ social security numbers, bank account information and credit card applications, regulators said Thursday.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Lower Decks’ Review: Life as Phaser Fodder

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Have you heard of the Sealey Challenge? Started in 2017 by the poet Nicole Sealey, the exercise invites people to read more poetry by setting a specific goal: 31 books in 31 days throughout the month of August. If that sounds appealing, and you don’t mind starting a few days late, you might jump in with “Concordance,” the latest collection by the estimable Susan Howe, which is one of nine new books we recommend this week.

headline: Experiencing War Far From the Battlefield
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Manhattan Project']
abstract: Two new books look at World War II from the perspectives of outsiders on the fringes of conflict.
lead_paragraph: It has been a long time since I enjoyed a book as much as I did LOVE IN THE BLITZ (Harper/HarperCollins, 496 pp., $28.99). Of the hundreds of books about World War II that I’ve read, this is one of the best. I would welcome the author, Eileen Alexander, as a fresh new voice, but for the fact that she has been dead for nearly 50 years.

headline: 3 Bon Appétit Journalists of Color Leave the Magazine’s Video Series
abstract: Two of them accused Condé Nast, the magazine’s parent company, of offering lower pay than what their white colleagues earned for video work.
lead_paragraph: Two months after Bon Appétit’s top editor resigned under pressure amid complaints of racial insensitivity, three journalists of color said they would no longer participate in the magazine’s popular video series.

headline: The Hottest New Label? U.S.P.S.
abstract: Saving the American postal system, one crop top at a time.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Postal Service has been financially besieged for years, and unless Congress acts, the independent agency could run out of money by 2021. Now, there are calls on social media to save, or at least support, the U.S.P.S. by shopping its surprisingly wide variety of goods on its online store.

headline: Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio Tests Positive, Then Negative, for Coronavirus
abstract: The governor said he felt confident in the results of a negative test that was taken hours after he tested positive while being screened to greet President Trump.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike DeWine tested negative for the coronavirus hours after a positive rapid-result test had prevented him from welcoming President Trump to Ohio on Thursday, a whiplash reversal that reflected the nation’s increasingly complex state of testing.

headline: 7 Things to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Theater', 'Music', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Classical Music', 'Radio', 'Central Park Summerstage', 'Dancing', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Children and Childhood', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Jazz']
abstract: How can you get your cultural fix when many arts institutions remain closed? Our writers offer suggestions for what to listen to and watch.
lead_paragraph: In April, the Public Theater suspended its Shakespeare in the Park season for the first time, a move as disheartening as it was responsible. One production has since re-emerged in a new form, a “Richard II” starring André Holland and adapted for radio by the director Saheem Ali. But if you’re missing the Delacorte’s visual pleasures, PBS, through its Great Performances series, has made last summer’s exuberant “Much Ado About Nothing” available on its website into September (it will also air the play on Aug. 14; check local listings).

headline: Michelle Obama Says She Is Dealing With ‘Low-Grade Depression’
abstract: In her new podcast, the former first lady connected her experience with the effects of quarantine and news about civil unrest and politics.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama said this week that she was experiencing “low-grade depression” and seemed to suggest that it was because of a combination of quarantine, racial unrest and the Trump administration’s response to the pandemic.

headline: Fewer Hip Fractures May Reflect a Drop in Smoking Rates
abstract: Bone drugs may account for only a small percentage in the decline in hip fractures over the past 40 years.
lead_paragraph: The incidence of hip fracture has decreased steadily over the past 40 years, but a new analysis suggests that new osteoporosis drugs have made only a small contribution to the trend.

headline: ‘A Killer Party’ Review: The Case of the Online Musical
abstract: With broad winks to Agatha Christie and the limitations of remote theater, a serialized song-and-dance mystery goes on. Well, not so much dance.
lead_paragraph: I used to have high standards for new musicals. Relevance, craft and a reason for being were traits I looked for but often found lacking. Now that we’re in lockdown, I’m just happy to see talented people working on anything that doesn’t actively make me wish they weren’t.

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT — A former top Saudi intelligence official publicly accused Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on Thursday of sending a team of agents to Canada to kill him.

headline: Chat Group Becomes Target of Moscow’s Wrath as Security Crackdown Widens
keywords: ['Informers', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners', 'Social Media']
abstract: The group started out as an online discussion of hobbies, schoolwork and sometimes politics. But then it was infiltrated by an informer for Russia’s all-powerful security services.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When a group of young Russians set up a chat group on social media nearly three years ago, they called themselves the “Club of Plant Lovers,” creating an innocuous gathering place for online discussion about their hobbies, university studies and sometimes politics.

headline: Enrico Navarra, Art World Visionary, Is Dead at 67
abstract: As a gallerist and publisher, he championed artists who weren’t yet fully appreciated, notably Jean-Michel Basquiat.
lead_paragraph: Enrico Navarra, a gallerist, collector and art-book publisher with a visionary instinct who promoted artists, especially Jean-Michel Basquiat, before the rest of the art world had fully appreciated the importance of their work, died on July 21 in Le Muy, France. He was 67.

headline: What Makes Kiarostami a Modern Master? Start Here
abstract: In the Iranian filmmaker’s “Certified Copy” and “Close-Up,” appearances deceive. You wind up questioning everything.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami is widely regarded as one of the great modern filmmakers, but if you discovered him at a particular peak of his international recognition — when he shared the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival in 1997 for “Taste of Cherry” — you might have been baffled. “Taste of Cherry” follows an enigmatic driver who picks up passengers on the outskirts of Tehran. He plans to commit suicide, he says, and needs someone to bury him. For viewers unfamiliar with Kiarostami, watching more than an hour of such conversations was perplexing, even tedious.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: August 2020
abstract: At least 287 pro-government forces and 144 civilians were killed in Afghanistan in August.
lead_paragraph: At least 117 pro-government forces and 37 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week, as peace talks continued to stall and Taliban forces waged targeted attacks on security forces. The deadliest attack took place in Baghlan Province, where the Taliban attacked Baghlan-e-Markazi District, killing four police officers and 12 pro-government militia members. Three outposts fell to the insurgents. Earlier in the week, in Balkh Province, new members of a military convoy were traveling to Dawlat Abad District from Mazar-e-Sharif when a roadside bomb exploded near a Humvee in the Yakhdan village of the district. Eight N.D.S. officers and two soldiers were killed, and two others were wounded. Days later, in the same province, a car full of explosives was detonated close to a commando unit in Balkh District, killing two commandos and eight civilians, while wounding an additional 20 commandos and 45 civilians. The explosion destroyed many nearby houses and the Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.

headline: For Three Suffragists, a Monument Well Past Due
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Sculpture', 'Nineteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Central Park will soon unveil its first sculpture depicting nonfictional female figures. “The fact that nobody even noticed that women were missing in Central Park — what does that say about the invisibility of women?”
lead_paragraph: Across the country, monuments honoring racist figures are being defaced and toppled. In New York’s Central Park, one statue is taking shape that aims to amend not only racial but also gender disparities in public art: A 14-foot-tall bronze monument of Susan B. Anthony, Sojourner Truth and Elizabeth Cady Stanton, three of the more prominent leaders in the nationwide fight for women’s right to vote.

headline: Inspired by Memories and Remedies, Earthy Home Scents From Loewe
abstract: An amateur plantsman, Jonathan Anderson shares his bounty with the rest of us.
lead_paragraph: Of all the senses, smell has a unique and scientifically proven ability to transport us to an earlier moment or chapter in our lives. For Jonathan Anderson, 35, the creative director of both Loewe and his namesake line, the earthy, green scent of tomato leaves will forever bring him back to his boyhood in Magherafelt, a small town in Northern Ireland surrounded by verdant lowlands and rolling hills. “As a kid, I loved greenhouses, and ours always smelled of tomato leaves,” he says. “It’s a strange, sharp smell, different from the fruit’s skin.”

headline: Coming Next: The Greater Recession
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: The suspension of federal benefits would create damage almost as terrifying as the economic effects of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: One pretty good forecasting rule for the coronavirus era has been to take whatever Trump administration officials are saying and assume that the opposite will happen. When President Trump declared in February that the number of cases would soon go close to zero, you knew that a huge pandemic was coming. When Vice President Mike Pence insisted in mid-June that “there isn’t a coronavirus ‘second wave,’” a giant surge in new cases and deaths was clearly imminent.

headline: The World Can Still Be Destroyed in a Flash

headline: Workers at Philadelphia Museum of Art Vote to Join Union

keywords: ['Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Term Limits (Political Office)', 'Constitutions', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s party clinched the majority of seats in Parliament, aiming to amend the Constitution and expand presidential powers. Rights groups are concerned.

headline: ‘I Was a Little Scared’: Inside America’s Reopening Schools

lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — It was the purple Powerade that convinced her.

headline: The U.S. Lifted Its Advisory Against Traveling Abroad. What Does That Mean?
abstract: After nearly five months, the State Department lifted its “do not travel” advisory.
lead_paragraph: The State Department lifted its blanket advisory warning American citizens against traveling abroad on Thursday, nearly five months after the department had issued the Level 4 “do not travel” warning — its highest advisory — against all international travel as the coronavirus spread.

lead_paragraph: The Tennessee Senate Republican primary may have taken a competitive turn in its final weeks, but Bill Hagerty proved that for red-state candidates in the Trump era, there are still few things more valuable than the endorsement of Donald J. Trump himself.

headline: When Marriage Is Just Another Overhyped Nightclub
abstract: Being single in your 30s can feel like waiting to enter a popular club, only to get in and think: What’s the big deal?
lead_paragraph: People treat you differently when you are steadily single. Not everyone, not all the time, not always overtly, not necessarily unkindly. They ask why no one has snatched you up, offer to set you up on blind dates, seat you at the singles table at formal events. They extend last-minute invitations to dinner parties when someone else has bailed.

headline: The Mom and Pop Factory With an Atomic Secret
keywords: ['Plastics', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Family Business', 'Manhattan Project', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Those trays that macarons come in? Plaxall makes them. But since the pandemic, it has pivoted to medical face shields. It’s not the first time the family business has done its patriotic duty.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare these days to be a small and successful manufacturer in New York City. And perhaps even rarer for a family-owned business to pivot its operations several times in moments of national need — including participating in a mysterious and ultra-top-secret military contract that redefined modern warfare.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Sweet Bean’ and ‘Jojo Rabbit’
abstract: A sweet Japanese film comes to Mubi. And an Oscar-winning satire airs on HBO.
lead_paragraph: SWEET BEAN (2016) Stream on Mubi. Sentaro (Masatoshi Nagase) — a Japanese baker who serves pancake-like pastries called “dorayaki” — is struggling, and appears perpetually grumpy. Then along comes Tokue (Kirin Kiki), the fairy godmother of “an,” the sweet red bean paste in the center of dorayaki. Seemingly out of nowhere, Tokue approaches Sentaro’s bakery and tells him she wants to work for him. Sentaro is hesitant at first. But Tokue’s an has something special, he realizes, and the wisdom she has to give is equally magical. In his review for The New York Times, Glenn Kenny wrote that “the movie, beautifully shot and acted, earns its ultimate sense of hope by confronting real heartbreak head-on, and with compassion.” “Sweet Bean,” based on a novel by Durian Sukegawa, was written and directed by Naomi Kawase, and it debuted at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival.

headline: Jimmy Fallon Sends Thoughts and Prayers to the N.R.A.
abstract: “That’s right, no more N.R.A., no more Confederate flags. This is turning into the worst year of Ted Nugent’s life,” the “Tonight Show” host said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

lead_paragraph: TOLLHOUSE, Calif. — In February, the child abuse hotline for Tollhouse, a small community in the Central Valley, received the first of several tips raising urgent concerns about the well-being of twin infant boys.

headline: Brooks Koepka Is Here to Win Majors, Not Friends

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Brooks Koepka teed off in the quiet calm of Thursday morning, he figured he was not just a contender, but a favorite to win the P.G.A. Championship.

headline: ‘Work It’ Review: Freestyling Through Senior Year
abstract: A straight-A high student scrambles to become a hip-hop dancer for her college application in this Netflix dance movie that pays homage to the genre.
lead_paragraph: In the middling dance movie “Work It,” now on Netflix, Quinn (Sabrina Carpenter) is a straight-A senior desperate to attend her dream university, Duke. So desperate, in fact, that when her college interviewer expresses an appreciation for dance, Quinn pretends it’s her passion, too. To keep up the ruse, she cobbles together a ragtag hip-hop troupe and starts to train. She’s a quick learner; how hard can it be to keep a rhythm?

headline: Authors Distill Their Writing Advice to Just a Few Words
abstract: A request to fellow writers: Inscribe your book to me with one pithy piece of guidance.
lead_paragraph: It has been nearly 20 years since the night in a newspaper office in Delhi when I came across a copy of a fax V.S. Naipaul had sent in response to a reporter asking for his rules of writing. (“Avoid the abstract; always go for the concrete.”) I found those rules useful. In recent years, I have had a mantra of my own: “Write every day, and walk every day.” A modest goal of 150 words daily and mindful walking for 10 minutes.

lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: How I Got My Daughter to Take Her A.D.H.D. Pill
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: She needed to know there’s no shame in taking medication for mental illness.
lead_paragraph: My 10-year-old daughter Norah didn’t want to take her medication for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder a few months ago. Not that this was the first time she’d told us no. Surely it wasn’t. It really depended on the day. Some days she took it without complaint, and other days she refused.

keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'Grandparents', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Cemeteries']

lead_paragraph: We had barely clicked our seatbelts into place when my mother said, “Do you mind if we stop at the cemetery?”

headline: What Sonia Sotomayor Told a 10-Year-Old Girl
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Equal Rights Amendment']
abstract: Reflecting on the words of a Supreme Court justice and women’s path to political equality.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Last February, before social distancing became a reality for us all, I was able to interview Justice Sonia Sotomayor for my “Contrapoder” podcast. Among our small audience was Sophie McLoud, 10. The girl had a question for Justice Sotomayor, the first Latina Supreme Court justice in American history. “Do you think a girl like me could become president of the United States?” Sophie asked. I’ll share the amazing answer that Justice Sotomayor gave Sophie later. For now, let’s focus on the latest news.

headline: Hot and Bothered: Four New Romance Novels
abstract: Looking for a pitch-perfect summer escape? We’ve got some recommendations.
lead_paragraph: We reach for romance when illness strikes, when the world weighs too heavily, when our own joy is hard to find but we need to know it’s still out there somewhere. This summer’s crop of romance novels are about squaring up to hardship and finding something better on the other side.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Around the World in 80 Trees’ and ‘The Truths We Hold’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: THE GUEST BOOK, by Sarah Blake. (Flatiron, 512 pp., $17.99.) “Welcome to old money, new heartbreak, big secrets and the kind of mouthwatering picnics nobody packs in real life,” was how Elisabeth Egan began her review of this novel set on the Maine island where the Milton family summers. After a tragedy Egan “did not see coming,” a granddaughter makes a shocking discovery.

headline: Living While Black in ‘Lovecraft Country’
abstract: Misha Green, the creator of this macabre new HBO series, discusses her obsession with horror and why its sense of dread and danger is not just an allegory.
lead_paragraph: “Lovecraft Country,” which debuts Aug. 16 on HBO, tells the intersecting stories of two Black families as they travel throughout the Jim Crow North confronting monsters — some fantastical (pale gray beasts called Elder Gods) and others that are no less horrific for being based in reality (racist sheriffs, predatory oligarchs).

headline: Investors Cozy Up to Danish Stocks
abstract: Denmark is enjoying one of the best-performing stock markets in the world this year. Recession-proof businesses and a strong safety net equal big gains.
lead_paragraph: Denmark is a place of hygge, happiness and — in the face of a global downturn — a high-performing stock market.

headline: So What Does Trump Have Against TikTok?
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'Mobile Applications', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Blacklisting', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: His foolish and dangerous edicts suggest that the United States, like China, no longer believes in a global internet.
lead_paragraph: The one thing my students all invariably know about China is that you can’t use Facebook there, or YouTube or Google. For at least a decade, China has maintained strict control over the internet and aggressively blocked foreign tech platforms within its borders.

headline: Gods, Monsters and H.P. Lovecraft’s Uncanny Legacy
abstract: The author’s stories have influenced countless works, including the new HBO series “Lovecraft Country.” But how do modern adapters reckon with his racism, his sexism and his profound weirdness?
lead_paragraph: “Lovecraft Country,” premiering Aug. 16 on HBO, follows a Black family entangled in eldritch phenomena. Based on Matt Ruff’s 2016 novel, the series is a sideways look at the terrors of Jim Crow America that nods to and reframes the work of H.P. Lovecraft, the widely cited if narrowly read pulp fiction writer from the early 20th century.

headline: I’m a Conservative Christian Environmentalist. No, That’s Not an Oxymoron.

In June, a handful of senators rolled out a bipartisan climate change bill. It is co-sponsored by Debbie Stabenow, Democrat of Michigan, and Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina.

lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Lifestyles of the Rich and Reckless: Posh Pandemic Parties

The catalyst was the viral image of a pool party where people were grouped a shot glass width apart, none of them wearing masks.

keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']

headline: Trump and His Allies Think They Know Who Counts
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Census']
abstract: But history has a way of confounding those who think they can control it.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, the Trump administration has fought to shape the 2020 census to its political benefit and the benefit of the Republican Party. In 2018, it sought to introduce a citizenship question on the census itself, to reduce response rates among immigrant communities. Then, after that was rebuffed by the Supreme Court, it tried to exclude unauthorized immigrants altogether, in direct conflict with the Constitution, which calls on Congress to count “the whole number of persons in each State.” Now it wants to cut the census short and deliver it uncompleted — a last-ditch effort to rig the nation’s politics for the sake of its exclusionary political vision.

headline: They Were Arrested During the Protests. Here’s What Happened Next.
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: Five New Yorkers describe the night they were arrested while participating in Black Lives Matter demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Mendez recalled how he had been held in a crowded cell for six hours after he was arrested during a protest, the first time that he had ever gone to a march. Clare Ramirez-Raftree said she ended up with welts on her wrists for days from the tight plastic handcuffs. And Patrick McElravey said police officers put him in a chokehold in Brooklyn.

headline: She Fell in Love, and the Dog Approved
abstract: Tara Harper knew Fritz Rahr was “the one” after he volunteered to join her on a trip to rescue a German shepherd — and then gave it a bath.
lead_paragraph: In June 2018, when Tara Harper told Frederick Rahr that she was going to drive eight hours round trip, from Dallas to Pasadena, Texas, to pick up an elderly and neglected German shepherd, she never imagined the man she had been seeing for just a few months would volunteer to join her. When he did, she figured he was just trying to score a few points with her.

headline: Abolish the Police? Those Who Survived the Chaos in Seattle Aren’t So Sure
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Small Business']

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Faizel Khan was being told by the news media and his own mayor that the protests in his hometown were peaceful, with “a block party atmosphere.”

keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Reality Television']
abstract: It’s hard for small farmers to earn a living selling their products. Enter the “farmer-influencer,” who can earn more by streaming farm life, in all its comforting monotony, to a growing online audience.

keywords: ['Unemployment Insurance', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Unemployment', 'Discrimination', 'Income Inequality', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'States (US)']

keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']

lead_paragraph: For about four months, as the pandemic bore down on New York City, an island had been left practically deserted in New York Harbor.

headline: A Season of Grief and Release: 5 Months of the Virus in New York City
abstract: A photographic timeline of a historic half-year.
lead_paragraph: The restaurant was empty, save for two other tables. Spoons slid through our dessert, split three ways. We were anxious but determined to enjoy it, somehow. It was March 10, and the coronavirus had just hit New York City. We laughed, but with worry in our brows and the preamble of panic in our eyes.

He’ll force other Republicans to back up his claim. He’ll get a TV show, hold rallies, be coy about running again in 2024.

headline: A Warming World
