headline: After a Generation, 2 Families in the Same Place Again
abstract: The couple met through a classic route: Her best friend was his brother’s girlfriend. But they soon found they had other connections, too.
lead_paragraph: A classic best-friend’s-boyfriend connection brought Danica Gould and John Stamatis together, in 2015, but it eventually emerged that their connections went back another generation. Just a coincidence? The couple isn’t convinced.

headline: A Running Mate Found in the Crowd
abstract: Alice Muglia and William Russo ran in the same political circles in Washington, but it took a few years before they turned a romantic corner.
lead_paragraph: Alice Muglia and William Russo had been running in the same political circles since 2012, when she was working for the re-election of President Barack Obama and he was working in the White House for Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who is now the presumptive Democratic nominee.

headline: Facebook Gaming Finally Clears Apple Hurdle, Arriving in App Store
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'iPad', 'Software', 'iPhone']
abstract: Saying Apple forced changes during months of rejection, the social network is releasing a version for iPhone and iPad users today.
lead_paragraph: For six months, Facebook tried to get Apple to approve its new Facebook Gaming app so it could be available in Apple’s App Store. Each time, Apple said no.

headline: Firefighters Called to Duty Hours Before Their Wedding
abstract: Danielle Day, an E.M.S. captain, and Zach Rey, a deputy fire chief, were able to “help somebody on their worst day, on our best day.”
lead_paragraph: Danielle Day was watching her bridesmaids get their hair and makeup done a few hours before her July 18 wedding when the alert came in.

headline: A Missed Connection, Six Years Later
abstract: The couple overlapped for a year while studying at Harvard Law School, but didn’t meet until 2017, when they matched on the League dating app.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Anderson and Robert Parisot can point to the day they almost met in 2011. They were both students at Harvard Law School at the time, and Ms. Anderson, who was in her third year, was participating in Harvard Law School’s Ames Moot Court Competition, a competition for appellate brief writing and advocacy. Mr. Parisot, who was a first-year law student, had been assigned to attend as part of his classes.

headline: Finally an Upgrade From the ‘Training Rings’
abstract: Ted Boerner and Rabbi Oren Postrel found the rapport from the start. Their temporary rings came a couple of years later.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, at the checkout counter of a five-and-dime store in Guerneville, Calif., Ted Boerner and Rabbi Oren Postrel looked down into the display case and saw rings in black velvet boxes for sale, at $7.99, $8.99 and $9.99.

headline: A Little Birdie Gave Him the Scoop at the Zoo
abstract: Eric Stern enlisted a cockatoo named Bo at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo to give Evan Zuzik a note that said: “Will you marry me?”
lead_paragraph: Eric Wasserman Stern and Evan Michael Zuzik figure they have eaten more than a thousand scoops of ice cream together, at least.

headline: Between Reps at the Gym, a Strong Connection
abstract: Lauren Maillian and Robert Palmer met during a workout and soon found they shared a similar mind-set about life and love.
lead_paragraph: When Lauren Maillian joined the New York Sports Club in Harlem, her intention was to work out. Robert Palmer had the same desire.

headline: Neither Could Have Imagined This Adventure
abstract: Claire Benjamin and Henry Fineberg married atop a mountain in White River National Forest near Aspen.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus forced Claire Benjamin and Henry Fineberg to rethink their original wedding plans, they decided to elope in Colorado, choosing June 27 as a new date for their nuptials. But as it turned out, that summer day brought enough snow and powerful winds to turn the couple’s ceremony into the kind of adventure they hadn’t planned on.

headline: Coronavirus Silences the Wonder Wheel
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Roller Coasters', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: A 100th anniversary celebration was planned for this star attraction on the Coney Island boardwalk this year. The owners are determined that it will spin again.
lead_paragraph: Deno’s Wonder Wheel, a 15-story signature feature of the Coney Island skyline, first spun to life in the wake of the Spanish flu pandemic a century ago. Now, as the coronavirus casts a growing pall over the storied amusement district, the family that owns the wheel says that the whirling behemoth will almost certainly go the entire season without carrying passengers for the first time in a hundred summers.

headline: Jack Dorsey on Twitter’s Mistakes
abstract: The social network’s C.E.O. has plans to improve the platform. But will the changes be enough?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Millions face eviction as pandemic relief measures end, researchers warn.
abstract: After the recent lapse of a federal supplement to unemployment payments, and with a patchwork of eviction moratoriums either at an end or set to expire soon, 30 million to 40 million tenants risk losing their homes in the coming months, according to a report released Friday by dozens of academic researchers and housing advocates.
lead_paragraph: After the recent lapse of a federal supplement to unemployment payments, and with a patchwork of eviction moratoriums either at an end or set to expire soon, 30 million to 40 million tenants risk losing their homes in the coming months, according to a report released Friday by dozens of academic researchers and housing advocates.

headline: Targeting WeChat, Trump Takes Aim at China’s Bridge to the World
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Mobile Applications', 'United States International Relations', 'Instant Messaging', 'Blacklisting', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The all-purpose app, which the administration is restricting along with TikTok, is how many Chinese living abroad stay in touch with one another, and with people back home.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — In China, WeChat does more than any app rightfully should. People use it to talk, shop, share photos, pay bills, get their news and send money.

headline: Trump takes aim at WeChat, China’s bridge to the world.
abstract: Late Thursday, the Trump administration issued an executive order that could pull WeChat, China’s most important app, from Apple and Google stores across the world and prevent American companies from doing business with its parent company, Tencent. Light on details, the decree could prove cosmetic, crushing or something in between.
lead_paragraph: Late Thursday, the Trump administration issued an executive order that could pull WeChat, China’s most important app, from Apple and Google stores across the world and prevent American companies from doing business with its parent company, Tencent. Light on details, the decree could prove cosmetic, crushing or something in between.

headline: Why an Accurate Census Is So Important
abstract: The Census Bureau’s move to cut its collection period short by one month in the midst of an already challenging pandemic has unnerved pollsters.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.

headline: Europe’s ‘Last Dictator,’ Facing Re-Election, Is Increasingly in Peril
abstract: For 26 years, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko has ruled Belarus as if it were his personal fief. In his sixth presidential election, the result is not in doubt, but he is being challenged like never before.
lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — The man often described as “Europe’s last dictator” has never looked so shaky.

headline: Power Outages Hit Manhattan and Queens as Utilities Face Storm Damage
abstract: About 180,000 customers lost electricity in an outage that Con Edison said was caused by issues with its “transmission system.”
lead_paragraph: Three days after a huge tropical storm swept through the New York City region and left more than a million people without power, much of Upper Manhattan was briefly plunged into darkness early Friday morning.

headline: Russia Continues to Meddle in Election to Aid Trump, U.S. Intelligence Says
abstract: Vice President Mike Pence made plans to visit Wisconsin after Joe Biden opted out of traveling there for the convention. Democrats called for an audit of the Postal Service’s new policies, citing concerns about potential mail-in voting issues.
lead_paragraph: [Follow the DNC Live: Biden’s speech, schedule, start time, streaming and more.]

headline: Summer Reading Contest Week 9: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 14 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 25.
lead_paragraph: Update: Winners have been announced!

headline: 4.8-Magnitude Earthquake Rattles Puerto Rico
abstract: The island has been shaken by a series of earthquakes and aftershocks since late last year.
lead_paragraph: A 4.8-magnitude earthquake shook southern Puerto Rico late on Thursday, leaving aftershocks in a region that has been rattled by clusters of earthquakes and tremors since late last year.

headline: Should I Quarantine After Traveling Outside California?
abstract: Friday: What you can do to protect yourself if you are traveling. Also: The Supreme Court sided with officials at a California jail.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Like many other U.S. states, California currently has no travel restrictions in place. That leaves a lot of travelers wondering about what precautions they should take after returning from a trip.

headline: More Wealthy Families Are Throwing a Lifeline to Distressed Businesses
abstract: The pandemic has created an opportunity for family offices to take a more hands-on approach by investing directly in companies that need capital.
lead_paragraph: During the pandemic, wealthy families have continued to use their investment pools, known as family offices, to gain access to the type of high-return opportunities once reserved for institutional investors. But they are taking a more hands-on role in those financial decisions.

headline: The ‘Indirect’ Costs at College Can Involve Nasty Surprises
abstract: Expenses for books, transportation and food outside a meal plan may be a problem for poor and moderate-income students, a new report finds.
lead_paragraph: Students and their families often focus on tuition and fees when budgeting for college. But there are costs that typically don’t appear on college bills, and they can add up — costs like books, laptop computers, transportation, and off-campus housing and meals.

headline: Getting Your Home Ready for Your Pandemic Puppy
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Animal Behavior', 'Dogs', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: You don’t have to give up on design just because the dog will probably chew everything in sight.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Crystal’s house in Oradell, N.J., wasn’t always a fun house for her Goldendoodle. Before she bought Bowie three years ago, she regularly polished the vintage pine floors of her 19th-century home, had a cozy reading nook in a corner of the living room, and covered her white sofa with colorful throw pillows.

headline: The Men Australia Detained in a Secretive Detention Camp
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: While profiling Behrouz Boochani, the story of the detention where he and others were held was underpinned by a sinister and sorrowful mood that ran through every person I interviewed.
lead_paragraph: You’re reading this week’s At War newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox every Friday. Email us at atwar@nytimes.com.

headline: Minorities continue to bear a heavy portion of the job market’s pain.
abstract: Black workers have made limited progress toward lowering their very high unemployment rate even as the jobless situation improves for their white counterparts, showing the uneven distribution of the pandemic’s economic pain.
lead_paragraph: Black workers have made limited progress toward lowering their very high unemployment rate even as the jobless situation improves for their white counterparts, showing the uneven distribution of the pandemic’s economic pain.

headline: As a temporary closing turns permanent, an owner and a worker try to carry on.
abstract: For Jackie Anscher, the closing of the boutique fitness studio where she taught spinning classes in Long Beach, N.Y., until March meant more than the loss of a job. It was the end of something she was passionate about and halted the deep connections she had built with clients.
lead_paragraph: For Jackie Anscher, the closing of the boutique fitness studio where she taught spinning classes in Long Beach, N.Y., until March meant more than the loss of a job. It was the end of something she was passionate about and halted the deep connections she had built with clients.

headline: Blackouts Hit Parts of New York City
abstract: Power outages early Friday morning hit large areas of New York, including the Upper West Side, Harlem and Queens, as about 180,000 customers lost electricity.
lead_paragraph: Power outages early Friday morning hit large areas of New York, including the Upper West Side, Harlem and Queens, as about 180,000 customers lost electricity.

headline: Horace Clarke, Standout in a Dismal Yankee Era, Dies at 82
abstract: He was a solid, dependable player, but he had the misfortune of joining the Yankees just as they tumbled from greatness.
lead_paragraph: Horace Clarke, a dependable though light-hitting second baseman for the Yankees who became indelibly and ingloriously associated with the team’s lean years in the 1960s and ’70s — what some sardonically labeled “the Horace Clarke era” — died on Wednesday at his home in Laurel, Md. He was 82.

headline: Ethel Smyth, a Composer Long Unheard, Is Recorded Anew
abstract: “The Prison” — her last major piece, premiered in 1931 — comes out on disc for the first time.
lead_paragraph: “The exact worth of my music will probably not be known till naught remains of the writer but sexless dots and lines on ruled paper,” Ethel Smyth wrote in 1928.

headline: Leaving Gun Towers and Barbed Wire for a Healing House
abstract: Susan Burton, an advocate for formerly incarcerated women, is racing against the clock to shelter those freed early because of the surge of coronavirus cases in prisons.
lead_paragraph: Dana Moore arrived in February as inmate No. WG4763 at the California Institution for Women east of Los Angeles, to complete her sentence of two years and eight months for possession of a firearm. The coronavirus numbers in the state’s prison system were climbing — a grave concern to Ms. Moore, who is immunocompromised. But last month, she grew teary as the prison gate rolled up. She was being released early, and carried out a cardboard box with her belongings into the waiting car of Susan Burton, the activist who was helping her leave behind the gun towers, the barbed wire and her anonymous prisoner ID for an eggnog-yellow bungalow on a quiet street in Los Angeles.

headline: Behind the Cover: Sweatpants Forever
abstract: A look at the collapse of the fashion industry and the triumphant rise of sweatpants.

headline: He found a new job, but the drop in pay is draining his savings.
abstract: When the pandemic hit, David Espy was working as a safety manager overseeing the construction of a resort hotel at Walt Disney World. But in mid-March, when virus-related shutdowns forced entertainment venues to close, Mr. Espy lost his job.
lead_paragraph: When the pandemic hit, David Espy was working as a safety manager overseeing the construction of a resort hotel at Walt Disney World. But in mid-March, when virus-related shutdowns forced entertainment venues to close, Mr. Espy lost his job.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Put your sourdough starter to work, and make Bryan Ford’s pan de coco.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The nation’s embrace of sourdough bread isn’t lessening as the months of pandemic living creep on, at least to judge from my inbox and social media feeds. The loaves are still everywhere, stout and crackle-crusted, with airy crumb reveals. People post success stories about their breads, lament their failures, trade tips for resuscitating slack starters with rye flour. They live their sourdough lives.

headline: When Schools Reopened in Germany, ‘We Swallowed Our Misgivings’
abstract: A mother recounted how worried she was sending her children back to in-person classes in the spring. But seeing her son “blossom” and the school’s safety measures eased her concerns.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The news that children in Berlin would return to classrooms last spring caught me and my husband by surprise. Like parents across the world, we were very concerned about anyone in our family getting or spreading the coronavirus.

headline: The Question I’m Always Asked
abstract: (And what they really want to know.)
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every weekday.

headline: Brent Scowcroft, a Force on Foreign Policy for 40 Years, Dies at 95
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: He was a national security adviser to President Ford and the first President Bush and an influential voice in Washington for decades.
lead_paragraph: Brent Scowcroft, a pre-eminent foreign policy expert who helped shape America’s international and strategic decisions for decades as the national security adviser to Presidents Gerald R. Ford and George Bush and as a counselor to seven administrations, died on Thursday at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 95.

headline: Oversight Member Blasts the Fed’s Efforts to Rescue Main Street
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Small Business']
abstract: The Federal Reserve president leading the Main Street lending program testified before a congressional commission, as one member labeled it a “failure.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s first-ever attempt to lend money to midsize businesses was destined to be a challenge. The push has proved to be an outright flop, according to a member of the oversight commission charged with monitoring it.

headline: How the C.E.O. of Harlem Children’s Zone Spends His Sundays
abstract: When Kwame Owusu-Kesse is not helping families and schools navigate the pandemic, he is trying to wean his toddler off “Baby Shark.”
lead_paragraph: Being promoted to chief executive of Harlem Children’s Zone in the middle of a pandemic didn’t feel like bad timing to Kwame Owusu-Kesse. Instead, he said, “it made me think more about our purpose and possibilities.”

headline: Trump Administration Penalizes Hong Kong Officials for Crackdown on Protesters
keywords: ['Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The sanctions are the first punishments brought against officials in China and Hong Kong for suppressing pro-democracy protests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration imposed sanctions on Friday on Hong Kong’s chief executive, Carrie Lam, and 10 other senior officials in Hong Kong and mainland China over their roles in cracking down on political dissent.

headline: Why Joe Biden Keeps Missing His Own V.P. Deadlines
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Politics and Government', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: On issues big and small, Joseph R. Biden Jr. will not be rushed, including the critical choice of a running mate. He’s deliberative, and he doesn’t mind extending his timetable — again and again.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign staff is making plans to introduce his eventual vice-presidential choice to key party constituencies. Donors are readying finance events featuring the still-unnamed running mate — “date and time to be announced.” An in-person reveal is being discussed.

headline: After It All, Serena Williams Still Has No. 24 In Sight
abstract: After the coronavirus paused the tours, Williams is gearing up for the U.S. Open, her next opportunity to tie Margaret Court’s Grand Slam singles title record.
lead_paragraph: After her latest long and unexpected break from the sport she once dominated, Serena Williams will return to competition next week at a new tournament, the Top Seed Open in Lexington, Ky.

headline: N.Y. Schools Can Reopen, Cuomo Says, in Contrast With Much of U.S.
abstract: In a long-awaited announcement, the governor says schools can welcome back students if the rate of infection in their communities remains low.
lead_paragraph: Schools across New York can reopen for in-person instruction this fall, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Friday, solidifying New York’s status as one of the few states in America that has a virus transmission rate low enough to bring children back into classrooms — not only in its rural communities but also in the country’s biggest city.

headline: Laid off, rehired, laid off again, and now without a weekly $600 boost.
abstract: After coronavirus-related lockdowns forced dining establishments in New York to close in March, Hannah Lane, 24, was laid off as a server in a popular Gramercy Park restaurant where she made about $60,000 a year.
lead_paragraph: After coronavirus-related lockdowns forced dining establishments in New York to close in March, Hannah Lane, 24, was laid off as a server in a popular Gramercy Park restaurant where she made about $60,000 a year.

headline: Covid Update: Don’t Rush the Vaccine
abstract: We’re developing a coronavirus vaccine with historic speed, but we can’t skip steps.
lead_paragraph: We’re developing a coronavirus vaccine with historic speed, but we can’t skip steps.

headline: Air India Jet With More Than 180 Passengers Skids and Cracks in Half
abstract: The plane, a Boeing 737, had been returning from Dubai when it skidded off a rain-soaked runway in the southern state of Kerala. The airline said 17 people had died.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — An Indian jetliner trying to land during a torrential downpour in southern India on Friday night skidded off a slick runway, crashed into a wall, tumbled into a valley and split in half, killing at least 17 people and injuring scores.

headline: This One Is for the Focaccia Lovers
abstract: Lighter and fresher than pizza, this crisp-edged flatbread is also a celebration of summer eggplant.
lead_paragraph: Ever since I went to college nearby, V&T Restaurant and Pizzeria in the Morningside Heights section of Manhattan has made my ideal of the eggplant pizza.

headline: A Picture of Change for a World in Constant Motion
abstract: What a masterpiece of Japanese printmaking teaches us about the way images circulate.
lead_paragraph: What a masterpiece of Japanese printmaking teaches us about the way images circulate.

headline: After Taking a Pandemic Hit, Billboard Ad Companies See Signs of Hope
keywords: ['Outdoor Advertising', 'Subways', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Company Reports', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Transit Systems', 'Quarantines', 'Urban Areas', 'Stations and Terminals (Passenger)']
abstract: The virus pummeled sales of ads on outdoor and transit displays, and a second wave could hamper a recovery. But executives believe the worst may be over for their business.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Male is an executive in a branch of the advertising business — billboards — that took a huge hit in the spring. So he was heartened by what he saw this week on his commute from Greenwich, Conn., to his office in Manhattan.

headline: At Talkspace, Start-Up Culture Collides With Mental Health Concerns
keywords: ['Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Text Messaging', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Start-ups', 'Privacy', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: The therapy-by-text company made burner phones available for fake reviews and doesn’t adequately respect client privacy, former employees say.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Ricardo Lori was an avid user of Talkspace — an app that lets people text and chat with a licensed therapist throughout the day. A part-time actor in New York City, Mr. Lori struggled with depression and anxiety, and he credited the app with helping him get out of an abusive relationship. He was a believer in Talkspace’s stated mission to make “therapy available and affordable for all,” and when the start-up offered him a job in its customer support department, Mr. Lori was ecstatic.

headline: As U.N. Warns of Catastrophe, Lebanon’s Leaders Debate Cause of Blast
abstract: The United Nations warning came as President Michel Aoun said the investigation into the deadly explosion in Beirut would examine if “external interference” played a role.
lead_paragraph: As rescue workers continued to comb the debris for survivors of the deadly explosion in the port of Beirut, and as the United Nations warned that Lebanon faced a humanitarian catastrophe, the nation’s leaders debated the possible cause of the blast but provided little new information.

headline: Pompeo Warned Russia Against Bounties on U.S. Troops in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is said to have sternly discussed payouts and red lines in a telephone call with Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has warned Russia’s foreign minister against Moscow paying bounties to Taliban-linked militants and other Afghan fighters for killing American service members, U.S. officials said.

headline: How to Handle a ‘Friendly’ Co-Worker Who’s Really a Total Jerk
abstract: A woman has a misogynist at her job. A 56-year-old despairs about his prospects. And employees are asked to pay for their own diversity training.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: E. Jean Carroll, Who Accused Trump of Rape, Can Go Forward With Suit
keywords: ['Immunity from Prosecution', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Libel and Slander', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A judge rejected President Trump’s bid to delay a defamation suit by Ms. Carroll, pointing to the recent Supreme Court ruling over his tax returns.
lead_paragraph: A New York judge has rejected President Trump’s bid to temporarily halt proceedings in a lawsuit filed against him by the writer E. Jean Carroll, who has accused him of rape, a ruling that allows the case to move forward in the months before the presidential election.

headline: Lorenzo Wilson Milam, Guru of Community Radio, Is Dead at 86
abstract: He helped start noncommercial stations in the 1960s and ’70s, offering an eclectic mix of music and talk. His goal: to change the world.
lead_paragraph: Lorenzo Wilson Milam, who devoted much of his life to building noncommercial radio stations with eclectic fusions of music, talk and public affairs, died on July 19 at his home in Puerto Escondido, Mexico. He was 86.

headline: How Accurate Are Virus Tests? Ohio Governor’s Results Show Positives and Negatives
abstract: With testing delays nationwide, experts are increasingly recommending a new type of rapid test that gives less accurate results. It is imperfect, but as one expert put it, “pretty good is a lot better than none.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio received a negative coronavirus test result on Thursday, hours after a positive test result had stopped him from meeting with President Trump in Cleveland. The contradictory results during a high-profile moment underscored the challenges of testing, an issue that has repeatedly stymied the virus response in the United States.

headline: Discouraged workers add to the cloud over the labor market.
abstract: The fall in the unemployment rate by nearly a full percentage point in July might seem to be unalloyed good news, a sign job seekers may soon be able to find a position.
lead_paragraph: The fall in the unemployment rate by nearly a full percentage point in July might seem to be unalloyed good news, a sign job seekers may soon be able to find a position.

headline: Dip for Dinner!
abstract: These no-fuss recipes are ideal for the busy days ahead.
lead_paragraph: Hi, there, and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Margaux Laskey here. Emily is headed out on vacation, so I’ll be sending dinner ideas to your inbox for the next few weeks. Got suggestions? Complaints? You can reach me at margaux@nytimes.com.

headline: This Is Not a Desk Chair
abstract: The pandemic has put video game equipment in unusually high demand. The gaming chair is ascendant.
lead_paragraph: In a rented home on a sunny street in Los Angeles, a team of professional gamers sat hunched over in swivel chairs while a pair of ergonomic specialists observed their posture, asked questions and took notes.

headline: The Simple Joys of Tamarind
abstract: Sweet, sour and tender under its brittle shell, the fruit’s pulp is equally at home in desserts and savory dishes.
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t a terribly naughty child by any means, but I had my share of errant behavior that kept my parents busy. Summers seemed to bring out the best or the worst in me, depending on which side of the equation you viewed it.

abstract: A start-up rethinks a little about how to live.

headline: Mauritius Faces Environmental Crisis as Oil Spills From Grounded Ship
keywords: ['Oil Spills', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A Japanese-owned bulk carrier ran aground near the Indian Ocean island in late July, with nearly 4,000 tons of fuel oil and 200 tons of diesel on board. And now its hull has cracked.
lead_paragraph: A ship that ran aground off the shores of Mauritius, in the Indian Ocean, began spilling oil into the country’s famed blue lagoons this week, triggering an environmental crisis in a tiny island nation that relies on its waters for fishing and tourism.

headline: The Presidential Debates Debate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Presidential Elections (US)']
abstract: Does this forum make sense for evaluating the candidates? Readers weigh in.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lost Summer: How Schools Missed a Chance to Fix Remote Learning
abstract: Education leaders spent months preparing to reopen classrooms. But with online learning set to continue for millions of students this fall, schools must catch up with reality.
lead_paragraph: With some combination of optimism, anxiety and wishful thinking, many educators spent their summers planning, in minute detail, how to safely reopen classrooms. Teachers stocked up on sanitation supplies as superintendents took a crash course in epidemiology and studied supply chain logistics for portable air filters.

headline: Police Violence in Portland Protests
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Reform', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Rural Areas', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The A.C.L.U. of Oregon says the police “are making a mockery of the First Amendment.” Also: Planned Parenthood and Black women; a free pass for Russia; universal internet; weekends in a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Washington N.F.L. Owner Dan Snyder Sues Media Company for Defamation
abstract: Snyder claimed in a lawsuit that an Indian website’s posts were “malicious criminal allegations.” It is his first public strike after a wave of attacks on his operation of the team.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Snyder, the owner of the Washington N.F.L. team, has accused an online media company of accepting payment in exchange for publishing defamatory rumors, including one that Snyder was named on a list of sexual offenders maintained by Jeffrey Epstein, the sex criminal and financier.

headline: Love Letter: Behind the Velvet Rope of Club Marriage
abstract: Plus: A road trip to remember.
lead_paragraph: For many singles, the pressure from parents, family members and friends to find love and get married can often result in feelings of inadequacy. Some assume that not being in a relationship is synonymous with a sad and lonely life (some also assume that marriage is the cure). In this week’s Modern Love essay, after years of being pressured by her parents to settle down, Katerina Tsasis, a writer who spent most of her 20s and 30s looking for love, got tired of feeling like she was standing in line to get into an exclusive club, and started living life on her own terms. Once married, she realized that marriage did not make her whole.

headline: Marquita Bradshaw on Her Tennessee Primary Victory: ‘I Could See the Momentum’
abstract: Ms. Bradshaw, an environmental justice advocate, is the first Black woman to be nominated for the Senate by a major party in Tennessee. “Working people showed that my viability was different,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Marquita Bradshaw, an environmental justice advocate who has run her Senate campaign on a shoestring budget, won an upset victory in the state’s Democratic primary on Thursday, brushing aside a party-backed candidate who had significantly out-raised her.

headline: House Can Sue to Force Testimony From McGahn, Appeals Court Rules
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appeals Courts (US)', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Impeachment']
abstract: A court endorsed the House Judiciary Committee’s ability to pursue testimony from the former White House counsel as part of its oversight responsibilities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Judiciary Committee can sue to force the former White House counsel Donald F. McGahn II to testify before Congress, a federal appeals court ruled on Friday.

headline: In These Immersive Shows, the Jury Is In (Your Home)
abstract: Sifting evidence and debating whodunit with strangers turns out to be an especially successful way for theater to be enjoyed from a laptop.
lead_paragraph: Last week I was called for jury duty. Twice. New York City has yet to resume in-person jury trials, but from a perch on my sofa, I could hear and assess one case involving the murder of an elderly woman and another concerning arson in a commercial building. These trials weren’t precisely real or even vaguely legal — and as both were Britain-based I doubt that I and my U.S. passport would have made it past voir dire. But I count each as an extrajudicial highlight in a week spent sampling new experiments in immersive theater and gaming. Verdicts follow.

headline: A New Hampshire Poet Laureate Lifts Her City’s Covid-19 Advisories
abstract: Tammi Truax, the Portsmouth poet laureate, writes a weekly poem for the city’s coronavirus newsletter, breaking up grim statistics with verse.
lead_paragraph: They arrive each week.

headline: Sharon Williams, a Nurturer on the Police Force, Dies at 54
abstract: When Ms. Williams came across troubled young women while on the job in New Orleans, she saw them as potential “angels.” She died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Here’s How to Crush the Virus Until Vaccines Arrive
abstract: To save lives, and save the economy, we need another lockdown.
lead_paragraph: In just weeks we could almost stop the viral fire that has swept across this country over the past six months and continues to rage out of control. It will require sacrifice but save many thousands of lives.

headline: Is TikTok More of a Parenting Problem Than a Security Threat?
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Social Media', 'Mobile Applications', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', '5G (Wireless Communications)', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Blacklisting']
abstract: Even as the White House moves against the Chinese social media app, the intelligence agencies do not see it as a major issue along the lines of Huawei.
lead_paragraph: TikTok has long presented a parenting problem, as millions of Americans raising preteens and teenagers distracted by its viral videos can attest. But when the C.I.A. was asked recently to assess whether it was also a national security problem, the answer that came back was highly equivocal.

headline: Want to Be a Doctor? Take Your Chances in a Closed Room With Strangers
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Medical Schools', 'Medical College Admission Test (MCAT)', 'Education', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS']
abstract: Admissions tests for many graduate schools have gone online. But not the MCAT, the exam for aspiring doctors. It must still be taken in person, pandemic or not.
lead_paragraph: Students applying to graduate schools can take the GRE, the LSAT and other tests at home this year because of the risks of gathering in an exam room for hours during the pandemic. But applicants sitting for the longest and arguably most grueling graduate entrance exam, the Medical College Admission Test, do not have that option.

headline: Ad Agency Sues Scott Rudin, Saying Producer Owes $6.3 Million
abstract: At issue: payment for media buying and marketing strategy for the Broadway revivals of “West Side Story” and “The Music Man.”
lead_paragraph: A major Broadway advertising agency has sued the powerful producer Scott Rudin, claiming he owes the company $6.3 million.

headline: Three Top Executives Are Out at WarnerMedia, HBO’s Parent Company
abstract: The shake-up came on the watch of the WarnerMedia chief executive, Jason Kilar, who joined the company in May.
lead_paragraph: In a sudden shake-up at one of Hollywood’s biggest companies, three top executives have left WarnerMedia, the AT&T division that houses HBO and the streaming service HBO Max, the company announced on Friday.

headline: Ship Cited in Beirut Blast Hasn’t Sailed in 7 Years. We Found It.
abstract: The explosive material responsible for the Aug. 4 blast in Beirut was carried there by the ailing cargo ship Rhosus in 2013. Here’s what happened next.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 21, 2013, at 11:27 a.m., a leaky ship arrived in Beirut’s port. It never left, and its volatile cargo would lead to tragedy in the city almost seven years later. The Rhosus was loaded with 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrate, which is believed to have blown up most of the port and damaged large parts of the city when it ignited in a warehouse on Aug. 4.

headline: Parents of College Students Worry, Should They Stay or Go?
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Parenting', 'Youth']
abstract: “This is a situation where you have to pray for the best and be ready for the worst,” one father said.
lead_paragraph: When Jacqueline Tourville, of Wells, Maine, thinks about sending her daughter off to college this month, the same questions keep circling in her mind.

headline: Brexit Behind Him, Boris Johnson Tries to Quiet Scotland’s Calls to Leave U.K.
abstract: Scottish polling shows a majority favor independence. The prime minister is concerned.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Barely six months after Britain broke away from the European Union, Prime Minister Boris Johnson is increasingly consumed with trying to stop the breakaway of restive parts of the United Kingdom.

headline: Are You a Working Mom? We Want To Hear Your Pandemic Story
abstract: The Times wants to know what your new normal looks like.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret being a working parent in the pandemic means doing multiple jobs at once. But for mothers, the burden may be crushing.

headline: Pence Will Visit Wisconsin While Biden Stays Home From Milwaukee Convention
abstract: The vice president’s decision underscored the different political wagers the two campaigns are making about the value of traveling to battleground states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Vice President Mike Pence, traveling aboard Air Force Two on Wednesday, heard that former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had scrapped his planned trip to Milwaukee to accept the Democratic presidential nomination, he saw an opportunity.

headline: Why the Coronavirus Is More Likely to ‘Superspread’ Than the Flu
abstract: Most people won’t spread the virus widely. The few who do are probably in the wrong place at the wrong time in their infection, new models suggest.
lead_paragraph: For a spiky sphere just 120 nanometers wide, the coronavirus can be a remarkably cosmopolitan traveler.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Besieges a Protest Leader as He Broadcasts Live
abstract: A helicopter and dozens of officers, some in tactical gear, were deployed for an arrest at a Manhattan apartment but withdrew after protesters arrived.
lead_paragraph: Derrick Ingram, an organizer of a group leading New York’s Black Lives Matter protests, was besieged inside his Manhattan apartment on Friday while a police helicopter patrolled overhead, officers banged on his door and police dogs waited in the hallway.

headline: Overlooked No More: Jovita Idár, Who Promoted Rights of Mexican-Americans and Women
abstract: As a teacher, writer, editor and activist, Idár preserved Mexican culture in South Texas and encouraged women to pursue an education and push for equal rights.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. This latest installment is one of many ways The New York Times is examining the centennial of the 19th Amendment.

headline: N.F.L.’s Push Ahead With Season Rankles Workers in the Home Office
abstract: Workers who have been ordered back to the league’s headquarters are resisting, arguing that the reopening was rushed and that in some ways they have been put in an “impossible situation.”
lead_paragraph: Almost alone in the sports world, the N.F.L. has promised to hold its 2020 season as scheduled even as the pandemic forces other sports leagues to cancel or reschedule games and construct elaborate self-contained communities to play their seasons.

headline: A Different View of a Jamaican Dancehall
abstract: On the verge of his first major exhibition, Akeem Smith shares a new artwork.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work into context. This week, we’re looking at a video by Akeem Smith, which will be part of his show “No Gyal Can Test” at Red Bull Arts in New York in late September. Smith’s work often takes inspiration from his experience working with his family’s fashion house, the Ouch Collective, and from the Jamaican dancehall community.

headline: Russia Continues Interfering in Election to Try to Help Trump, U.S. Intelligence Says
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: But a new assessment says China would prefer to see the president defeated, though it is not clear Beijing is doing much to meddle in the 2020 campaign to help Joseph R. Biden Jr.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia is using a range of techniques to denigrate Joseph R. Biden Jr., American intelligence officials said Friday in their first public assessment that Moscow continues to try to interfere in the 2020 campaign to help President Trump.

headline: Falwell Taking Leave From Liberty University Amid Photo Uproar
abstract: Jerry Falwell Jr., the college’s president and a supporter of President Trump, agreed to a request by the school’s board of trustees.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Jerry Falwell Jr. is officially out at Liberty University.]

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: The kindness of strangers in Beirut. Students share what it’s like to return to school. 75 years since the atomic bombings. Burna Boy’s Afro-fusion music. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. I found this week sobering. Did you feel the same? If your heart broke seeing the devastation in Beirut, you might want to take a look at how you can help. Maybe you just need these quick stress-reducing strategies — I certainly do. Wherever you are, I hope that you are safe and that the weekend brings you a chance to rest and recharge. Take care and enjoy some incredible journalism.

headline: Treating Our Shared World as an Extension of Our Homes
abstract: Picking up trash makes the outdoors a more beautiful space to inhabit — for everyone.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. The At Home team got a lovely email recently from a woman in Brooklyn who lives near Prospect Park. One of her pandemic activities, she reported, is to go to the park to collect trash. She walks in one direction, gloved and masked, picking up detritus and filling a plastic bag. Then she walks back across the fields she’s made pristine. “It looks clean,” she wrote, “and I’m filled with happiness I can share by protecting this recreational area as a sanctuary during a pandemic.”

headline: Trump’s Orders on WeChat and TikTok Are Uncertain. That May Be the Point.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Mobile Applications', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Social Media', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Blacklisting']
abstract: The restrictions on the two Chinese-owned apps followed a familiar model for other policy announcements on China from the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s sudden decision late Thursday to restrict two popular Chinese social media services from the United States has created confusion about how broad the bans on doing business with China could ultimately be.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: New York schools move toward reopening.
lead_paragraph: Schools across New York can reopen for in-person instruction this fall, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said Friday, making it one of the few states in America to forge ahead with reopening plans.

headline: ‘Hope is Really Important in This Work’
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'Newsletters', 'Elections', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)']
