headline: Canada Has Placed Its First Vaccine Order, but Don’t Expect a ‘Silver Bullet’
abstract: Before the federal government announced an order for millions of doses of a still unproven vaccine, its top doctor sounded a note of caution.
lead_paragraph: For Canadians anxiously craving an inoculation against the coronavirus, this week brought both optimism and words of sobering caution.

headline: Millions of Evictions Are a Sharper Threat as Government Support Ends
keywords: ['Evictions', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Landlords', 'Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Without more federal aid for workers, experts are expecting the largest disruption to the housing market since the Depression.
lead_paragraph: For the 108 million people who live in a rental home or apartment, Aug. 1 was a grim milestone. It marked the first time rent was due after much of the nation’s economic response to the coronavirus had expired.

headline: Brent Carver, Versatile Tony-Winning Actor, Dies at 68
abstract: He played Hamlet, the wizard Gandalf and Tevye in “Fiddler on the Roof.” But he was probably best known for “Kiss of the Spider Woman.”
lead_paragraph: Brent Carver, a sensitive, soft-spoken yet nakedly emotional Canadian actor and singer who won a Tony Award for his starring role in the 1993 musical “Kiss of the Spider Woman,” died on Tuesday at his home in Cranbrook, British Columbia. He was 68.

headline: Jobs, School Reopenings, Summer Desserts: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Bolivia Under Blockade as Protesters Choke Access to Cities
abstract: Six million people have been marooned by 70 roadblocks set up to protest the government’s response to the coronavirus and the postponement of the country’s general election.
lead_paragraph: TARIJA, Bolivia — Antigovernment protesters in Bolivia blockaded some of the country’s main roads this past week to challenge the delay of general elections and rebuke the government’s poor response to the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Republicans and Democrats Remain Divided on Stimulus Package
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Economy', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: Lawmakers were still at an impasse after meeting Friday, and President Trump’s advisers said they would recommend that he act on his own through an executive order.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers were still at an impasse after meeting Friday, and President Trump’s advisers said they would recommend that he act on his own through an executive order.

headline: Job Growth Slowed in July, Signaling a Loss of Economic Momentum
abstract: The ranks of the employed grew by 1.8 million, a drop from the pace of the previous two months, as renewed business closings hampered the recovery.
lead_paragraph: The American economy slowed in July as the pace of hiring eased from the robust rate of the previous two months, a victim of waning momentum and the resurgence of the coronavirus in many parts of the country.

headline: Bernard Bailyn, Eminent Historian of Early America, Dies at 97
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Books and Literature', 'History (Academic Subject)', 'Revolutionary War, American (1775-83)', 'Pulitzer Prizes', 'Bancroft Prizes', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: On topic after topic he shifted the direction of scholarly inquiry, winning two Pulitzers and a Bancroft Prize for his innovative research and groundbreaking works.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Bailyn, a Harvard scholar whose award-winning books on early American history reshaped the study of the origins of the American Revolution, died on Friday at his home in Belmont, Mass., a suburb of Boston. He was 97.

headline: Red Cross Cancels Guantánamo Visit Over Coronavirus Cases
keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Military Tribunals', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Disease Rates']
abstract: The pandemic has forced the longest absence of the humanitarian organization from the remote military prison in Cuba since it opened in January 2002.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: Trump Threatens to Bypass Congress as Stimulus Talks Fail Again
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: Democrats said the talks had been “disappointing,” and President Trump promised to use executive orders to provide relief if no agreement could be reached.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Crisis negotiations between the White House and top Democrats teetered on the brink of collapse on Friday, as both sides said they remained deeply divided on an economic recovery package and President Trump threatened to bypass Congress and act on his own to provide relief if no deal could be reached.

headline: Beirut on the Potomac
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Beirut, Lebanon, Explosions (2020)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The American spirit gets a Lebanese makeover.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — A society at the point of detonation suffers from internal rot. This was true, for example, of the Austro-Hungarian and Ottoman Empires in 1914. I am interested in two contemporary cases: the spark that blew up 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrate stored since 2014 in a warehouse at Beirut’s port, and the pathogen about one-thousandth the width of an eyelash that has killed at least 160,500 Americans and infected more than 4.9 million as President Trump has flailed.

headline: ‘If We Get It, We Chose to Be Here’: Despite Virus, Thousands Converge on Sturgis for Huge Rally
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Masks', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: Tens of thousands of motorcyclists roared into the western South Dakota community on Friday, lining Main Street from end to end, for the start of the annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally.
lead_paragraph: STURGIS, S.D. — Tens of thousands of motorcyclists roared into the western South Dakota community of Sturgis on Friday, lining Main Street from end to end, for the start of an annual rally that kicked off despite objections from residents and with little regard for a public health emergency ravaging the world.

headline: What It’s Like to Be a Virtual N.B.A. Fan
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Basketball', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Stadiums and Arenas']
abstract: No standing up, and definitely no cursing: The basketball superfan known as Bongo Lady takes us behind the screen as she is beamed into an N.B.A. game from her couch in Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: Malenda Meacham usually watches the Memphis Grizzlies play their home games at FedEx Forum from her perch in Section 106. She stands. She cheers. She paces. And, of course, she pretends to pound on the cartoon bongos whenever they flash on the arena’s big screens.

headline: How to Volunteer or Donate to Help Others This School Year
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Content Type: Service', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Families and Family Life', 'Food Banks and Pantries']
abstract: Many students and their families are struggling. Here are some ideas to help your neighbors, your schools and your community.
lead_paragraph: If you have already figured out how your family’s work and school situation might look this fall, remember other families might not be as secure. All parents want to stay or get healthy, give their children the best shot at an enriching school year and support themselves and their partners as they balance work and child-rearing — but this is an unprecedented, uncertain year. Millions of people are facing job loss, food insecurity, health problems and other worries in this ever-changing period.

headline: New York Is Positioned to Reopen Schools Safely, Health Experts Say
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Education', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Children and Childhood', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Transmission, even in New York City, is well below thresholds experts say are safe, but issues like adequate ventilation to combat aerosol spread of the virus remain.
lead_paragraph: New York State, the center of the worst coronavirus outbreak in the world four months ago, is now one of the few places in the country that may be able to safely reopen schools, several public health experts said after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo gave districts permission to do so.

headline: Know Your Pandemic Schooling Options
abstract: As districts decide how to handle the fall semester, parents are podding up, scheduling tutors and enlisting relatives.
lead_paragraph: Even as some of the first schools open for the new school year, many public school districts across the country are still weighing their options for the fall. The constant uncertainty and reopening options — in-person, hybrid, remote — have left parents to figure out how they will manage another term of balancing work, caregiving and education. And according to Heather Hill, a professor of education at Harvard University, many areas haven’t taken the necessary steps to make learning accessible to all students remotely.

headline: Former Angels Employee Charged in Pitcher’s Overdose Death
abstract: Tyler Skaggs, who had fentanyl and oxycodone in his system at the time of his death, would not have died if not for the fentanyl, federal prosecutors said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A former employee of the Los Angeles Angels was charged with conspiracy to distribute fentanyl in connection with the fatal overdose of Tyler Skaggs, a pitcher for the team, federal prosecutors announced on Friday.

headline: 2 Black Staff Members Quit Bon Appétit as Tensions Over Race Continue
abstract: Troubles at the magazine surfaced in June, when the top editor resigned under pressure after staff members complained of a toxic culture.
lead_paragraph: The tensions over race at Condé Nast’s food magazine continue.

headline: Joe Arpaio Loses Arizona Primary to Reclaim His Old Job as Sheriff
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections', 'Sheriffs']
abstract: Voters instead backed Jerry Sheridan, Mr. Arpaio’s former chief deputy, who promised to revive many of Mr. Arpaio’s policies but without the showmanship.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Joe Arpaio, the bellicose former Arizona sheriff whose harsh immigration tactics earned him international notoriety, narrowly lost his Republican primary as he tried to regain his old office in Maricopa County.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 8, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 8, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about Sahar Fares, a paramedic who died in the explosion in Beirut, misstated her age. She was 27, not 24.

headline: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Job Growth Slows, Signaling Longer Recovery
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 8, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “What started as an exercise class encompassed so much more. I’m a therapist on a bike. I’m sure a lot of people can relate to the emotional loss.”

headline: Postal Service Leader Sets Reorganization Amid Scrutiny Over Mail Ballots
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Absentee Voting', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The Trump donor who runs the post office pledged that such changes would not affect the ability to deliver ballots on time this fall.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service on Friday announced a substantial reorganization meant to increase efficiency as Democratic lawmakers demanded an inquiry into whether changes by President Trump’s postal officials could threaten the effective use of mail-in ballots for the November election.

headline: Georgia Businessman Charged With Hoarding Face Masks and Price Gouging
abstract: The man, Milton Ayimadu, allegedly hoarded 200,000 face masks and sold them for double what he paid, according to the U.S. Attorney’s Office.
lead_paragraph: A Georgia businessman has been charged with hoarding 200,000 face masks that he bought from a foreign country and selling them for twice as much as he paid on his baby clothing website, according to the Department of Justice.

headline: Lollapalooza
abstract: Brooke Husic and Sid Sivakumar warm us up for a tournament with a hot Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today we almost have a double debut — it’s Sid Sivakumar’s second effort (after an excellent Monday grid), and we haven’t seen Brooke Husic in The New York Times before, although she constructs elsewhere, including USA Today and independent venues (including Mr. Sivakumar’s, if you want to go full circle). This puzzle is full of debuts and personality, and it has an assertive feel to it that I absolutely love, definitely a challenge that is more than the sum of its amusing, corny, profound and confounding parts.

headline: Away From Gridlock in Washington, Trump Puts on a Show for His Club
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Masks', 'News and News Media', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: The president held what was billed as a news conference. But there was almost no news, he again said the virus would disappear and his audience seemed at times less the nation than his golf club members.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After spending a day huddled with his campaign advisers at his private club in Bedminster, N.J., President Trump emerged on Friday night for a surprise “news conference” that seemed at times to be as much a benefit for his loyal club members as it was about making any news or addressing the crisis facing the nation.

headline: ‘When You Say Badminton, You Say Indonesia’
abstract: Badminton is part of the national identity. It is the only sport in which Indonesia has won an Olympic gold medal, and the country had expected to add another this month in Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA — Raja Sapta Oktohari, the muscular and youthful president of the Indonesian Olympic Committee, was finding it hard to contain his enthusiasm.

headline: Tiger Woods’s Latest Adjustment Becomes a Burden
abstract: On Friday, Woods struggled with a new longer putter on the way to a hard-earned two-over-par 72. He finished eight strokes behind the P.G.A. Championship leader Haotong Li.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At this stage of Tiger Woods’s career, unpredictability is as sure a bet as a red shirt on Sunday.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘I Used to Go Here’ and Monster Trucks
abstract: Gillian Jacobs goes back to college in an indie comedy, and the Diesel Brothers host three hours of monster truck stunts.
lead_paragraph: I USED TO GO HERE (2020) Rent or buy on iTunes and other streaming platforms and pay TV operators. The “Community” star Gillian Jacobs heads back to college in this indie comedy from the director Kris Rey. Jacobs plays a 30-something writer named Kate who returns to her alma mater following a breakup and disappointing reviews of her first novel. The homecoming is spurred by an invitation from Kate’s former writing professor (and crush), played by Jemaine Clement, who asks her to read from her book. The return to campus life allows Kate to revisit a time when feeling adrift wasn’t so terrifying.

headline: Coronavirus Spares Gaza, but Travel Restrictions Do Not
abstract: The blockaded Gaza Strip has not recorded any cases of community transmission of the coronavirus, but new restrictions on movement continue to make life difficult.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — There was barely enough space to move on the popular Omar al-Mukhtar street in Gaza City on the eve of the Muslim celebration of Eid al-Adha as throngs of Palestinians — almost none with masks — crowded into colorful clothing shops and huddled around makeshift food stands.

headline: Bear Hugs and Bubbles: Why Some N.F.L. Players Opted Out
abstract: “I’m literally bear-hugging another creature on the other side of the ball every single play,” Leo Koloamatangi, a Jets offensive lineman, said. “If that guy has any symptoms, I’m going to get them.”
lead_paragraph: When his daughter, Marae, is old enough, Philadelphia Eagles receiver Marquise Goodwin will teach her to put family first. He will say that she should prioritize the people she loves most when making decisions. He will share his own choice, made five months after she was born: He will sit out the 2020 N.F.L. season.

headline: Rave Under the Kosciuszko Bridge: Are Illicit Parties Endangering N.Y.C.?
abstract: Videos and photos posted on social media of a number of parties show few guests abiding by social-distancing guidelines.
lead_paragraph: On a humid Saturday night, under a segment of the Kosciuszko Bridge, which connects Brooklyn and Queens, hundreds of people at an illicit gathering danced and swayed to the thumps of hip-hop and electronic music. Some wore masks. Many did not.

headline: As Lebanon Reels, Long-Awaited Hariri Assassination Verdicts Loom
abstract: A U.N.-backed court will soon pronounce verdicts in a 15-year-old bombing in Beirut that roiled the Middle East. But critics say the court’s protracted deliberations and huge expense have undermined its original purpose.
lead_paragraph: The blast ripped off balconies along the Mediterranean, smashed windows blocks away and echoed across Beirut, leaving a city shattered by the immeasurable loss.

headline: Trump’s Axios Interview, Kanye West’s Campaign: The Latest in the 2020 Race
abstract: President Trump wants to brand Joe Biden as a doddering gaffe machine. But the incumbent’s own rhetoric causes so much controversy it is overwhelming the strategy.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.

headline: Unwanted Truths: Inside Trump’s Battles With U.S. Intelligence Agencies
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Last year, intelligence officials gathered to write a classified report on Russia’s interest in the 2020 election. An investigation from the magazine uncovered what happened next.

headline: How to Help Your Pet With Post-Quarantine Separation Anxiety
abstract: The pandemic is hard on our dogs and cats, too.
lead_paragraph: In the early days of the coronavirus pandemic, many people began social distancing from relatives and investing additional time with pets. Animal shelters reported record numbers of pets going into foster homes, with placement rates from 50 percent to 70 percent, according to the ASPCA and the Best Friends Animal Society. Petfinder.com saw adoption inquiries nearly double from March to May compared with the previous three months. But when it eventually comes time for people to return to work, pets may be ill-equipped to handle the long days at home alone.

headline: Thoughtful Gift Ideas That Newlyweds Will Actually Use
abstract: Wedding pros and other industry experts share their go-to wedding gifts.
lead_paragraph: The wedding registry was created years ago to help guests determine what newlyweds want or need for their home as a married couple — think monogrammed towels, china and kitchen mixers. But in recent years, it has evolved into much more. The registry has become a place for gifting just about anything a couple may dream of, from designer furniture and wine collections to honeymoon excursions and even down payments on a home. Family and friends also like to give gifts that reflect their relationship to the couple as well as their own experiences and tastes. Narrowing down a gift selection, however, can be challenging.

headline: Near U.K.’s Busiest Port, Brexit Hopes Are Layered in Asphalt
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Freight (Cargo)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: A 27-acre site is being built to handle trucks amid fears that new trade rules will slow freight movement. It has been nicknamed the “Farage Garage” after the pro-Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage.
lead_paragraph: MERSHAM, England — The fields around the quiet village of Mersham, just 20 miles from the white cliffs of Dover, are a vision of idyllic English countryside. Lush, green trees sway above rolling acres of golden wheat. The spire of a 13th-century church looms on the horizon.

headline: Trump Wants U.S. to Get Cut of Any TikTok Deal. No One Knows How That’d Work.
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'United States Economy', 'Politics and Government', 'Social Media', 'Mobile Applications', 'Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)']
abstract: The president has repeatedly called for a big payment to the Treasury Department if a Chinese company sells the app to Microsoft, but there is no provision in the law for that.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If he were still running casinos in rough-and-tumble Atlantic City, N.J., President Trump’s demand about Microsoft’s possible purchase of TikTok might be translated this way: I want a piece of the action.

headline: Chris Dodd, an Insider From Biden’s Past, Is Helping Him Pick His Future
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: As Biden works to win over progressive voters, he has empowered a Washington uber-veteran long trailed by allegations of personal and financial indiscretion.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. knew how to flatter an old friend.

headline: Dolphins Have Hidden Fingers. So Do Seals. These Sea Creatures Did Not.
keywords: ['Fingers', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Dolphins and Porpoises', 'Whales and Whaling', 'Evolution (Biology)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Paleontology', 'Sea Lions', 'Crocodiles', 'Reptiles', 'Penguins', 'Seals (Animals) and Sealing', 'Research', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-animals']
abstract: A recent analysis of the flippers of living and extinct marine animals shows the enduring power of “baby mittens.”
lead_paragraph: Put a dolphin’s front flipper in an X-ray machine, and you’ll see a surprise: an arc of humanlike finger bones. The same goes for a sea turtle, a seal, a manatee and a whale. All of these animals had four-legged ancestors that lived on land. As their various lineages adapted to life in the water, what had been multidigit limbs slowly transformed into flippers.

headline: The Nudes Aren’t Going Away. Katie Hill’s OK With That.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', '#MeToo Movement', 'Nudism and Nudity', 'Books and Literature', 'ADULTERY']
abstract: Nine months after stepping down from Congress, she is trying to move forward.
lead_paragraph: If Katie Hill were a different person, she might have gone away and found religion. Perhaps she would have tearfully apologized, a dutiful husband by her side, and vowed to do better. Maybe she would have checked herself into sex rehab, hiked the Appalachian Trail or flat-out denied anything untoward had occurred.

headline: Turn Your Newspaper Into a Basket
abstract: Behold all the news that’s fit to weave.
lead_paragraph: Months into the pandemic, you’ve most likely spent more time decluttering — and assessing the amount of joy sparked by forgotten discoveries — than you’d ever expected. Now you’re on to organizing, and baskets are a great way to collect all of those little things floating around your home. You can transform your newspaper into a receptacle to keep things tidy that’s also a woven work of art. Here’s how.

headline: When Covid-19 Hit, Many Elderly Were Left to Die
keywords: ['Nursing Homes', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Elderly', 'Hospitals', 'Protective Clothing and Gear', 'Nursing and Nurses']
abstract: Warnings had piled up for years that nursing homes were vulnerable. The pandemic sent them to the back of the line for equipment and care.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Shirley Doyen was exhausted. The Christalain nursing home, which she ran with her brother in an affluent neighborhood in Brussels, was buckling from Covid-19. Eight residents had died in three weeks. Some staff members had only gowns and goggles from Halloween doctor costumes for protection.

headline: Black at U.T., and Beyond
abstract: A student set out to document the experiences of his Black classmates on their predominantly white campus. These are some of their stories.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, before the start of his senior year at the University of Texas at Austin, Adraint Bereal set out to chronicle the lives and experiences of Black students at his predominantly white college. (Black students comprised 4.9 percent, or roughly 2,500 of U.T. Austin’s 51,832 students, in fall 2019.)

headline: Without $600 Weekly Benefit, Unemployed Face Bleak Choices
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Unemployment', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Evictions', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: A federal supplement to jobless pay was a lifeline for millions and for the economy. Its cutoff, even if temporary, may have lasting consequences.
lead_paragraph: When Latrish Oseko lost her job last spring, government aid helped prevent a crisis from becoming a catastrophe.

headline: Three New Books by Women in the American Political Sphere
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Women and Girls', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Memoirs by Representative Ilhan Omar, the political analyst Tiffany Cross and the former congresswoman Katie Hill recount trials, victories and hopes for changing the country.
lead_paragraph: THIS IS WHAT AMERICA LOOKS LIKEMy Journey From Refugee to CongresswomanBy Ilhan Omar275 pp. Dey Street. $27.99.

headline: Hong Kong Officials Condemn and Mock Trump Administration Sanctions
abstract: Officials in Hong Kong targeted by new United States sanctions argued on Saturday that the move harmed American interests and would have little impact on them.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong and Chinese officials by turns condemned and mocked a Friday move by the Trump administration to impose sanctions on Hong Kong’s chief executive, Carrie Lam, and 10 other senior officials for their roles in a prolonged crackdown on political dissent in the city.

headline: Trump, Russia and an Intelligence Document: Key Moments
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'National Intelligence Estimates']
abstract: Officials told The New York Times Magazine that the draft of a classified document reporting that Russia favored President Trump in the 2020 election was changed to soften its assessment.
lead_paragraph: A little more than a year ago, American intelligence agencies drafted a classified document reporting that the Russian government favored President Trump in the 2020 presidential election, a finding that fit with their consensus that the Kremlin tried to help him in 2016.

headline: U.S. Surpasses 5 Million Cases
abstract: President Trump signed executive measures for pandemic relief as stimulus talks stalled. And Brazil reached two coronavirus milestones: more than 100,000 deaths and more than three million cases.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read live coronavirus updates here.

headline: Pitchers Are Creatures of Habit. A Season of Chaos Is Testing Them.
abstract: Some have resorted to throwing against mattresses in quarantine. Some have sustained early injuries. And all pitchers are trying to cope without their normal routines.
lead_paragraph: Of all the elements that make baseball distinctive, nothing compares to pitching. In what other team sport does the most influential player spend most of the schedule resting? Training for the treacherous job of throwing overhand repeatedly, at high speeds, requires careful calibration and strict routines.

headline: Don’t Be Ashamed of Those Extra Pounds
abstract: So you’ve put on some weight during lockdown. You can obsess over it, but you can also be kinder to yourself. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: With the explosion of lockdown-friendly home exercise programs and advice, it may seem as if it’s never been easier to work out at home. But the reality is, it’s probably never been harder. For every person posting a sweaty “crushed it” selfie on Instagram, there’s another one (or four) just trying to endure pandemic-induced stress. Add in constant access to the refrigerator and a pantry overstocked with panic buys, and the guilt about what we’ve eaten — or the exercise we haven’t done — piles on faster than you can say “Quarantine 15.”

headline: No Pajama Pants Allowed While Learning From Home, Illinois District Says
abstract: The Springfield, Ill., school district said it would require students to follow its dress code regardless of how classes are held.
lead_paragraph: Students in the capital of Illinois are not allowed to wear hats, bandannas, sunglasses, pajama pants or slippers in school buildings. And that dress code now extends to their bedrooms and kitchen tables.

headline: No Wrist Corsages, Please
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Has America grown since 1984, or will the knives still be out for Biden’s running mate?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the cusp of Joe Biden teaming up with a woman, I am casting back to my time covering the first woman who was a serious contender for veep.

headline: Air India Crash Investigators Focus On a Dangerous Runway and a Pilot’s Actions
abstract: As investigators sought the cause of a jetliner accident that killed 18 people, blame began to fall on the pilot and the hilltop runway.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The sky had turned black.

headline: Profits Rebound at Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Berkshire reported earnings of $26.4 billion in the second quarter, a turnaround from its $49.7 billion loss in the first quarter, when the pandemic caused a plunge in the stock market.
lead_paragraph: The strong recovery in the stock market — and a surge in the value of Apple’s stock, in particular — drove a rebound in profits for Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway in the second quarter.

headline: It’s Neighbor vs. Neighbor in a Co-op. Who Wins?
abstract: Co-op boards do not like to get in the middle of resident disputes. But if one shareholder is tormenting another, the issue must be addressed.
lead_paragraph: Q: The rear windows of my apartment in a Westchester co-op overlook a small outdoor sitting area with views of woods, birds, squirrels and chipmunks. Since spring, a new resident as been grilling there, obliterating the serenity of the space. After shareholders complained, the board insisted he move his grill 10 feet from the wall, but didn’t make any other demands. He’s still out there daily with two grills, chairs and an enormous toy car. He shouts and blasts his music. When I complained to management, I was told that he’s allowed to grill. But what about my comfort and my rights to use the space that he now dominates?

headline: Make This Ginger-Lime Chicken ASAP
abstract: Ali Slagle’s chicken recipe, J. Kenji López-Alt empanadas, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: The week’s most popular dishes include Ali Slagle’s mayo-marinated recipe for ginger-lime chicken (above), J. Kenji López-Alt’s beef empanadas and Millie Peartree’s mango slaw. Find more recipes in the collection below.

headline: Your Hot-Weather Guide to Coronavirus, Air-Conditioning and Airflow
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Air Conditioning', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Windows']
abstract: Indoor air is riskier than outdoor air. So what do you do if it’s really hot out?
lead_paragraph: Despite its critical role in our daily lives, air is not something most of us spend a great deal of time thinking about. It’s that easy to take for granted. Unlike water, we don’t need to fill up a cup to consume it. If some escapes from the room, more will find its way back in, whether we open the door or not.

headline: Variety: Cross Ties
abstract: Will Shortz is back to tie us up, but we can get across these nine little puzzles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — This is our second set of “Cross Ties” this year, so you may recognize the challenge before us (this puzzle type premiered on March 22, with a spoiler-filled accompanying column).

headline: America’s Military Should Confront Its Past, Not Bury It
keywords: ['Neo Nazi Groups', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'History (Academic Subject)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The German military’s infiltration by far-right extremists should be a warning for how we confront our own troubled history.
lead_paragraph: At the end of May, German police commandos arrived outside a rural home owned by a sergeant major in that country’s most elite special forces unit, the KSK. Buried in the backyard they found a trove of weapons, explosives and Nazi memorabilia. In response, Germany’s defense minister announced that she would disband one-quarter of the unit because of the widespread infiltration of far-right extremists into its ranks. But as several news reports have made clear, it is suspected that the infiltration extends far beyond a single segment of the KSK.

headline: Perfect the Art of Pickling and Ponder a Night of Poetry
abstract: Check out a reading by emerging writers, learn the secrets of Jewish cuisine and channel Rube Goldberg.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: A Song That Changed Music Forever
abstract: 100 years ago, Mamie Smith recorded a seminal blues hit that gave voice to outrage at violence against Black Americans.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 10, 1920, two African-American musicians, Mamie Smith and Perry Bradford, went into a New York studio and changed the course of music history. Ms. Smith, then a modestly successful singer from Cincinnati who had made only one other record, a sultry ballad that fizzled in the marketplace, recorded a new song by Mr. Bradford called “Crazy Blues.” A boisterous cry of outrage by a woman driven mad by mistreatment, the song spoke with urgency and fire to Black listeners across the country who had been ravaged by the abuses of race-hate groups, the police and military forces in the preceding year — the notorious “Red Summer” of 1919.

headline: Why Is Everyone Buying Gold?
abstract: It’s one of the best performing assets in the world this year. That’s not a great sign.
lead_paragraph: Gold bugs — investors perpetually bullish on gold — have long been seen as a paranoid fringe of the financial world, holding the shiny asset as a hedge against a disaster they always think is near. But lately, they appear to be on to something. This year, gold is the best performing traditional asset in the world. Its price just topped $2,000 an ounce for the first time. From serious investors to newly minted day traders, everyone is talking up its virtues.

headline: Sports Podcasts Even a Newbie Can Enjoy
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Basketball', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Soccer']
abstract: Just because you can’t go to the games doesn’t mean your summer has to be athlete-free.
lead_paragraph: Even after months of postponed seasons and canceled events, sports leagues continue to struggle to rebound (at least, in the United States). For fans, this means that 2020 will most likely be a year with fewer games and without any in-person games. Fortunately, there’s a raft of podcasts that can give seasoned fans some content to fill that void — and these four shows are so entertaining and enlightening that even the most sports-disinterested person will probably enjoy tuning in. Find them in your listening app of choice.

headline: Pelosi Is Playing Hardball on Coronavirus Relief. She Thinks She’ll Win.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Emboldened by Republican divisions and a favorable political landscape, the speaker is refusing to agree to a narrow relief measure, unbothered by charges that she is an impediment to a deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the clock ticked down Thursday on a self-imposed deadline for a breakthrough in coronavirus relief talks with no deal in sight, Jim Cramer, the brash CNBC host, had an on-air proposal for Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California.

headline: Trump Threatens to Use Executive Order for ‘Critical Relief’
abstract: Though it’s unclear whether he has the authority to do so, President Trump said on Friday that if Congress did not reach an agreement, he would act unilaterally to extend a coronavirus economic aid package.
lead_paragraph: Though it’s unclear whether he has the authority to do so, President Trump said on Friday that if Congress did not reach an agreement, he would act unilaterally to extend a coronavirus economic aid package.

headline: Clashes Erupt in Beirut at Blast Protest as Lebanon’s Anger Boils Over
abstract: The demonstrations were fueled by fury over the corruption and negligence of the country’s ruling elite. Security forces fired tear gas to push back the protesters.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Violent clashes between demonstrators and security forces transformed much of central Beirut into a battle zone of flying rocks, swinging batons and clouds of tear gas on Saturday, as the fury over a huge explosion in Beirut’s port this week fueled attacks on government buildings.

headline: How Kristi Noem, Mt. Rushmore and Trump Fueled Speculation About Pence’s Job
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: After Ms. Noem, the South Dakota governor, flew to Washington on Air Force One, rumors about her ambitions ensued. She made a second trip to smooth things over with Mike Pence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since the first days after she was elected governor of South Dakota in 2018, Kristi Noem had been working to ensure that President Trump would come to Mount Rushmore for a fireworks-filled July 4 extravaganza.

headline: 3 Graphic Novel Detective Stories
abstract: Dynamic duos set out to solve mysteries for others and end up uncovering truths about themselves.
lead_paragraph: Recently my daughter was searching for her sketchbook when she found her missing paintbrushes instead. Such is the recovery of lost belongings. You’re looking for one thing, you find something else. I’ve stumbled onto story ideas this way. I’m so sure I’m writing about a missing brother, when I discover I’m actually writing about empathy and self-acceptance. Most good mysteries strike a graceful balance between plot and character development. These three do just that, by inviting you to look and look again, to uncover the stories underneath.

headline: How to Diversify Orchestras
abstract: Readers offer their ideas in response to the music critic Anthony Tommasini’s suggestion that blind auditions be ended.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Frances Allen, Who Helped Hardware Understand Software, Dies at 88
abstract: One of the few women in the computer industry in its early days, she paved the way for the efficient, lightning-fast apps of today.
lead_paragraph: Frances Allen, a computer scientist and researcher who helped create the fundamental ideas that allow practically anyone to build fast, efficient and useful software for computers, smartphones and websites, died on Tuesday, her 88th birthday, in Schenectady, N.Y.

headline: C.D.C. Closes Some Offices Over Bacteria Discovery
abstract: The move highlights the risk of Legionnaires’ disease outbreaks when buildings are reopened after coronavirus lockdowns.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s foremost public health agency is learning that it is not immune to the complex effects of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The Voting Will End Nov. 3. The Legal Battle Probably Won’t.
abstract: As the two parties clash over how to conduct an election in a pandemic, President Trump’s litigiousness and unfounded claims of fraud have increased the likelihood of epic postelection court fights.
lead_paragraph: The stormy once-in-a-lifetime Florida recount battle that polarized the nation in 2000 and left the Supreme Court to decide the presidency may soon look like a high school student council election compared with what could be coming after this November’s election.

headline: Protests Erupt on the Streets of a Battered Beirut
abstract: Demonstrators took hold of Lebanon’s capital, fueled by widespread outrage after a blast in Beirut’s port that killed at least 154 people and destroyed entire neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators took hold of Lebanon’s capital, fueled by widespread outrage after a blast in Beirut’s port that killed at least 154 people and destroyed entire neighborhoods.

headline: Remains of Sailor and 7 Marines Killed in Training Accident Are Recovered
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The servicemen had been missing since the amphibious assault vehicle they were in sank off the coast of Southern California on July 30.
lead_paragraph: The remains of seven Marines and one sailor killed in a training accident off the coast of Southern California late last month were recovered on Friday in a U.S. Navy underwater salvage operation, according to the authorities.

headline: Richard Lapointe, Exonerated in a Murder Case, Dies at 74
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Advocates worked for decades to free him in the murder of his wife’s grandmother in Connecticut; in 2015 a court finally agreed.
lead_paragraph: Richard Lapointe, convicted on dubious evidence in 1992 of one of the more shocking murders in recent Connecticut history, fought for more than two decades for his release from prison, with a small army of supporters backing him. In 2015 he and his advocates finally succeeded.

headline: ‘Godspell’ Review: Musical Theater Rises From the Dead
abstract: The Berkshire Theater Group put on the first professional musical in the U.S. since the pandemic lockdown, and it’s a revival in every sense.
lead_paragraph: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — And it came about that the faith of the devoted was sorely tested during the months of famine, and there was a great hunger to believe again. Thus on a hazy night in August, several score of them gathered, with their lower faces hidden as the times demanded, in a parking lot in a small city in the lap of the Berkshire Mountains. They were looking for signs of a resurrection.

headline: Robbie Waters, an Old-School Cop and Legislator, Dies at 84
abstract: A Sacramento fixture, Mr. Waters drove a 1932 Ford and crossed paths with Patty Hearst and Squeaky Fromme. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: America Could Control the Pandemic by October. Let’s Get to It.
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Quarantines', 'Masks', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'United States Economy', 'Disease Rates']
abstract: The solutions to combating the coronavirus are no mystery. It’s time to do this right.
lead_paragraph: Six to eight weeks. That’s how long some of the nation’s leading public health experts say it would take to finally get the United States’ coronavirus epidemic under control. If the country were to take the right steps, many thousands of people could be spared from the ravages of Covid-19. The economy could finally begin to repair itself, and Americans could start to enjoy something more like normal life.

headline: Pac-12 Players Say Commissioner Was Dismissive of Their Virus Concerns
abstract: The players, who have pushed for more-frequent virus testing and stronger protection of their status with the team, said Pac-12 Commissioner Larry Scott offered no concrete mandates for the league’s universities.
lead_paragraph: When a group of Pac-12 Conference players who are threatening to opt out of the football season met with Commissioner Larry Scott on Thursday night, they had two primary objectives: pushing for more-frequent coronavirus testing and protecting the eligibility and status of players who choose not to play for health reasons.

headline: The Deafening Silence of a Coronavirus Championship
abstract: Many sports have returned to play without fans. Golf is deciding a major championship without them. For players used to feeding off the crowd’s energy and reactions, it’s just not the same.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For three days of the P.G.A. Championship, golf’s first major of this discombobulated sports year, the world’s best players were introduced at the start of their rounds by a public-address announcer with no public to address.

headline: What to Do When Covid Doesn’t Go Away
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Lyme Disease', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Chronic Condition (Health)']
abstract: Lessons for coronavirus long-haulers from my own experience with chronic illness.
lead_paragraph: Among the many things that nobody knows about the disease that has overturned our lives is how long its effects last. I don’t just mean the possibility of coronavirus damage lurking invisibly in the heart or lungs or brain. I mean the simpler question of what it takes, and how long, for some uncertain percentage of the sick to actually feel better.

headline: Rick Gates, Ex-Trump Aide and Mueller Witness, Is Publishing a Memoir
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: “Wicked Game” is slated for release in October, at the height of the presidential campaign, but Mr. Gates says, “It’s not a salacious book.”
lead_paragraph: He was the star witness in the Russia investigation, whose testimony helped convict two powerful advisers to the president. Now, Rick Gates, a high-level aide on Donald J. Trump’s 2016 campaign, is preparing to tell his story in a memoir that will be published weeks before the 2020 election.

headline: Brent Scowcroft Didn’t Always Follow ‘the Scowcroft Model’
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Cold War Era', 'Persian Gulf War']
abstract: As national security adviser, he voiced strong opinions and acted on them, especially when it came to Beijing and Moscow.
lead_paragraph: It became known in foreign policy circles as “the Scowcroft model.” Brent Scowcroft, the former national security adviser for Presidents Gerald Ford and George H.W. Bush, who died Thursday, was frequently praised for establishing a paradigm for doing that job that many of his successors attempted (or claimed) to follow. The irony is that the real Brent Scowcroft, a man of strong views, didn’t always fit the paradigm himself.

headline: Stay Cool Without Racking Up a Bill
abstract: Four ways to air-condition your home more efficiently in the summer heat.
lead_paragraph: If you are relying on your air-conditioner around the clock this summer and fretting about your bills, fear not. There are several money-saving steps you can take to stay cool — whether you have a window unit or a central system.

headline: How to Prepare for Your Return to the Office
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Workplace Environment', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Nervous about the possibility of going back to the workplace? Here’s what to take into consideration.
lead_paragraph: Since the coronavirus hit the United States in the spring, about 35 percent of American workers have switched to telecommuting, according to a recent survey by the National Bureau of Economic Research. And with the end of summer fast approaching, you may be wondering about your return to the office — should you return at all.

headline: Craft Show
abstract: The art of the puzzle shines through this multilayered and sometimes deceptively simple-looking example.
lead_paragraph: Deb Amlen and Caitlin Lovinger are on assignment. The Sunday column was written by the New York Times editor, intrepid solver and recently converted constructor, Helen T. Verongos.

headline: Shirley Ann Grau, Writer Whose Focus Was the South, Dies at 91
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Pulitzer Prizes']
abstract: In books like her novel “The Keepers of The House,” which won a Pulitzer Prize, Ms. Grau wrote unsparingly about race relations.
lead_paragraph: In the heat of the civil rights struggle, the Ku Klux Klan tried to intimidate Shirley Ann Grau, a white Southerner who had written about interracial marriage, by burning a cross on her front lawn.

headline: Tiz the Law Wins the Travers in a Runaway
abstract: The colt has now won six of his seven starts, including the Belmont Stakes, and will head to the postponed Kentucky Derby as the favorite after breezing to victory at Saratoga.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The Belmont Stakes champion Tiz the Law added the Travers Stakes to his winning résumé on Saturday, making him the favorite to win the postponed Kentucky Derby next month and then possibly to claim the sport’s 14th Triple Crown with a Preakness victory in October.

headline: In Champions League, a Coach With the Right Résumé Can Still Get It Wrong
abstract: For Europe’s superclubs, the bar for success hasn’t changed. What teams look for in a coach absolutely has.
lead_paragraph: The strangest thing about Zinedine Zidane’s rise into the ranks of the finest coaches in the world should, really, be that nobody saw it coming, not even those at Real Madrid who had been observing him up close as he learned the craft.

headline: Sidestepping Congress, Trump Signs Executive Measures for Pandemic Relief
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: President Trump signed the directives after two weeks of stalemate with Democrats over a recovery package, using legally dubious measures to try to restore lapsed benefits.
lead_paragraph: President Trump took executive action on Saturday to circumvent Congress and try to extend an array of federal pandemic relief, resorting to a legally dubious set of edicts whose impact was unclear, as negotiations over an economic recovery package appeared on the brink of collapse.

headline: Trump’s Go-It-Alone Stimulus Won’t Do Much to Lift the Recovery
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: A series of executive actions will provoke lawsuits but is unlikely to stoke faster growth in an economy that has cooled this summer.
lead_paragraph: The executive actions President Trump took on Saturday were pitched as a unilateral jolt for an ailing economy. But there is only one group of workers that seems guaranteed to benefit from them, at least right away: lawyers.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A New Cash Cow for Farmers: Turning the Chores Into Clicks
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 9, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “The storytelling part is what I’m good at. I’m not that good at the farming part.”

headline: Dustin Johnson, Surrounded by Young Challengers, Leads the P.G.A. Championship
abstract: Collin Morikawa, a 23-year-old playing in his second major, shot a five-under-par 65 to join the chase ahead of Sunday’s final round.
lead_paragraph: In the crowd-free quiet of the P.G.A. Championship on Saturday, Collin Morikawa could hear two kayakers on the lake below the 16th hole of TPC Harding Park trying to identify golfers on the cliff above them. Eventually, the pair came up with the name of the player walking with Morikawa — Adam Scott, the former world No. 1 from Australia.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Surviving Jeffrey Epstein’ and Shark Week
abstract: Lifetime’s two-part series features interviews with Jeffrey Epstein’s accusers, and Discovery Channel’s week of shark-themed programming begins.
lead_paragraph: SURVIVING JEFFREY EPSTEIN 8 p.m. on Lifetime. This two-episode special will look into the crimes of Jeffrey Epstein, the wealthy financier and sex offender who died in federal custody last year. For years Epstein had been accused of sexually abusing underage girls, but had avoided federal charges until he was arrested in 2019 for sex trafficking. Epstein’s death, which was ruled a suicide, left many of his accusers angry that he would never stand trial. This documentary focuses on eight of the accusers, who shed light on Epstein and his inner circle.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 9, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 9, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about fraternity brothers and sorority sisters who are working to get Greek organizations off campus misidentified the sorority that the Emory student Emma Pinto left. It was Zeta Tau Alpha, not Kappa Kappa Gamma. The article also misspelled the surname of a student at Vanderbilt. He is Jared Bauman, not Baumann.

headline: A Club That Sharpens Our Craft
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs', 'Newspapers', 'Book Clubs']
abstract: Eight years ago, a group of Times journalists began meeting to discuss works they admired. Now you can watch a session, too.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: ‘The Guy in Front of Me Called a Name, and the Other Guy Turned’
abstract: A street scene at the end of the day, carrying a gift on a packed train and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Democrats Hold Edge as Battle for Senate Majority Becomes ‘Knife Fight’
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As the campaign enters a critical period, the pandemic, their primary strategy and their presumptive nominee have given Democrats a shot at winning the chamber.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In February, Democrats began getting anxious about the crucial Senate race in North Carolina. An unknown Republican-affiliated group was suddenly pouring millions of dollars behind the candidacy of Erica Smith, a progressive state senator who they believed had no chance of winning the seat in November.

headline: A Bookstore That Shines as ‘a Lighthouse of a Free Society’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Politics and Government', 'Secession and Independence Movements', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: A Hong Kong bookseller has recreated his shop in Taipei, and it has become a symbol of Taiwan’s vibrant democracy.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Inside a hushed bookstore in central Taipei one recent night, Ju Lee-wen stood beneath a large black banner that said “Revolution Now!” and raised her fist into the air.

headline: In California, It Will Take More Than a Parade to Save an Imperiled Census
keywords: ['Census', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Population', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many Latinos in low-income communities say they are hearing a message about the 2020 census: Your participation is not wanted.
lead_paragraph: PERRIS, Calif. — For one day at least, as a 10-car parade of vehicles with honking horns, pompoms and signs reading “Get Counted” crawled through this predominantly Latino agricultural town about 70 miles east of Los Angeles on Friday, it was hard to forget that the 2020 census was going on and that it mattered.

headline: ‘Christianity Will Have Power’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Whites', 'Evangelical Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: Donald Trump made a promise to white evangelical Christians, whose support can seem mystifying to the outside observer.

headline: Afghanistan to Release Last Taliban Prisoners, Removing Final Hurdle to Talks
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The decision clears the way for the last of 5,000 insurgents to be freed. President Ashraf Ghani announced the release after convening an assembly of 3,000 representatives to seek their advice.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan on Sunday said his government would release a last batch of Taliban prisoners, removing the final hurdle in the way of direct negotiations with the insurgents to end the country’s long war.

headline: ‘Top Cop’ Kamala Harris’s Record of Policing the Police
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police Reform', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Racial Profiling', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Attorneys General', 'District Attorneys', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Criminal Justice']
abstract: Senator Harris is speaking out amid the police reform movement. But how did she oversee police misconduct as a district attorney and attorney general?
lead_paragraph: During this summer of tear gas and turmoil, Kamala Harris has not been quiet.

headline: Notes From a Virus Tracker’s Log
abstract: With over 200,000 cases in Los Angeles County alone, contact tracers like Radhika Kumar have their work cut out for them.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times asked Radhika Kumar, a contact tracer for California Connected, an ambitious effort by the state to track people who have been infected with or exposed to the coronavirus, to keep a log of her interactions over the course of a day’s work.

headline: This Contact Tracer Is Fighting Two Contagions: The Virus and Fear
abstract: Convincing infected people to open up means helping them confront deeply held concerns about deportation or job loss.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Radhika Kumar goes to work every morning hoping to save lives. As a contact tracer for Los Angeles County, her job, at least on paper, entails phoning people who have tested positive for the coronavirus, along with others they may have exposed, and providing them with guidance on how to isolate so as not to infect others. If that sounds easy, it is not.

headline: Boycotted. Criticized. But Fox News Leads the Pack in Prime Time.
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Television', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Cable Television', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Led by Tucker Carlson and Sean Hannity, the channel’s pro-Trump lineup outranked every network from 8 to 11 p.m. in June and July.
lead_paragraph: In one sense, this has been a difficult period for Fox News: a star anchor fired after being accused of sexual harassment, a lawsuit depicting a misogynist workplace, a top writer exposed as a racist internet troll, advertiser boycotts and outrage after Tucker Carlson called protesters “criminal mobs” and questioned the patriotism of a senator who lost her legs in Iraq.

headline: The Wallets of Wall Street Are With Joe Biden, if Not the Hearts
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Through donations, finance executives played a critical role in helping Joe Biden turn his campaign around. They’ve mostly grown to like him, if not love him.
lead_paragraph: As Wall Street donors arrived at a fund-raiser for Joseph R. Biden Jr. at a Midtown Manhattan restaurant earlier this year, campaign staff members asked if they wanted to sign up for pictures with the candidate. More than a few of the bankers and private-equity investors politely declined, opting to mingle over glasses of wine instead.

headline: How to Move Your Elephant During a Pandemic
keywords: ['Elephants', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Circuses', 'Zoos', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-photojournalism', 'your-feed-animals']
abstract: After decades in captivity and a 1,700-mile road trip from Argentina into Brazil, an Asian elephant named Mara finally gained a chance to roam.
lead_paragraph: The border between Argentina and Brazil had been closed by the coronavirus pandemic for nearly two months when, in early May, an unusual convoy approached the checkpoint in Puerto Iguazú. There were 15 people, all of whom had gone days with little sleep, and six vehicles, including a crane and a large truck.

headline: Saudi Aramco Says Profit Fell 73 Percent as Demand for Oil Shrank
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Company Reports']
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic took a major toll on the oil giant’s earnings, but Aramco will maintain its hefty dividend for shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, said on Sunday that its quarterly earnings plunged more than 73 percent compared to a year ago, as lockdowns imposed to curb the coronavirus pandemic drastically cut the demand for oil and slammed prices.

headline: Stimulus, Election Day, Serena Williams: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Week in Business: The Stimulus Mess
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Unemployment', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: A jobs report that found  the U.S. economy added 1.8 million jobs in July, and President Trump signed executive orders to extend some of the benefits in the virus relief law.
lead_paragraph: The July employment report on Friday morning showed that America’s job market appears to be losing steam after two months of improvement. The 1.8 million jobs added in July was a sharp slowdown from the 4.8 million gained in June, as businesses closed again in parts of the country where the virus has surged. The unemployment rate was 10.2 percent in July, down from 11.1 percent in June. Only a little more than 40 percent of the jobs lost since the pandemic hit have been recovered. And even as employers are hiring, other workers are being let go permanently after assuming that their layoffs were temporary.

headline: This Company Boasted to Trump About Its Covid-19 Vaccine. Experts Are Skeptical.
abstract: Inovio, a Pennsylvania biotech company, has spent years claiming to be on the cusp of important vaccines. It has never brought one to market.
lead_paragraph: As the deadly new virus spread globally, Inovio Pharmaceuticals, a small biotech company in Pennsylvania, rushed to develop a vaccine. After announcing promising early results, Inovio’s stock soared more than 1,000 percent. Riding the momentum, the company sold more shares to the public.

headline: At Least 97,000 Children in the U.S. Tested Positive in Last 2 Weeks of July
abstract: Trump’s unilateral economic relief actions come under fire. Ohio’s governor urges use of rapid tests, but with caution after his false positive.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Covid-19 news and updates.]

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘A Speck in the Sea’
abstract: This is a story about isolation — and the struggle to close the space between us.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: At Least 1 Dead and 20 Wounded in Washington, D.C., Shooting
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: An off-duty police officer was in critical condition after multiple people opened fire on what appeared to be a block party, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A shooting in Washington, D.C., early on Sunday morning left at least one person dead and 20 people wounded, the authorities said.

headline: Terry Cannon, Creator of an Alternative to Cooperstown, Dies at 66
abstract: His Baseball Reliquary collects quirky artifacts and honors people who wouldn’t ordinarily be elected to the august Baseball Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Terry Cannon, who created a waggish alternative to the Baseball Hall of Fame with oddball artifacts like a cigar partly smoked by Babe Ruth and unconventional inductees like Dock Ellis, who claimed to have pitched a no-hitter on LSD, died on Aug. 1 at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 66.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: End your weekend with Meera Sodha’s chicken curry with her naan and raita and a bit of chutney to set yourself up for the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. You know what’s a good thing to cook on a Sunday afternoon? Meera Sodha’s chicken curry (above), which her mom taught her to make, and her naan to go with it, which her aunt taught her to make. I like to make some raita as well. We’ve got a fine recipe for hot mango chutney, too, but I’ll use store-bought. I’m not looking for projects at the end of the weekend, just comfort and deliciousness. I want to eat early, and then go binge “Queen Sugar” for a while. Will you join me?

headline: It’s a Tough Time for the Left. But I’m More Optimistic Than Ever.
keywords: ['Socialism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Strikes', 'Elections', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Politics and Government', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On both sides of the Atlantic, the signs of radical possibility are everywhere.
lead_paragraph: Never in my life have political conditions felt so ripe for change.

headline: Israel Will Be Perfectly Happy With President Biden
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Palestinians']
abstract: It’s the best we can do — for a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — In the pile of old notebooks I saved from  when I was covering American politics for an Israeli newspaper (and when reporters still used a pad and pen), I found five mentions of Joe Biden’s Israel story.

headline: A Brazilian Soccer Mine Strikes Gold in Madrid
abstract: Renan Lodi’s arrival at Atlético Madrid has fulfilled his dream of playing in the Champions League, but it also produced a long-awaited payday for the scouting business that discovered him.
lead_paragraph: CURITIBA, Brazil — In many ways, there is nothing extraordinary about Renan Lodi. A defender at the Spanish soccer club Atlético Madrid, Lodi is among the hundreds of Brazilian players who have crossed the Atlantic to play for European clubs in elite competitions like the Champions League.

headline: A Reckoning for College Fraternities and Sororities
abstract: Perspectives from two readers who have studied them.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gloria DeNard, Who Educated Through Jazz, Is Dead at 93
abstract: She founded the East Harlem music school Manna House Workshops because, she said, “I wanted the people in the community to have a better feeling of self-worth.”
lead_paragraph: Gloria DeNard studied voice at the Juilliard School. She sang on CBS Radio and toured the world as a U.S.O. performer. But it was offstage, as an educator and activist, that she made her biggest impact.

headline: Adin Steinsaltz, 83, Dies; Created Epic Translation of Talmud
abstract: A rabbi and scholar, he wrote more than 60 books, but his crowning achievement (he called it his hobby) was his 45-year, 45-volume translation of a key Jewish text.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz, a towering scholar of the bedrock Jewish texts who spent four and a half decades writing a 45-volume translation of the Babylonian Talmud and made it accessible to hundreds of thousands of readers, died on Friday in Jerusalem. He was 83.

headline: Pleas to Abolish the Death Penalty
abstract: Readers cite moral and legal reasons the sentence is wrong.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Macron Urges World Leaders to Speed Aid to Lebanon After Explosions
abstract: The vow to accelerate help, made during a video call with other heads of state, comes amid furious demonstrations in Beirut against the Lebanese government.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France called on world leaders to fast-track financial and humanitarian aid to Lebanon on Sunday after explosions last week decimated parts of Beirut and left more than 150 people dead.

headline: 5.1 Magnitude Earthquake Strikes North Carolina
abstract: The earthquake near the border with Virginia was the strongest in the region since 1916, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 5.1 that struck North Carolina near its border with Virginia on Sunday morning was the area’s largest in over a century, the United States Geological Survey said.

headline: Players to UConn Coach: ‘There’s No Way That We Can Play’
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Draft and Recruitment (Sports)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coaches and Managers', 'College Athletics']
abstract: For Connecticut, the call to pull the plug on the college football season was clear. The Power 5 schools have been far less decisive.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut football coach Randy Edsall’s moment of clarity came when he was recently walking up the hill to his team’s practice field.

headline: Composting Has Been Scrapped. These New Yorkers Picked Up the Slack.
abstract: People like Vivian Lin, who quit her job at an architecture firm to start a composting business, have helped fill the void after the city suspended curbside organic waste collection.
lead_paragraph: In the months since New York City scrapped the bulk of its voluntary composting program, Vivian Lin has reoriented her life.

headline: Col. Steven dePyssler, Who Aided Veterans’ Families, Dies at 101
abstract: He acquired everything from toilet paper to plane parts for Air Force squadrons. Later, he advised widows on veterans’ benefits. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Trump’s Orders on Coronavirus Relief Create Confusion
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Payroll Tax', 'Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Small Business', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: Businesses and the unemployed faced uncertainty as administration officials defended the president’s directives and Democrats criticized them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s attempt to circumvent Congress to provide coronavirus relief in the absence of a broad agreement resulted in confusion and uncertainty on Sunday for tens of millions of unemployed Americans and countless businesses seeking aid after critical benefits lapsed.

headline: The Coming Eviction Crisis: ‘It’s Hard to Pay the Bills on Nothing’
abstract: If the federal government repeats the mistakes of the last recession, millions of Americans will lose their apartments and homes.
lead_paragraph: In Columbus, Ohio, judges have relocated eviction hearings to the cavernous halls of the city’s convention center, to ensure there’s plenty of space for the grim business of throwing families onto the street.

headline: Beirut’s Blast Is a Warning for America
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Beirut, Lebanon, Explosions (2020)']
abstract: In this country, as in Lebanon, everything is now politics.
lead_paragraph: When I first heard the news of the terrible explosion in Beirut, and then the rampant speculation about who might have set it off, my mind drifted back some 40 years to a dinner party I attended at the residence of Malcolm Kerr, then president of the American University of Beirut.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
