headline: Retired Police Officer Tracks Down Escapee Who Shot Him Almost 50 Years Ago
keywords: ['Prison Escapes', 'Fugitives', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: “It was like unfinished business,” the former Denver officer said of finding the fugitive, who had been living under an alias in New Mexico for decades.
lead_paragraph: Daril Cinquanta, a retired Denver police officer, never forgot the man who shot him while he was on duty in 1971. So when the man, Luis Archuleta, escaped from prison in 1974, Mr. Cinquanta made it his mission to track him down.

headline: Belarus Says Longtime Leader Is Re-elected in Vote Critics Call Rigged
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Elections']
abstract: A government exit poll said Aleksandr Lukashenko had won almost 80 percent of the vote. That triggered protests against the repressive regime, and a heavy police response.
lead_paragraph: [Read more on what’s happening in Belarus: protests, police and government.]

headline: Ohio Governor Says His Flawed Virus Test Shouldn’t Undercut New, Rapid Methods
abstract: Several states are trying to increase coronavirus testing with faster methods, undeterred by less accurate but quicker readouts.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio, who last week tested positive for the coronavirus, then negative and then negative again, said on CNN on Sunday that his roller-coaster ride should not be reason for people to think “that testing is not reliable or doesn’t work.”

headline: The N.B.A.’s ‘Yacht Club Six’ Seek Respect and a Lifeline
abstract: With the regular season winding down, more than hotel envy now afflicts the six lower-rung teams that are living in a lower-rung Disney World resort and trying to crash the N.B.A. playoffs.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Only one of the 22 teams invited to Walt Disney World for the N.B.A. restart arrived with a worse record than the Phoenix Suns. Then Phoenix won its first five seeding games here, including a buzzer-beating upset of the Los Angeles Clippers, and completely changed the tenor of interactions with the other teams at its hotel.

headline: The Opposite of Subtle
abstract: Relax, everyone! Lynn Lempel has helped us find something very important.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — A friend who is a physician once used this puzzle’s theme as a way to explain the distinction between mere forgetfulness and true cognitive decline to me. Well, he didn’t actually use the puzzle, obviously, but the subject of Lynn Lempel’s crossword was a helpful analogy.

headline: Beirut Blast Hit 3 Disparate Neighborhoods. Now They’re United in Rage.
abstract: The demands for a change in Lebanon’s leadership are growing louder.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For months, the restaurateurs poured their time and money into a gamble on a new joint called “The Barn.”

headline: In Women’s Golf, Virus Upends the Typical Paths to a Pro Career
abstract: The U.S. Women’s Amateur championship concluded on Sunday, but the search by nonprofessionals for competitive women’s golf events has been onerous since the college season was canceled last spring.
lead_paragraph: ROCKVILLE, Md. — The Jacksonville Amateur Championship in Florida is not a typical stop on the summer circuit for the reigning U.S. Women’s Amateur champion. But Gabriela Ruffels wanted competitive tournament rounds ahead of her title defense, so in July she joined two others as the first women to play in the men’s event.

headline: 8 Dead After Attack in a Wildlife Reserve in Niger
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Giraffes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government', 'Terrorism']
abstract: French humanitarian workers, their Nigerien driver and a guide were killed, according to the authorities. The group was visiting an area known for its West African giraffes.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Gunmen killed eight people on Sunday at a wildlife reserve in Niger, including six French humanitarian workers, their Nigerien driver and a guide, according to authorities.

headline: The Key to an Inclusive Recovery? Putting Women in Decision-Making Roles
abstract: As the world sketches out post-pandemic plans, Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, the head of U.N. Women, explains why having more women in leadership positions could lead to better results.
lead_paragraph: — Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, executive director of U.N. Women

headline: Yankees Cool Off in a Heated Series Against the Rays
abstract: An injury to Giancarlo Stanton and three narrow losses to a division rival over the weekend slowed some of the Yankees’ early momentum.
lead_paragraph: Just more than a quarter into this unusual 60-game season, this is where the Yankees stand: A 10-6 record, leading the American League East. They possess one of the most talented rosters and best records in Major League Baseball, and were leading the American League in runs and home runs as of Sunday afternoon.

headline: Trump’s Directives Were Supposed to Offer Relief. Most May Not.
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Student Loans', 'States (US)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Payroll Tax', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Evictions']
abstract: Because Congress controls federal spending, at least some of the measures will almost certainly be challenged in court. Or they may become moot if Congress reaches a deal.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, in announcing his executive measures on Saturday, said he was bypassing Congress to deliver emergency pandemic aid to needy Americans. But his directives are rife with so much complexity and legal murkiness that they’re unlikely, in most cases, to bring fast relief — if any.

headline: After Falwell Stumbles, His Hometown Sees a Leader in Need of Redemption
abstract: Jerry Falwell Jr. has courted controversy repeatedly, but a provocative Instagram post led to him stepping aside as Liberty University’s president.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Jerry Falwell Jr. is officially out at Liberty University.]

headline: In the Wake of Protests
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Some of what we saw was people cosplaying consciousness — symbolism that cost nothing and shifted no power.
lead_paragraph: We are in a period of post-mortem reflection following the time during which racial justice protests were at their most intense. We now must ask ourselves: What has changed and what hasn’t? Have power and privilege truly been disrupted? Has oppression been alleviated? What will be the legacy of this moment?

headline: Scenes From a Biker Rally, Undaunted by the Virus
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Camps and Camping', 'Festivals']
abstract: Meet the motorcyclists gathered in Sturgis, S.D., for a giant annual rally, with plenty of regard for one another but little for the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: STURGIS, S.D. — Despite the coronavirus pandemic, tens of thousands of motorcycle enthusiasts converged over the weekend outside the small South Dakota community of Sturgis for the 80th annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally.

headline: Salmonella Cases Linked to Onions Increase to Nearly 900
abstract: Grocery chains, including Publix and Giant Eagle, have recalled onions supplied by Thomson International and products that may contain the onions.
lead_paragraph: A salmonella outbreak linked to onions has expanded to 43 states and Canada, prompting a recall from a producer in California and various grocery chains, health officials said.

headline: How Pro-Trump Forces Work the Refs in Silicon Valley
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: The new referees in American politics are Facebook, Google and Twitter, and they would be wise to pay attention to lessons the old media tried to learn.
lead_paragraph: One of the oddest moments during last month’s tech hearings on Capitol Hill came when a Florida congressman darkly hinted that Google was making it difficult for him to find a website he was looking for, The Gateway Pundit.

headline: Collin Morikawa Delivers Magic at the P.G.A. Championship
abstract: In the first major tournament since the pandemic stalled the sports world, the title went to a magnetic 23-year-old who turned pro just last year.
lead_paragraph: In a sports year upended by the coronavirus pandemic, championship moments have been long awaited, and Collin Morikawa created an extraordinary one on Sunday at the 102nd P.G.A. Championship at T.P.C. Harding Park in San Francisco.

headline: Hong Kong Arrests Jimmy Lai, Media Mogul, Under National Security Law
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)']
abstract: The pro-democracy figure is the most high-profile person detained under the sweeping legislation imposed by Beijing. “It’s hard to believe this is Hong Kong,” said a journalist.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In a high-profile attack on free speech and dissent in Hong Kong, the police on Monday arrested Jimmy Lai, a prominent pro-democracy media tycoon, and raided the offices of his newspaper, demonstrating China’s resolve to silence the opposition and bring the city to heel.

headline: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 1 Finale Recap: The Defense Rests
abstract: On Della’s advice, Perry calls an unexpected witness to the stand. Will the gamble pay off?
lead_paragraph: It’s all connected. This is Perry Mason’s argument as he takes on his star witness (and a hostile one at that), Sgt. Ennis, in court. It beggars belief that an accountant like George Gannon could have executed his two accomplices (both of them professional hoods), driven across town with a bullet wound, then blown his own head off with a shotgun.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Capone’ and ‘The Titan Games’
abstract: A biopic about the aging crime boss starring Tom Hardy arrives on Amazon. And an athletic competition show on NBC closes out its second season.
lead_paragraph: CAPONE (2020) Stream on Amazon and Kanopy; rent on Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. The Al Capone of this film is not the iconic bootlegger and crime boss that audiences are likely familiar with. He’s just spent 11 years in federal prison for tax evasion, and neurosyphilis is claiming his mind. As portrayed by Tom Hardy, Capone is “a boogeyman bloated with body fluids,” according to Ben Kenigsberg’s review for The Times. During this twilight period, the retired gangster lives in Palm Island, Fla., in the care of his wife, Mae (Linda Cardellini), and a doctor played by Kyle MacLachlan. Still under surveillance by law enforcement and haunted by the crimes he committed as a younger man, Capone struggles to recall where he hid millions of dollars before he was imprisoned.

lead_paragraph: With New York City on the cusp of cutting $1 billion from the Police Department, a city councilwoman, Vanessa L. Gibson, told her colleagues that enough was enough.

headline: ‘I’d Rather Stay Home and Die’
abstract: A fear of hospitals is leading many Mexicans to delay treatment for coronavirus until it is too late for doctors to help them.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A gray Suzuki stopped outside the General Hospital of Mexico and deposited a heaving Victor Bailón at the entrance. He had refused to come to the hospital for days, convinced that doctors were killing coronavirus patients. By the time he hobbled into the triage area and collapsed on the floor, it was too late.

headline: Should a Study on Pesticides Affect Our Use of Them?
keywords: ['Pesticides', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Research', 'Heart', 'West Nile Virus', 'DDT (Dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane)', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Recent research, which found a link between pyrethroids and deaths from heart disease, highlights the limitations of epidemiological research.
lead_paragraph: With summer here and more people choosing to escape their coronavirus prisons into yards, parks, woods and streets, a recent study suggests yet another potential health risk, albeit one far less concerning than the virus: exposure to pyrethroids, a major group of insecticides widely used to protect against everything from malaria parasites and West Nile virus to bed bugs and ticks, as well as a host of agricultural and garden pests.

headline: When Things Aren’t OK With a Child’s Mental Health
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Everyone is stressed and anxious now. We have to find and help the children who are hurting most.
lead_paragraph: Last week, to write about the risks of summer — the recurring safety issues of children being out in the sun, or near the water, I talked to safety-minded pediatric emergency room doctors about what was worrying them, as they thought about the children they might be seeing during their shifts over the coming weeks, and I specified that I wasn’t asking about Covid-19 infection — I was asking about other dangers to children, in this summer shadowed by that virus.

headline: A Rare Economic Bright Spot in the U.S. Health System: The Vet’s Office
abstract: Usually during an economic downturn, people tend to spend less on health care for pets. This time, the opposite is happening.
lead_paragraph: The human health care system has struggled financially through the coronavirus pandemic, losing billions from the cancellations of lucrative elective operations as patients were first told to stay away from hospitals and then were leery of setting foot in one.

headline: I Have a Cure for the Dog Days of Summer
abstract: It’s hot, Donald Trump is still president, the pandemic is still raging, and did I mention that it’s hot?
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — August and February are the two months I like least. August because it’s hot and dry and the wildflowers are mostly spent. February because it’s cold and gray and by February I have lived too long without wildflowers. Thanks to climate change, February doesn’t get all that cold anymore, though it’s still gray. February will always be gray in Middle Tennessee.

headline: On the Shores of Cape Cod, Where the Oyster Is Their World
abstract: Pollution, development and overharvesting have greatly diminished America’s natural oyster habitat. Aquaculture and adaptable farmers have changed the game.
lead_paragraph: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Randy Harris shares a collection of images from the shores of Cape Cod.

headline: Trump’s directives were supposed to offer relief. Most may not.
abstract: President Trump, in announcing his executive measures on Saturday, said he was bypassing Congress to deliver emergency pandemic aid to needy Americans. But his directives are rife with so much complexity and legal murkiness that they’re unlikely, in most cases, to bring fast relief — if any.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, in announcing his executive measures on Saturday, said he was bypassing Congress to deliver emergency pandemic aid to needy Americans. But his directives are rife with so much complexity and legal murkiness that they’re unlikely, in most cases, to bring fast relief — if any.

headline: Saudi Aramco’s profit fell 73 percent as demand for oil shrank.
abstract: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, said on Sunday that its quarterly earnings plunged more than 73 percent compared to a year ago, as lockdowns imposed to curb the coronavirus pandemic drastically cut the demand for oil and slammed prices.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, said on Sunday that its quarterly earnings plunged more than 73 percent compared to a year ago, as lockdowns imposed to curb the coronavirus pandemic drastically cut the demand for oil and slammed prices.

headline: Start-ups braced for the worst, but the worst never came.
abstract: When the coronavirus pandemic first hit in March, many technology start-ups braced themselves for The End, as business dried up, venture capitalists warned of dark times ahead and restructuring experts predicted the beginning of a “great unwinding” after a decade-long boom.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus pandemic first hit in March, many technology start-ups braced themselves for The End, as business dried up, venture capitalists warned of dark times ahead and restructuring experts predicted the beginning of a “great unwinding” after a decade-long boom.

headline: A Designer Who Got Her Discipline From Dance
abstract: Marina Moscone makes elegant women’s wear that privileges handcraft and meticulous attention to detail.
lead_paragraph: When the New York-based women’s wear designer Marina Moscone was 3, she stole her father’s burgundy leather briefcase and used it to carry around the sketches she made wherever she went. Not long after, she announced to her parents that she was becoming a fashion designer. A few years later, at age 7, she decided that she would eventually move from her native Vancouver, British Columbia, to New York to study at the Parsons School of Design. She had learned about the school while watching reruns of the Canadian TV show “Fashion File.”

headline: The Rising Photographer Inspired by Her Home Country
abstract: The Jamaica-born, London-based Amber Pinkerton makes stylish pictures that lead with her subjects’ humanity.
lead_paragraph: Amber Pinkerton never intended for her work to be a commentary on racism, classism or colorism, but perhaps more than any other medium, photography has an uncanny ability to reflect our reality back to us in ways both beautiful and stark. Pinkerton grew up in a creative family in what she describes as a comfortable “bubble” within uptown Kingston, Jamaica. As a child, she would watch her mother making mosaics in the courtyard of their home, her aunts sewing clothes and her older brother sketching anime characters.

headline: T Process | Sophia Moreno-Bunge
abstract: The florist creates a wild, sculptural arrangement of plants including golden rain tree, oats, artichoke flowers and green persimmons.
lead_paragraph: The florist creates a wild, sculptural arrangement of plants including golden rain tree, oats, artichoke flowers and green persimmons.

headline: Daniela Soto-Innes Is One of the Most Exciting Chefs Working Today
abstract: At Cosme, Atla and now Elio, she has reimagined both Mexican cuisine and how professional kitchens are run.
lead_paragraph: “Can you hug?” This was one of the countless questions the chef Daniela Soto-Innes had to ask herself in May while turning Atla, her contemporary Mexican all-day cafe in New York’s NoHo neighborhood, into a takeout spot that could operate effectively while keeping its staff safe during the pandemic. She and her nine cooks were getting used to working with masks on, but were they allowed to act the way they normally did, she wondered, like some amalgamation of an athletic team and a family? And how could they translate a restaurant built to feel like a laid-back afternoon hangout into an experience people could take home in disposable containers?

headline: The British Designer Paying Tribute to the Immigrant Experience
abstract: Transforming discarded fabrics into forward-looking men’s wear, Priya Ahluwalia draws on her family’s Nigerian and Indian roots.
lead_paragraph: In 1990s South London, a young Priya Ahluwalia would watch as members of her extended family got ready for garage raves, styling themselves in matching two-piece sets, dresses with chain belts and patterned silk shirts. “All the guys wore earrings,” she recalls. “I used to wish I could go party with them, too.” Perhaps her longing helped crystallize these memories, because similar pieces, such as candy-hued sweater vests, vividly patchworked hoodies and jackets made from deconstructed Levi’s, have found their way into some of the 27-year-old British men’s wear designer’s recent collections. In fact, a thread of nostalgia runs through all of Ahluwalia’s designs: In addition to drawing from the aesthetics prominent during her own childhood, she pays homage to those of other cultural epochs, as well as to her family’s Nigerian, Indian and Jamaican heritage and the broader immigrant experience in the United Kingdom.

headline: The Artist Unraveling American History
abstract: Best known for her series of deconstructed flags, Sonya Clark offers poignant, clearsighted reminders of this country’s legacy of racial violence.
lead_paragraph: Sonya Clark’s work is unequivocally political: Her 2019 wall hanging “These days. This country. This history.” consists of the remains of an unraveled American flag onto which the unmistakable X of the Confederate battle flag, also in tatters, has been woven, the two flags hopelessly intertwined. She believes the election of Donald Trump added fuel to her fire, and indeed, these days, as we witness the continuing state-sanctioned murder of Black people, her work feels especially relevant. Yet the western Massachusetts-based Clark, 53, isn’t making work for the news cycle. While some political art can, like Trump himself, feel temporary, a product of and for its time, Clark’s goes to the root of longstanding injustices and hypocrisies woven, if not into the actual flag, then into the metaphorical fabric of American culture.

headline: In Niger, an Architect Looking to the Country’s Design Traditions
abstract: Eschewing a Western definition of modernity, Mariam Kamara instead conceives of buildings and spaces that account for how people really live.
lead_paragraph: At age 6, the architect Mariam Kamara moved with her family from Niamey, the capital of Niger, deep into the country’s vast Saharan interior, not far from the 15th-century city of Agadez, where the narrow streets of the historic center are lined with centuries-old houses built from rust-red adobe. During their five years in the desert, Kamara and her father, a mining engineer, traveled frequently into the nearby mountains, where they visited caves rich with neolithic paintings and polished stone, remnants of a time when the area was green and populated by nomads. “This open archaeological site really gave me a sense of what my region is about,” says Kamara, 41, who splits her time between Providence, R.I., where her husband is a professor of computer science at Brown University, and Niamey, where her firm, Atelier Masomi, has operated since 2014. “It’s not the story we’re fed about Africa being this place with no history.”

headline: The Artist and Filmmaker Envisioning a Safer World for Black Women
keywords: ['Art', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Interspersing found footage with original interviews, Ja’Tovia Gary makes poetic video works that elucidate the realities of racial injustice — and how the country might change.
lead_paragraph: Ti’jhae Beecher is 7 years old when she happens upon the artist and filmmaker Ja’Tovia Gary on the corner of West 116th Street and Malcolm X Boulevard in Harlem in 2019. Gary, flanked by a camera crew and with a microphone in hand, had stopped her to ask a simple question: “Do you feel safe?” Beecher, who is standing with her grandfather, answers yes and proceeds to tell Gary about how she feels prepared to leave the house every day, but that there are times when she is upset about having to wake up early for school. Gary agrees that waking up early is, in fact, the worst, and then asks Beecher if, for the most part, she feels good. Beecher replies plainly: “I don’t feel like I’m in danger.”

headline: The Designer Bringing Traditional Persian Fabrics to British Men’s Wear
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'London Fashion Week']
abstract: With her paisley prints and contemporary silhouettes, Paria Farzaneh shares her singular perspective with an ever-widening audience.
lead_paragraph: This past January, during men’s fashion week in London, the designer Paria Farzaneh invited guests to an East London boys’ school for an Iranian wedding. A bride sat onstage in a traditional white lace gown before a banquet of Persian pastries and urns overflowing with pastel-colored roses and baby’s breath. The groom, seated next to her, wore a paisley-printed ski jacket, its high, mouth-covering neck pre-empting the protective masks of the pandemic. An older community leader in a black suit presided over the faux ceremony in Farsi, as the viewers sat divided by gender — men on one side of the aisle, women on the other, though the men outnumbered the women and ended up infringing on their section. This was a deliberate move on Farzaneh’s part intended to highlight the power imbalance she feels in her industry — where a woman truly at the helm of her own brand is still something of a rarity — and was typical of the subtle gestures toward the tensions of our present moment that are embedded in her line. At the end of the ceremony, the groom rose and strode down the aisle, followed by a procession of young men dressed in looks from the fall 2020 collection of Farzaneh’s namesake line, which combined the swagger and oversize silhouettes of streetwear with the understated, earthy palette of hand-printed Iranian textiles.

headline: T Process | Aiko Hachisuka
abstract: The Los Angeles-based sculptor repurposes 40 to 50 pieces of clothing to create each one of her wall-mounted works.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles-based sculptor repurposes 40 to 50 pieces of clothing to create each one of her wall-mounted works.

headline: The Designer Who Gives Her Pieces Minds of Their Own
abstract: Elizabeth Garouste’s richly layered interiors and fantastical furniture are as appealing now as they were when she first caught Paris’s attention in the ’80s.
lead_paragraph: As a girl, the furniture designer and artist Elizabeth Garouste had a profound fear of the furnishings and objects in her home, in Paris’s Montparnasse neighborhood. “I always thought that things around the house would furtively move themselves, that they had their own souls,” she says in her native French. Garouste was born into a Jewish family in 1946, just after World War II ended, and had a grandmother who didn’t mince words when it came to describing the recent atrocities. “I transferred a kind of terror onto everything,” Garouste reflects, “and, really, I may have decided to make furniture as a means of taming those items that I grew up with.” Her primary aim for the pieces she now creates is to endow each with a buoyant personality.

headline: Juliana Huxtable’s Next Chapter
abstract: The artistic polymath has pushed the limits of genre, exploring ideas about gender and politics in nearly every form imaginable.
lead_paragraph: Juliana Huxtable is not one to sit idle. Since graduating from Bard College in 2010, she has leapt between various corners of the New York arts scene: as the host of Shock Value, a semiregular transgender-inclusive party; as a model; as a member of the arts collective House of Ladosha; and as a creator and performer who has both D.J.ed and shown work at major museums. Coming off her last art show — an array of off-kilter multimedia work titled “Interfertility Industrial Complex: Snatch the Calf Back” that opened at Reena Spaulings Fine Art in New York this past fall — her plan was to focus for a bit on her music, traveling the world for D.J. and music gigs she’d lined up in cities ranging from Amsterdam to Novi Sad, Serbia.

headline: The Jewelry Designer Inspired by Ancient Rituals and Artifacts
abstract: Drawing on years of research and working with one of Jaipur’s premier enamel artisans, Alice Cicolini makes pieces destined to become talismans.
lead_paragraph: It’s telling that it was an artifact, not a stone or a vintage bauble, that set the London-based designer Alice Cicolini on her path to making jewelry. Thirteen years ago, while working as the director of arts and culture at the British Council in India, Cicolini traveled to Mehrangarh, a resplendent 15th-century fort and series of palaces with an accompanying museum in Jodhpur. Among the collection of courtly textiles, armory and miniature paintings, a maharani jewelry box caught her eye. “It would have housed many of the things you need to perform solah shringar,” she explains, referring to the ancient Hindu practice of a bride on her wedding day wearing 16 traditional adornments, from bell-embellished anklets to glass and gold bangles. “The box itself was fairly ordinary looking, but the idea of what its contents constituted was magic to me.”

headline: T Process | Pierre Davis
abstract: The Los Angeles-based fashion designer hand-embroiders a T-shirt from No Sesso’s spring 2020 collection.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles-based fashion designer hand-embroiders a T-shirt from No Sesso’s spring 2020 collection.

headline: The Artist Making Bulbous, Colorful Sculptures Out of Thrifted Clothes
abstract: Each of Aiko Hachisuka’s intricate, hand-stitched pieces is a meditation on memory, materiality and domestic labor.
lead_paragraph: When, as a young girl in Nagoya, Japan, Aiko Hachisuka observed her mother and grandmother sewing, she didn’t quite know what they were doing — maybe mending a sock or attaching buttons, she thinks now — but she was keenly aware that they were not to be disturbed. “I was very attracted to that focus, and the creative headspace that they were in,” she says. It was the closest thing to a studio practice that she had been exposed to. “I knew I needed to have work myself,” she says. “My first attempt at that was to go and buy a sketchbook.”

headline: A Designer Making Clothes for Black Femmes — and for Everyone Else, Too
abstract: With help from those in her creative community, Pierre Davis has created a truly inclusive brand in No Sesso.
lead_paragraph: One February during New York Fashion Week, rays of sunlight poured through the windows of Chelsea’s Pier 59 Studios, setting off a glimmer of rhinestones across the butt of a belly-bearing gray velour tracksuit. As the model Maya Monés, her ’60s-inspired shoulder-length wig flipped upward at the ends, made the customary spin at the edge of the catwalk, she brushed her palms across two short words spelled out by the gems, the declaration of a singular presence: “No Sesso.”

headline: A Floral Designer Who Forages in the Hills of Malibu
abstract: Using unexpected materials to create lush arrangements, Sophia Moreno-Bunge brings the Californian wilderness indoors.
lead_paragraph: Sophia Moreno-Bunge sees possibilities for floral design everywhere: in mushrooms, seaweed, driftwood, bread, tomatoes on the vine. “It’s the weird, overlooked, maybe forgotten things,” she says of the materials that capture her imagination and coalesce in unexpected arrangements that might combine plumes of papyrus, say, with waxy chartreuse anthuriums and a branch of ripening green lemons. Indeed, Moreno-Bunge is part of a new wave of designers — among them the Berlin-based studio Mary Lennox and the New York-based Joshua Werber — for whom the term florist seems too narrow a definition; they’re artists who not only confirm the obvious appeal of blooms but also reveal the magnificence of their landscapes’ less flamboyant elements: leaves, vegetables, seedpods, weeds and humble grasses.

headline: The Acclaimed Soba Maker Who Champions Home Cooking
abstract: Working out of her California kitchen, Sonoko Sakai pays homage to Japanese culinary traditions through recipes, food activism and intimate classes.
lead_paragraph: Wandering among the artisanal shops of Kamakura, Japan, with her grandmother, a young Sonoko Sakai used to watch with fascination as tofu makers, tea roasters and rice millers crafted their products by hand. There was a fishmonger who delicately sliced and dried his fish on wire mesh screens, and a senbei (rice cracker) maker who sat on a tatami mat turning over each crisp, aromatic disc with chopsticks above a charcoal grill.

headline: Trump Goes Around Congress to Provide Pandemic Relief
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: It’s unclear whether the measures he signed will have any immediate effect, but the president pressed ahead anyway: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, a self-proclaimed master at making deals, again opted for executive action over negotiation with Congress. And, yes, we’re still waiting for Joe Biden to pick a running mate. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: 15 Creative Women for Our Time
abstract: Whether in the realm of art or design, food or fashion, these talents have stayed true to themselves and, in doing so, have pushed the boundaries of their respective fields.
lead_paragraph: Whether in the realm of art or design, food or fashion, these talents have stayed true to themselves and, in doing so, have pushed the boundaries of their respective fields.

headline: Jonathan Majors on ‘Lovecraft Country’: Horror as a Full Body Scream
abstract: The actor talked about starring in the new HBO series, which blends the supernatural with a critique of American racial injustice, and about how acting saved his future.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Majors knows what makes him an exceptional actor. “I’m willing to hurt more,” he said. “I’m just willing to hurt. It doesn’t bother me.”

headline: Big Finance, Big Tech and Joe Biden
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Although they haven’t necessarily fallen in love with the Democratic presidential candidate, many on Wall Street and in Silicon Valley are falling in line.

headline: Belarus’s Leader Vows to Crush Protests After Claiming Landslide Election Win
keywords: ['Elections', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)']
abstract: Violent clashes between the police and protesters erupted across Belarus on Monday after President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko declared victory in a vote widely dismissed as fraudulent.
lead_paragraph: MINSK — A day after the leader of Belarus, often called “Europe’s last dictator,” claimed a landslide re-election victory, his capital slipped into mayhem late on Monday as protesters barricaded streets and riot police officers beat back crowds of demonstrators with violent baton charges, stun grenades, tear gas and rubber bullets.

headline: Trump Floats Gettysburg as Site for Nomination Speech
abstract: President Trump was momentarily evacuated from the White House briefing room during a news conference. The Obamas, the Clintons, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and a former Republican governor will speak during the Democratic convention.
lead_paragraph: [Follow the DNC Live: Biden’s speech, schedule, start time, streaming and more.]

headline: An Interview With the Health Officer for Santa Cruz
abstract: Dr. Gail Newel has taken the heat as Santa Cruz went from being one of the safest coastal counties in the state to the site of a recent surge.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Chicago Police Arrest More Than 100 People After Looting Batters Downtown
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Looting (Crime)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Vandalism']
abstract: The city briefly raised most of the bridges to the main shopping and business district. Mayor Lori Lightfoot condemned the crowd’s actions as “abject criminal behavior.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — All summer, demonstrators have marched through Chicago to protest police misconduct. In many neighborhoods, gun violence has been unrelenting, soaring to levels not seen in decades. The coronavirus pandemic is resurging, now sickening hundreds of people each day.

headline: Here’s the business news to watch this week.
abstract: 🗣 It’s a relatively light week for earnings, with a majority of the S&P 500 having already reported their latest quarterly results. Notable releases include Simon Property Group on Monday; InterContinental Hotels and SoftBank on Tuesday; Cisco, Lyft and Tencent on Wednesday; and Applied Materials and Deutsche Telekom on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: 🗣 It’s a relatively light week for earnings, with a majority of the S&P 500 having already reported their latest quarterly results. Notable releases include Simon Property Group on Monday; InterContinental Hotels and SoftBank on Tuesday; Cisco, Lyft and Tencent on Wednesday; and Applied Materials and Deutsche Telekom on Thursday.

headline: AIDS Quilts for an Artist and His Partner, Sewn During a New Pandemic
abstract: Tom Rauffenbart had resolved to create a tribute to his partner, the artist David Wojnarowicz. A sewing circle of women took up the cause for both men, stitching through lockdown.
lead_paragraph: Since the fall of 2019, six women, some from the art world, others retired social workers, had labored on two AIDS quilts devoted to the memories of the artist David Wojnarowicz and his partner, Tom Rauffenbart. The women converged from all over New York City on the neighborhood of Washington Heights, at the home of Anita Vitale, who had met Mr. Rauffenbart, a fellow social worker, in the 1980s.

headline: What You Get for $630,000 in California
abstract: A two-bedroom cottage in Oakland, a 1940 house in Sacramento and a two-bedroom condominium in Culver City.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom cottage in Oakland, a 1940 house in Sacramento and a two-bedroom condominium in Culver City.

headline: $630,000 Homes in California
abstract: A two-bedroom cottage in Oakland, a 1940 house in Sacramento and a two-bedroom condominium in Culver City.
lead_paragraph: This house, at the end of a quiet cul-de-sac in the Fruitvale neighborhood, is within walking distance of a pocket park and an athletic field, as well as a public elementary school. Less than a mile away is Peralta Hacienda Historical Park, a complex that includes the footprints of two adobe homes built in the early 19th century and an 1870 farmhouse where there are exhibits on local history and culture. The nearest BART station is about a 10-minute drive, and downtown Oakland is about 15 minutes away by car.

headline: Citrus Flavoring Is Weaponized Against Insect-Borne Diseases
abstract: The E.P.A. has approved nootkatone, which is found in cedars and grapefruit. It repels ticks, mosquitoes and other dangerous bugs for hours, but is safe enough to eat.
lead_paragraph: Adding a new weapon to the fight against insect-borne illnesses like Lyme disease and malaria, the Environmental Protection Agency on Monday approved a new chemical that both repels and kills ticks and mosquitoes.

headline: McDonald’s Sues Former C.E.O., Accusing Him of Lying and Fraud
keywords: ['Fast Food Industry', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Executive Compensation', '#MeToo Movement', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The fast-food chain said Steve Easterbrook, who was fired last fall, concealed evidence during an investigation into his conduct.
lead_paragraph: Eight months had passed since McDonald’s fired its chief executive, Steve Easterbrook, for sexting with a subordinate. Mr. Easterbrook had apologized and walked away with tens of millions in compensation, and the fast-food chain had moved on under a new chief executive.

headline: Catholic Churches Drop Hymns After Accusations Against Composer
abstract: David Haas, a composer known for “Blest Are They,” “We Are Called,” “You Are Mine” and other favorites, has been accused of sexual abuse and harassment by multiple women, an advocacy group says.
lead_paragraph: Several Roman Catholic archdioceses have banned a well-known liturgical composer from performing in their churches and many others have stopped playing his music after dozens of women accused him of sexual misconduct and harassment over more than 40 years.

headline: Washington N.F.L. Team Owner Files Claims Hinting at a Conspiracy
abstract: Daniel Snyder is seeking documents from a former employee to bolster his case asserting a campaign to damage him is being waged as shareholders seek to sell their stake in the team.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Snyder, the owner of the Washington Football Team, has accused a disgruntled former team employee of taking money and assisting in a campaign to spread damaging information against him, his latest effort to fight back attacks on his ownership of the N.F.L. club.

headline: How Are You Doing?
abstract: Sometimes it feels like the only pleasure available in the day is cooking.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. How are you doing? It’s been five months now, for some of us, living and working at home, or living at home and doing essential work out in the world, or living at home and not working anywhere. We’re stuck with the kids, the parents, the pod or ourselves alone, together apart, apart together. Grocery runs, a wait at the post office, protests, gas for the truck. Sometimes it feels as if the only pleasure available in the day comes when we can step away, finally, to cook, to make something delicious, something to take our minds off the state of the world.

headline: In Push to Play, College Football Stars Show Sudden Unity
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Organized Labor', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Social Media']
abstract: The blending of athletes’ #WeAreUnited and #WeWantToPlay campaigns showed students asserting themselves in ways that have been uncommon (and often stifled) in college sports.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago this month, a push to unionize college football players ended in defeat.

headline: Delta Air Lines Bought an Oil Refinery. It Didn’t Go as Planned.
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Refineries', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Delta’s foray into oil refining illustrates some of the reasons the business was in trouble even before the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Jet fuel is known as the Steady Eddie of the refinery business, a predictable profit maker that balances the seasonal gyrations of gasoline and diesel sales. But for airlines, it is a headache — a big and unpredictable expense that confounds managers.

headline: The Welcome Return of the Chicks
abstract: How would Nashville be different if it hadn’t pushed the trio away? A conversation about “Gaslighter” and beyond.
lead_paragraph: After the killing of George Floyd and the protests for racial justice that followed, the Dixie Chicks finally unloaded their old name because of its unwelcome associations with the Old South. After rebranding as the Chicks, the group released “Gaslighter,” its first new album in 14 years.

headline: 2 Dead and at Least 7 Injured in Baltimore Gas Explosion
abstract: Three brick rowhouses were destroyed in the blast, and firefighters searched by hand for more people who might be trapped in the pile of wreckage.
lead_paragraph: A gas explosion leveled three rowhouses in a northwest Baltimore neighborhood on Monday morning, leaving at least two people dead and at least seven others injured, the authorities said.

headline: Going to the Dentist During a Pandemic
keywords: ['Teeth and Dentistry', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']

headline: Taking Protest to the Streets, and the Mayor’s Front Door
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Privacy', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Vandalism']
abstract: City leaders and public health officials are now seeing protests outside their own homes, with some protesters wielding bullhorns, spray paint, and even eggs and paintballs.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The city was exploring a proposal to cut 50 percent of the police department’s budget to promote racial justice and alternatives to policing last month, but Debora Juarez, the first enrolled Native American on the Seattle City Council, was not yet willing to throw her support behind such a steep cut without a plan for how to carry it out.

headline: After a Flop, Amazon Makes Another Foray Into Video Games
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Amazon said it was rebranding Twitch Prime, in another attempt to crack the video game market after a big-budget game effort failed.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Amazon stumbled as it worked to break into the lucrative video game industry. Now it’s trying again.

headline: Lebanon’s Government Resigns Amid Widespread Anger Over Blast
abstract: The cabinet stepped down as fury over a giant explosion last week in Beirut spurred new protests.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon’s cabinet resigned on Monday, opening up new political uncertainty as the country struggles with a crippling economic crisis and reels from an enormous explosion last week that ravaged swaths of the capital.

headline: Trump Moves to Force Manhattan D.A. to Reveal Details of Inquiry
keywords: ['Trump Tax Returns', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Lawyers for the president said a subpoena seeking eight years of tax returns amounted to illegal “harassment.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump, seeking to block a subpoena for his tax returns, plans to ask a federal judge to order the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., to disclose details about his investigation into the president’s business practices, according to a letter filed on Monday.

headline: Who the Heck Is That?
abstract: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
lead_paragraph: The Danish-American journalist, photographer and author Jacob RIIS (1849-1914) has been in the New York Times Crossword 180 times, most recently in Jacob Stulberg’s puzzle on Tuesday, Aug. 4.

headline: When Bugs Crawl Up the Food Chain
abstract: We usually think of insects as meals for vertebrates such as frogs. But arthropods may turn the tables more often than you think.
lead_paragraph: Epomis beetle larvae look delicious to frogs. They’re snack-size, like little protein packs. If a frog is nearby, a larva will even wiggle its antennae and mandibles alluringly.

headline: Governors Say Trump’s Order on Pandemic Relief Could Wreck State Budgets
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Taxation', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'States (US)', 'Governors (US)', 'Local Government']
abstract: With Congress at an impasse on stimulus talks, disarray over resuming negotiations bodes poorly for reaching a deal this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Governors across the United States struggled on Monday with how to make good on President Trump’s order that their economically battered states deliver billions more in unemployment benefits to jobless residents.

headline: Quarantine Envy Got You Down? You’re Not Alone
abstract: A beach house, a suburban home, a home without children, a home filled with family: These days, everyone wants something that someone else has.
lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus hit France, Leila Slimani, a popular French-Moroccan novelist, and her family left Paris for their country home. Once there, Ms. Slimani began writing a quarantine diary for the newspaper Le Monde. The response, especially from people in teeny Parisian apartments, was so scathing, she apparently abandoned the series. When the billionaire David Geffen posted photos of his mega-yacht on Instagram while he quarantined in the Grenadines, the backlash led him to turn his account private.

headline: Review: Packing 14 Up-to-the-Minute Monologues in ‘One Room’
abstract: A collection of short solo works from the Weston Playhouse furthers the redefinition of theater online — and of life in isolation.
lead_paragraph: Five months into internet exile, playgoers have a lot of questions. Two of the biggest for me are: Is what we’re seeing online really theater? And why so many monologues?

headline: ‘Stanley Kubrick,’ a Brisk New Biography of a Major Talent
abstract: David Mikics’s entry in the Jewish Lives series captures the greatness of the director of “2001,” “The Shining” and other classics.
lead_paragraph: Pauline Kael was no fan of Stanley Kubrick’s movies. She deplored his “arctic spirit.” She compared “A Clockwork Orange” to the work of a Teutonic professor. In her review of “2001: A Space Odyssey,” she wrote: “It’s a bad, bad sign when a movie director begins to think of himself as a mythmaker.”

headline: Fed’s Main Street program funneled its first loans to casinos, roofers and dentists.
abstract: The Federal Reserve released detailed data on Monday on its first-ever attempt to get loans to midsize businesses, and the figures show that the program is reaching a diverse — if tiny — set of borrowers.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve released detailed data on Monday on its first-ever attempt to get loans to midsize businesses, and the figures show that the program is reaching a diverse — if tiny — set of borrowers.

headline: Hong Kong Arrests Jimmy Lai and Raids Headquarters

lead_paragraph: The police in Hong Kong arrested the pro-democracy media mogul Jimmy Lai, becoming the most high-profile person detained under China’s sweeping legislation.

headline: The Global Internet Is a Mirage
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The TikTok deal risks fracturing the internet. But let’s be honest, it’s always been fractured.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: The Champions League Returns With a Plan for Everything
abstract: The plans for European soccer’s showpiece competition seem to account for every possibility. But even before the teams arrive, the coronavirus is asking hard questions.
lead_paragraph: Those final few minutes, just before kickoff, have been mapped out with almost military precision. At exactly 8:50 p.m. local time, a disinfected Champions League match ball will be placed on a ceremonial plinth. At 8:53 p.m., the players will leave their locker rooms. The teams will enter the field, separately, no more than two and a half minutes later.

headline: What Your Recipe Box Says About You
abstract: Quarantine has given a former New York Times columnist the time to come to grips with a lifetime’s worth of clipped and faded recipes.
lead_paragraph: This is it. The perfect time. What better distraction as I continue to dodge a deadly virus, mourn those who could not, worry about my country’s soul and find comic relief in links that I obsessively impose on friends and family?

headline: Botched Primary Election Creates New Crisis in Puerto Rico: ‘This Is a Travesty’
abstract: Puerto Ricans lost confidence in their electoral system after ballots failed to reach polling places, forcing officials to partially suspend a primary.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rican politics became engulfed on Monday in the confusing aftermath of a chaotic primary election that was partially suspended over the weekend when paper ballots failed to reach voting precincts, making it impossible for many people to vote.

headline: Niven Patel, a Miami Chef, Is Not Giving Up on 2020
abstract: A return to indoor dining may be far off, but he just opened a new, Caribbean-inspired restaurant and is moving ahead with plans for others.
lead_paragraph: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — The last week in July was an especially stressful one for Niven Patel, and for Floridians in general.

headline: Holly Humberstone Wants Her Songs to Last a Lifetime
abstract: The young British singer, who writes conversationally intimate pop music, is about to release her debut EP.
lead_paragraph: When the singer and songwriter Holly Humberstone began working with the writer and producer Rob Milton on her debut EP, they quickly arrived at a shorthand for the kinds of lyrics they were aiming for.

headline: Taylor Swift, No. 1 Again, Is Last to Benefit From an Obscure Chart Rule
abstract: When a physical album is sold, it often comes with a digital copy. Which one counts in Billboard’s totals is changing.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift, who holds the No. 1 album for a second time with “Folklore,” may be one of the last stars to benefit from Billboard’s so-called bundling rule, which lets artists sell albums with merchandise or concert tickets. Long criticized for distorting the charts, that guideline is set to be curtailed in October.

headline: An Exhibition Tells the Story of a Drug War Leader, but Not All of It
abstract: The Drug Enforcement Administration’s exhibition on Harry J. Anslinger, a founding father of American drug policy, does not delve into criticism that he used racial slurs.
lead_paragraph: Harry J. Anslinger’s pioneering work as head of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics has largely been unsung, though experts see him as the founding father of America’s war on drugs.

headline: Collin Morikawa’s Joyful Win Broke Through Golf’s Pandemic Fog
abstract: Morikawa, 23, delivered a dazzling final round at the P.G.A. Championship to become the long-overdue first major champion of the 2020 season.
lead_paragraph: As Collin Morikawa hoisted the huge Wanamaker Trophy above his head on Sunday evening, giving it a quick, jubilant shake, the lid went clattering off. Again, he was providing exactly what golf needed in a season dimmed by plague.

headline: Fay Chew Matsuda, Steward of Chinese Immigrant Legacy, Dies at 71
abstract: A social worker turned preservationist, she directed the Museum of Chinese in America. “Sometimes it was literally dumpster-diving,” she said of rescuing artifacts.
lead_paragraph: Fay Chew Matsuda, a first-generation Chinese-American who devoted her career as an amateur museum curator to preserving the heritage of overlooked generations of immigrants from China, died on July 24 at her home in Sound Beach, N.Y., on Long Island’s North Shore. She was 71.

headline: 100 Years Ago, ‘Crazy Blues’ Sparked a Revolution for Black Women Fans
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Blues Music', 'Women and Girls', 'Nineteen Hundred Twenties']
abstract: Mamie Smith’s song wasn’t just an artistic breakthrough. It proved Black women and girls bought records, paving the way for today’s fan armies.
lead_paragraph: “Music was my refuge.”

headline: Pints or Primers? U.K.’s Push to Open Schools May Force a Choice
abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson calls it a “moral duty” to open Britain’s schools, but with cases already rising slightly, that might mean closing pubs and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain, having moved aggressively to reopen its economy after three months of coronavirus lockdown, now faces what some experts cast as a binary trade-off for a land that loves a good book as much as a cold pint: schools or pubs?

headline: Identical Twins With Two Very Different Destinies
keywords: ['Twins', 'Families and Family Life', 'Multiple Births', 'Heart', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Parenting']
abstract: A father looks to science and faith to understand his son's congenital heart defect.
lead_paragraph: After we had our twin sons, we took pictures of them together and separately. The pictures taken separately always kept up a certain symmetry: If we snapped one twin propped on a couch, or in the bouncer, or resting his chin on his grandmother’s shoulder, we made sure to get the other twin in the same pose.

headline: ‘A Thousand Cuts’ Review: A Free Press Endures Lacerations
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Censorship']
abstract: This documentary profiles Maria Ressa, a journalist who has fearlessly chronicled abuses in the Philippines under the Duterte government.
lead_paragraph: The death by a thousand cuts that gives this documentary from Ramona S. Diaz its title is the death of democracy — a slow wounding that eventually makes the democracy too weak to survive. And while that assessment, offered by the journalist Maria Ressa, refers to the Philippines under Rodrigo Duterte, the absorbing and multipronged “A Thousand Cuts” presents the country as a test lab for autocracy — and suggests that its experiments have a high potential to travel.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Lebanon’s government, Jimmy Lai, Causeway Bay Books: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Hassan Diab and his cabinet resigned on Monday, opening up a political void as the country reels from an enormous explosion last week in Beirut.

headline: E.P.A. to Lift Obama-Era Controls on Methane, a Potent Greenhouse Gas
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Methane', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The reversal is the latest move in the Trump administration’s ongoing effort to weaken environmental rules, but it could be quickly undone after the November election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is expected in the coming days to lift Obama-era controls on the release of methane, a powerful climate-warming gas that is emitted from leaks and flares in oil and gas wells.

headline: Michigan Democrats Hesitate on Whitmer as V.P.: ‘Selfishly, We Need Her Here’
abstract: She is suddenly on Joe Biden’s shortlist. Can Michigan afford to lose her?
lead_paragraph: WEST BLOOMFIELD, Mich. — With Joseph R. Biden Jr. expected to announce his choice of running mate in the coming days, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan has suddenly joined the pack of leading contenders in the home stretch — a turn that has some Democrats in the state excited, but has left others concerned about how they, and Michigan, might fare without her.

headline: ‘Made in Italy’ Review: Father and Son Reunion
abstract: The sale of a Tuscan villa forces a grieving widower and his troubled son to reconnect in this trite comic drama.
lead_paragraph: The title promises “Made in Italy,” but I wouldn’t get too excited. Oh, there’s pretty scenery (including the requisite cypress trees), and a villa to yearn for, even in its dusty, dilapidated state. But for a movie that’s supposedly meant to lift us off our couches and set us down in a verdant dreamscape, this limp foreign-soil fantasy from James D’Arcy doesn’t come close to getting the job done.

headline: Lebanon’s Prime Minister Resigns Amid Anger Over Explosion
abstract: Prime Minister Hassan Diab of Lebanon announced that he and his cabinet ministers would resign amid widespread anger over the explosion last week that killed more than 150 people.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Hassan Diab of Lebanon announced that he and his cabinet ministers would resign amid widespread anger over the explosion last week that killed more than 150 people.

headline: Algerian Journalist Sentenced to 3 Years for Reporting on Protests
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The journalist Khaled Drareni was convicted after reporting on the Hirak protest movement, which forced the removal of the country’s longtime ruler, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, last year.
lead_paragraph: A prominent Algerian journalist was sentenced to three years in prison Monday for reporting on anti-government demonstrations, a lawyer and a human rights official said. It’s the latest sign of a hardening crackdown on the press in Algeria, one that has drawn condemnation from international observers.

headline: England’s Flawed Virus Contact Tracing Will Be Revamped
abstract: After months of complaints about its centralized, privatized system, Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s government says resources will be diverted to local public health authorities.
lead_paragraph: England will overhaul its faltering coronavirus contact-tracing system, the government said on Monday, shifting some control from private contractors to local public health teams and cutting the jobs of thousands of call center workers who had complained of having no one to call.

headline: A Push to Return U.K.’s ‘Motor City’ to Its Cycling Roots
abstract: Coventry can be forbidding for cyclists. But before it became Britain’s Detroit, the city was famed for making bicycles.
lead_paragraph: COVENTRY, England — Through leafy suburban streets, then up and over a narrow bridge, the path for cyclists heading north into Coventry seems smooth and easy until it ends abruptly — at a busy four-lane “ring road” with no on ramp.

keywords: ['Taxation', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Payroll Tax', 'Medicare', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Social Security (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Now he’s prescribing hydroxychloroquine to fight recession.
lead_paragraph: As the U.S. economy careens toward disaster, congressional talks about what to do appear to have ground to a halt. So on Saturday President Trump — speaking at one of his golf courses, of course — announced four executive measures that, he claimed, would rescue the recovery.

headline: Stephen Curry Has ‘Major FOMO’ in Life Outside the N.B.A. Bubble
abstract: Curry led the Golden State Warriors to the N.B.A. finals for five consecutive years, but now he’s not even going to the playoffs. “You miss it badly,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

lead_paragraph: A day after finally providing some run support for their ace, Jacob deGrom, and winning a weekend series against the Miami Marlins, the Mets appeared to be enjoying an upswing after an underwhelming start to their season.

headline: Rangers Score First Pick in the N.H.L. Draft
abstract: After getting swept out of the postseason qualifying tournament, the Rangers won the No. 1 overall pick in the 2020 draft. The team has had six first-round picks in the past three years.
lead_paragraph: A month and a half after the initial phase of the N.H.L. draft lottery was held, the Rangers won No. 1 selection and the opportunity to select the consensus top prospect Alexis Lafreniere, a dazzling 18-year-old wing from Quebec.

headline: To Withhold or Not: Trump’s Order Gives Employers a New Dilemma
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Payroll Tax', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Businesses are grappling with difficult legal and logistical questions about how to respond to the president’s payroll-tax holiday order.
lead_paragraph: The White House has pitched its payroll tax holiday as a boon to American workers that would fatten their paychecks and provide a jolt to the economy. But for companies large and small, the presidential intervention poses difficult legal and logistical questions that only add to the uncertainty that executives and workers are contending with during the pandemic.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was abruptly pulled out of the White House Briefing Room in midsentence during a televised news conference on Monday after a shooting near the Executive Mansion.

headline: Roadtripping Before the D.N.C.
abstract: Times reporters discuss the realities of election coverage amid a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Jennifer Medina, your host, filling in for Lisa Lerer.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: The road to reopening schools in the U.S. keeps getting rockier.
lead_paragraph: The road to reopening for U.S. schools keeps getting rockier, with new research reflecting just how vulnerable children can be to the coronavirus. At the same time, some American parents, fearful of the potential consequences of remote learning, have filed lawsuits to demand in-person classes.

keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: For residents of Connecticut and New York who are still without power, frustration with utility companies grew as temperatures rose.
lead_paragraph: After Darren Demeterio was diagnosed with Stage 4 colon cancer last year, a scan in June detected a new cancerous spot on his liver. His doctor told him to to eat healthily and stay positive.

headline: Boris Johnson Says U.K. Has a ‘Moral Duty’ to Reopen Schools
abstract: On Monday, Prime Minister Boris Johnson doubled down on his stance to fully reopen schools next month in the United Kingdom and said it was a “moral duty.”
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Prime Minister Boris Johnson doubled down on his stance to fully reopen schools next month in the United Kingdom and said it was a “moral duty.”

headline: Wayne Fontana, Hitmaker With ‘The Game of Love,’ Dies at 74
abstract: The song brought him and his British Invasion band, the Mindbenders, a bit of success in the mid-1960s. Then he went solo, and the hits did not keep coming.
lead_paragraph: Wayne Fontana, a British Invasion-era singer best known for his 1965 hit song “The Game of Love,” died on Thursday at a hospital in Stockport, England. He was 74.
