headline: These Shows Are Made for Walking
abstract: The pandemic has darkened theaters around the country. So this summer, some are staging scenes in parks and fields for small groups of masked patrons.
lead_paragraph: ASHFIELD, Mass. — In trees. On stilts. Atop a roof. Aboard a boat.

headline: Bankrupt Brooks Brothers Finds a Buyer
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Bankruptcies', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The retailer is seeking court approval of a $325 million sale to a group backed by the mall owner Simon Property Group and Authentic Brands Group, a licensing firm.
lead_paragraph: Brooks Brothers, the venerable retailer that was founded in 1818 and filed for bankruptcy last month, said it would be sold to Simon Property Group, the biggest mall operator in the United States, and Authentic Brands Group, a licensing firm.

headline: Top General in Middle East Says U.S. Troop Levels Will Drop in Iraq and Syria
abstract: The commander, Gen. Kenneth F. McKenzie Jr., said U.S. forces would continue to combat pockets of Islamic State fighters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top American military commander in the Middle East said on Wednesday that U.S. troop levels in Iraq and Syria would most likely shrink in the coming months, but that he had not yet received orders to begin withdrawing forces.

headline: Britain’s New Record: A Recession Worse Than in Europe and North America
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Quarantines', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Recession and Depression', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: Seventeen years of economic growth have been wiped out in Britain’s late and long lockdown.
lead_paragraph: Britain discovered on Wednesday that its economy had suffered a recession deeper than any other reported by a European or North American country during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: What Happens When the Season Changes?
abstract: Taking refuge outdoors is still an option.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. It’s refreshing and awful at once, to read the questions and concerns of our audience here At Home, to discover how resilient and kind and optimistic we are, even as a sense of foreboding envelops some, bringing a kind of lethargic anxiety, an abiding loneliness, a worry about what happens when the season changes, when the air turns cold.

headline: With the Biden-Harris Ticket, Environmental Justice Is a Focus
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Green New Deal', 'Income Inequality', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: Climate change leaders said the choice of Harris signaled that Democrats will try to ensure that communities burdened by pollution would benefit from a transition to clean energy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just six days before Joseph R. Biden Jr. tapped Kamala Harris to be his running mate in the presidential election, the California senator released sweeping environmental justice legislation. The timing, climate activists said, was important if not prescient.

headline: 60 Talented Educators Join The New York Times Teaching Project
abstract: Representing 29 states and subject areas across the curriculum, these teachers will bring the mission of The Times to their schools for the 2020-21 school year.
lead_paragraph: In July, we officially welcomed a distinguished group of 60 educators to The New York Times Teaching Project. Chosen from hundreds of applicants and representing 29 states, these teachers are passionate about bringing the mission of The Times — helping people understand the world through on-the-ground, expert and deeply reported independent journalism — to their school communities.

headline: Google, Facebook and Others Broaden Group to Secure U.S. Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Political Advertising', 'QAnon']
abstract: More tech companies met with government agencies on Wednesday to fight disinformation on social media.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, Google and other major tech companies said on Wednesday that they had added new partners and met with government agencies in their efforts to secure the November election.

headline: It Was Business, It Was Personal: The Redstones’ Father-Daughter Feud
abstract: A period of estrangement between Shari Redstone and her combative father, Sumner Redstone, ended with a reconciliation before his death and the daughter taking over the family empire.
lead_paragraph: In more than 50 years as a force in the media industry, Sumner M. Redstone clashed with his only son, his nephew, his wife, his romantic partners, his business rivals and the actor Tom Cruise.

headline: James Harris, Towering Wrestler Known as Kamala, Dies at 70
abstract: He became a top draw portraying a stereotypical menacing African warrior who was always supposed to lose to his white opponents. He died of Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 11, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 11, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about the re-election challenge faced by President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus misspelled the surname of one of his supporters. She is Lyudmila S. Krokhaleva, not Khrokhaleva.

headline: Postponed College Football Games Could Disrupt $1 Billion in TV Ads
abstract: Fox and Disney, which owns ESPN and ABC, prepare to take another hit from a pandemic that has already affected them with shutdowns and delays.
lead_paragraph: The postponement of much of the college football season could disrupt the flow of more than $1 billion from advertisers to the television networks that count on a slate of game broadcasts every fall.

headline: Two Indianapolis Police Officers Charged With Assaulting Protesters
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Assaults']
abstract: The two were indicted after videos taken by TV crews showed officers repeatedly striking one woman with batons and shoving another to the ground, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Two Indianapolis police officers have been charged with assaulting two women at a protest, the authorities said Wednesday, the latest officers to face criminal charges that they used excessive force against protesters demanding an end to police violence.

headline: Mexico’s Former President Accused in Bribery Scandal
abstract: Corruption allegations against past presidents have never led to prosecution. Will the latest claims about Enrique Peña Nieto lead to the first?
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — For Mexicans, the news is disturbing — and disturbingly familiar. A key witness in a major corruption case has accused former President Enrique Peña Nieto of directing bribes to fund his presidential campaign.

headline: Biden-Harris, Masks, Moths: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Progressives Didn’t Want Harris for V.P. They’re Backing Her Anyway.
abstract: Joe Biden’s selection of Kamala Harris reaffirmed progressives’ fears of a Biden administration rooted in establishment politics. But rather than revolt, many snuffed out their criticisms.
lead_paragraph: From the moment Bernie Sanders exited the presidential race in early April, many activists, organizers, progressive groups and elected officials had held out hope that Joseph R. Biden Jr. would elevate one of their ideological allies to the vice presidency — someone like Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts or Representative Karen Bass of California. Kamala Harris, an establishment-friendly senator from California and more of a moderate, was near the bottom of their list.

headline: A Florida Sheriff Has Ordered His Deputies Not to Wear Masks
abstract: The sheriff forbade his deputies from wearing masks while on duty, with some exceptions, and also barred visitors to his offices from wearing them.
lead_paragraph: When the sheriff in Marion County, Fla, wrote an email to his deputies this week about a new mask order, he expected there would be complaints. “I can already hear the whining,” Sheriff Billy Woods wrote, noting that he did not make the decision “easily.”

headline: Air Force Helicopter Hit by Gunfire Was Forced to Make Emergency Landing, F.B.I. Says
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Helicopters', 'Transportation']
abstract: One crew member was treated at a hospital for injuries that were not life-threatening, according to the authorities, who said they were investigating the shooting.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. and the U.S. military said Wednesday they were investigating the shooting of an Air Force helicopter this week during a routine training exercise over Northern Virginia that injured one airman and forced the crew to make an emergency landing.

headline: Why One Activist Injured in Charlottesville Won’t Give Up
abstract: For Constance Paige Young, who was among the counterprotesters injured in Charlottesville, it is a moral obligation to continue showing up.
lead_paragraph: As Americans continue to protest systemic racism, showing up at rallies and demonstrations day after day in many cities across the country, the motivation for sustained activism is both personal and informed by one’s community. How do people keep going? What galvanizes them? For Constance Paige Young, who was among the counterprotesters injured in Charlottesville, Va., three years ago, after a white man drove his car into the crowd, killing one woman, it is a moral obligation to continue showing up.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: One Georgia district might foretell the chaos of the coming semester.
lead_paragraph: The first U.S. schools to resume in-person teaching have shown the perils of reopening with the virus still out of control, painting a picture of chaos and deeply divided communities. In one district in Georgia, nearly 1,200 students and staff members have already been ordered to quarantine.

headline: P.S.G. Breaks Its Glass Ceiling. Now Comes the Hardest Part.
abstract: Two late goals lifted the French champions past Atalanta and into the Champions League semifinals. Can their talent finally finish the job?
lead_paragraph: In that second half, the cavalry kept coming, wandering off the bench and onto the field one after the other. As Atalanta’s players blinked back the sweat, it must have felt as if Paris St.-Germain could draw from a bottomless well of talent.

headline: ‘Fat Talks,’ an Investigation, and a Reckoning: How Collegiate Runners Forced Reform
abstract: Athletes detailed “fat talks” and eating disorders they said a prominent coach at Wesleyan had fostered. When the same coach was assigned to lead changes in the environment he created, the students protested once again.
lead_paragraph: In early March, 36 Wesleyan University track and cross-country alumni signed a letter describing a culture of rampant body shaming and eating disorders within the program that they said a prominent coach had fostered.

headline: Could the Beirut Explosion Be a Turning Point for Lebanon?
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Beirut, Lebanon, Explosions (2020)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Chronic corruption must be rooted out.
lead_paragraph: The appalling negligence that left more than 2,700 tons of ammonium nitrate sitting for more than six years at Lebanon’s port in Beirut, just waiting to explode, perfectly if tragically encapsulates the official corruption and incompetence in a country where almost everything that can go wrong does go wrong.

headline: Administration Reaches Out to Democrats on Stimulus Bill
keywords: ['Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin talked with Speaker Nancy Pelosi for the first time since negotiations on a new coronavirus relief bill collapsed, but neither side showed any willingness to budge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, spoke on Wednesday with Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California to discuss a coronavirus relief package, though the conversation appeared to do little to resolve the standoff between the White House and top congressional Democrats over another economic stimulus measure.

headline: G.O.P.ers Can’t Find Their Kamala
abstract: The attacks from Trump’s allies just don’t seem to fit.

headline: North Korean Hacking Group Attacks Israeli Defense Industry
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Israel says the attack was thwarted, but a cybersecurity firm says it was successful. Some officials fear that classified data stolen by North Korea could be shared with Iran.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Israel claimed Wednesday that it had thwarted a cyberattack by a North Korea-linked hacking group on its classified defense industry.

headline: Trump’s Cabinet From Hell
abstract: The contest is over. Meet the winning Worst.
lead_paragraph: If you run into Attorney General William Barr over the weekend, be sure to congratulate him.

headline: Health Experts Warn About Perils of New Virus Data Collection System
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Hospitals', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An administration shift is putting a burden on hospitals and undercutting the integrity of data on the pandemic, current and former members of a federal advisory panel said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly three dozen current and former members of a federal health advisory committee, including nine appointed or reappointed by the health secretary, Alex M. Azar II, are warning that the Trump administration’s new coronavirus database is placing an undue burden on hospitals and will have “serious consequences on data integrity.”

headline: Kamala Harris’s Cultural Impact
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Biden’s pick for vice president comes with important advantages, but also some complexities.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden’s selection of Kamala Harris, the daughter of a Jamaican father and a South Asian mother, both immigrants, is both historic and inspiring.

headline: Biden and Harris Pledge a Strong Challenge to Trump and a Path Out of Crisis
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Joe Biden and Kamala Harris made their debut as running mates in Wilmington, Del., offering a vision of recovery from the coronavirus and pressing their case that the president has made things worse at every turn.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris made their debut as running mates in a high school gymnasium on Wednesday, pledging to lead the country out of the coronavirus crisis amid an onslaught of attacks from President Trump as the two national tickets went head-to-head for the first time, less than three months before Election Day.

headline: How Big a Role Will Kamala Harris Play?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Women and Girls', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: As Ms. Harris joins the Democratic ticket, the question now is how much power she will wield over the campaign and in office.
lead_paragraph: — Teresa Younger, president and chief executive of the nonprofit Ms. Foundation for Women

headline: Her Voice? Her Name? G.O.P.’s Raw Personal Attacks on Kamala Harris
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Political Advertising', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'News and News Media', 'Television']
abstract: ‘Radical leftist’ or not progressive enough? In the hours after Ms. Harris’s announcement as Joe Biden’s vice president, the Trump campaign struggled to launch a clear attack on the Biden-Harris ticket.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Opening an ugly new chapter in the 2020 campaign, President Trump and allies in the Republican Party and on Fox News have swiftly gone all-in on sexist and personal attacks against Kamala Harris, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, from Mr. Trump demeaning her as “angry” and “horrible” to commentators mocking her first name to comparing her to “payday lenders.”

headline: Ohio State Football Is Canceled. Will Trump Take the Hit?
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Football (College)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The Big Ten Conference’s decision to cancel its football season reverberated across Ohio, where the Buckeyes’ football program looms large. Some voters blamed President Trump’s handling of the virus.
lead_paragraph: CENTER OF THE WORLD, Ohio — As he stood outside the Dollar General store, loading groceries into his pickup, Dennis Kuchta pondered what it will mean not to have an Ohio State football season this fall.

headline: Black Women Asked Their Party for What They Wanted. What Happens Next?
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Kamala Harris is the first woman of color on a major party ticket. For the women who helped get her here, the moment is joyful, and worrisome.
lead_paragraph: Halliestine Zimmerman, a 71-year-old retired accountant in Mauldin, S.C., has cast a ballot in every election since she came of voting age, having watched her mother work to get more African-Americans to vote in the 1950s.

headline: ‘Storm Over Brooklyn’ Review: A Flash Point of Racial Violence
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: This documentary on the race-related killing of the Black teenager Yusuf Hawkins in 1989 never settles on a satisfying point of view.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 23, 1989, a Black teenager named Yusuf K. Hawkins was fatally shot in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, after being surrounded by a group of white youths, an incident of race-related violence that became a lightning rod in New York and beyond. In the wake of George Floyd protests, the documentary “Yusuf Hawkins: Storm Over Brooklyn” could scarcely be timelier.

headline: Biden and Harris’s Incident-Free, Audience-Free Debut
abstract: For all the oddities endemic to a mid-virus presidential campaign, the pair’s maiden gathering reflected a scene that seemed entirely plausible, even predictable, a year ago.
lead_paragraph: It was probably always going to be strange.

headline: The True Coronavirus Toll in the U.S. Has Already Surpassed 200,000
abstract: A New York Times analysis shows a high number of deaths above normal — with the most recent rise in excess deaths focused in the South and West.
lead_paragraph: A New York Times analysis shows a high number of deaths above normal — with the most recent rise in excess deaths focused in the South and West.

headline: Crispy Brisket Bits
abstract: Jon Olsen tries to unite us, as we try to say “crispy brisket bits” 10 times fast.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw the constructor Jon Olsen, he was feeling kind of blue, but he’s clearly better now, because he is calling on us to unite.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 13, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2020.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on Wednesday about pro-democracy protests in Thailand misidentified a subject in the image. Benjamaporn Nivas is second from the left in the image; she is not being interviewed.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A ‘Quantum Leap’ for Black Women Is Followed by Worry of What’s Next
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 13, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “It was time for the Democrats to recognize who brought them to victory and who brings them to victory every time — it is Black women.”

headline: ‘Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.’: Behind the Scenes of the Emotional Series Finale
abstract: As they initiate one last time jump, two of the showrunners, Maurissa Tancharoen and Jed Whedon, discuss bidding a bittersweet farewell to the Marvel secret agency.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the series finale of “Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.”

headline: Could Owl and Crocodilian Tears Lead to a Cure for Your Dry Eyes?
abstract: By studying the numerous ways animals keep their eyes wet and healthy, scientists hope to help address human vision problems.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Arianne Pontes Oriá stands firm: She does not make animals cry for a living.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: U.K. recession, WeChat, Belarus: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Britain has suffered a recession deeper than any other reported by a European or North American country during the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Aliens Are Protesting in Israel. They Still Can’t Beat Bibi.
abstract: This summer’s protests against the prime minister have given Israel’s toothless left an outlet — but not power.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Just when Israeli democracy most needed saviors, they materialized.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Selena + Chef’ and ‘Jazz on a Summer’s Day’
abstract: Selena Gomez hosts a cooking show from quarantine. And a new restoration of a 1960 jazz concert film is on Film Forum’s virtual cinema.
lead_paragraph: SELENA + CHEF Stream on HBO Max. At the start of this quarantine cooking program, Selena Gomez makes a confession: “I can’t even fix eggs properly,” she says. The show pairs Gomez with famous chefs who teach her to do that and more. First up: a video call from the French chef and restaurateur Ludo Lefebvre, who instructs Gomez in the finer points of omelet making (a piece of advice: “give a little massage to the eggs with the butter”), before ramping up the difficulty, moving swiftly to soufflé. Other guest chefs during the show’s 10 episodes include Nancy Silverton, Roy Choi and Tanya Holland.

headline: In Women’s Suffrage, a Spotlight for Unsung Pioneers
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Nineteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Through articles, a book, a play and more, a Times special project commemorating the ratification of the 19th Amendment focuses on lesser-known women who were crucial to the fight.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Trevor Noah Can’t Tell Whether Trump Is Attacking or Defending Biden
abstract: After the president called Kamala Harris “horrible” because of her treatment of Joe Biden at a debate, Trevor Noah said, “I thought this election would be Trump versus Joe Biden.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Facebook Will Promote Voting by Mail as Trump Attacks Method
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Social Media', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The voter information hub, on Facebook and Instagram, will feature prompts to vote and reminders of key election deadlines.
lead_paragraph: One of the most valuable pieces of real estate on the internet will soon promote vote by mail to a broad audience of up to 70 percent of American adults over the next 82 days.

headline: ‘Feeling Seen for the First Time,’ Indian-Americans Cheer Kamala Harris’s Selection
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Indian-Americans', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Indian-American political leaders and community advocates described the choice of Ms. Harris as the Democratic vice-presidential nominee as a powerful statement on American possibility.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. selected Senator Kamala Harris of California as his running mate, Neil Makhija’s father sent him a photo.

headline: On Native American Land, Contact Tracing Is Saving Lives
abstract: As the coronavirus spread on the Fort Apache reservation in Arizona, medical teams sought out residents who might have been exposed. The effort paid off in unexpected ways.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus is raging through the White Mountain Apache tribe. Spread across a large reservation in eastern Arizona, the Apaches have been infected at more than 10 times the rate of people in the state as a whole.

headline: ‘We Are the Guinea Pigs’: Hollywood Restarts Its Blockbuster Machine
abstract: “Jurassic World: Dominion,” filming in England, is a chance for the movie industry to see if it can move past the financial woes caused by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Like most actors, Bryce Dallas Howard is used to showing up on film sets knowing what lines she’s supposed to say, when she’s supposed to say them and, often, not much more.

headline: After Agnes Chow Is Arrested in Hong Kong, a ‘Mulan’ Meme Is Born
abstract: Supporters of Ms. Chow, a 23-year-old activist detained under Hong Kong’s national security law, flooded Twitter with images comparing her to the Chinese folk heroine.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Soon after one of Hong Kong’s best-known democracy activists was arrested this week under the national security law imposed on the city by the Chinese government, supporters turned her into a “Mulan” meme.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Making an Earnest Effort
abstract: Should there be one designated communicator on a trip to a foreign country or deux?
lead_paragraph: Chris writes: My wife, Amanda, expects me to communicate whenever we travel to a foreign country. She would not even say merci in Paris! I speak terribly, but I make an earnest effort. I hope to travel again one day. Before then, I’d like Amanda to learn some basic phrases.

headline: He Was an Active Guy. Suddenly His Legs Ached After a Few Blocks.
abstract: He was in robust health, but then his legs hurt, he was chronically congested, even his ears became swollen. What could cause all that?
lead_paragraph: “Wow, brother, you look awful!” the middle-aged woman called out to the 48-year-old man as he made his way slowly to the table. The siblings were from a large, close-knit family, together (back before Covid-19 hit) to celebrate the birthday of their 8-year-old niece. The woman always described her brother as strapping or robust; he now looked neither. He limped toward the table as if his left leg was somehow too weak to carry him. His normally ruddy complexion looked gray. His face looked both thinner — as if he’d lost weight since she last saw him two weeks earlier — but also fatter, his cheeks chipmunk-swollen, especially strange in his otherwise bony face. One of his ears was the only spot of color on him, fire-engine red and oddly enlarged.

headline: A Midwest Transplant Tries Not to Break the Bank in Manhattan
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Nick Anderson was paying less than $1,000 a month in Wisconsin before he moved to New York and got acquainted with city prices. Which of these options would you choose?
lead_paragraph: Nick Anderson was paying less than $1,000 a month in Wisconsin before he moved to New York and got acquainted with city prices. Which of these options would you choose?

headline: Missing Weddings? Lucy Foley’s Sinister Best Seller Will Cheer You Up
abstract: When it comes to nightmare nuptials, “The Guest List” takes the cake.
lead_paragraph: REGRETS ONLY Among this summer’s many cancellations: wedding drama of the kind that leads you to gossip with cousins over mini quiche and lukewarm champagne. The British author Lucy Foley appears to have scratched our itch for matrimonial distraction; her runaway best seller, “The Guest List,” is now in its 10th week on the hardcover fiction list, currently at No. 5. This murder mystery revolves around a wedding, which may be the key to its popularity with the socially distanced set. Foley says: “Maybe people are reading it and thinking, ‘Things could be worse. I could be stuck in the middle of nowhere with this lot.’”

headline: Are They Still Beach Books if You’re Not Reading Them on the Beach?
abstract: Of course they are — and this summer, more than ever, indulge in some page-turning escapism.
lead_paragraph: What a strange summer this has been. The lead-up was an excruciating blend of boredom and heartbreak, and the actuality is a series of quandaries that feel like an unwinnable round of Scruples: Is it safe to eat a burger off your neighbor’s grill? Do you need to wear a mask while biking? Can the virus survive chlorine?

headline: Architecture, in Abstract: A Quiz
abstract: Can you identify the cities where these abstract architectural photographs were taken?
lead_paragraph: Can you identify the cities where these abstract architectural photographs were taken?

headline: My Boyfriend Is Mad At His White Parents for Me. But I Don’t Care.
abstract: His family often asks me about Black Lives Matter and racism. My boyfriend is annoyed, but I’m happy to teach them.
lead_paragraph: I am a young Black woman who’s been quarantining with my white boyfriend for months. It’s been mostly great for us as a couple. When we visit his family nearby, they often ask me about the Black Lives Matter protests, in which we’re participating. I find them genuinely interested, respectful and curious about why expressions like “All Lives Matter” are racist. I’m happy to engage. But my boyfriend gets furious with them! He turns simple questions into big fights. What am I missing?

headline: Waiting for My Baby Boy, Worrying About My Baby Brother
abstract: It’s hard to savor the joys of first-time motherhood while your brother fights against cancer.
lead_paragraph: My family and I organized a Mother’s Day Zoom in May. My mother isn’t much for gifts, but she lives for family together time. In the age of Covid-19, gathering around a screen with me, my dad and two brothers would have to do.

headline: Unicorn Floats and a Marriage Deflated
abstract: We never imagined our marriage would be tested so ferociously. Finding the magic again meant mending the tears in our relationship.
lead_paragraph: Not too long ago, I found myself sitting at a local coffee shop trying to  focus on the task at hand: writing the introduction to an article concerning a unicorn float. You know, the kind that goes in the pool and shows up all over Instagram by people who don’t appear to have any intention of getting wet? I’ve neither owned nor been on a unicorn float at any point in my life, and can’t particularly say I care one way or another about them. However, here I am. What makes this assignment all the more burdensome is that one hour before, my husband of nearly 10 years told me he no longer wanted to be married to me.

headline: Manhattan Real Estate Recovery Lags
abstract: The suburban market is booming and Brooklyn is hot.
lead_paragraph: The real estate market in New York City and its suburbs has seen huge changes during the pandemic. The near-total shutdown of the industry predictably put it on pause, but the reopening has sparked a booming, competitive seller’s market, at least in the suburbs. Manhattan is lagging, even in comparison to Brooklyn.

headline: Boing! Amid Retail’s Sag, a Nice Bounce for Mattress Sales
abstract: From a three-figure Casper with “cozy performance” to a $400,000 Hästens Grand Vividus, people seem to be investing in bedtime.
lead_paragraph: Linus Adolfsson opened up the Madison Avenue location of Hästens Sleep Spa on March 1. By March 10, he closed the store, which sells high-end beds, and the three locations he owns in Los Angeles with his business partner Carl Larsson. His reaction involved unprintable exclamations of woe.

headline: Poem: My Father Disappears Into Flowers
abstract: A poem that reminds us there is always more to come.
lead_paragraph: Poetry forever grants us leaps and blurs. Sometimes it’s not enough to be where we are. Sometimes we need to be everywhere: present with the lost, held by transient blossoms. Jan Beatty’s new poems in “The Body Wars” shimmer with luminous connection, travel a big life and grand map of encounters. Deeper breath feels present in the poem’s original uses of punctuation — stanzas, even a last one, ending with a colon. More to come? Always more. Most important, “he’s not gone” floats by itself, the truth a daughter tunes to. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: Is Individualism America’s Religion?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Opinion’s Jeneen Interlandi and Elizabeth Bruenig join the podcast.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to “The Argument” from your mobile device:

headline: Why You Should Still Care About ‘Bicycle Thieves’
abstract: On the unforgettable heartbreak and enduring pleasures of an Italian neorealist masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: “People should see it — and they should care.” Those are the concluding words to one of the more passionate raves in the annals of New York Times film criticism: Bosley Crowther’s 1949 review of the Italian movie introduced to American audiences as “The Bicycle Thief.”

headline: The Immoral Double Life of the Former King of Spain
abstract: An outdated culture allowed King Juan Carlos I to become a lobbyist for Arab dictatorships and to hide his fortune for decades.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — One of my first assignments as a reporter, in 1996, was to interview an alleged lover of the king of Spain, Juan Carlos de Borbón y Borbón. My editors at El Mundo asked me to look into whether Bárbara Rey, a Spanish film and television actress, demanded money from the state in exchange for keeping her relationship with the married king secret. In the end, I didn’t get the interview. Under pressure, Ms. Rey chose to remain silent. Thus our king’s two great weaknesses — women and money — remained the country’s worst-kept secret for another two decades.

headline: Managing Pandemic Health Risks on College Campuses
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Quarantines', 'Masks', 'Medicine and Health', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness']
abstract: How college students can stay healthy during an unpredictable fall semester.
lead_paragraph: College life was designed around community and togetherness. Now we are attempting to retrofit it for the opposite — with physical distancing, fewer people and the elimination of most in-person gatherings.

headline: After Trump, America Needs Accountability for His Corruption
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Restoring the rule of law is not the same as “lock her up.”
lead_paragraph: Last week, NPR’s Lulu Garcia-Navarro asked Joe Biden whether, if elected, he could envision Donald Trump being prosecuted. Biden replied that the prosecution of a former president would be a “very, very unusual thing” and probably “not very good for democracy.” The former vice president said he would not stand in the way if the Justice Department wanted to bring a case, but when Garcia-Navarro pressed him, he suggested she was trying to bait him into a version of Trump’s threat against his 2016 opponent: “Lock her up.”

headline: I Started Khan Academy. We Can Still Avoid an Education Catastrophe.
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Education (K-12)', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Videophones and Videoconferencing', 'Mathematics', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Virtual school will never be a perfect replacement for in-person learning, but there’s a lot of room for improvement.
lead_paragraph: It is becoming clear that many of our nation’s children could be attending school from home for this school year and possibly longer. If educators and families aren’t empowered with the right support and tools, this will evolve from an education crisis to an education catastrophe.

headline: Why Parents, With ‘No Good Choice’ This School Year, Are Blaming One Another
abstract: Every choice on what to do about schooling amid a pandemic is potentially risky or unfair. Even if the problem is systemic, the angst is personal.
lead_paragraph: It’s the newest front in America’s parenting wars.

headline: We Just Saw the Future of Anti-Abortion Laws
abstract: An appellate court has reinstated a bizarre grab bag of statutes that were invalidated more than three years ago.
lead_paragraph: Well, that didn’t take long.

headline: How Trump’s Push to Reopen Schools Backfired
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'E-Learning', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Organized Labor', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Distrust of the president and his motives hardened the conviction of some educators that teaching in person was unsafe, helping drive union opposition.
lead_paragraph: In June, with the coronavirus crisis appearing to hit a lull in the United States, teachers and parents around the country finally began feeling optimistic about reopening schools in the fall. Going back into the classroom seemed possible. Districts started to pull together plans. Then came a tweet.

headline: Rebel Poet’s Death Leaves 40 Years of Epic Afghan Work Unfinished
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Politics and Government', 'Poetry and Poets', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Cold War Era']
abstract: He was a Marxist revolutionary and minister in Afghanistan’s short-lived communist government. But Sulaiman Layeq spent the last decades of his life writing an epic poem about an Islamist insurgent.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As the Afghan poet and former leftist revolutionary Sulaiman Layeq was suffering from blast wounds that never healed, his verses dried up.

headline: Worried Lenders Pounce on Landlords Unable to Pay Their Loans
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Foreclosures', 'Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Private Equity', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Some hedge funds and private equity firms that lent money to property owners are now suing them for falling behind on interest payments.
lead_paragraph: Five months into the pandemic, hotel rooms remain largely unreserved, office space sits empty and hardly anyone is venturing into malls. Commercial tenants are struggling to pay their rents, and property owners are struggling to make payments on the loans they took out to finance the buildings.

headline: Joe Biden and the Great Leaders of 2020 Are Part of a Club
abstract: They’re the graduates of public universities, and they’ve stepped into the void of presidential leadership.
lead_paragraph: Since the Harvard-Yale game that was the 1988 general election, all U.S. presidents, including the Wharton School graduate currently occupying the White House, have been Ivy League alumni. President Gerald Ford (University of Michigan, ’35) often ditched “Hail to the Chief” as his walk-on music and replaced it with his college fight song, but he never won the Electoral College, having assumed the Oval Office after Richard Nixon resigned.

headline: They’re Desperate to Reopen Their Gyms, No Matter What the Law Says
keywords: ['Health Clubs', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Exercise', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: New Jersey is one of seven states where health clubs have been barred from reopening. The governor says it’s too soon, but some gym owners are rebelling.
lead_paragraph: In an act of defiance, Joe Logue, a retired Marine, affixed a military gas mask and headphones before beginning his chest-and-arm workout at a New Jersey gym that had gone rogue.

headline: Lacrosse Plays On in the Pandemic, Creating Tough Calls for Families
abstract: The contentious debate about whether to play or cancel summer recruiting showcases has resembled the tense and divided national response to the coronavirus itself.
lead_paragraph: FARMINGTON, Conn. — The Middlesex Bears had waited for months to compete in the New England Cup, an elite recruiting showcase for high school girls’ lacrosse players. Already, the coronavirus pandemic had forced a postponement to late July from June and a change of venue. Then a legal battle between the women’s collegiate lacrosse coaching association and the cup’s organizers had threatened to cancel the showcase at the last minute.

headline: Should Trump and Pence Be Worried About Kamala Harris? Let’s Go to the Tape.
abstract: The story of her career can be explained, in part, by a series of dramatic moments during congressional hearings and primary debates. Here are five of them.
lead_paragraph: The story of the political career of Kamala Harris can be told, in part, by videotape. Ms. Harris has risen to public attention — and more important, risen to the attention of Joseph R. Biden Jr., who picked her as his running mate on Tuesday — because of a series of often dramatic moments during congressional hearings, town halls and primary debates. Here are five of them, with our commentary.

headline: He Is 16 and His Mother Died of Covid-19. What Happens To Him Now?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Foster Care', 'Quarantines', 'Homeless Persons', 'Orphans and Orphanages', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Children who lost their parents in the pandemic are fighting to hold on to what is left of their families.
lead_paragraph: For the Fryson brothers, the year had begun on a hopeful note. They had finally reunited with their mother, Beatrice McMillian, after years of being in foster care.

headline: The Three Abductions of N.: How Corporate Kidnapping Works
keywords: ['Child Custody and Support', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: When estranged parents take children across borders, a shadowy industry of “recovery agents” can get them back — for a fee.
lead_paragraph: A few days before Christmas 2013, Stuart Dempster hired a car to take him from Bangkok to the rural town of Ban Phai, in northeastern Thailand. Mr. Dempster, a 55-year-old track and field coach from Australia, was accompanied by a tall, burly security contractor. The two men were preparing to abduct Mr. Dempster’s daughter.

headline: Some Light in the Darkness for London’s West End
abstract: The Donmar Warehouse is the first major playhouse in the city to reopen, with a socially distanced sound installation.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Finally, some light in the darkness. The Donmar Warehouse has made stage history as the first playhouse here to open its doors to a paying public in the almost five months since the coronavirus lockdown began. Brave? Yes, and, even better, with a brilliant production.

headline: Retail Chains and Small Businesses Are Struggling in N.Y.C.
abstract: Since March, more than 2,800 businesses in the city have permanently closed, and others are barely holding on. Even national chains are leaving.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: California Becomes First State to Report 600,000 Coronavirus Cases
abstract: North Korea lifted a lockdown as New Zealand extended one. Britain will require some travelers to self-isolate. France declared Paris a high-risk region for the virus.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Covid-19 news and updates.]

headline: New Zealand Beat the Virus Once. Can It Do It Again?
abstract: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has revived her “go hard, go early” approach as officials grapple with a mysterious cluster that might have originated in a frozen food warehouse.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — As the week began, New Zealanders were celebrating 100 days without community spread of the coronavirus, drinking at pubs, packing stadiums and hugging friends.

headline: What Scares Salem? October Without Halloween
keywords: ['Halloween', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Parenting', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Cities, towns, retailers and confectioners across the country are bracing themselves for more subdued festivities this year — if they have them at all.
lead_paragraph: Times have changed in Salem, Mass., since the 17th century, when 200 people were accused of practicing witchcraft and 20 were executed for it. Today, the city of 43,000 revels in its macabre lore and has turned Halloween into a monthlong celebration where apple cider is consumed by the gallon, potions and herbs promise protection from evil spirits, and countless children and adults roam the streets in search of sugary and spooky delights.

headline: Hedge funds and private equity firms gave loans. Now they’re suing.
abstract: With the delinquency rate on large commercial loans tied to real estate in the United States nearly doubling in just one month, big banks, which are among the largest real estate lenders, have been generally willing to give property owners time to work things out with tenants. A class of smaller lenders are showing their impatience.
lead_paragraph: With the delinquency rate on large commercial loans tied to real estate in the United States nearly doubling in just one month, big banks, which are among the largest real estate lenders, have been generally willing to give property owners time to work things out with tenants. A class of smaller lenders are showing their impatience.

headline: How Hollywood is trying to avoid the virus as it restarts filming.
abstract: Hollywood has been unable to restart production on its own soundstages in California. So big movie studios, under pressure to get their production assembly lines running again, have focused on overseas shooting. The “Avatar” sequels are filming again in New Zealand. Sony Pictures has “Uncharted,” its adaptation of a popular video game, going in Berlin, report Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes:

headline: The Rise of QAnon
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Over three years, the far-right conspiracy theory QAnon has spread from the outskirts of the internet into the mainstream. And by next year, it will most likely make its way into Congress: A QAnon supporter is almost sure to be elected after winning a Republican House primary runoff in Georgia this week.

headline: Episode Four: ‘Here’s Another Fun Thing You Can Do’
abstract: Is it possible to limit the power of white parents?
lead_paragraph: Public education won’t be fair until school systems limit the power of white parents. But is that even possible? Chana finds two schools that are trying to do just that, and both are actually inside the I.S. 293 building. One is downstairs in the basement, where a charter school called Success Academy Cobble Hill opened about seven years ago. The other is upstairs at the newly-renamed Boerum Hill School for International Studies.

headline: A Lifetime of Seeing the Good and the Bad Between Neighbors
abstract: Sarah Friar, a native of Northern Ireland, is chief executive of the social network Nextdoor, a sometimes unruly platform aimed at connection.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Friar grew up during the Troubles. Raised in a small town in Northern Ireland, she saw neighbors turn against one another in violence, and also come together in solidarity.

headline: Norwegian Taxis, Wirelessly Charging While They Wait for a Fare
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Automobiles', 'Batteries', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Electric Jaguars in Oslo, using tech from a former NASA architect, will soon be able to recharge on special pads embedded under the road.
lead_paragraph: Starting next year, two dozen specially outfitted electric Jaguar taxis will roam the streets of the very green capital of Norway. And when they are idling at special taxi lines, they will be able to be recharged from the ground up.

headline: Why Teachers Aren’t Ready to Reopen Schools
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Principals (School)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Charter Schools', 'School Discipline (Students)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: The president is demanding schools return to in-person learning. Officials are answering that call. But teachers and their unions say many of those plans are unsafe.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: The Boston Tea Party Was More Than That. It Was a Riot.
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Revolutionary War, American (1775-83)']
abstract: We do not care for the revolutionary spirit to survive the revolution. The revolution, however, goes nowhere without it.
lead_paragraph: In July 1776, George Washington ordered the brand-new Declaration of Independence read aloud to a jubilant New York City crowd. A small group opted to continue their celebration into the evening. Led by an artillery officer, the revelers toppled the colossal, gilded statue of King George III at Bowling Green.

headline: 2 German blue chips, a steel maker and a travel giant, both deep in the red.
abstract: Two of Germany’s biggest corporations reported huge losses on Thursday, illustrating the degree to which the pandemic has pushed companies to the brink.
lead_paragraph: Two of Germany’s biggest corporations reported huge losses on Thursday, illustrating the degree to which the pandemic has pushed companies to the brink.

headline: ‘Terror Crocodile’ the Size of a Bus Fed on Dinosaurs, Study Says
abstract: The monster animal, more closely related to American alligators than modern crocodiles, had teeth the size of bananas and a strange enlarged snout.
lead_paragraph: They had teeth the size of bananas, were as long as buses and limos, and preyed on dinosaurs that fed near their waterways.

headline: Why Be Vulnerable?
abstract: Nothing like a pandemic to show people we don’t have it all together.
lead_paragraph: Every so often a word bubbles to the surface of our cultural consciousness and then it’s seemingly unavoidable. This year, in addition to the term “trauma,” it’s “vulnerability.” (Both are apt for a time of widespread social inequality, illness and unemployment.)

headline: ‘Spree’ Review: Desperately Seeking Likes
abstract: A ride-share driver turns serial killer in this depressing social-media thriller.
lead_paragraph: Hideous to look at and agonizing to listen to, “Spree” must hold the record for the greatest number of annoying characters in a single movie. Coarsely merging social-media critique and slasher comedy, this shallow take on the evils of internet addiction is as unoriginal as it is unfunny.

headline: ‘Represent’ Review: Running for Office, and Seeking More Than Votes
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Women and Girls', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: In this documentary, three women, driven by a desire to reshape their communities, seek office.
lead_paragraph: In “Represent,” a documentary about women in local politics, getting the vote is only part of the battle.

headline: ‘The Bay of Silence’ Review: Awash With Secrets
abstract: This British-Dutch thriller heaps on the supporting characters but doesn’t give them much room to breathe.
lead_paragraph: “The Bay of Silence” takes its name from a spot on the Ligurian coast of Italy. The waters may teem with tasty seafood, but this thriller, about a man trying to make sense of his wife’s tangled past, is a net full of red herrings.

headline: ‘An Easy Girl’ Review: Carnal Knowledge
abstract: An inexperienced teenager and her more sophisticated cousin experience a transformative summer in this smart and sultry coming-of-age story.
lead_paragraph: The French nymph, poised on the precipice of womanhood, has long been an art-house cliché, and “An Easy Girl” knows it. Sensual and sly, this fourth feature from Rebecca Zlotowski — after “Planetarium” in 2017 — is both too clever and too subtle to pander to stereotype. So when we see Sofia (the stunning Zahia Dehar) frolic, bare-breasted, in a secluded cove in Cannes, her teasing of Georges Lechaptois’s camera tells us emphatically that she’s no ingénue.

headline: ‘Sputnik’ Review: A Return From Space, With a Little Something
abstract: This Russian sci-fi horror picture strongly advises that what you find in space should stay there.
lead_paragraph: This creepy Russian sci-fi horror picture does not take its title from the famous satellite the Soviet Union launched in 1957. Rather, it invokes the literal meaning of the word, which translates to English as “companion.”

headline: ‘Change of Life’ Review: A Film From a Portuguese Master, Newly Restored
abstract: Paulo Rocha’s 1966 triumph is set in a Portuguese fishing village, where residents live hand-to-mouth.
lead_paragraph: The Portuguese director Paulo Rocha, who died in 2012, created a memorable body of work, with aesthetic roots both in Italian neorealism and the French New Wave. It’s worth exploring in and of itself and with respect to its continuity with Portugal’s cinema as a whole. He’s different from greats like Manoel De Oliveira (with whom he worked as an assistant) and Pedro Costa, but he shares definite affinities with them.

headline: He Needed to Train. David Duchovny’s Pool Was Out There.
abstract: Rudy Garcia-Tolson’s attempt to make a fifth Paralympic swim team after three years of retirement was missing a crucial element — a pool where he could train. Enter Special Agent Mulder.
lead_paragraph: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year. Read Garcia-Tolson’s first installments here and here.

headline: Harris Offers a Preview of What She’ll Bring
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: The new running mate played both defense and offense: This is your morning tip sheet.
lead_paragraph: The first day of the Biden-Harris ticket kicked off like many Biden events this year: late. It’s Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: Tales of Hope and Resilience as a Museum Reopens
abstract: An outdoor exhibition of quarantine stories at the New-York Historical Society offers a healing space for emotionally drained New Yorkers. The museum invites visitors to record their own experiences.
lead_paragraph: What will it take for New Yorkers to process the events of the past few months — the emotional toll of thousands of deaths, social unrest, economic insecurity and the abrupt cessation of life as we knew it? The New-York Historical Society is hoping a new exhibition, humble but moving, can offer a space for some of our feelings to catch up with us.

headline: What’s Happening in Belarus?
abstract: After a disputed election, the police cracked down violently on protests. But demonstrations continued, calling for the longtime president to resign.
lead_paragraph: After the longtime president of Belarus, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, claimed 80 percent of the vote in what many Western governments said was a sham election in August, protesters across the country have continued to turn out in droves, only to be met with a fierce police crackdown as the government tries to maintain its grip on power.

headline: The Democratic contenders pledge a path forward out of crises.
abstract: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kamala Harris made their debut as running mates in a high school gymnasium on Wednesday, pledging to lead the country out of the coronavirus crisis.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kamala Harris made their debut as running mates in a high school gymnasium on Wednesday, pledging to lead the country out of the coronavirus crisis.

headline: Harris crystallizes Trump’s view of women: They’re ‘nasty’ or housewives.
abstract: In the hours since Kamala Harris joined the Democratic presidential ticket, President Trump has responded by sorting women into two categories: the good “suburban housewife” he believes will vote for him, and nasty women who have not shown him or his political allies sufficient respect.
lead_paragraph: In the hours since Kamala Harris joined the Democratic presidential ticket, President Trump has responded by sorting women into two categories: the good “suburban housewife” he believes will vote for him, and nasty women who have not shown him or his political allies sufficient respect.

headline: Mass Beatings and Detentions in Belarus as President Clings to Power
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The violence appeared aimed at scaring off protesters who have taken to the streets since Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, an authoritarian, claimed victory in last weekend’s election.
lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — Accounts of violent beatings of protesters and mass detentions mounted in Belarus on Thursday as the country’s embattled president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, deployed brute force to cling to power.

headline: Air travel is recovering slower than expected, energy agency says.
abstract: A global “stalling of mobility,” especially in air travel, has prompted the International Energy Agency to make a slight downgrade in its forecast for oil demand in 2020. The agency said Thursday that demand would fall by 8.1 million barrels a day in 2020, 140,000 barrels lower than last month’s prediction.
lead_paragraph: A global “stalling of mobility,” especially in air travel, has prompted the International Energy Agency to make a slight downgrade in its forecast for oil demand in 2020. abstract: “The boundaries between subjects are really artificial constructs by humans, like the boundaries between colors in a rainbow.”

abstract: Thursday: The year has started out looking different across the state. Also: A dangerous fire in northern Los Angeles County.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

abstract: Fine-art postcards, Bottega Veneta rain boots — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
