headline: Democratic Senators Suggest Bill of Rights for College Athletes
abstract: The framework, unlikely to be taken up before the election, proposes protections for athletes who have asserted themselves during the pandemic and sought more ways to earn money.
lead_paragraph: College athletes who have asserted themselves in recent months on many issues, including social justice matters, the right to cash in on their fame, and improved health and safety conditions if they are to play football this fall during the pandemic, gained powerful backing on Wednesday with Democratic senators announcing a framework for a college athletes’ bill of rights that would support those causes.

headline: Protesters Blocked ICE Buses in Oregon. Federal Agents Responded in Force.
abstract: Using crowd-control weapons, agents were able to extract people who were detained on one of the buses after hundreds of protesters in Bend, Ore., blocked the vehicles from moving.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of federal agents were deployed in Bend, Ore., late Wednesday after protesters stood for hours to block the path of buses that held two people who had been seized by immigration agents, according to witnesses and videos from the scene.

headline: Explaining the markets, in three charts.
abstract: It can be hard to keep up with everything going on in the markets. From DealBook, here is a chart-heavy spin through some of the big stories you need to know.
lead_paragraph: It can be hard to keep up with everything going on in the markets. From DealBook, here is a chart-heavy spin through some of the big stories you need to know.

headline: He Wasn’t Toscanini, but He Made Orchestras Sing
abstract: New box sets continue the debate over John Barbirolli, the New York Philharmonic’s music director from 1937 to ’42.
lead_paragraph: “He drove the orchestra hard whenever there was a shadow of an excuse for doing it.”

headline: 5 Takeaways From Kamala Harris’s First Full Day on the Biden Ticket
keywords: ['Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: She is adding sizzle, bringing in lots of cash, carving out an anti-Trump role and seemingly confounding the Republican opposition.
lead_paragraph: When Joseph R. Biden Jr. dialed up Senator Kamala Harris on a videoconference call and asked her The Question — “You ready to go to work?” he said, to which she replied, “Oh my God, I am so ready” — his choice as vice president was a well-kept secret but hardly a surprise.

headline: ‘Martin Margiela: In His Own Words’ Review: A Visionary’s Handiwork
abstract: A rather conventional documentary about a fashion designer whose creations were anything but.
lead_paragraph: You can count on one hand the number of photos of the Belgian fashion designer Martin Margiela on the internet. Which is to say that the first documentary about his life and career is called “Martin Margiela: In His Own Words” for a reason — he is the film’s narrator, offering sensible and diligent assessments of his own work and gosh-golly takes on his influence, but not much more. Only his hands — lovely, patient — appear onscreen.

headline: Kurt Luedtke, Newspaperman Turned Screenwriter, Dies at 80
abstract: He led The Detroit Free Press at 33, then gave up journalism for Hollywood. “Absence of Malice” was one result; an Oscar for “Out of Africa” was another.
lead_paragraph: Kurt Luedtke, a former newspaper executive who forged a successful second career writing Hollywood screenplays, notably for “Absence of Malice” and the Oscar-winning “Out of Africa,” died on Sunday at a hospital in Royal Oak, Mich. He was 80.

headline: David Galante, Who Spoke Belatedly About Auschwitz, Dies at 96
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: It took him decades before he felt comfortable sharing the horrors he witnessed during the Holocaust. He died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: In N.Y.C.’s Spring Virus Surge, a Frightening Echo of 1918 Flu
abstract: In March and April, death rates rivaled those seen during the country’s deadliest pandemic, a new study finds. “What 1918 looked like is basically this.”
lead_paragraph: The 1918 influenza pandemic is the deadliest in modern history, claiming an estimated 50 million lives worldwide, including 675,000 in the United States.

headline: Israel and United Arab Emirates Strike Major Diplomatic Agreement
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Israeli Settlements', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations', 'Peace Process']
abstract: President Trump announced that Israel and the United Arab Emirates would establish “full normalization of relations” and that in exchange Israel would forgo for now “declaring sovereignty” over occupied West Bank territory.
lead_paragraph: Israel and the United Arab Emirates reached a landmark accord sealed by President Trump on Thursday that could presage a broader realignment in the region as the two agreed to “full normalization of relations” in exchange for Israel suspending annexation of occupied West Bank territory.

headline: In Europe, Millions of Jobless Are Falling Through the Cracks
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Politics and Government', 'Unemployment', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Government efforts to subsidize wages and prevent layoffs have kept many in jobs, but they aren’t sheltering an army of precarious workers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Thierry Hombert stepped onto the balcony of his sparsely furnished apartment and took one last long look around. When the coronavirus hit France, the short-term catering gigs on which he lived for a decade disappeared, and he was now selling his home to make ends meet.

headline: 18-Year-Old Dies After He Is Stabbed and Set on Fire in the Bronx
abstract: The teenager was attacked in an apartment building near Yankee Stadium. The police later arrested the brother of his former girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: Winston Ortiz was shy teenager who family members said had become depressed in recent days over a breakup with his first girlfriend. So, he was excited when he heard from her on Wednesday afternoon, they said, and he left his family’s Bronx apartment in high spirits.

headline: Salt Lake City Suspends Use of Police Dogs in Arrests After Black Man Is Bitten
abstract: The Police Department said that the use of the dogs in arrests would be suspended until the city could review its policies and practices.
lead_paragraph: [Update: Officer who ordered police dog to bite a Black man is charged with assault.]              The authorities in Salt Lake City suspended the use of police dogs in arrests after one bit a Black man who was on one knee with his hands in the air during an incident in April, the mayor said on Wednesday.

headline: Lebanon’s Parliament Confirms State of Emergency, Extending Army Power
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Beirut, Lebanon, Explosions (2020)', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: Parliamentary approval of the measures for Beirut, which last until Aug. 21 but can be renewed, has raised concerns about civil liberties.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In its first session since a devastating explosion rocked Beirut last week, Lebanon’s Parliament approved a state of emergency that extends sweeping powers to the army in the city, a situation that rights groups have said could pose a threat to freedoms.

headline: Find a Popular Virtual Book Club
abstract: One activity that the pandemic hasn’t interrupted? Reading. If you’re looking to join a well-established virtual book club, for community or structure, here are a few places to start.
lead_paragraph: One activity that the pandemic hasn’t interrupted? Reading. If you’re looking to join a well-established virtual book club, for community or structure, here are a few places to start.

headline: Phillips Auction House to Open Hamptons Location
abstract: The new space in Southampton will open on Friday with 70 works from upcoming auctions, like Jean-Michel Basquiat’s “Portrait of A-One A.K.A. King.”
lead_paragraph: Galleries and other commercial art spaces have begun to reopen in New York but some are still choosing to expand outside the city’s limits to reach clients who have decamped because of the coronavirus pandemic. Phillips, one of the world’s top auction houses, will open a new location in Southampton, N.Y., on Friday.

headline: Aesha Ash Takes Her Place at the Head of the Class
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Discrimination']
abstract: This former City Ballet dancer becomes the first Black female member of the School of American Ballet’s permanent faculty. Yes, it’s a big deal.
lead_paragraph: An aspiring ballerina starts out bright and shiny, a vessel of faith and devotion. But little by little, as disappointments mount and personal tragedies overwhelm, faith and fortitude can crumble. That glow can fade.

headline: 9 Things to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Art', 'Music', 'Theater', 'Museums', 'Dancing', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Classical Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Opera', 'Festivals', 'Children and Childhood', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: How can you get your cultural fix when many arts institutions remain closed? Our writers offer suggestions for what to listen to and watch.
lead_paragraph: If this were a typical August, dance fans would be heading to the southern tip of Manhattan right about now for the annual Battery Dance Festival, an eclectic collection of local and international dance companies performing on an outdoor stage against a sunset-streaked harbor.

headline: Are You Overpraising Your Child?
abstract: All those “Good jobs!” might be undermining kids’ independence and self-confidence.
lead_paragraph: “I love it!”

headline: Quiz: A Strange Time for Sports
abstract: Sports has taken some unexpected turns over the last six months. How well do you remember them?
lead_paragraph: Sports has taken some unexpected turns over the last six months. How well do you remember them?

headline: Protests Take On Thai Monarchy, Despite Laws Banning Such Criticism
keywords: ['Royal Families', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Libel and Slander']
abstract: The rare questioning of Thailand’s royal family comes as student-led demonstrations have gained momentum, testing the government and the boundaries of strict lèse-majesté laws.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The plainclothes men showed up late at night near Thammasat University in Bangkok, casing out the residence where the student activist slept. On Thursday morning, Panusaya Sithijirawattanakul went to her sociology class, called her mother and waited for her arrest. She was sure it was to come.

headline: Supreme Court Lets Rhode Island Make Voting by Mail Easier Amid Pandemic
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The court rejected a request from Republicans to block an order suspending a requirement that witnesses or a notary observe the completion of absentee ballots.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday rejected a request from Republicans to block a trial judge’s ruling making it easier for voters in Rhode Island to cast absentee ballots during the coronavirus pandemic. The judge’s ruling suspended a requirement that voters using mailed ballots fill them out in the presence of two witnesses or a notary.

headline: Trump’s Attacks on the Biden-Harris Ticket
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “The contrast between the energetic and forward-looking Biden-Harris team and an increasingly pathetic President Trump couldn’t be more clear,” writes a reader.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Phil Collins and the YouTube Twins Tell Us About Music
keywords: ['Radio', 'Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The brothers Tim and Fred Williams have wowed the internet with their YouTube reactions to vintage music. Why are generation-spanning videos like theirs so popular right now?
lead_paragraph: Tim Williams and his twin brother, Fred, recently recorded themselves listening to the nearly 40-year-old hit “In the Air Tonight” by Phil Collins. In the video, the two ride the ebb and flow with some serious head nodding as the song swells toward a climactic moment.

headline: A playbook for combating QAnon
keywords: ['Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: QAnon can no longer be ignored. What internet companies could do to stop its spread.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: Steve McQueen and Chloé Zhao Works Will Play at the New York Film Festival
abstract: The main slate also includes documentaries by Jia Zhangke and Frederick Wiseman in an event that has been reshaped by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: New work by Steve McQueen, Chloé Zhao and Azazel Jacobs are among the highlights of the main slate of the 58th New York Film Festival, organizers announced Thursday. Some of the selections will also play the Toronto and Venice festivals; the organizers of all three big fall events are cooperating because there are fewer titles to choose from amid the pandemic.

headline: 9/11 Light Tribute to Take Different Shape
keywords: ['Museums', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: The twin columns will not be projected into the sky this year because of coronavirus concerns for the workers who put it together. But other buildings may shine blue.
lead_paragraph: The two ghostly columns of light rise each Sept. 11 from the area near ground zero, reaching upward and replicating the shape of the Twin Towers that were destroyed by the Qaeda attacks of 2001.

headline: U.S. Seizes Bitcoin Said to Be Used to Finance Terrorist Groups
abstract: ISIS and other groups openly solicited virtual currency donations because they mistakenly believed that the transactions would be anonymous, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States government said on Thursday that it seized about $2 million in Bitcoin and other types of cryptocurrency from accounts that had sent or received funds in alleged financing schemes for three foreign terrorist organizations: Al Qaeda, ISIS and Hamas’s paramilitary arm, the Al Qassam Brigades.

headline: Think QAnon Is on the Fringe? So Was the Tea Party
keywords: ['QAnon', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Conspiracy Theories']
abstract: Followers of the pro-Trump conspiracy movement are winning elections and worrying moderate Republicans. Sound familiar?
lead_paragraph: Democrats dismissed it as a fringe group of conspiracy-minded zealots. Moderate Republicans fretted over its potential to hurt their party’s image, while more conservative lawmakers carefully sought to harness its grass-roots energy. Sympathetic media outlets covered its rallies, portraying it as an emerging strain of populist politics — a protest movement born of frustration with a corrupt, unaccountable elite.

headline: Chicago’s Rise in Shootings
abstract: The Cook County Board president says it has nothing to do with bail reform. Also: When voting results are delayed; Turkey’s part in NATO; Hong Kong’s postponed election.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Who Would Replace Kamala Harris in the Senate for California? Let the Jockeying Begin
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: As the Democratic vice-presidential nominee hits the campaign trail, a race to replace her kicks off.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Within nanoseconds of the ascension this week of Senator Kamala Harris to the Democratic presidential ticket, her home state of California was already looking to the next question: Who will replace her if she becomes vice president?

headline: ‘Lovecraft Country’ Review: Nightmare on Jim Crow Street
abstract: HBO’s new horror series sends a Black family on a quest across 1950s America, where anyone they see might be a monster.
lead_paragraph: There were a lot of ways “Lovecraft Country” could have gone wrong, but timing didn’t turn out to be one of them. It’s a good moment to get attention for a scary-monster series that rejuvenates the horror genre by making the heroes Black and putting America’s racist history at the center of the story.

headline: Trump’s Labor Chief Accused of Intervening in Oracle Pay Bias Case
keywords: ['Whistle-Blowers', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Discrimination', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A Labor Department lawyer asserts that she faced reprisal after saying Secretary Eugene Scalia was set to settle a suit for a sum she found too low.
lead_paragraph: A senior Labor Department lawyer contends she faces removal from her job after objecting to Labor Secretary Eugene Scalia’s intervention in a pay discrimination case against Oracle, a tech giant with close White House connections.

headline: Coco Gauff Was Rising When Tennis Stopped. She Plans on Going Higher.
abstract: “Having those months off to work on certain stuff definitely helped,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Before it all stopped, no tennis talent was on a steeper climb than Coco Gauff was.

headline: ‘Boys State’ Review: Give Me a Teen and I’ll Show You a Politician
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The winning if overly eager-to-please documentary “Boys State” looks at an annual educational program for teenage boys.
lead_paragraph: American democracy is alive and well, or at least functioning, in “Boys State,” a happy pill of a documentary. Each year, thousands of high-school boys congregate in their home states for some intense governance cosplay sponsored by the American Legion. In a single whirlwind week, participants are embedded in opposing parties — like Federalists and Nationalists — decide platforms and run for office, including governor. The movie focuses on the 2018 edition of Texas Boys State, when some 1,000 teens embraced ideals and engaged in a lot of hoo-ha togetherness.

headline: In a Pair of ‘Hubs,’ the N.H.L. Postseason Has Been Anything but Neutral
abstract: Fighting has made a comeback, rest is more important than ever and players are hiding injuries from opponents staying in the same hotel. “It’s been nasty from the beginning,” said one TV analyst.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The N.H.L. restart was less than three minutes old when Justin Williams, a Carolina Hurricanes forward, offered bare-knuckled proof that the fight was on to win the Stanley Cup, although the calendar read Aug. 1, the postseason’s start date.

headline: Daimler to Settle U.S. Emissions Charges for $2.2 Billion
abstract: The agreement is a small fraction of the sum that Volkswagen paid after admitting to emissions cheating in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The German automaker Daimler said Thursday that it had agreed to pay $2.2 billion to settle accusations that Mercedes-Benz cars and vans sold in the United States were programmed to cheat on emissions tests.

headline: As Britain Climbs Out of an Economic Pit, Tough Questions Loom
abstract: The government’s aid programs are winding down, and officials are so far resisting pressure to extend them. But what if the virus resurges?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — To understand why Britain has spiraled into the deepest recession of its modern history, go for a stroll in central London, no longer a ghost town but still a shadow of its once-bustling self.

headline: Students, Tell Us About Your Experience With the Summer Reading Contest.
abstract: We want to hear your thoughts, reflections and discoveries after 10 weeks of reading The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: As we wrap up the 11th year of our Summer Reading Contest, we’re seeking student voices on what it has meant to you to participate.

headline: Remote Learning Is Hard. Losing Family Members Is Worse.
abstract: I’m a low-income student in a crowded apartment, and my family is vulnerable to Covid-19. The benefits of returning to school are not worth our health.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Last month, I learned that my uncle died of Covid-19. Not long after, his mother passed away from the virus, too. Since my parents are essential workers, I’m starting my senior year of high school worrying whether they’re next.

headline: Massachusetts Forces Two Theaters to Reduce Seating Capacity
abstract: Only 50 audience members apiece will be allowed to attend tent performances of “Godspell” and “Harry Clarke" in the Berkshires.
lead_paragraph: Two closely watched summer theater productions — the first in the U.S. with union actors since the coronavirus pandemic exploded — are being required to reduce their seating capacity to comply with changing local regulations.

headline: Theater to Stream: ‘Finish the Fight’ and a Starry ‘Jacksonian’
keywords: ['Theater', 'Edinburgh Festival Fringe', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: This month, watch Ming Peiffer’s play about the women’s suffrage movement and a virtual reading that reunites Ed Harris and Bill Pullman.
lead_paragraph: “I was so incredibly moved and touched, and also a little bit angry that I had never heard of any of these women,” said Ming Peiffer of her reaction to reading Veronica Chambers’s “Finish the Fight!: The Brave and Revolutionary Women Who Fought for the Right to Vote.”

headline: Belgian Designer Accuses Virgil Abloh of Copying. Again.
abstract: Walter Van Beirendonck says Louis Vuitton’s latest men’s collection looks familiar, and Kanye West steps into the fray.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, the rapper, designer and presidential candidate Kanye West passionately defended his longtime friend and former creative partner Virgil Abloh on Twitter. “Virgil can do whatever he wants,” he wrote. “Do you know how hard it’s been for us to be recognized?”

headline: Who Is Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, Belarus’s Unlikely Opposition Leader?
abstract: Ms. Tikhanovskaya spent her summers in rural Ireland, as a “Chernobyl child” sent to the country for respite. Her host family remembers her as a compassionate leader, even as a youngster.
lead_paragraph: When Svyeta, then age 12, arrived in rural Ireland from Belarus in the mid-1990s, it was her strong grasp of English and her kindness that stood out.

headline: Israel-U.A.E., New Zealand, Kamala Harris: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: With No Fanfare, Williams Sisters Give It Their All
abstract: It looked more like a practice match in atmosphere, but Serena topped Venus in a tight match at the Top Seed Open.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than 22 years since Venus and Serena Williams first played each other on tour. They were teenagers then, with beads in their hair and braces on their teeth.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: I first heard the term “busman’s holiday” — meaning a leisure activity that mirrors your job — a few years ago, from my mother, when my Christmas wish list comprised about a dozen books and not much else. What can I say? I really like to read.

headline: Fortnite Creator Sues Apple and Google After Ban From App Stores
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Mobile Applications', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Epic Games, the maker of the popular game, provoked the tech giants by violating their policies, then released a social media campaign and lawsuits to confront them.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s and Google’s spats with app developers over their cut of revenues exploded into a high-stakes clash on Thursday when the tech giants kicked the wildly popular game Fortnite out of their app stores and the game’s maker hit back with lawsuits.

headline: A Bouquet of Group Art Shows Near Houston Street
abstract: These expansive exhibitions, in galleries on or near the Lower East Side, create an immersive sense of art and the reawakening art scene.
lead_paragraph: Nothing says welcome back to the art world like a gallery group show. Consider it a choral, rather than solo, performance that speaks of the diversity and durability of art, an affirmation that is especially needed after months of inactivity, isolation and uncertainty. Not that any of that is over.

headline: Trump Eliminates Major Methane Rule, Even as Leaks Are Worsening
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Methane', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The weakening of Obama-era efforts to fight climate change amounts to a gift to many oil companies. Researchers warn that the decision ignores science.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration formally weakened a major climate-change regulation on Thursday — effectively freeing oil and gas companies from the need to detect and repair methane leaks — even as new research shows that far more of the potent greenhouse gas is seeping into the atmosphere than previously known.

headline: Webinars on Teaching and Learning With The New York Times
abstract: The first two webinars in our back-to-school series are all about using The Learning Network to help you bring the world to your students, for free.
lead_paragraph: We’ll be hosting dozens of professional development webinars for teachers during this school year on ways to teach and learn with The New York Times and The Learning Network — all for free. We know we’ll all need to be supporting one another through what promises to be a challenging year of teaching and learning amid a pandemic.

headline: Le Kha Phieu, Vietnam Leader Who Was Pushed Out, Dies at 88
abstract: He served for less than four years as the country’s general secretary, losing his post after unusually public factional struggles.
lead_paragraph: Le Kha Phieu, a career military man whose tenure as a hardline leader of Vietnam ended ignominiously when he was removed from office amid unusually public infighting, died on Aug. 7 in Hanoi. He was 88.

headline: Tobe Nwigwe Never Planned to Go Viral. Then He Rapped About Breonna Taylor.
abstract: The Houston rapper and singer has been making music with a close-knit team for five years. A 44-second track released in July brought his message to a larger audience.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Tobe Nwigwe has spent five years as an independent rapper and singer on the Houston scene, building an audience — including fans like Erykah Badu and Michelle Obama — with weekly song drops that unfailingly arrive with a brand-new video. His plan has always been consistency, not virality. But sudden, unexpected fame arrived last month after he released a track that called attention to the police killing of Breonna Taylor in Kentucky.

headline: You Probably Won’t Catch the Coronavirus From Frozen Food
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Food', 'Containers and Packaging', 'Chickens', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Reports that the virus was detected in a trans-continental shipment of frozen chicken wings sparked concerns online. But experts aren’t worried.
lead_paragraph: Amid a flurry of concern over reports that frozen chicken wings imported to China from Brazil had tested positive for the coronavirus, experts said on Thursday that the likelihood of catching the virus from food — especially frozen, packaged food — is exceedingly low.

headline: Don’t Like What You See on Zoom? Get a Face-Lift and Join the Crowd
abstract: Cosmetic surgeons say business is booming after elective surgery opened up, with quarantine proving a time to heal in secrecy from renovation of face and body.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of people, stuck at home and tired of staring at their own haggard faces on Zoom, are finding a fix: face and eye lifts, chin and tummy tucks and more.

headline: How to Cycle Up ‘Mount Everest’
abstract: A biking challenge known as “Everesting” — hill repeats equal in distance to the climb up the mountain — is catching on, with records rapidly falling.
lead_paragraph: As my altimeter clicked past 27,000 feet for the day — into the range of the low oxygen “death zone” on Mount Everest — and my eyes blurred with sweat and sunscreen, a white Ferrari accelerated past me into a curve.

headline: Winning the Right to Vote Was the Work of Many Lifetimes
abstract: It took generations of women — mothers and daughters, leaders and followers — to secure the 19th Amendment.
lead_paragraph: In March 2019, the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery opened an exhibition called “Votes for Women: A Portrait of Persistence.” As curator, I visited archives around the country looking for original objects and images that would reveal new aspects of the suffrage movement. I wanted to widen the story and address the roles played by women of color, especially.

headline: Tropical Storm Josephine Forms in the Atlantic
abstract: The 10th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, Josephine is not expected to hit the Caribbean islands or the mainland United States, according to the National Hurricane Center.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Josephine has formed in the Atlantic, 975 miles southeast of the northern Leeward Islands, and is expected to strengthen over the next two days before weakening as it passes well north of Puerto Rico, according to the National Hurricane Center.

headline: Justice Dept. Accuses Yale of Discrimination in Application Process
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Asian-Americans', 'Whites', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Trump administration said the university discriminated against Asian-American and white applicants. Yale defended its practices and vowed to maintain them.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Thursday accused Yale University of violating federal civil rights law by discriminating against Asian-American and white applicants, an escalation of the Trump administration’s moves against race-based admissions policies at elite universities.

headline: Afghanistan to Investigate Video Showing Forces Mutilating Taliban Corpses
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Many fear the video and other inflammatory clips circulating on social media will fuel revenge-taking long after any peace deal.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s defense ministry said it was investigating a video circulating on social media Thursday that showed men in Afghan army uniform mutilating bodies of purported Taliban fighters.

headline: Pompeo Says He and Military Warned Russia on Bounties for Killing U.S. Troops
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Passports']
abstract: The secretary of state’s acknowledgment came as a new detail surfaced about the intelligence that led to the C.I.A. assessment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said he warned Russia against offering bounties for killing American and coalition troops in Afghanistan, even as President Trump has denigrated as a “hoax” a C.I.A. assessment that Russia carried out such a covert operation.

headline: Young Adults Report Rising Levels of Anxiety and Depression in Pandemic
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Youth', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Research', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: A new C.D.C. survey indicates that young people, as well as Blacks and Latinos of all ages, are showing signs of deteriorating mental health and some are resorting to substance abuse.
lead_paragraph: The collateral damage from the pandemic continues: Young adults, as well as Black and Latino people of all ages, describe rising levels of anxiety, depression and even suicidal thoughts, and increased substance abuse, according to findings reported by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Konrad Steffen, Who Sounded Alarm on Greenland Ice, Dies at 68
abstract: A renowned researcher on rising sea levels, he died after falling into the kind of crevasse that warming has created. “It looks like climate change actually claimed him as a victim,” a colleague said.
lead_paragraph: Konrad Steffen, an Arctic scientist whose work showed that climate change is melting Greenland’s vast ice sheet with increasing speed, died on Saturday in an accident near a research station he created there 30 years ago. He was 68.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our critic recommends a televised short-film festival, an earnest new comedy or embarking on a doctor show mega-marathon.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

abstract: Was she the right pick?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

headline: In Derecho’s Wake, More Than 250,000 in Midwest Struggle Without Power
abstract: Residents in Iowa, Illinois and surrounding states were still without electricity days after Monday’s storms brought hurricane-force winds.
lead_paragraph: A group of storms that tore through the Midwest this week has left homes destroyed, crops demolished and over a quarter of a million people still without power days later.

headline: U.S. Labels Chinese Language Education Group a Diplomatic Mission
keywords: ['Chinese Language', 'Foreign Students (in US)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Propaganda', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: State Department officials said the move was aimed at informing American schools of potential propaganda from the government group’s programs, largely known as Confucius Institutes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department announced on Thursday that it was designating the U.S. headquarters of a Chinese government educational organization as a diplomatic mission, in the latest action by the Trump administration to limit official operations by China in the United States.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Deaths are climbing in the U.S., and data suggests the official toll is an undercount.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Covid-19 news and updates.]

headline: N.C.A.A. Doctors Say Football Is a Bad Idea. But They Aren’t Deciding.
abstract: The conferences, not the N.C.A.A., will make the decisions about whether to play a season in the fall.
lead_paragraph: The juxtaposition of Big 12, Southeastern and Atlantic Coast Conference leaders explaining why they were forging ahead with plans to play football this fall while speaking on one of the pandemic’s deadliest days in the United States since May was too much for Dr. Carlos del Rio, an executive associate dean at the Emory University School of Medicine.

headline: This Is Where I Stand
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Politics and Government', 'Discrimination', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: The power of conservative radicalism in an age of upheaval.
lead_paragraph: Radicals are not my cup of tea, but I’m grateful for them. The radicals who brought us Occupy Wall Street and the Bernie Sanders campaign gave the problem of income inequality a prominence it wouldn’t have had without them.

headline: Breonna Taylor’s Family Meets With Kentucky Attorney General
abstract: Five months after Breonna Taylor’s killing during a police raid, her family met with Daniel Cameron, Kentucky’s first Black attorney general, and renewed their pleas for justice.
lead_paragraph: Five months after Breonna Taylor’s killing during a police raid, her family met with Daniel Cameron, Kentucky’s first Black attorney general, and renewed their pleas for justice.

headline: Biden, Seizing on Masks as a Campaign Issue, Calls for a Mandate
abstract: Joe Biden said wearing a mask was “about your responsibilities as an American” as he and his new running mate, Kamala Harris, drew a contrast with President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his newly selected running mate, Senator Kamala Harris of California, called on Thursday for Americans to be required to wear masks, offering one of the first glimpses at how the Democratic ticket plans to confront the coronavirus and draw a contrast with President Trump.

headline: Trump’s Racist, Statist Suburban Dream
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Discrimination', 'Suburbs']
abstract: Racial inequality wasn’t an accident. It was an ugly political choice.
lead_paragraph: Conservatives do love their phony wars. Remember the war on Christmas? Remember the “war on coal”? (Donald Trump promised to end that war, but in the third year of his presidency coal production fell to its lowest level since 1978, and the Department of Energy expects it to keep falling.)

headline: $400 Unemployment Supplement Is Really $300, and Won’t Arrive Soon
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Unemployment', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: New state claims fell below one million for the first week since March. But jobless ranks remain vast, and a White House relief plan faces hurdles.
lead_paragraph: The federal aid to unemployed workers that President Trump announced last weekend looks likely to be smaller than initially suggested — and it remains unclear when the money will start flowing, how long it will last or how many workers will benefit.

headline: How Biden Chose Harris: A Search That Forged New Stars, Friends and Rivalries
keywords: ['Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Joe Biden winnowed a large list of candidates to four finalists before settling on Kamala Harris, in a process shaped by questions of loyalty. He is eyeing other contenders for top administration jobs.
