headline: A Geopolitical Earthquake Just Hit the Mideast
abstract: The Israel-United Arab Emirates deal will be felt throughout the region.
lead_paragraph: For once, I am going to agree with President Trump in his use of his favorite adjective: “huge.”

headline: Trump Makes Clear His Opposition to More Money to Support Mail Voting
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: The president’s remarks fueled alarm among Democrats that he is seeking to undercut the election and sow confusion about the outcome.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump stirred new questions on Thursday about whether he would seek to hold up new money to the Postal Service to impede mail-in voting this fall in the middle of the pandemic.

headline: Netanyahu Drops Troubled Annexation Plan for Diplomatic Gain
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'International Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In an abrupt reversal, Israel’s prime minister “suspended” a promise to annex part of the West Bank in exchange for a historic opening with the U.A.E.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For the past 16 months, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel had doggedly pursued a right-wing dream that he saw as securing his legacy: annexing West Bank territory that the Palestinians counted on for a future state, potentially dealing a death blow to a two-state solution.

headline: Kushner Says Meeting with Kanye was a ‘Friendly Discussion’
abstract: During a news briefing on Thursday, Jared Kushner, President Trump’s senior adviser, said that he and Kanye West had had a “great discussion” during a recent meeting in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: During a news briefing on Thursday, Jared Kushner, President Trump’s senior adviser, said that he and Kanye West had had a “great discussion” during a recent meeting in Colorado.

headline: In Tell-All Foreword, Cohen Promises Sordid Tales Trump ‘Does Not Want You to Read’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: In his memoir, “Disloyal,” Michael D. Cohen, President Trump’s onetime lawyer and fixer, claims that he had unique access to Mr. Trump, a man with “no true friends.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michael D. Cohen, President Trump’s onetime lawyer and fixer, released the foreword of his upcoming jailhouse tell-all on Thursday, posting to his website an introduction in which he promised stories involving the president and everything from “golden showers in a sex club in Vegas, to tax fraud, to deals with corrupt officials from the former Soviet Union.”

headline: What Will a Virtual Convention Look Like?
abstract: We talked to Tom Perez, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, to find out.
lead_paragraph: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

headline: 5 South Texas Communities Have the Country’s Highest New Infection Rates
abstract: “When the state opened, that’s when we saw the infection rate increase dramatically,” one city health official in the region said of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Texas — The five metropolitan areas in the United States that now have the highest rate of new coronavirus cases relative to their population are all in South Texas, according to data compiled by The New York Times.

headline: Trump Encourages Racist Conspiracy Theory About Kamala Harris
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Discrimination']
abstract: President Trump said he heard that Ms. Harris, the presumptive Democratic vice-presidential nominee born in California, was not eligible for the ticket, repeating a theory that is rampant among his followers. Constitutional scholars quickly called his words false and irresponsible.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Thursday encouraged a racist conspiracy theory that is rampant among some of his followers: that Senator Kamala Harris, the presumptive Democratic vice-presidential nominee born in California, was not eligible for the vice presidency or presidency because her parents were immigrants.

headline: ‘Project Power’ Review: Ye Olde Bangs, Scares and Clichés
abstract: Jamie Foxx heads up this very busy and familiar action movie, which also stars Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Dominique Fishback.
lead_paragraph: Midway through “Project Power,” a shiny, noisy, more-or-less tolerable blowout from Netflix, the rugged-yet-caring hero gives the tough-yet-sensitive youngster a quick talking to. Basically he speaks to this young grasshopper’s potential, a moment that made me wonder if there were any Scientologists on board, before dropping some wisdom on her. If you’ve seen a lot of action movies, you know what’s next: confusion, scares, brinkmanship, big and bigger bangs — anything new just won’t do.

headline: W Magazine Will Live Another Day, in Deal With Bustle Digital Group
abstract: The movie and television producer Jason Blum, the racecar driver Lewis Hamilton and the model Kaia Gerber will also be investors.
lead_paragraph: W magazine, the oversize fashion magazine whose 450,000-person circulation belies an outsize influence, is changing hands again. Now to be known as W Media, its new operating partner will be Bustle Digital Group, a web company whose properties include Bustle, an online magazine for women, and Mic, the social justice-focused website, along with a group of investors that includes the movie and television producer Jason Blum, the racecar driver Lewis Hamilton and the model Kaia Gerber, Cindy Crawford’s daughter, who is just 18.

headline: Man Charged With Murdering 4-Year-Old Whose Killing Prompted U.S. Anti-Crime Operation
abstract: The Justice Department last month named an operation to combat violent crime in cities after LeGend Taliferro, who was shot and killed while he slept in an apartment in Kansas City, Mo.
lead_paragraph: The authorities said on Thursday that they had arrested and charged a man with killing LeGend Taliferro, a 4-year-old boy from Kansas City, Mo., whose shooting death led the Justice Department to begin an operation in his name that sent hundreds of federal agents into cities to confront a rise in violence.

headline: Hit After Hit
abstract: Nam Jin Yoon makes his New York Times Crossword debut and is very modest about his talent.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — There is a lot to learn when it comes to making crossword puzzles, and it often takes aspiring constructors many attempts before an editor deems a puzzle worthy of publication.

headline: Prison Inmate Killed Himself With Coronavirus Mask, Officials Say
abstract: Daniel Ocasio was found inside his cell at the Corrigan-Radgowski Correctional Center in Uncasville, Conn., prison officials said.
lead_paragraph: A prison inmate in Connecticut this week hanged himself in his cell with a cloth mask that had been issued to him as part of an effort to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, correction officials and the state’s chief medical examiner said.

headline: Israel-U.A.E. Relations, Belarus, Europe Unemployment: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Glance (and a Rooster) That Changed Everything
abstract: After a massive earthquake struck Haiti, a young woman turned in desperation to a Vodou priest. She could not have imagined what happened next.
lead_paragraph: A wooden spoon. A green onion. A pot with three legs. One bottle of Florida water. Another of Champagne Andre. Three candles. A bag of “poud pa janbe” (“don’t-cross-here powder”). And most important, a young rooster.

headline: Quotation of the Day: When Coronavirus Took Their Parents, the Fight to Stay Together Grew
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 14, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “Your physical home is gone, your emotional home is gone. Then, you’re going to be put with someone you’ve never known in your life. That is a terrifying process for any child.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 14, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 14, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the closing of The Daily News’s Manhattan newsroom misidentified the newspaper where Jen Sheehan works. Ms. Sheehan works for The Morning Call, not The Orlando Sentinel.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘World’s Toughest Race’ and ‘Motherless Brooklyn’
abstract: Bear Grylls hosts a new reality competition show on Amazon. And Edward Norton’s “Motherless Brooklyn” adaptation airs on HBO Signature.
lead_paragraph: WORLD’S TOUGHEST RACE: ECO-CHALLENGE FIJI Stream on Amazon. You have to feel some sympathy for the competitors featured in this adventure series: As an opening montage shows participants climbing, hiking and paddling through rugged terrain, the show’s host, Bear Grylls, explains that each day of the competition “will present a new array of relentless challenges designed to break them down physically, mentally and emotionally.” Soon after, Grylls offers an addendum: “All of them,” he says, “are going to suffer.” So it seems safe to say that the show — like the competition itself — is not for the faint of heart. It pits dozens of teams from many countries against each other in an 11-day race all over Fiji.

headline: We Will Pay for Our Summer Vacations With Winter Lockdowns
abstract: This was Europe’s chance to beat back coronavirus before winter comes. We’re wasting it.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH, Scotland — This spring, when Western Europe became an epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic, countries imposed strict lockdowns: In France, a person needed a permit to go shopping; Spain required children to stay indoors the entire day; in Scotland and Wales, people could go outside for a walk only once a day and had to stay within a five-mile radius. Thanks to this, European countries were able to not only flatten the Covid-19 curve but to also keep levels of infection very low.

headline: North Korea, Fighting to Hold Back Virus and Floods, Says No Thanks to Outside Aid
abstract: The country has reported extensive flood damage. But its leader, Kim Jong-un, says that humanitarian aid might bring in Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, says the nation is facing “two crises at the same time” — fighting the spread of the coronavirus and coping with extensive flood damage. But Mr. Kim has ordered his country not to accept any international aid for fear that outside help might bring in Covid-19, the state news media reported on Friday.

headline: One I.C.U., Five Patients: A Different View of the Virus’s Toll
abstract: With exclusive access in a Houston hospital, a Times team documented the impact of the health crisis on Hispanic families, in words, images and graphics.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: How a Personal Touch Revived Bayern Munich
abstract: Hansi Flick has turned Germany’s best team into one of the most formidable squads in Europe. His secret is that there is no secret.
lead_paragraph: The day before the biggest game of his life, Per Mertesacker was called into a room at Germany’s peaceful, beachside training facility a couple of hours outside the Brazilian town of Porto Seguro and was told he would not be playing.

headline: I Exchanged Notes With Elena Ferrante. Sort of.
abstract: The process of publishing an excerpt from the author’s new novel was just as mysterious as the writer herself.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: The Liberty Are Showing Promise, Even in Their Struggle
abstract: The Liberty’s season hasn’t gone as planned, but they have been competitive in several losses, and key players are showing growth.
lead_paragraph: The Liberty’s season wasn’t supposed to start with Sabrina Ionescu, the do-it-all No. 1 draft pick, spraining her ankle in the third game of her W.N.B.A. career. The injury was especially crushing after she had broken out for 33 points, seven rebounds and seven assists against the Dallas Wings just 48 hours earlier. The Liberty’s fans, after consecutive second-to-last-place seasons, had gotten a glimpse of what a potential franchise cornerstone running the offense could look like.

headline: Beirut’s Shiites Like the Idea of Change, but Like Hezbollah More
keywords: ['Beirut, Lebanon, Explosions (2020)', 'Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Shiite Muslims']
abstract: In a Shiite stronghold, people agree that the political system is dysfunctional and needs replacing, but not if that means Hezbollah ceding its power.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Near sunset, squads of young men gather along the narrow roads that lead in and out of their working-class Shiite neighborhood.

headline: Jimmy Fallon Thinks Trump Might Have a Problem With Women
abstract: “At this point, our best shot at Trump attacking Covid is someone telling him the virus ovulates,” Fallon said after the president called Kamala Harris a “mad woman.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Many of us are stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: News Quiz: Kamala Harris, Vaccine, Football
abstract: Did you follow the headlines this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the headlines this week?

headline: South Sea Islanders Don’t Want to Be Forgotten
abstract: In a peaceful city in Queensland, descendants of plantation laborers worry stories of trauma and resilience will be forgotten without efforts to preserve them.
lead_paragraph: The first thing I saw in Mackay was the sun setting over towering fields of sugar cane. I had come to meet Starrett Vea Vea, a South Sea Islander leader with an infectious laugh, and found him with a friend. He was explaining, as he often did, how his ancestors had been lured to Australia, first to plant cotton, then sugar cane.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Wittgenstein and Other Thinkers Dealt With a Decade of Crisis
abstract: Wolfram Eilenberger’s “Time of the Magicians” elegantly traces the life and work of four figures who transformed philosophy in the 1920s.
lead_paragraph: In the autumn of 1922, as Germany was convulsed by food shortages and soaring inflation, the philosopher Martin Heidegger wrote a letter to his wife about the intricate choreography required to secure the most basic needs. “Mother asks if they should send potatoes even before 1 Oct; I answered yes and sent the money at the same time,” he explained. “What should I do when the potatoes arrive?”

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Pesticides, Cancer and Coronavirus
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Find Me’ and ‘The Revisioners’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: HABEN: The Deafblind Woman Who Conquered Harvard Law, by Haben Girma. (Twelve, 288 pp., $16.99.) In this inspiring memoir, Girma recounts her Eritrean-American childhood, her parents’ harrowing refugee experience, her triumph as the first deafblind graduate of Harvard Law School and her career as an advocate fighting for people with disabilities. Along the way, she helps build a school in Mali, develops an innovative text-to-braille communication system, climbs an iceberg in Alaska and meets with President Obama at the White House.

headline: Birds and Horses and Eels, Oh My! New Books About Animals
abstract: Three new books — by Jennifer Ackerman, Sarah Maslin Nir and Patrik Svensson — explore some familiar and some less known members of the animal kingdom.
lead_paragraph: THE BIRD WAYA New Look at How Birds Talk, Work, Play, Parent, and ThinkBy Jennifer Ackerman355 pp. Penguin Press. $28.

headline: Treasure and Turmoil in the Deep Sea
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Water Pollution', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: The growing push to mine the seabed threatens the vast and rich ecosystem between the surface and the seafloor.
lead_paragraph: There is treasure in the sea, and much of it lies in plain view on the deep ocean floor. Fields of metallic nodules and towering hydrothermal chimneys accumulate precious and industrially prized metals, estimated to be worth many billions to even trillions of dollars.

headline: How Young People Can Own Their Health Care (Even if They Still See a Pediatrician)
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Telemedicine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Privacy', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Helping young adults with the skills they need to transition to health care independence — with a bonus script for canceling appointments.
lead_paragraph: Owning your health care is a key life skill for young people, like doing laundry, voting and making ramen — and it’s one you can start learning, even (or especially) while living under your parents’ roof.

headline: The Particular Pain of Pandemic Grief
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Grief (Emotion)', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Families and Family Life', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: I had never told my father I loved him until he lay dying half a world away, body wrecked with coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t thank me, love. It’s just my job.” The nurse’s words were clear, firm, efficient. Just like her, in the two hours I had known her.

headline: Kamala Harris, the Prosecutor Trump Fears Most
abstract: She is the perfect person to build a case against the president.
lead_paragraph: Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, our case today is against the most powerful man in the world. And using the most powerful weapon of government by the people, you can hold this man accountable for the first time in his life, when you pass judgment on Nov. 3.

headline: The Mayor Is Ready for School to Open. The School Buildings Are Not.
abstract: Limited space, broken air-conditioning, windows that don’t work; nothing will be easy about reopening school this fall.
lead_paragraph: Like all New York stories, the drama around the reopening of schools in the city is, in the end, a real estate story. It has the familiar whiplash plot — one that begins with hope and anticipation, is driven by obsession and uncertainty and then leaves you unraveled and scrambling for second- and third-rate solutions.

headline: Two Campaign Reporters Put the Harris Pick in Perspective
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: As part of The Times’s Election 2020 event series, two journalists who have covered Kamala Harris and Joe Biden discussed the presumptive Democratic ticket.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: My Country Is Under Attack
keywords: ['Elections', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Belarusians took to the streets to reclaim their dignity. The government responded with brutal violence.
lead_paragraph: The opposition leader, fearing for her safety and her family, has been forced to flee. Peaceful protests have been met with violence: Hundreds wounded, two dead. People have disappeared into detention, violently pulled off the streets. And every night around 6 p.m., before the most brutal police violence begins, the internet is shut down. Belarus is under attack from its own government.

headline: A Large Coffee and a Marriage Proposal to Go
abstract: Drs. Ariel Schaap and Joshua Heisler, both internists who met as pre-med students 10 years ago, had a small outdoor wedding in Englewood, N.J. Then it was back to work.
lead_paragraph: From the start, Ariel Schaap had cause to believe that Joshua Heisler might benefit from a caffeine infusion.

headline: N.Y.C. Schools Are Set to Open in a Month. Principals Fear That’s Too Soon.
keywords: ['Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'Principals (School)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: School leaders are running up against major obstacles and unanswerable questions ahead of the planned reopening. A large group of principals has called on the mayor to delay in-person instruction.
lead_paragraph: Alexa Sorden, an elementary school principal in the Bronx, has been pacing through the empty hallways of her school, trying to figure out how to make the most consequential school reopening effort in the country actually work.

headline: Business Chiefs Seek N.Y.C. Mayoral Candidate, With $100 Million as Bait
abstract: Stephen Ross, a billionaire developer, and Daniel Doctoroff, a tech executive, are trying to influence the 2021 mayoral race in New York.
lead_paragraph: With less than a year before the Democratic mayoral primary, New York City’s business leaders are actively plotting how best to use their influence and money to shape the race to become Bill de Blasio’s successor.

headline: How 14 Elephant Seals Assisted an Antarctic Ice Study
abstract: Mapping currents in the Southern Ocean is vital to monitoring climate change, but hard to conduct. So scientists turned to seals for help.
lead_paragraph: At the bottom of the planet is the Southern Ocean, its waters cold and roiling and sheathed with ice many months of the year.

headline: How Queer Women Powered the Suffrage Movement
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', "Women's Rights", 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Women and Girls', 'Nineteenth Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: For many suffragists, scholars have found, the freedom to choose whom and how they loved was tied deeply to the idea of voting rights.
lead_paragraph: In 1920, the suffragist Molly Dewson sat down to write a letter of congratulations to Maud Wood Park, who had just been chosen as the first president of the League of Women Voters, formed in anticipation of the passage of the 19th Amendment to help millions of women carry out their newfound right as voters.

headline: State and Local Budget Pain Looms Over Economy’s Future
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Local Government', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Providing more aid to struggling governments has become one of the biggest issues tangling up the debate over another pandemic rescue package.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The U.S. economy struggled to shake off the last recession, with historically slow growth and a labor market that took more than six years to recover its earlier employment levels. A big part of the reason: state and local governments, which cut spending and fired workers amid widespread budget shortfalls.

headline: A Third of TikTok’s U.S. Users May Be 14 or Under, Raising Safety Questions
keywords: ['Social Media', "Children's Online Privacy Protection Act", 'Children and Childhood', 'Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Three current and former employees expressed concerns about the Chinese-owned app’s safeguards for preteen children.
lead_paragraph: If Microsoft or another company buys TikTok before President Trump bans the Chinese-owned video app on national security grounds, it will acquire a giant community of devoted fans and a lucrative platform for selling ads.

headline: Renovating for a New Normal
keywords: ['Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Telecommuting', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'E-Learning', 'Home Schooling', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Working and schooling from home for the foreseeable future has prompted some homeowners to consider major home renovations.
lead_paragraph: Kristen Meehan’s home office is often a brown Adirondack chair on her front lawn, with hedges that make a halfway decent Zoom backdrop.

headline: Nursing Home Families Yearn to Visit Loved Ones Again
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Elderly', 'Nursing Homes', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'your-feed-health', 'Elder Care', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Struck hard by the pandemic, long-term and assisted living facilities shut their doors to outsiders. Many still have not reopened.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Cathy Baum helped both her mother and her mother-in-law move into memory care in an assisted living facility in Reston, Va. Because Ms. Baum lived nearby, she could visit four to five days a week and keep a watchful eye on them.

headline: Families Priced Out of ‘Learning Pods’ Seek Alternatives
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Education (K-12)', 'E-Learning', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Income Inequality', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Should public school systems provide teachers for small-group instruction?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Shy Rodriguez heard about one of the hottest trends in education during the pandemic — “learning pods,” where parents hire teachers for small-group, in-home instruction — she knew immediately it was something she could never afford for her sons.

headline: Shhh! We’re Heading Off on Vacation
abstract: Sharing vacation adventures used to be fun. But during the pandemic, some travelers are content to let the tree fall in the forest, so to speak, without a single soul to hear it.
lead_paragraph: Next month, Elena Gaudino will fly from New York to Las Vegas, rent an S.U.V. and drive to the Grand Canyon, Joshua Tree National Park and other desert destinations. The 10-day road trip stands in for her favorite annual tradition — Burning Man, the Nevada arts festival that was canceled this year because of the pandemic — and gives her something to look forward to after a coronavirus-induced travel dry-spell.

headline: A Century-Old Moving Company Says the Summer of Covid Is ‘Insane’
abstract: 'Point a finger on a map, people are moving there.'

headline: How the World’s Largest Garbage Dump Evolved Into a Green Oasis
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Wetlands', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: The radical fix for a noxious landfill in Staten Island: Bury the trash, plant some grass and do nothing for 20 years.
lead_paragraph: A little less than two decades ago, the last steaming load of garbage arrived at Fresh Kills Landfill. A packed-high barge turned slowly out of the Arthur Kill — that long, dishwater-brown tidal strait that separates Staten Island from New Jersey — and then docked at the Sanitation Department’s pier, an event celebrated less as a matter of ecological stewardship at the time than a triumph of not-in-my-backyard politics.

headline: The Black Lives Next Door
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Discrimination', 'Affordable Housing', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: A new generation of activists is trying to figure out where to concentrate its efforts. Residential desegregation is the final frontier.
lead_paragraph: Last year in San Mateo, Calif., a history teacher at Hillsdale High School conducted a mock hearing of South Africa’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission. Sophia Heath, then a freshman, played an anti-apartheid lawyer. She recalls that she “was really excited and that was the beginning of where my activism started.” On the web, she found Coalition Z, a youth group that registers voters and presses officials to combat climate change, provide more equitable school funding and enact gun control. Ms. Heath started a local chapter.

headline: Black Like Kamala
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Discrimination', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republican efforts to deny Senator Harris’s identity as an African-American and turn her into a noncitizen are destined to fail.
lead_paragraph: It was probably inevitable that becoming Joe Biden’s running mate would result in controversy over Kamala Harris’s heritage.

headline: Tackling a Century-Old Mystery: Did My Grandmother Vote?
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', "Women's Rights", 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Nineteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: Had she, in the throes of segregation and suffrage, cast a hard-won vote? I needed to know.
lead_paragraph: I was looking for my grandmother. That meant spending a warm fall day in a reading room among reference books, microfilm reels and acid-free folders.

headline: America’s Retirement Race Gap, and Ideas for Closing It
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Child Savings Accounts', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Income Inequality', 'Social Security (US)', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Discrimination', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Longevity', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Scholars and policymakers have proposed ways to fix the inequities between whites and people of color, including changes to Social Security and building wealth from birth.
lead_paragraph: The protest movement across the United States this summer has prompted a national conversation about ways to correct the acute economic inequities facing Black and other Americans of color. Those inequities don’t end when people retire.

headline: The Women Who Fought Against the Vote
abstract: To understand the suffragists, and why their battle took so long, you also have to understand the anti-suffragists.
lead_paragraph: The sinking of the Titanic in 1912 inspired a flood of articles on seemingly every aspect of the disaster. One of the oddest appeared in The Woman’s Protest, a journal dedicated to opposing women’s suffrage.

headline: In Prison, Learning Magic by Mail
abstract: A deck of cards cut from milk cartons. A wand made with medical tape. How a group of inmates learned “the magic of magic.”
lead_paragraph: When the magician Kris Nevling was released from prison two years ago, he had been incarcerated for most of his life.

headline: How Kate Pierson, of the B-52’s, and Monica Coleman, Spend Their Sundays
abstract: The couple reopened their 10-cabin lodge in the Catskills in May. They live close by, making music and gardening.
lead_paragraph: “I have been in Phase 1 since March,” said Kate Pierson, an original member of the inimitable new-wave band the B-52’s, who has run Kate’s Lazy Meadow, a rustic, funky getaway in Mount Tremper, New York, with her wife, Monica Coleman, an artist, since 2004. (They also have a sister property in Landers, Calif.)

headline: Fighting for the Vote With Cartoons
keywords: ['Cartoons and Cartoonists', "Women's Rights", 'Voting and Voters', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Cartoonists used the press to battle anti-suffrage stereotypes and create a new image for the movement to enfranchise women.
lead_paragraph: When Alice Paul recruited a cartoonist for her newspaper The Suffragist in 1914, the idea of that activist was already sketched in the public mind — and it was not pretty. Throughout the 19th century and into the 20th, Americans had encountered countless images showing women suffragists as old, mannish and unattractive. In pursuing the vote, women were portrayed as threatening national values, the sanctity of the home and their husbands’ masculinity.

headline: The Japanese Surrender: A Sailor’s Perspective
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: What the end of a long war might have been like for a sailor in Tokyo Bay on Sept. 2, 1945.
lead_paragraph: In remembrance of the day Japan first agreed to surrender, Aug. 15, the latest article from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series by The Times that documents lesser-known stories from the war, is a look back by James Stavridis, a retired United States Navy admiral and former supreme Allied Commander of NATO. He imagines how a sailor anchored in Tokyo Bay might have experienced the official surrender ceremony on Sept. 2.

headline: Welcome to the Covid-19 Mental Health Struggle
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Graphic Novels', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Creativity', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: An artist with schizoaffective disorder shares her strategy for self-care.

headline: Firm Helping Run U.S. Coronavirus Database Refuses Senators’ Questions
abstract: People who recover from the virus have a three-month window of safety, C.D.C. guidance shows. The U.S. Postal Service warned several states that it may not be able to meet deadlines for delivering last-minute mail-in ballots.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Covid-19 news and updates.]

headline: 9/11 Tribute Lights Won’t Be Projected Into Sky This Year
abstract: The decision to cancel the tribute was made because "the health risks during the pandemic were far too great" for the crew of about 40 stagehands and electricians.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: Should Schools in Your County Be Open?
abstract: Enter your location to find out.
lead_paragraph: Enter your location to find out.

headline: Courting Without Clichés
abstract: Ron Bel Bruno and Edward Goldberg, a 50-something couple, connected quickly after meeting online. “It was instant. It was instant. It was instant.”
lead_paragraph: Ron Bel Bruno had at least 27 years of experience with internet dating, he said, when he encountered Dr. Edward Goldberg online in September 2016.

headline: Those Night-Shift Talks Were Easy as Pie
abstract: A cherry-sorting warehouse in Washington State was where they met, but when they decided to be together, it was outside of the other Washington.
lead_paragraph: A windowless, fluorescent-lit warehouse, in Wenatchee, Wash., where millions upon millions of cherries — Bings, Sweethearts, Raniers, Tietons — are sorted and graded and packaged each summer, was where the romance between Corena Sharp and Mark Olson began.

headline: Three Months Later, She Replied
abstract: Rabbi Jennifer Gubitz got Matan BenYishay’s three-month-old message on the dating app JDate after renewing her lapsed membership.
lead_paragraph: After Rabbi Jennifer Anne Gubitz reactivated her lapsed dating app memberships and joined new ones in August 2017, she was intrigued by a three-month-old message on JDate from Matan BenYishay who had the screen name TzedekNerd (tzedek means justice in Hebrew).

headline: He Jogged Back Into Her Life
abstract: They met after college, but their relationship didn’t develop until years later in Washington, after she saw him jogging by the car she was in.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after graduating from college in 2003, Marisol Orihuela and Mark Roland both ended up living in the same Atlanta house that was sponsored by the Jesuit Volunteer Corps, to which both had enlisted for a year of public service.

headline: New Role for a Soap Opera Writer: Husband
abstract: Ron Carlivati, the head writer for a daytime drama, says David Rogal, who he met at a movie theater, prevents his life from becoming a soap opera.
lead_paragraph: While Ron Carlivati has made a career out of writing soap operas, his longtime partner, David Rogal, often prevents Mr. Carlivati’s life from becoming one.

headline: It Might Have Been Called a Carat Cake
abstract: As Kara Maser began slicing a birthday cake her sister made novelty diamond rings tumbled out, and Barry Funt got down on one knee with the real one.
lead_paragraph: When Kara Weiss Maser got Barry Marc Funt’s text in March 2019 out of the blue, she figured it had to do with some community-related activity. Two decades earlier he had lived across the street from her in Livingston, N.J., when they were both married with small children.

headline: Perfectly in Sync During a 35-State Road Trip and a 1,200-Mile Hike
abstract: The couple met at Yale, in an unconventional marching band, and by the time they got to Kansas, years later, they knew they belonged together.
lead_paragraph: The first time Henry Chapman asked out Melinda Becker, an acquaintance at Yale, where both were members of the imprecise and non-marching Yale Precision Marching Band, she was not entirely convinced he was being up front with her.

headline: Two World Travelers Find Love Close to Home
abstract: The many roads traveled by Shana Caro and Georgina Emerson eventually led to each other, via the dating app Hinge, in February 2018.
lead_paragraph: Shana Caro, a 31-year-old scientist at Columbia University who grew up in White Plains, N.Y., has lived in Borneo, Costa Rica, Uganda, Kenya, Oxford, and a tiny town in the Netherlands called Wageningen.

headline: Kingston: A City Remade by the Coronavirus
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Gentrification']
abstract: A writer who moved upstate for a slower lifestyle fears that the latest wave of migrants, fleeing Covid, will bring their worst instincts with them.
lead_paragraph: Kingston, a small city in upstate New York, became my home four and a half years ago. Seeking space, affordability, green, and quiet, my husband and I traded Brooklyn for this city of 23,000. Unwittingly, we joined a slow-drip migration north.

headline: Protesting Her Own Employer
keywords: ['Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Strikes']
abstract: How an assistant apparel designer at Adidas came to lead daily protests against her employer’s handling of race.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: Attracted by Their ‘Intellectual Curiosity’
abstract: Alex Song and Kelly Jean Qu met three years ago just as she was preparing to leave New York. But then she decided to stay.
lead_paragraph: By the time Alex Song said his first hello to Kelly Jean Qu in September 2017, she was saying goodbye to New York, where she had lived for nearly three years, and on the verge of moving back to her native Los Angeles.

headline: He Got Her Attention, but the Guitar Hero Had to Go
abstract: Drs. Chloe Ciccariello and Krishn Khanna, who met at Columbia, got off to a shaky start, but eventually hit it off in chemistry class.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Chloe Ciccariello remembers looking forward to a quiet nap one day in August 2006 at her Columbia dormitory, which was then assigned mostly to freshman engineering students. Suddenly the deafening sounds of electric guitar music outside her door roused her from bed in search of the source.

headline: Trump vs. the Post Office

headline: Somalia’s Army Told Her to Sew a Skirt. Now She’s One of Its Top Officers.
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Lt. Col. Iman Elman, who was born in Somalia but raised in Canada in a family of peace activists, sees herself as continuing that tradition from a different platform.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — When Iman Elman decided to enlist in the Somali National Army in 2011, the officer distributing uniforms gave her one shirt and two pairs of pants. Puzzled, Ms. Elman asked about the missing shirt. There was none, he said. The extra set of pants was provided for her to sew into a skirt.

headline: The Undertold, Undersold Story of Kamala Harris
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Women and Girls', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: As a prosecutor she can make you tremble. But as a trailblazer can she make you cry?
lead_paragraph: When I saw on Wednesday morning that Kamala Harris had released a short video marking and celebrating her selection as Joe Biden’s running mate, I clicked — eagerly and instantly. I wanted to continue riding my wave of excitement about all the firsts: first woman of color on a major party’s presidential ticket, first Black woman specifically, first Asian-American.

headline: For Palestinians, Israel-U.A.E. Deal Swaps One Nightmare for Another
abstract: With annexation of the West Bank off the table and Arab diplomacy turned inside out, the Palestinian struggle, once focused against Israel, now is to remain relevant.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When the unmarked United Arab Emirates plane touched down on the tarmac in Tel Aviv one night in May carrying 16 tons of unsolicited medical aid for the Palestinians, it was rejected by the Palestinian leadership, which said that nobody had coordinated with them about the shipment.

headline: ‘This Is Unforgivable’: Anger Mounts Over Mauritius Oil Spill

headline: Trump revives a racist conspiracy theory against Harris.
abstract: President Trump on Thursday encouraged a racist conspiracy theory that is rampant among some of his followers: that Senator Kamala Harris is not eligible for the vice presidency or presidency because her parents were immigrants.

headline: Who from California would replace Kamala Harris in the Senate?
abstract: If Mr. Biden is elected president, Ms. Harris’s rise will leave an opening in January for her seat in the Senate representing California. That pick will be made by Gov. Gavin Newsom, a Democrat, and it stands to be consequential for both the sprawling state and the nation.

headline: Dozens Are Feared Dead in Nepal Landslide
abstract: Eleven bodies were recovered and 27 people were still missing. Some of the homes lost had been rebuilt after Nepal’s devastating 2015 quake.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — A landslide caused in part by unusually heavy rain in a district of Nepal bordering China buried dozens of homes early Friday, killing at least 11 people and leaving 27 others missing, officials said.

She was immediately enthralled by the landscape — undulating meadows dotted with methane pipes — and also the strange stillness of the air.

headline: There’s nothing normal about back-to-school sales this year.

abstract: The estate of Robby Browne, a top real estate broker who died of Covid-19, is selling his Central Park West condo, where celebrities and friends once mingled.

headline: The Bubble Bursts for Gregg Popovich and the Spurs

lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Criticizing the leadership of President Trump is a longstanding practice for Gregg Popovich. You almost expect it by now when the coach of the San Antonio Spurs gives an interview.

headline: It’s Always the Summer of the Shark
keywords: ['Sharks', 'Animal Behavior', 'Surfing', 'Swimming', 'Beaches', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: Even during a pandemic, we cannot get the white shark out of our minds. Despite the rare attack, experts say humans have little to fear.
lead_paragraph: The shark rested on its back, its jaws parted in ecstasy, punch-drunk after feasting on a whale carcass off the coast of Nantucket, in Massachusetts.

headline: How to Add More Play to Your Grown-Up Life, Even Now
abstract: Play can feel silly, unproductive and time consuming. And that’s precisely the point.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s play!” my friend’s 4-year-old squealed, tugging on my arm. I was tired, so I told her, “I’m too lazy to play.” But I wasn’t allowed to be lazy because I’m big, she said. Unable to come up with a convincing rebuttal, I found a place to hide while she counted to 20. Fred Rogers said that play is “the work of childhood.” Kids take this work seriously, they’re good at it, and they can teach us a thing or two about why play is important — especially now.

headline: Michael Cohen releases details about his forthcoming memoir.
abstract: Several unflattering memoirs about President Trump have come out this summer, but one potentially damaging book remains on the horizon: “Disloyal,” by Michael D. Cohen, his former fixer and lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Several unflattering memoirs about President Trump have come out this summer, but one potentially damaging book remains on the horizon: “Disloyal,” by Michael D. Cohen, his former fixer and lawyer.

headline: Luchita Hurtado, Artist Who Became a Sensation in Her 90s, Dies at 99
abstract: For years she worked in the shadow of her artist husbands and more famous peers, painting at night when the children were asleep. Then a trove of her work was discovered.
lead_paragraph: Luchita Hurtado, an artist whose paintings and drawings emphasized the interconnectedness of all living things with a visionary intensity that was almost shamanic, but whose work was recognized by the art world only late in her life, died on Thursday night at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 99.

headline: For Mom in South Korea, Sending a Child Back to School Was Worth the Risk
abstract: The safety measures in place, like glass partitions and reduced classroom sizes, eased her worries. Plus, Korean children “are even more obsessed about wearing masks than adults,” she said.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — I decided to send my 8-year-old daughter back to school in late May because I figured we might as well adapt to the new normal rather than run away from the coronavirus out of fear. It doesn’t look as if the virus will go away anytime soon, and I wanted my daughter, Tae-yeon, to quickly acclimate to the changed environment rather than being severed from school life after finishing just first grade last year.

headline: Taking the Edinburgh Fringe’s Madcap Energy Online
abstract: For the first time in its 73-year history, the hugely influential festival is canceled. Devoted fans and theater makers are finding ways to keep the spirit alive.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — David Chapple began planning his trip to the 2020 Edinburgh Festival Fringe a year ago, since you can’t be too prepared when you hold the world record for the most Fringe performances attended in one season.

headline: Taking Hard Line, Greece Turns Back Migrants by Abandoning Them at Sea
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Many Greeks have grown frustrated as tens of thousands of asylum seekers languished on Greek islands. Now, evidence shows, a new conservative government has a new method of keeping them out.
lead_paragraph: RHODES, Greece — The Greek government has secretly expelled more than 1,000 refugees from Europe’s borders in recent months, sailing many of them to the edge of Greek territorial waters and then abandoning them in inflatable and sometimes overburdened life rafts.

lead_paragraph: One afternoon in June, the artist Sanford Biggers, having returned to the city after a stretch bunkered out of town with his wife and young daughter to avoid the pandemic, opened up his expansive basement studio in Harlem for a socially-distanced visit.

headline: ‘We’ve Already Survived an Apocalypse’: Indigenous Writers Are Changing Sci-Fi
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Science Fiction', 'Indigenous People', 'Native Americans', 'Navajo Indians', 'APACHE INDIANS']
abstract: Long underrepresented in genre fiction, Native American and First Nations authors are reshaping its otherworldly (but still often Eurocentric) worlds.
lead_paragraph: When Cherie Dimaline was growing up near Penetanguishene, a small town on the Georgian Bay in Ontario, her grandmother and great-aunts told her stories about a werewolf-like monster called the rogarou. It wasn’t spoken of as a mythical creature but as an actual threat, the embodiment of danger in a place where Indigenous women face heightened risk of violence.

headline: A Black Marxist Scholar Wanted to Talk About Race. It Ignited a Fury.
abstract: The cancellation of a speech reflects an intense debate on the left: Is racism the primary problem in America today, or the outgrowth of a system that oppresses all poor people?
lead_paragraph: Adolph Reed is a son of the segregated South, a native of New Orleans who organized poor Black people and antiwar soldiers in the late 1960s and became a leading Socialist scholar at a trio of top universities.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Dorie Greenspan’s latest, raspberry ice cream and magic-shell chocolate sauce, and more summery recipes for the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Dorie Greenspan is back in The Times this week with a fantastic recipe for raspberry ice cream and magic-shell chocolate sauce (above) that I think you may want to use as the foundation for your weekend cooking plans. Dorie being Dorie, which is to say a much better maker of desserts than your average person, the ice cream recipe is slightly different from ones that you may have used before.

lead_paragraph: ZURICH — Like many parents in the United States, I am nervous about what will happen when schools reopen on Monday. The only difference is that here, in Switzerland, we already experienced what it was like to send our children back to school, in the spring.

headline: McConnell Appears Set to Quietly Suffocate Long-Debated F.B.I. Surveillance Bill
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Law and Legislation', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Terrorism', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: The Senate majority leader has long been a strong supporter of extending Patriot Act provisions. This year, he’s letting them remain lapsed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Every few years since Congress passed the Patriot Act to bolster F.B.I. surveillance powers after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, parts of it came up for renewal and national security hawks darkly warned that even briefly letting them lapse would unacceptably endanger America.

keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Strikes', 'Factories and Manufacturing']

lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — The popular uprising against President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus entered a new phase on Friday as protests spread at the state-run factories at the core of his political base.

headline: A Bee, or Not a Bee?
abstract: There are about 4,000 bee species in the U.S, but many other insects sport their telltale patterns. Here’s how to spot some of these clever mimics.
lead_paragraph: There are about 4,000 bee species in the U.S, but many other insects sport their telltale patterns. Here’s how to spot some of these clever mimics.

headline: How the Battle for Women’s Suffrage Played Out in the Pages of the Book Review
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Nineteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Books and Literature', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: What did our critics think of the histories, memoirs and novels that explored the road to the 19th Amendment?
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 18, 1920, the 19th amendment was ratified, marking a pivotal moment in the fight for women's rights. This centennial has provided myriad opportunities to reflect on the amendment’s legacy — from the newfound parity the vote represented to the sidelining and enduring disenfranchisement faced by women of color. Even before the amendment’s passage, debates about the women’s movement were taking place in the pages of the Book Review. Women’s history and early feminist thought were newly available to readers as writers attempted to understand the “new woman” and her goals. In these archival pieces, reviewers consider the merits of suffrage literature — and occasionally, of suffrage itself.

headline: When Lamb Chops Met Romaine
abstract: The combination of grilled lamb chops, crisp romaine lettuce hearts and creamy ranch dressing is almost a salad, but not quite.
lead_paragraph: There are some summer evenings so steamy that the only thing I can bear to eat is a giant bowl of leafy salad. And this whole month of August has been full of those kinds of nights, one sticky sunset after the next.

headline: Get Inspired
abstract: Try something new this week like yakitori-style salmon or a mafe-inspired tofu dish.
lead_paragraph: Hi! And welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. What day is it again? Oh, right. It’s Friday. Happy Friday! (Does T.G.I.F. mean anything to anyone anymore?) If your life is like mine right now, each day blends into the next. I wake, I drink coffee, I make what feels like 463 meals, I send approximately 1,232 emails, I break up 56 fights between my kids, then I collapse into bed and sleep. Rinse and repeat.

headline: Museums and Other New York Cultural Institutions Can Open Aug. 24
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said that museums would be allowed to open at 25 percent capacity and with timed ticketing in place.
lead_paragraph: Museums and other cultural institutions will be allowed to open in New York City starting on Aug. 24, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Friday, following five months of a pandemic shutdown that has resulted in substantial layoffs and financial crises for many of these organizations.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Black activists in Chicago. Retail in Manhattan. An elephant’s pandemic journey. Bike shorts. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. This week, we had major news in the U.S. presidential race: Joe Biden’s selection of Sen. Kamala Harris as his running mate. As we get closer to the fall, the election season is intensifying, and it will continue to do so over the next two weeks with the Democratic and Republican conventions. So before all of that starts, try to take a break from the news cycle. Maybe make some homemade ice cream. Or enjoy a bit of moth-watching. But still make time for some incredible journalism.

headline: A Space for Black Dance Artists to Create in the Hudson Valley
abstract: New Dance Alliance announces a residency program and its first three recipients: Angie Pittman, Johnnie Cruise Mercer and Leslie Cuyjet.
lead_paragraph: When the staff, leadership and advisory committee of the New Dance Alliance gathered to draft a letter in support of the Black Lives Matter movement, the group soon realized that words wouldn’t be enough to demonstrate the organization’s commitment to racial justice. “It became really apparent to us that, unless we were backing it up programmatically, whatever we were writing was hollow,” Fernando Maneca, the president of the Dance Alliance’s board, said in an interview.

headline: Julian Bream, Maestro of Guitar and Lute, Dies at 87
abstract: It could be argued that he, even more than Andrés Segovia, established the guitar’s credibility as a serious solo instrument.
lead_paragraph: Julian Bream, the English musician who pushed the guitar beyond its Spanish roots and expanded its range by commissioning dozens of works from major composers, and who also played a crucial role in reviving the lute as a modern concert instrument, died on Friday at his home in Wiltshire, England. He was 87.

headline: Parents, Students and Teachers Give Britain a Failing Grade Over Exam Results
abstract: All-important “A-level” tests that determine college placement were canceled this year. In their place, officials designed a complex system of estimated grades that many say treats the disadvantaged unfairly.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of teenagers in England tore open envelopes this week bearing the results of their A-levels, comprehensive exams that are supposed to assess the quality of their secondary education and serve as a barometer for college entrance.

headline: Obesity Raises the Risk of Death From Covid-19 Among Men
abstract: Obesity is not an independent risk for women, according to a new study, perhaps because their fat is distributed differently.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has been an unpredictable foe from the start. It triggers silent or barely perceptible infections in some individuals, while in others it sets off a cascade of complications that overwhelm the body and lead to death.

headline: ‘Ted Lasso’ Review: Jason Sudeikis as America’s Nicest Export
abstract: A fish-out-of-water sports comedy on Apple TV+ takes folksiness to a new level of sophistication.
lead_paragraph: You could hear that the new Apple TV+ sitcom “Ted Lasso” is based on a pair of one-joke video promos, made for NBC Sports, and have a “What is the world coming to?” moment. But that would just mean you had forgotten about “Cavemen” (2007), based on a series of Geico ads, or “Hey Vern, It’s Ernest” (1988), an outgrowth of local spots featuring the supremely annoying Ernest P. Worrell.

headline: Outdoor Medicine for the Play-Starved Soul
abstract: Pairing Molière and Millay for a socially distanced audience, Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey offers light entertainment just when we need it.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The emailed instructions from the box office tell you to put on your mask before you even get out of your car.

headline: Eusebio Leal Spengler, Who Restored Old Havana, Dies at 77
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'World Heritage Sites']
abstract: His decades-long effort to preserve a capital’s colonial buildings turned a former slum into a tourist destination and capitalist success story.
lead_paragraph: Eusebio Leal Spengler, who led an effort to preserve Old Havana, transforming that historic district from a forgotten slum into an architectural jewel and tourist destination, died on July 31 in Havana. He was 77.

headline: Love Letter: A Prescription for Despair
abstract: Plus: Mending a deflated marriage.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all had moments in our lives when we’ve felt like there was absolutely nothing that could turn our luck around. For Naomie Brinvilus, a writer from Haiti, that moment came after her country’s devastating 2010 earthquake, which left her family homeless and hungry. Feeling desperate, she sought help from a spiritual guide. His prescription of a wooden spoon, green onion, a young rooster and other talismans would not only bring her into a promised season of good fortune, it would also lead her to find love with a handsome stranger in the most unlikely of places — a cholera treatment center.

headline: Trump’s Campaign (Against the Post Office)
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers discuss President Trump’s claims that voting by mail leads to fraud and suggest ways to ensure that all votes get counted.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Summer Lunch That Feels Like a Splurge
abstract: A lobster salad doesn’t have to be relegated to special occasions, David Tanis argues.
lead_paragraph: A pandemic has many downsides. And the lobster industry is among the many sectors it’s taken a toll on.

headline: Plucky Characters? Ugh. Make Mine Prickly and Difficult.
abstract: Marilyn Stasio finds much to like in the latest batch of crime novels, filled with abrasive, unpleasant sorts.
lead_paragraph: Plucky heroines make me queasy. (It takes so much energy to be plucky.) The protagonist of Katie Tallo’s first novel, DARK AUGUST (HarperCollins, 448 pp., paper; $16.99), is better than that. Augusta (Gus) Monet is smart and resourceful, just too stubborn to know when to quit. When she returns to her hometown — Elgin, Ontario, “a town that once was but is no more” — her instinct is to burn it down. But “greed and spite and toxic wastewater” from fracking have taken care of that already. So her only business here is to claim the house (and the old dog who comes with it) left to her by her great-grandmother.

headline: Military Families Have Been Voting by Mail for Decades
keywords: ['Absentee Voting', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)']

lead_paragraph: Politically, we don’t agree on much. One of us is a libertarian-leaning conservative, and the other a left-leaning progressive.

headline: Hitting the Glass Ceiling, Suddenly, at Pinterest
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Start-ups', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Ben Silbermann, the C.E.O., had few answers to allegations that the social media company has a culture of discrimination.
lead_paragraph: The stories of gender exclusion I heard this week from women working at Pinterest and their former colleagues were numbingly similar, with most using the same words over and over again: Sidelined. Shut down. Doors closed. Inner circles. Toxic secrecy. Homegrown boys club. Left out of meetings. Out of key decisions. Out of promotions. Out.

headline: Principal in Holocaust Dispute Shouldn’t Have Been Fired, Judge Rules
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Principals (School)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The Palm Beach County, Fla., school board fired the principal, William Latson, after an email exchange with a parent about Holocaust education came to light.
lead_paragraph: A high school principal in Florida who refused to say that the Holocaust was “a factual, historical event” because he had to stay “politically neutral” should not have been fired, a judge ruled on Thursday.

headline: Polish Cleric Retires in Face of Cover-Up Accusations. It’s Not Enough, Critics Say.
abstract: Pope Francis accepted the resignation of Archbishop Slawoj Leszek Glodz of Poland, a move seen as a subtle rebuke. But far more is needed to address the abuse of children by priests, advocates say.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis this week accepted the resignation of the archbishop of Gdansk, Poland, who has been accused of protecting priests facing allegations of child abuse, a step seen as a subtle rebuke but also criticized as inadequate.

headline: Pleasantly Bitter and Thoroughly Grown-Up, No Alcohol Needed
keywords: ['Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: A new crop of booze-free beverages brings dimension and depth to the genre.
lead_paragraph: Are Zoom happy hours still the way to “go out,” five months after Covid-19 locked much of the country indoors? Most nondrinkers probably wouldn’t be able to say. It gets tiresome watching friends slowly sip on whiskey after their Collins glasses of sparkling water have gone empty. Eventually, nondrinkers bow out.

headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Silent Witness’
abstract: Amid the real-life terrors of a pandemic, the writer takes solace in this long-running British crime series, which may be the only TV drama whose title character is a corpse.
lead_paragraph: It may sound perverse, if not masochistic, to say that I’ve spent weeks of quarantine watching autopsies. But these procedures have been the ultimate escape: Taking place in a distant, fictional environment, they usually involve an agent of death that isn’t a volatile, out-of-control virus but a volatile, out-of-control human being. (At least a relentless person’s range is limited.)

headline: Older Children and the Coronavirus: A New Wrinkle in the Debate
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Age, Chronological', 'Research', 'Contact Tracing (Public Health)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Education (K-12)', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: A new report from South Korea throws into question an earlier finding regarding transmission by older children.
lead_paragraph: A study by researchers in South Korea last month suggested that children between the ages of 10 and 19 spread the coronavirus more frequently than adults — a widely reported finding that influenced the debate about the risks of reopening schools.

headline: For Clint Frazier, Another Chance to Prove He Belongs in the Bronx
abstract: For years, the young outfielder has been too flawed to play full-time but too talented to trade away. Now, a series of Yankees injuries has given him a fresh chance to make his mark.
lead_paragraph: Two days after making his first-ever opening day roster at age 25, Clint Frazier was demoted. The Yankees removed him from their active roster and sent him to their alternate site in Pennsylvania, a new feature for the 2020 season for reserve players to stay fresh.

headline: Retail Sales Rise for Third Month, Though Growth Slows
abstract: The increase was a sign that consumerism remained resilient, but the recovery has been buoyed by government assistance that expired at the end of July.
lead_paragraph: Even as coronavirus infections continued to spread, in-person school reopening plans were scrapped and unemployment stayed near record highs, Americans kept shopping in July with retail sales rising 1.2 percent from June, reflecting a rare bright spot in the battered economy.

headline: Why ‘Cancel Culture’ Is a Distraction
abstract: A reporter’s last thoughts before putting the phrase to rest.
lead_paragraph: I made a promise to myself. Having had the privilege of appearing on “The Daily,” and having used that privilege to discuss “cancel culture” over the course of not one, but two episodes, I would not write about the phrase ever again.

headline: How to Have a Date Night at Home
abstract: Start with steak Diane for two.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. The weekend is upon us again, though for many it’ll be no different from the other days that we pass by like towns off the interstate, long-haul truckers driving endlessly through the night. It’s hard to distinguish between them when we spend so much time in the same space at home, working or not working, screening or not screening, marking or not marking the time. Everything looks like blacktop.

headline: California’s Ban on High-Capacity Magazines Violates the Second Amendment, Court Rules
abstract: Supporters of tougher gun laws called the ruling a dangerous infringement on the ability of states to protect their residents from mass shootings.
lead_paragraph: California’s ban on high-capacity magazines violates the right to bear arms under the Second Amendment, a federal appeals court ruled on Friday.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Hollywood film production is restarting with elaborate precautions to protect the cast and crew.
lead_paragraph: After a five-month hiatus, Hollywood film production has returned. But you won’t find cast and crew members in Los Angeles County, where coronavirus cases remain high and testing is scarce. Instead, studios are shooting overseas, bringing numerous safety protocols with them. Among the first test cases is Universal’s “Jurassic World: Dominion,” which has become a model for moviemaking in the Covid-19 era.

headline: Expecting at the National Zoo: Washington Hopes to Gain a Baby Panda
abstract: Mei Xiang, a 22-year-old giant panda, has “tissue consistent with fetal development” and could deliver in a few days, according to the zoo.
lead_paragraph: The number of pandas at the Smithsonian National Zoo might grow by one in just a few days, officials announced on Friday: Mei Xiang appears to be pregnant.

headline: In Diplomatic Doubleheader, U.S. Seizes Iranian Fuel From Ships Headed to Venezuela
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The high-seas handover blocked two diplomatic adversaries from evading American economic sanctions. Iran denied it was its fuel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has seized more than 1.1 million barrels of Iranian fuel that was headed to Venezuela, officials said on Friday, in a high-seas handover that blocked two diplomatic adversaries from evading American economic sanctions.

headline: Bayern 8, Barcelona 2. The End.
abstract: A thrashing in the Champions League quarterfinals showed Bayern Munich at the peak of its powers and Barcelona at the end of the line.
lead_paragraph: Lionel Messi turned his back. He had given the ball away, but he made no effort to atone for his error, no attempt to regain control. He stopped, waited a beat, and then looked to the other end of the field. It was as if he knew what was going to happen, and he did not care — or could not bear — to watch.

headline: How Apple’s 30% App Store Cut Became a Boon and a Headache
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'E-Commerce', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Twelve years ago, Apple introduced the App Store, a peculiar online marketplace for the year-old iPhone. It had 500 offerings. Apple told app makers it would take a 30 percent cut of their sales, and few complained.

keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Social Media', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Women and Girls', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Executive Compensation', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks']

On Friday, 236 employees of Pinterest, a company known for its virtual pinboards, expressed solidarity on an internal chat app with three former co-workers who have accused the company of racial and sex discrimination and retaliation.

keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Arms Trade']

lead_paragraph: The United States suffered an embarrassing diplomatic defeat on Friday when the United Nations Security Council rejected a proposal to indefinitely extend an arms embargo on Iran, with even America’s strongest allies refusing to buckle under pressure from the Trump administration to take a harder line.

headline: Canadiens Even Series With an Emotional Rout of the Flyers
abstract: Montreal’s coach, Claude Julien, had emergency heart surgery after losing Game 1 of their first-round series against Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Kirk Muller, behind the Montreal Canadiens bench as interim head coach on Friday, was too emotional to check his phone between periods, although he had been expecting a text or two.

headline: The Unlikely Triumph of Italian Nationhood
abstract: Italy coheres as America breaks apart.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MARGHERITA, Italy — In Italy there are seasons — and then there is the season. Summer comes, the country’s woes are set aside, and, to the eternal refrain of “tutti al mare” (“Everyone to the sea”), the exodus to the consoling coast begins. The national debt fades between sea and stars.

headline: Justice Dept. Says Yale Discriminates. Here’s What Students Think.

lead_paragraph: When Siddarth Shankar applied to Yale in 2017, he did not hesitate to identify himself as Asian-American, and wrote about how visiting family members in conflict-ridden Kashmir had shaped his worldview.

lead_paragraph: Billy Goldenberg, an Emmy-winning composer who worked with Barbra Streisand and Elvis Presley, scored Steven Spielberg’s early work and wrote the theme music for more than a dozen television series, has died at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: When Trump Calls a Black Woman ‘Angry,’ He Feeds This Racist Trope
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']

lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris may become the first Black woman elected as vice president, but for now she’s still being slotted into a well-worn mold, as President Trump and his allies seek to cast her as “a mad woman.”

headline: Looking Behind Trump’s Latest Attack on Canada’s Aluminum Exports
abstract: We spoke with an economist in Washington about the U.S. president’s latest trade salvo against his neighboring trade partner.
lead_paragraph: That didn’t take long. The new trade deal between Canada, the United States and Mexico was barely a month old when President Trump, during a tour of a Whirlpool appliance factory, announced that he’d again placed tariffs on aluminum from Canada.

keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
