headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Girl in Black and White’ and ‘Know My Name’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: THE WORLD DOESN’T REQUIRE YOU: Stories, by Rion Amilcar Scott. (Liveright, 320 pp., $16.95.) Scott sets this collection, like his first, in a fictional, mostly black utopian community founded after “the only successful slave revolt in the nation’s history.” An “impressive myth-slayer,” our reviewer, Salamishah Tillet, wrote, he shows that “sidelining” white racist characters doesn’t erase the effects of slavery.

headline: Quarantine and Travel: Strict Penalties, Rare Enforcement
abstract: As quarantine requirements for travelers have become increasingly common throughout the United States, the prevailing theme is the difficulty of effective enforcement.
lead_paragraph: Mika Salamanca’s mug shot is a departure from most of the images you’ll find of her online, particularly the ones she posts on Instagram to her 1 million-plus followers — winsome selfies and playful portraits with her head cocked to the side. But in the photograph released by the Honolulu Police Department, Ms. Salamanca, a social media influencer from the Philippines, stares directly into the camera, her expression inscrutable.

headline: How the ‘Useful Idiots’ of Liberal New York Fueled Income Inequality
abstract: Kurt Andersen, founder of Spy magazine and the author of “Evil Geniuses,” on how affluent lefties slept through the escalating inequality crisis. Including him.
lead_paragraph: In his new best-selling book, “Evil Geniuses: The Unmaking of America: A Recent History,’’ the author and cultural critic Kurt Andersen performs a deep excavation of the country’s inequality crisis. He finds the roots not only in the balance-tilting schemes of Wall Street and the champions of right-wing political economics but also in the obliviousness of the liberal professional class.

headline: What Pro Wrestling Taught Me and My Immigrant Grandmother
abstract: Fists in the air, my tiny Taiwanese grandmother delighted in the sequins and showmanship of WrestleMania stars.
lead_paragraph: “Your grandmother would’ve loved The Rock,” said my husband, Brendan, as he turned on “The Titan Games,” and I sank into our living room couch.

headline: The Voices Missing From the Convention
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: Democratic elites marginalized two of the most popular Latino politicians during the convention.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention featured not only a slate of the party’s heavyweights, but also several prominent Republicans. Missing from the lineup? Prominent progressive Latinos.

headline: Senators Lead an Increasingly Diverse Nation. Their Top Aides Are Mostly White.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Minorities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: A new study shows that 11 percent of top aides shaping policy and public messaging in senators’ Washington offices are people of color, compared with almost 40 percent of the American populace.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As senators chart a response to a deadly pandemic and an economic crisis that have disproportionately hurt Black Americans and other people of color, the top aides leading their offices are overwhelmingly white — far more so than the country as a whole.

headline: Joe Biden: The Anti-Chaos Candidate
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former vice president’s unifying impulses were on full display, even at the risk of annoying his party’s progressive wing.
lead_paragraph: Given the givens, it wasn’t a half-bad nominating party for Joe Biden and Kamala Harris.

headline: With the Speech of His Life, Joe Biden Becomes the Man for This Moment
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: A country in pain gets a lesson in perseverance.
lead_paragraph: Let’s be honest. One of the big questions attending Joe Biden’s big speech at the Democratic National Convention was whether he still had enough gas and enough grip to get to the end of it without losing velocity or swerving this way and that.

headline: Lang Lang, Piano Thunderer, Greets Bach’s Austere ‘Goldbergs’
abstract: For 20 years, the superstar pianist resisted playing this towering work in public. Now he’s releasing not one recording of it, but two.
lead_paragraph: Habits are hard to break. That’s one reason people are still asking “How’s it going?” during a world-upending pandemic. A similarly reflexive “Fine” often follows, which is why it was so jarring when, during a recent interview, the pianist Lang Lang responded with a wince and shouted: “It’s horrible!”

headline: Tennis’s Most Ambitious Doubleheader in Years Is Underway
abstract: Two players withdrew from the first New York event, the Western & Southern Open, after their fitness trainer tested positive for the virus, but the main draw starts Saturday for the U.S. Open’s precursor.
lead_paragraph: When the Western & Southern Open begins in the northeasterly location of Queens on Saturday, it will be the first part of the most significant tennis doubleheader since the 2012 Wimbledon tournament and the Olympic tennis competition were played on the same well-tended grass courts of the All England Club.

headline: How a Free Meals Power Broker Spends His Sundays
abstract: For years, Winston Chiu has been committed to eliminating food waste and hunger. The pandemic has made his job a lot harder.
lead_paragraph: Before the coronavirus outbreak, Winston Chiu, a co-founder of the Brooklyn-based nonprofit Rethink, helped his organization collect leftover food from corporate kitchens, restaurants and grocery stores. The food would then be repurposed into free, healthy meals and given to other organizations to distribute to the hungry.

headline: The Chick’s in the Mail? Rural America Faces New Worries With Postal Crisis
keywords: ['Rural Areas', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Absentee Voting', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The Postal Service is crucial to farmers and rural areas that President Trump won in 2016. Now, residents worry it is being dismantled.
lead_paragraph: Rhiannon Hampson thought she would hear a cacophony of cheeping when she went to her post office in coastal Maine to fetch a delivery of newly hatched chicks. But the cardboard boxes addressed to her poultry farm were silent.

headline: A Detailed Look at the Downside of California’s Ban on Affirmative Action
abstract: Ending racial preferences in a state university system harmed Black and Hispanic students while doing little to lift whites and Asian-Americans, a study asserts.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-four years ago, California was consumed by debate over affirmative action. A charismatic Black businessman named Ward Connerly led support for Proposition 209, a ballot initiative to ban racial preferences in admission to the state’s world-renowned public universities. The measure passed with 55 percent of the vote and inspired similar changes in nearly a dozen other states.

headline: I’ve Been to Every Convention Since ’88. Here’s What’s Missing This Year.
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: What is American politics without a bit of schmoozing?
lead_paragraph: I’ve attended every convention since 1988, when Michael J. Dukakis accepted the Democratic presidential nomination. That year, as I exited Atlanta’s rapidly emptying Omni Coliseum after the balloons had dropped, I stopped to chat with a prominent Southern Democratic senator. He was all smiles, sure that the party’s four days of festivities would lead to Mr. Dukakis beating George H.W. Bush. Like thousands of other Democrats in attendance, he thought it was in the bag.

headline: Witnessing Pandemic New York, With an Ear to the Past
abstract: The Times photographer Todd Heisler has crisscrossed New York City during the pandemic. A new project combines the images he captured with audio from before the virus quieted the city.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Goldman Sachs Has Money. It Has Power. And Now It Has a Font
abstract: The custom-made Goldman Sans is ‘neutral, with a wink’ — or boring and derivative, according to fontheads.
lead_paragraph: There are so few ways to express yourself when you’re Goldman Sachs. Sure, you can commission a 10-part documentary series about your company’s history, and your chief executive can moonlight as a D.J. in the Hamptons. But how do you let the masses know what it’s like to really be you, the bank, in your everyday functions, processing financial spreadsheets and taking companies public?

headline: Reading Elena Ferrante in English? You’re Also Reading Ann Goldstein
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Italian Language', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Language and Languages']

lead_paragraph: Millions of readers in thrall to Elena Ferrante, the secretive and wildly popular Italian novelist, must accept certain conditions.

headline: Watch the Four Moments That Mattered on the Fourth Night of the D.N.C.
abstract: Two of our correspondents break down highlights from the Democrats’ first virtual convention.
lead_paragraph: Adam: Wow. OK, so much to say. First, we’re going to get to Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s speech in depth for sure, but that was quite a moment. A lot of people were worried that the convention would overshadow the party’s 77-year-old candidate; Barack Obama, the roll call, Michelle Obama. But these four virtual days will — I would wager — be remembered for a long time because of the speech that Mr. Biden gave. If there was a room, I suspect he would have blown it away.

headline: The Solar System Winked
keywords: ['Stars and Galaxies', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Ilana Ozernoy and Nina Mouritzen, both immigrants who moved to New York the same year, believe that they were always destined to meet.
lead_paragraph: When Ilana Ozernoy was a young girl growing up in the Soviet Union, her father, Leonid Ozernoy, a prominent astrophysicist in Moscow, bought her a telescope.

headline: How White Progressives Undermine School Integration
abstract: A robust body of research shows the benefits of integration. Why, then, is it so hard to achieve?
lead_paragraph: New York City, one of the most demographically diverse places on the planet, is also home to one of the most segregated school districts in America. That contrast has rattled New York’s self-image and given rise to major integration efforts over the past several years. Most have failed. And across America, desegregation has never been tried at scale, partly because of resistance from white liberals.

headline: Remembering Katrina and Its Unlearned Lessons, 15 Years On
keywords: ['Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Levees and Dams', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: There’ve been so many storms — literal, cultural and political — since the hurricane hit New Orleans. But for the sake of all cities, we can’t forget it.
lead_paragraph: Early in the evening on Aug. 25, 2005, Hurricane Katrina made landfall in Florida. A modest Category 1 storm, with top winds of only about 90 miles per hour, it passed just north of Miami, then lumbered across the Everglades toward the warm waters of the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: We Have Crossed the Line Debt Hawks Warned Us About for Decades
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'National Debt (US)', 'Government Bonds', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Interest Rates', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The debt of the United States now exceeds the size of its gross domestic product. That was considered a doomsday scenario that would wreck the economy. So far, that hasn’t happened.
lead_paragraph: Economists and deficit hawks have warned for decades that the United States was borrowing too much money. The federal debt was ballooning so fast, they said, that economic ruin was inevitable: Interest rates would skyrocket, taxes would rise and inflation would probably run wild.

headline: The Hottest Commodity in Pandemic New York? Fresh Air
abstract: The skyscrapers are empty, and the streets and parks are full. Here’s how the city is reinventing itself.
lead_paragraph: By late summer, New Yorkers are usually feeling grateful for the air-conditioned offices, gyms, restaurants, community centers, theaters and museums that abound in this vertical city.

headline: Live Like a Star
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)']
abstract: Short-term rentals around the country offer connections to the rich and famous, including the likes of Frank Sinatra, Bob Dylan and Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald.
lead_paragraph: Short-term rentals around the country offer connections to the rich and famous, including the likes of Frank Sinatra, Bob Dylan and Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald.

headline: Frank Sinatra Slept Here, and So Can You
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Celebrities']
abstract: In New York and across the country, the former homes of famous writers, musicians and film stars are available as short-term rentals.
lead_paragraph: For an evening to a month at a time, at prices ranging from about $70 to $4,200 a night, online rental platforms offer anyone a chance to live in places where legends like F. Scott Fitzgerald, John Steinbeck and Frank Sinatra once lived.

headline: Democratic Convention: Best and Worst Moments From Joe Biden’s Big Night
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Stuttering', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Disabilities']
abstract: Our columnists and contributors give their rankings.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for the closing night of the Democratic National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rank the evening on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the night was a disaster for Democrats; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump for Biden-Harris. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which highlighted Joe Biden, Senator Cory Booker, Senator Tammy Duckworth and one very charming 13-year-old.

headline: Who Could Forget That Smile?
abstract: Eight years after first meeting, Cianni Pitt-Matthews resurfaced at Shanavia Thomas’s workplace.
lead_paragraph: Shanavia Thomas, a 29-year-old insurance claims adviser, was working in Hamilton, N.J., on a summer day in 2017 when, she said, a familiar smile “just lit up the entire office.”

headline: ‘No Explanation for the Electricity Between Us’
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living']
abstract: Phyllis Waldron, 85, and Al Bartschke, 90, met at their retirement community. Both were widowed after long marriages.
lead_paragraph: Phyllis Waldron discovered there is no age limit on feeling like the new kid in town when she moved to the Florida retirement community Water’s Edge of Bradenton last fall.

headline: The Setup That Lasted Six Years
abstract: Friends had tried to set up Permele Doyle and Garner Robinson since 2010, but it wasn’t until six years later that they had their first date.
lead_paragraph: Since 2010, mutual friends had been trying to set up Permele Doyle with William Robinson, who is known by his middle name, Garner.

headline: Finding Love After Divorce
abstract: After both were divorced, Raj Sardesh and Alexander Seidel met 12 years ago at a support group for L.G.B.T.Q. people. They connected almost immediately.
lead_paragraph: A common experience of divorce seems like an unlikely origin for a love story, but so it was for Raj Sardesh and Alexander Seidel.

headline: Finding Love at First Glance
abstract: Katherine Desmond and Pedro Henrique Martins felt an instant attraction during an internship at DuPont in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Desmond was the local in a group of engineering interns at DuPont, the chemical company in Wilmington, Del., when she and Pedro Henrique Martins met in 2014.

headline: When a Love Expert Falls in Love
abstract: Love was a strictly professional pursuit for Helen Fisher, an anthropologist, and John Tierney, a writer — that is, until they fell in love.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, John Tierney followed Helen Fisher around the American Museum of Natural History, hoping she could put the Manhattan singles scene into perspective for him. She came through solidly.

headline: For Two Art Lovers, a Picture-Perfect Scene
abstract: A photo capturing their embrace reminds them of how far they have come as a couple.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Simone Blaser and Vincent Houzé had only been dating for two months when a New York Times photographer snapped a photo of them in mid-embrace at Storm King Art Center, an open-air museum in Mountainville, N.Y., that features one of the country’s largest collections of contemporary outdoor sculptures.

headline: Firm Footing Found After a Jenga Challenge
abstract: Ronald Longe and Sunil Oommen met online, a year after Mr. Longe faced unexpected detours in his life.
lead_paragraph: “Destiny is a series of detours.”

headline: Hospital Staff Turned Wedding Planners
abstract: Enver Candan, who is undergoing treatment for acute leukemia, is immunocompromised, so his wedding to Miranda Wickham was off until they called on Project Cupid.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic upended the wedding plans of Miranda Wickham and Enver Candan, as it did for so many couples, yet if it hadn’t been for the virus, Ms. Wickham might not have been there to badger her fiancé to seek the medical treatment that may have saved his life.

headline: A Pandemic-Proof Bubble?
abstract: The N.B.A. has sealed off its players and staff in a secure campus in Florida — a medical and social experiment unlike anything in the history of sports.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: After a Few Missed Cues, a Connection
abstract: Eric Wilson attempted to woo Nekpen Osuan after the two met in Washington four years ago, but it took awhile for her to catch on.
lead_paragraph: Nekpen Osuan doesn’t waste time mobilizing when she finds a cause that moves her. She is a founder and chief executive of WomenWerk, a nonprofit organization that helps empower women of color, as well as an active volunteer for organizations including SEO Scholars, an education enrichment and mentoring program. But when it comes to romance she is not quite as quick on her feet.

headline: What We Learned From the D.N.C.
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Last night, the Democratic National Convention capped off four days of remote speeches, video montages and roll-call votes with a final address from the party’s presidential nominee, Joe Biden.

headline: Biden’s Big Moment
abstract: He never would have imagined the circumstances of this speech, but he managed to make the most of it.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to a convention recap edition of On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Why Would Vladimir Putin Want to Get Rid of Aleksei Navalny Now?
abstract: The unchanging leader of the regime is Mr. Putin; the unchanging leader of the opposition is Mr. Navalny. But everything changes.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, as the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny was returning to Moscow from the Siberian city of Tomsk, where he had been meeting with opposition candidates ahead of local elections, he began to feel ill. A heart-rending video was later posted online — one of the passengers on the plane had managed to capture Mr. Navalny’s groans and cries of pain. They sounded like the screams of a dying man.

headline: Steve Bannon’s Business Partners
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The former Trump adviser was charged with defrauding investors in a private project to build a border wall. He’s not the only big name associated with it.

headline: Laying Down His Tools, Belarus Worker Takes Up Mantle of Protest Leader
abstract: Sergei A. Dylevsky, a Belarusian tractor factory worker, has emerged as a populist leader in demonstrations against President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko.
lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — After seeing multiple people with fractured bones, purple bruises and other injuries — the result of a brutal crackdown on protests against the widely contested re-election of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus — Sergei A. Dylevsky, a worker at the Minsk Tractor Works, decided he had had enough.

headline: The Top-Seeded Lakers Set Things Right With a Game 2 Win
abstract: “We played with a sense of desperation,” said Anthony Davis, who had 31 points and 11 rebounds.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, after the Los Angeles Lakers lost their opening game of the N.B.A. playoffs to the Portland Trail Blazers, Anthony Davis found himself the object of LeBron James’s attention. Davis had struggled for the Lakers on Tuesday night in Game 1 of their first-round series, so James gave him a pep talk.

headline: Joe Biden Says Goodbye, Uncle Joe and Hello, Father of the Nation
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Democratic National Convention', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: In his convention acceptance speech, Mr. Biden offered a new image for the next four years.
lead_paragraph: He is no longer “Uncle Joe.”

headline: After Covid, China’s Leaders Face New Challenges From Flooding
abstract: Unusually heavy rains have wreaked havoc in central and southwestern China, leaving hundreds dead and disrupting the economy’s post-pandemic recovery.
lead_paragraph: Having brought the coronavirus pandemic largely under control, China’s leaders are now struggling with a surge of crippling floods that have killed hundreds of people and displaced millions across the central and southwestern parts of the country.

headline: Kamala Harris’s father, a footnote in her speeches, is a prominent economist.
abstract: In a warm, encyclopedic tribute to her family Wednesday night, as she formally accepted the vice-presidential nomination, Senator Kamala Harris skimmed past any discussion of her father, Donald J. Harris, a Jamaican-born professor of economics at Stanford University.

After being implicated in the nation’s largest college admissions prosecution, Lori Loughlin resigned from her exclusive country club, downsized from her expansive Bel Air estate, and saw her acting career crater. Then, on Friday, Ms. Loughlin was sentenced to prison.

headline: Xi Declares War on Food Waste, and China Races to Tighten Its Belt
abstract: The Communist Party’s “clean plate” campaign targets livestreaming extreme eaters, wasteful diners and others amid concerns about China’s ability to feed its 1.4 billion people.
lead_paragraph: Chinese regulators are calling out livestreamers who binge-eat for promoting excessive consumption. A school said it would bar students from applying for scholarships if their daily leftovers exceeded a set amount. A restaurant placed electronic scales at its entrance for customers to weigh themselves to avoid ordering too much.

headline: They’re Making the Rent. Is It Costing Their Future?
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Evictions', 'Landlords', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Federal aid and eviction bans have kept many tenants in their homes. With that support ebbing, it can take charity and sacrifice to avoid dislocation.
lead_paragraph: They’ve made it with government checks and family help. They’ve made it with savings and odd jobs. They’ve made it with church charity, nonprofit rescue funds, GoFundMe campaigns. One way or another, through five months of economic dislocation, the nation’s tenants have for the most part made their rent.

lead_paragraph: A highlight of my week, every week, is the glorious mixed produce box I get from County Line Harvest. I make a run to the farmers’ market for extra bits and bobs when I can, picking up whatever looks good — herbs, flowering greens, plums. But since March, for a million reasons, I’ve been buying and eating way less meat than I used to.

headline: The Poundcake of Your Dreams
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Dairy Products', 'Cakes']
abstract: This buttery loaf has a moist, golden crumb, a crème fraîche tang and a texture just as light (or dense) as you like.
lead_paragraph: For a cook in the 18th century, the recipe for poundcake was obvious from its name: a pound each of butter, eggs, sugar and flour, beaten together and baked until done. Golden-topped, rich and flavored with a splash of rosewater or dash of mace, it was the tight-crumbed grandparent of every butter cake we bake today.

headline: Ray Cave, Influential Time Magazine Editor, Is Dead at 91
abstract: After bringing big changes to Sports Illustrated in the 1960s and ’70s, Mr. Cave had an equally significant impact at Time.
lead_paragraph: Ray Cave, who as the managing editor of Time magazine for eight years oversaw a revamping of its stodgy look, introduced new sections, expanded its lifestyle coverage and promoted long-form single-subject issues like “Children of War,” died on Monday at his home in Boothbay, Me. He was 91.

lead_paragraph: The road to Arecibo Observatory in northwestern Puerto Rico winds upward through farms and rainforest. Chickens run across the road. Then, suddenly, you reach the top: a fence, guards and gleaming white buildings and towers, as if you had stumbled into the lair of a James Bond supervillain.

headline: U.K. Exam Chaos Prompts Stampede for College Places
abstract: Universities rejected thousands of students when exam results were announced. With those grades now withdrawn, many are demanding places that have already been filled.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The calls to Newcastle University started early this week, flooding in at the rate of 1,500 in a day. At Reading University, staff were forced to set up a makeshift phone bank in the library. Durham University, facing overwhelming demand for places in September’s freshman class, offered a cash reward to some young people if they deferred their education for a year.

headline: The Most Comforting Dish of All
abstract: A beloved dish from Yotam Ottolenghi’s father inspired this one-pan spaghetti dinner.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — My father passed away last December. In his final months, he wasn’t the dad I’d known — always terrifically absorbed in anything that came up in conversation. Regardless of whom he was talking to, he would find something genuinely engrossing, an opportunity to learn a fact or communicate one. He also lost his appetite, which was equally shocking, because food remained a spring of little joys for him, even when everything else seemed pointless, painful and confusing.

headline: California Struggles to Contain Sprawling Wildfires
abstract: The spreading wildfires have burned more than 500,000 acres throughout the state, killed five people and forced more than 60,000 to evacuate their homes.
lead_paragraph: The spreading wildfires have burned more than 500,000 acres throughout the state, killed five people and forced more than 60,000 to evacuate their homes.

headline: ‘Tenet’ Review: Christopher Nolan’s Time-Bending Take on James Bond
abstract: John David Washington stars as an unnamed, uncreased C.I.A. agent in a spectacle full of scenes running backward and forward.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Maybe it is our collective enslavement to the superhero-industrial complex, but right now the movie world is looking for a savior. If it turns out to be Christopher Nolan, it wouldn’t be the first time: Films of his, like “Inception,” “Interstellar” and “Dunkirk,” have, in years past, “saved” summers, reputations, studios. His “Dark Knight” trilogy sure saved the Warner Bros.-DC partnership — in fact possibly he saved that a bit too hard, with franchise filmmakers ever since toiling in his shadow. Can Nolan save cinema from the coronavirus, its deadliest foe yet? Perhaps, if Covid-19 can be tripped up by the grandfather paradox or has a hitherto undiscovered weakness for sharp tailoring.

headline: The Players Are Doing It for Themselves, Not Us
abstract: The joy of elite soccer is real. So is the pain. And that’s true even when no one is watching.

lead_paragraph: Steve Grossman, a saxophonist who caught the jazz world’s attention when he was recruited by Miles Davis at just 18, died on Aug. 13 in Glen Cove, N.Y. He was 69.

headline: The Simplest Noodles
abstract: Spicy ramen noodles, braised chicken with artichokes and coconut-gochujang chicken are on the menu this week.
lead_paragraph: Hello! And welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. I’ve always been the kind of person who likes to cook when things feel out of control. My mom died when I was quite young, and the kitchen was her place, so when she died, it became my place, where I escaped to — and still do, to find comfort in making a recipe that will work if I just follow the instructions. How life-affirming, right?

headline: Laura and Marco, Tropical Storms, Form

lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Laura and Tropical Storm Marco formed on Friday, the latest named storms of a busy Atlantic hurricane season.

headline: Older New Yorkers Sweat It Out, Waiting for Promised Air-Conditioners

lead_paragraph: It seemed like a noble idea to offer quick help during the pandemic: New York City would give away free air-conditioners this summer to low-income older people who are stuck indoors.

headline: We Heard Our First Live Music in Months. Nothing Beats It.
abstract: In-person concerts are cautiously re-emerging. So two of our critics took in a quartet performance in a parking lot.
lead_paragraph: MORRISTOWN, N.J. — Live performance ended abruptly in March as the coronavirus spread around the world, putting musicians out of work and audiences out of concert halls. Artists have taken to the internet, sending out livestreams, prerecorded streams, streams from the archives — almost all with the implied caveat that nothing beats the real thing, the real sound.

headline: ‘Comfort Viewing’: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Melrose Place’
abstract: When did everything get so serious? This ’90s prime-time soap was sensational in every sense.
lead_paragraph: In the 1994 hit “Reality Bites,” Vickie (Janeane Garofalo) is sitting across from her best friend, Lelaina (Winona Ryder), in a diner, lamenting that she is “maybe, probably,” dying of AIDS. She thinks about it every day, all day, she says, but it’s as if it weren’t even happening to her. It’s as if she were a character “on some crappy show like ‘Melrose Place.’”

headline: Schools Briefing: Lessons From Around the World
abstract: Finland, Israel, South Korea, Kenya, and the UK are all preparing for the school year differently.
lead_paragraph: This is the Coronavirus Schools Briefing, a guide to the seismic changes in U.S. education that are taking place during the pandemic. Sign up here to get the briefing by email.

headline: How to Help a Child With Delays in Motor Skills and When to Get Support

abstract: Occupational therapy is not just for kids with disabilities, it can benefit a wide variety of children.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Dahlstrom, 42, is worried about her 3-year old son, Levi, entering preschool this fall. He has little interest in picking up a pencil or crayon, and when he does, he still holds it in a toddler’s fisted grip. He struggles with tracing lines and using scissors. He has trouble pulling shirts on and off himself, and shows absolutely no desire to begin potty training.

headline: Love Letter: Surviving the Distance, One Letter at a Time
abstract: Plus: A love written in the stars.
lead_paragraph: When stay-at-home measures went into effect in March, some new and blossoming relationships were put on pause. Others were prematurely defined as couples hastily began to quarantine under one roof, like Patricia Liu, a rising college senior who moved in with her boyfriend of three months. Their decision to live together led to a deeper connection, but after 48 days of playing house, her boyfriend’s military duty called for a separation with no calls or texts. Soon, letters became the only way to bridge the distance. She wrote one for every day they would be apart, 49 in total.

headline: For Quick Coronavirus Testing, Israel Turns to a Clever Algorithm
abstract: Inspired by a mother’s question, the new method will be introduced across Israel this fall, just in time for flu season, and could be coming soon to the U.S.
lead_paragraph: BEERSHEBA, Israel — A team of three Israeli scientists has pioneered a coronavirus testing procedure that they say is faster and more efficient than any now in use, testing samples in pools of as many as 48 people at once.

headline: Trump says he is ‘the only thing standing between the American dream and total anarchy.’

headline: Economic Data Points to Pause in Recovery as Aid Programs Expire
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stimulus (Economic)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The economy’s rebound showed signs of stagnating. Then enhanced unemployment benefits and a small-business loan program expired.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s economic recovery is in an uneasy pause, with key indicators of hiring, shopping and investment stalling or in retreat in the wake of a resurgence in coronavirus cases across broad sections of the country, and with Congress and President Trump showing no signs of progress on another stimulus deal.

headline: Libyan Rivals Call for Peace Talks. It May Be Wishful Thinking.
abstract: The announcement of a cease-fire was a rare positive development in a chaotic conflict plagued by foreign meddling. But skeptics abound.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Rival political leaders in Libya announced an immediate cease-fire on Friday and called for talks to demilitarize Sirte, the seaside city that has become the focus of international efforts to break the stalemated conflict in the oil-rich but dysfunctional North African nation.

headline: Baseball’s New Game Plan: Wait a Few Days and Hope for Good Health
abstract: The Mets’ limited coronavirus infection showed it was probably inevitable it would hit a New York team. When they return, though, they are a team worth watching.
lead_paragraph: Health is paramount, of course, and not the usual kind of health we talk about with the Mets. Two members of their traveling party tested positive for the coronavirus on Thursday — one player and one staff member — and Major League Baseball has paused their season in an effort to prevent the spread.

lead_paragraph: This page is no longer being updated. As of mid-September, more than 30 states had begun paying benefits.

headline: DeJoy Tells Senators Election Mail Will Be Delivered ‘Fully and on Time’
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Absentee Voting', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The postmaster general, under fire for recent changes that have slowed mail delivery, defended his approach and asked Congress to help free the Postal Service from costly retirement obligations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Louis DeJoy, the embattled postmaster general whose cost-cutting and operational changes have prompted widespread concern about mail-in voting, said on Friday he was “extremely, highly confident” the Postal Service could handle the largest vote-by-mail program in American history. He said it was “outrageous” for Democrats to suggest that he might intentionally slow ballot delivery to help President Trump.

headline: Answering the Many Questions About ‘The One and Only Ivan’
abstract: The new Disney+ film about a talented gorilla might leave you wondering about the real great ape that inspired the story. We have answers.
lead_paragraph: Can a gorilla ape Banksy? That’s the setup of Disney’s new animal rights flick, “The One and Only Ivan,” inspired by the true story of a silverback gorilla who spent 27 years intimidating children at a shopping mall in Tacoma, Wash. In the film, he becomes politicized over his imprisonment and expresses his outrage through art. Directed by Thea Sharrock and based on K.A. Applegate’s Newbery Award-winning book of the same title, this retelling is candy sweet compared with the real Ivan’s cameo in the 1991 documentary “The Urban Gorilla,” which turned him into a 500-pound cause célèbre. This computer-animated Ivan is able to speak for himself (in the voice of Sam Rockwell). As legal efforts in Germany, Argentina and the Balearic Islands have established precedents that could make primate personhood a future civil rights fight, what’s the film’s ratio of fiction to fact? We answer this and other questions below.

headline: Kenya’s Health Workers, Unprotected and Falling Ill, Walk Off Job
abstract: Hundreds of health workers have tested positive and some have died, while health facilities are overwhelmed and government officials are accused of stealing funds for medical supplies.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Doctors in public hospitals say they have not been paid, some for as long as six months. They’re furious that they’ve been given faulty protective gear, or none at all. Hundreds of government health workers have fallen sick with the coronavirus, and yet many say their medical insurance was cut in July, just when hospitals became overwhelmed with cases.

headline: What Would You Include in the Criterion Collection?
abstract: The prestigious Blu-ray/DVD archive is overwhelmingly white. We want to hear your suggestions.
lead_paragraph: A report by Kyle Buchanan and Reggie Ugwu looked at the Criterion Collection, the trove of deluxe Blu-rays and DVDs of films by the most highly regarded filmmakers. Of more than 1,000 titles, only six were by African-American filmmakers, and none were by anyone born after 1957.

headline: The Zombie Ants
abstract: When ants are accidentally marked as dead, they find a way to rejoin the living.
lead_paragraph: Every corpse is an ecosystem. Each fallen bird, landed fish, beached whale, decomposing log, plucked flower is destined to change from a conglomerate of giant molecules, the most complex system in the universe known, into clouds and drifts of much smaller organic molecules. The process of decay is driven by scavengers, in nature beginning with vultures and blowflies and ending with fungi and bacteria.

headline: Direct from Edinburgh: Theaters Are Closed, but a ‘Zoo’ Is Open
abstract: Among the performances you can catch online are a one-woman show about sexual assault and riffs on “Heart of Darkness” and “Rocky.”
lead_paragraph: Most Augusts, the Edinburgh Festival Fringe presents thousands of live performances in the Scottish capital, saving some of its most unusual specimens for a subfestival called the Zoo. Not this August, sadly, and yet the cessation of live theater has made the teeming collection of dance, performance and physical theater available to a much wider audience online, under the rubric Zoo TV. Our critics had a look around at offerings — some new, some old, all Fringe — that ranged from unwatchable to unforgettable.

headline: Meet the Philosopher Who Is Trying to Explain the Pandemic
abstract: Giorgio Agamben criticizes the “techno-medical despotism” of quarantines and closings.
lead_paragraph: Stumping for regional candidates in Tuscany this month, Italy’s former interior minister Matteo Salvini waved around a surgical mask — and pointedly did not wear it. Covid-19 has taken more than 35,000 lives since it struck Italy in January. But now the daily death toll is typically in single digits, and Mr. Salvini, the leader of the anti-immigration League party, wants to put the country back to work. “Italians are being held hostage, kept at a distance, masked,” he hollered, “and meanwhile they let thousands of lowlifes land their boats and do what they want, go where they want, spit, infect. Enough is enough!”

headline: Overlooked No More: Leonora O’Reilly, Suffragist Who Fought for Working Women
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Voting and Voters', 'Biographical Information', 'Nineteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Organized Labor', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: She was a charismatic and powerful public speaker who pushed for equal pay for equal work, better labor standards and overall empowerment for women.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times. This latest installment is one of many ways The New York Times is examining the centennial of the 19th Amendment.

headline: From Ai Weiwei, a Portrait of Wuhan’s Draconian Covid Lockdown
abstract: Ai said the documentary film “Coronation,” which he directed remotely from Europe, “is trying to reflect what ordinary Chinese people went through.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In January, the Chinese city of Wuhan became the first in the world to undergo a lockdown to fight the coronavirus pandemic. In many ways this crucial period remains a mystery, with few images escaping the censors’ grasp.

headline: MASS MoCA’s Founding Director to Step Down
abstract: Joseph C. Thompson, who started in the position in 1988, spent his first 11 years working just to open the museum, in a former industrial complex.
lead_paragraph: Joseph C. Thompson, who became the founding director of the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in 1988, will step down from that post near the end of October, the institution announced on Friday.

headline: 7 Takeaways From the Democratic National Convention
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Joe Biden rallied the party around him, with help from Barack Obama and Bernie Sanders. But even as Democrats reach out to disaffected moderates, they’re also holding together a fractured coalition.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our daily updates on the latest presidential election polls.]

headline: Deidre Davis Butler, Who Fought for Disability Rights, Dies at 64
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT']
abstract: A wheelchair user herself, she helped draft a landmark law and held government posts championing people with disabilities, especially those of color.
lead_paragraph: When she was a girl growing up in New Jersey, Deidre Davis Butler made an unlikely sight on the tennis court. A spinal tumor had impaired her mobility — later in life she would be in a wheelchair — but her father had taught her how to play the net, in her own particular way.

headline: Golden State Killer Sentenced to Life in Prison Without Parole
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Forensic Science', 'Sex Crimes', 'Genealogy', 'Serial Murders', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Prosecutors said that Joseph James DeAngelo committed 13 murders and nearly 50 rapes that terrorized California in the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: A former police officer who pleaded guilty to a series of murders and kidnappings that terrorized California for decades was sentenced on Friday to multiple terms of life without parole after more than 45 victims and family members testified over three days to the pain and anger caused by the man known as the Golden State Killer.

headline: In Praise of the Simple Routine
abstract: It doesn’t need to be punishing or packed with to-dos.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. I’ve been measuring the progression of days by the ripeness of my neighbor’s tomatoes. They have a solitary Roma tomato plant on their patio whose fruits look perfect, plump and pale orange, not ready for plucking, but soon.

headline: Kentucky Derby to Run Without Fans at Churchill Downs
abstract: Race officials had hoped to allow a reduced number of fans to see the Triple Crown leg in person, but said an increase in cases in and near Louisville meant they had to reconsider.
lead_paragraph: Churchill Downs on Friday abandoned its plan to hold the 146th running of the Kentucky Derby before a limited number of fans, saying it would run without live spectators because of a significant increase in coronavirus cases in and around Louisville.

headline: Will It Be Safe to Return to School?
abstract: Plans to ensure safe classes vary by province and school board or are still in the works. Two experts offer their views on what’s ahead.
lead_paragraph: For many families, back-to-school season can be a fraught time. But this year, the pandemic may take that tension to a whole new height.

headline: Fact-Checking the Democratic National Convention
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Democratic National Convention']
abstract: The four-day virtual event focused on character rather than policy. Still, Democrats exaggerated about Social Security, jobs and the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: [Follow our daily updates on the latest presidential election polls.]

headline: Britney Spears Conservatorship to Remain As Is Until 2021
abstract: The singer has called for changes to the legal arrangement that controls her life and finances, but the guardianship was extended through Feb. 1.
lead_paragraph: A request by the pop singer Britney Spears to substantially change the setup of the court-approved conservatorship she has lived under for 12 years will not be decided on until February, a California judge said this week amid a flurry of filings by Spears and her family.

headline: What to Know About Stuttering
keywords: ['Stuttering', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voice and Speech', 'Brain', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Democratic National Convention', 'your-feed-health', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: The speech disorder can play havoc with sociability, relationships, even identity, but there are ways to handle it.
lead_paragraph: For a couple of minutes on Thursday, the sprawling, virtual Democratic National Convention seemed to hold its collective breath as 13-year-old Brayden Harrington of Concord, N.H., addressed the nation from his bedroom, occasionally stumbling on his words. “I’m a regular kid,” he said into a home camera, and a recent meeting with the candidate “made me feel confident about something that has bothered me my whole life.”

headline: A Portrait of a Man Named Jonathan
abstract: Erica Deeman’s thoughtful pictures of members of the African diaspora highlight her subjects’ humanity.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work into context. This week, we’re looking at a piece by Erica Deeman, who focuses on portrait photography, exploring questions of race and identity. Her new show, “Familiar Stranger,” opens next week at Anthony Meier Fine Arts.

headline: Getting Children Flu Shots Is Even More Important This Year
abstract: Doctors offer advice on when and where to safely get vaccinated.
lead_paragraph: Making sure that your kids get a yearly flu shot is always a good idea, but even more so this fall, as the coronavirus continues to spread throughout much of the United States.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Kamala Harris’s Indian roots. Our new work lives. Greek life during Covid-19. The sounds of New York City. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. I hope it brings you some sunshine wherever you are. If there’s no sun in sight, maybe you’ll be inspired by the people who are packing up and temporarily moving to warmer climes. (I have to confess, I’m tempted.) Whatever you end up doing, be sure to make time for some great journalism.

headline: New Safety Standards for Moviegoing as U.S. Theaters Reopen
abstract: The nation’s major multiplex chains are selling tickets again, and they have announced uniform health protocols to make patrons feel safer.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Some people go to the gym. Some people go to church,” Megan Colligan, the president of Imax Entertainment, said at a news conference on Friday to mark the reopening of theaters in much of the United States. “And some people really do need to go to the movies.”

headline: In Belarus Town, People Tasted a Bite of Freedom. It Lasted 2 Days.
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Strikes', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Protesters in Grodno won some extraordinary concessions from the local government, including a police apology and a pledge of press freedom. They did not last long.
lead_paragraph: GRODNO, Belarus — For two days this week, a city on the western edge of authoritarian Belarus tasted freedom.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Europe is entering a new phase in the pandemic as a fresh wave of infection strikes countries that had initially reined in the virus.
lead_paragraph: Europe is entering a new phase in the pandemic as a fresh wave of infection strikes countries that had initially reined in the virus.

headline: Postal Service, Lori Loughlin, Elena Ferrante: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Nina Popova, Dancer Who Fled Bolsheviks and Nazis, Dies at 97
abstract: Ms. Popova, who grew up in Russia, toured the globe, danced on Broadway and became a teacher. She died of the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: The Dreaded Lanternfly, Scourge of Agriculture, Spreads in New Jersey
abstract: The insect poses a serious threat to American crops, particularly vineyards, and inspires creative backyard methods of eliminating them.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 17, a banner floated in the blue sky above Ocean Grove, N.J., with a call to arms: “JOIN THE BATTLE — BEAT THE BUG.” A large picture showed an insect with crimson and Dalmatian-spotted wings outspread. The spotted lanternfly, the Northeast’s pest à la mode, was back.

headline: Climate Activists Gain Seats on Harvard Oversight Board
abstract: The candidates were the first ones elected through a petition campaign since 1989, when anti-apartheid activists put Archbishop Desmond Tutu on the panel.
lead_paragraph: Bucking tradition, a group of climate activists has won three seats in an election to an important governing body at Harvard University, the Board of Overseers, the university announced Friday.

headline: The TV Divide: Convention Ratings Surge on MSNBC as Fox News Dips
keywords: ['Television', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Live television viewership for the Democratic National Convention fell 17.6 percent from 2016, but many Americans watched online.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Democratic National Convention attracted an average nightly television audience of 21.6 million viewers, down roughly 18 percent from 2016 but still a respectable number given how many Americans have turned away from traditional TV sets in favor of online video and streams.

headline: Trump Administration Says Some Coronavirus Tests Can Bypass F.D.A. Scrutiny
keywords: ['Tests (Medical)', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: The new policy states that so-called laboratory-developed tests will no longer require F.D.A. authorization.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration this week ordered the Food and Drug Administration to allow the use of a certain class of laboratory tests, including some for the coronavirus, without first confirming that they work.

headline: Why She’s Still Protesting
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'Newsletters', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: Our interview with the woman who stands in dissent outside Adidas every day.
lead_paragraph: Our producer Stella Tan on last Friday’s episode:

headline: ‘It’s Hard to See Your Memories Burn’: Loss From Wildfires Grows in California
abstract: Some of the ancient, towering conifers in Big Basin Redwoods State Park are a casualty of the fires that have wracked the state.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Towering over the coast, straining for sun as they’ve done since before there was such a thing as California, the old-growth giants of Big Basin Redwoods State Park stood in flames on Friday. John Gallagher thought of his sons. Darryl Young thought of his father. Laura McLendon thought of her wedding day.

headline: Why Antibody Tests Won’t Help You Much
abstract: Most antibody tests are useful only for large population surveys, diagnosis in certain children or when initial diagnostic testing fails, according to an expert panel.
lead_paragraph: Getting an antibody test to see if you had Covid-19 months ago is pointless, according to guidelines issued this week by a major medical society.

headline: N.B.A. Playoff Teams Feel the Pain of Bubble Injuries
abstract: The Rockets, Sixers, Blazers and Magic, are among the teams coping with injuries to key players. The results are mixed.
lead_paragraph: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: Is the Lockdown Making You Depressed, or Are You Just Bored?
abstract: We shouldn’t pathologize normal unpleasant emotions — which doesn’t mean we shouldn’t do something about them.
lead_paragraph: There has been a lot of talk recently about how the coronavirus pandemic has unleashed a mental health epidemic of depression and anxiety.

headline: National Enquirer Chief David Pecker Loses Top Job in Company Merger
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Names, Organizational']
abstract: As the longtime media executive moves to an adviser role, American Media, the parent of The National Enquirer, has been renamed A360Media as part of a planned merger with a logistics company.
lead_paragraph: David J. Pecker, the tabloid media titan who drew the scrutiny of federal investigators for his alleged role in Donald J. Trump’s 2016 presidential campaign, is out as the leader of the parent company of The National Enquirer, Us Weekly and other publications, according to a company announcement on Friday.

headline: National Zoo Panda Gives Birth
abstract: Mei Xiang, a 22-year-old giant panda at the Smithsonian zoo in Washington, D.C., is the oldest panda to give birth in the United States, officials said.
lead_paragraph: After days of speculation and anticipation, a giant panda at the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington gave birth to a cub on Friday evening, the zoo announced.

headline: Barack Obama Delivers a Jeremiad
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In his convention speech, the former president sought to renew faith in the democratic project.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020, standing in front of an exhibition about the Constitution in Philadelphia, Barack Obama fully became an American Jeremiah.

headline: Ex-Green Beret Charged With Spying for Russia in Elaborate Scheme
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Prosecutors said he provided classified information to Russian intelligence operatives for years, betraying the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former Army Green Beret captain was accused on Friday of violating espionage laws after federal investigators said they uncovered evidence he joined the military at the behest of Russian intelligence operatives and had betrayed the United States for years.

headline: A Presidential Historian Makes a Rare Appearance in Today’s Political Arena
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Jon Meacham’s remarks at this week’s Democratic National Convention sprang from a long friendship with Joe Biden and a desire to add historical context to the present moment.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the historian and biographer Jon Meacham got an unusual request from Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign. The campaign wanted him to speak at the Democratic National Convention — not to endorse Mr. Biden, but to put the stakes of this election in historical context.

headline: Biden Always Had a Simple Message. He Rode It to the Nomination.
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Joseph R. Biden Jr. never wavered from his central message: that President Trump was a danger to American democracy, while he was a stable, experienced leader. Now it will be tested in a fierce battle with the president.
lead_paragraph: Staring into the camera, Joseph R. Biden Jr. recalled the white supremacist protests in Charlottesville, Va., declared that the soul of the nation was at stake in this election and, invoking America’s founding creed, claimed history’s call by vowing to defeat a president who he said threatens democracy itself.

headline: Trump Holds a Rare White House Funeral for His Younger Brother, Robert
keywords: ['White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It was the first time a president has held an East Room funeral for a member of his family in nearly 100 years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Growing up in Queens, Robert S. Trump learned to survive in the shadow of a rambunctious older brother, Donald, who monopolized attention. In adulthood, his older brother was his boss at the Trump Organization. And near the end of his life, he became his older brother’s defender, joining him in publicly excoriating their niece, Mary, who had written a memoir about life inside a family she characterized as cold and cruel.

headline: Military Surveillance Planes Didn’t Spy on Protesters, Pentagon Report Finds
keywords: ['Military Aircraft', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Inspectors General']
abstract: But the Air Force’s inspector general concluded that National Guard officials failed to obtain prior approval from Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper to use the planes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Deploying a little-known National Guard reconnaissance plane in four American cities to monitor protests this spring did not violate rules against the military collecting intelligence on citizens, a Pentagon report has concluded.

headline: Another Putin Critic Apparently Poisoned
keywords: ['Poisoning and Poisons', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Will the West take action against whoever may have harmed Aleksei Navalny?
lead_paragraph: Aleksei Navalny — reportedly still in a coma — has finally been allowed to fly to Germany for treatment, so at least the mystery of what caused Russia’s most prominent opposition figure to collapse in terrible agony on a flight over Siberia may be resolved. But if it does turn out to be poison, to which all signs point, it will still not explain who attacked him or why.

headline: Hangout for Dorian Gray
abstract: Trenton Charlson steals a little of our youth.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a tough one, and an example of what the street fashion bloggers call “high-low,” a mingling of very opulent clues that require knowledge of opulent things and some nice commercial mentions for hoi polloi. Here’s a weird hint: There are no Zs nor any Qs, which is very strange for a Trenton Charlson puzzle. Every other letter is accounted for.

headline: Joe’s Fearsome Weapon Against Trump: Simple Decency
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Biden takes on Donnie Darkness and promises to bring us into the light.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Whenever I called my mom to tell her something bad had happened, she said, “I know.”

headline: Justice Dept. Questions Former C.I.A. Director for 8 Hours
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Inspectors General']
abstract: John O. Brennan is a witness, not a target, in the inquiry being led by John H. Durham, a U.S. attorney, but the C.I.A. under Barack Obama could be subject to further criticism by the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The former C.I.A. director John O. Brennan was told during eight hours of questioning on Friday that he was not the target of any criminal inquiry as part of a divisive Justice Department examination into the Russia investigation’s origins.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Felt Sick in March? Antibody Test Won’t Tell Much
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 22, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “If you were sick back in March you probably don’t have antibodies anymore, and if you were only mildly sick you may not have gotten antibodies.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 22, 2020
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 22, 2020.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the reopening of Florida schools referred incorrectly to Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach Counties. They are the three largest counties in Florida; they do not have the state’s three largest school districts.

headline: Covid in the Classroom? Some Schools Are Keeping It Quiet
abstract: Some states and school districts provide detailed data on school outbreaks. Others choose to keep such information under wraps.
lead_paragraph: On the first day of school in Camden County, Ga., local Facebook groups were already buzzing with rumors that a teacher had tested positive for the coronavirus. The next day, a warning went out to school administrators: Keep teachers quiet.

headline: Greece … or Devon? Camping Outshines Continent for Britons This Summer
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Road Trips', 'Recreational Vehicles', 'Camps and Camping']
abstract: With many vacationers reluctant to go abroad because of the pandemic, “for the first time in the U.K., owning a caravan is kind of cool.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This summer, Louise Towers and her partner are loading their four children and Nellie the dog into a camper van for their annual holiday. It’s an honored tradition: Each of the past five summers, they took a road trip through continental Europe in a home-on-wheels.

headline: Trump’s Approval Rating, Biden’s Low Bar: This Week in the 2020 Race
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Democratic National Convention, on the whole, was aimed more at appealing to moderates than rallying the base. Will the Republicans take the opposite approach?
lead_paragraph: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.

headline: I’ve Been Away From My Apartment for Months. What Happens Now?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: Courts have long held that tenants can stay away from their apartments for extended periods because of health reasons. But don’t neglect your home.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in an Upper East Side apartment with a rent-stabilized lease, which requires me to live there at least 183 days a year. I have been away since the start of the pandemic. What happens if I stay away for more than half the year? And how do I maintain it in the meantime?

headline: Wedding Canceled or Postponed? Here’s How to Get a Refund
abstract: For many couples whose wedding plans were derailed by the coronavirus crisis, getting a refund or a credit from vendors has been an uphill battle.
lead_paragraph: Frank Dariano and Sharon Mensah had planned to marry on July 5, with 50 guests in attendance, at a resort in Banff National Park in the Rocky Mountains of Alberta, Canada. But they canceled the wedding shortly after shelter-in-place orders were issued in San Jose, Calif., their hometown. “Our plans really went south as the pandemic started cracking down on international travel,” said Mr. Dariano, an administrative assistant at an outpatient rehabilitation center in Sunnyvale, Calif.

headline: Finally Organize Those Photos
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Photography', 'Content Type: Service', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Scrapbooks', 'Orderliness and Clutter']
abstract: Sorting your photographs, whether digital or print or both, can seem daunting. Here are some simple ways to catalog and organize your images.
lead_paragraph: Spending more time at home has offered the opportunity to tackle all sorts of ambitious projects, from D.I.Y. focaccia to work-space upgrades. Yet there’s one task that still seems impossible: organizing hundreds, if not thousands — or even hundreds of thousands — of print and digital photographs. The idea of sorting through them feels daunting, so instead you do nothing. The shots pile up; the cycle continues.

headline: Is the ‘Convention Bounce’ a Thing of the Past?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Elections (US)']
abstract: After the Democratic primary campaign came to an abrupt halt in late March as the coronavirus swept through the nation, the Democrats and Republicans have looked to the conventions as their candidates’ biggest stage.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.

headline: Cartilage Is Grown in the Arthritic Joints of Mice
abstract: Researchers discovered a way to awaken dormant stem cells and transform them into cartilage. If the technique works in humans, it may help ease debilitating joint pain.
lead_paragraph: The painful knees and hips experienced by so many people with osteoarthritis result from a loss of cartilage, which serves as a sort of cushioning in the joints. It had long been thought that cartilage, once gone, cannot grow back.

headline: Crummy College Quarantine Food Goes Viral: A Lemon as a Side Dish?
keywords: ['Food', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Dormitories', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

headline: Why Some Tropical Fish Are Gettin’ Squiggly With It
abstract: On occasion, different species of angelfish produce hybrid offspring even more colorful than the parents.
lead_paragraph: When American painter Bob Ross said, “There are no mistakes, only happy accidents,” he was ostensibly referring to paint on a canvas.

headline: As Politicians Clashed, Bolivia’s Pandemic Death Rate Soared
abstract: Bolivia was mired in political turmoil when the pandemic hit. The response was chaotic. And the surge in deaths that followed was among the worst in the world, according to an analysis by The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: TARIJA, Bolivia — So many people were dying that the government’s numbers couldn’t be accurate.

headline: A Glimmer of Hope for Trump? How Bush Mounted a Comeback in 1988
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 1988', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For Biden, a cautionary tale. For Trump, a negative strategy for rebounding in a race.

headline: ‘A Bit Surreal’: The Lonely Plight of the Great Barrier Reef
keywords: ['Reefs', 'Global Warming', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: The tourism operators who depend on the natural wonder, already contending with climate change, have been walloped by the pandemic. The absence of visitors is bad for them — and the reef.
lead_paragraph: CAIRNS, Australia — Diving beneath the ocean, Russell Hosp swam toward the limestone bed of the Great Barrier Reef, where he reattached bits of blue staghorn coral. With tourists gone, he was filling the void with this small act of conservation, which took his mind off the uncertain future on land.

headline: 5 Podcasts to Bring Theater Into Your Home
abstract: Many theater companies are closed, but that doesn’t mean you can’t immerse yourself in the magic of a play.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, stages mostly remain dark. But there is another option for finding that full immersion into the magic of the theater, and that’s through podcasts. These shows, available on most listening apps, will challenge the assumption that you need to be in a theater seat to be transported into another world.

headline: Navalny, Being Treated in Germany, Looms Over Russian Politics
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: His sudden, unexplained illness comes amid political uprisings in Russia’s Far East, and just weeks before municipal elections take place across the country.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Russia’s most prominent opposition figure, Aleksei A. Navalny, arrived in Berlin for treatment on Saturday after falling into a coma in Siberia in what his family and supporters suspect was a deliberate poisoning weeks before nationwide local elections.

headline: Make and Jar Pomodoro to Last All Year Long
abstract: Who knows what the rest of 2020 will bring, but at least you’ll have quality pasta sauce to enjoy just like Nonna used to make.
lead_paragraph: Correction: Aug. 24, 2020 An earlier version of this article omitted an ingredient. Adding lemon juice to the tomato sauce helps ensure safety in canning. The earlier version also incorrectly used ingredients and procedures that can be dangerous for home canning. Carrots, celery, basil and other low acidic vegetables should not be included in the sauce for canning; they can be added when the sauce is reheated for use. Finally, new jars should be used for canning.

headline: Lamenting the loss of the in-person convention.
abstract: I’ve attended every convention since 1988, when Michael J. Dukakis accepted the Democratic presidential nomination. That year, as I exited Atlanta’s rapidly emptying Omni Coliseum after the balloons had dropped, I stopped to chat with a prominent Southern Democratic senator. He was all smiles, sure that the party’s four days of festivities would lead to Mr. Dukakis beating George H.W. Bush. Like thousands of other Democrats in attendance, he thought it was in the bag.
lead_paragraph: I’ve attended every convention since 1988, when Michael J. Dukakis accepted the Democratic presidential nomination. That year, as I exited Atlanta’s rapidly emptying Omni Coliseum after the balloons had dropped, I stopped to chat with a prominent Southern Democratic senator. headline: If Storms Hit California, Blazes May Be Tougher to Control
abstract: Two groups of wildfires have swelled to become the second- and third-largest blazes the state has seen.
lead_paragraph: California firefighters had good weather on their side on Saturday as they battled wildfires that have torched nearly one million acres and forced the evacuation of more than 119,000 people from their homes. But their fortune may run out on Sunday, when storms with strong winds, lightning and little rain may return to the region.

headline: Stop Campus Partying to Slow the Virus? Colleges Try but Often Fail
abstract: Coronavirus outbreaks at colleges reopening for fall classes underscore the difficulties of policing student behavior.
lead_paragraph: At Cornell University, students started arriving over the past week hoping for a safe and socially distanced fall semester. Jason Chang already has doubts.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, here with a cryptic? Double happiness.
lead_paragraph: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — It’s always a treat to get a Cox/Rathvon creation on an off week. Those of us who solve the acrostic have an advantage, as we are already on these constructors’ sophisticated and funny wavelength, but you don’t need a fancy surfboard or nerves of steel to hop on — the water is warm, and if you see a shark, just maintain eye contact and soldier on.

headline: We Are Living With Brain Cancer. Here’s How Biden Could Help Us.
abstract: Like Beau Biden, we have glioblastoma. It doesn’t get the attention it should.
lead_paragraph: If Joe Biden reaches the White House, he will have more direct experience with cancer than most presidents. His eldest son, Beau Biden, died in 2015, at 46 from glioblastoma, the most aggressive form of primary brain cancer. Glioblastoma is deadly — median survival from time of diagnosis is only 14 months — and notoriously difficult to treat.

headline: Brennan is told he is not a target of criminal inquiry into Russia investigation.
abstract: The former C.I.A. director John O. Brennan was told during eight hours of questioning on Friday that he was not the target of any criminal inquiry as part of a divisive Justice Department examination into the Russia investigation’s origins.

lead_paragraph: SEVILLE, Spain — He leaked files that led to the prosecution of one of the biggest labor corruption scandals in Spain’s history. But instead of being lauded for whistle-blowing, he was charged with revealing workplace secrets and sentenced to two years in prison.

lead_paragraph: Approximately half the albums that have topped the Billboard album chart since the beginning of 2019 have been made available as part of a bundle, in which it is offered as an add-on sale to a more expensive item, typically an article of clothing or a concert ticket.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: But what Republicans learn from the Trump era will make all the difference.
lead_paragraph: It must pain Donald Trump, deep down in his showman’s soul, to have had his convention taken away from him. The arguable peak of his presidency, the hubristic State of the Union that preceded the coronavirus, raised the reality-television elements of the address to new heights — reuniting a military family! Bestowing a Presidential Medal of Freedom! You can only imagine what brazen gimmicks, what WWE stagecraft, Trump would have rolled out for a convention taking place in normal times.

keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The next president can undo some of the recent efforts to weaken environmental protections. But it’ll take work.
lead_paragraph: That the Interior Department has now blessed oil and gas drilling in the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge comes as no surprise. It was a foregone conclusion once Lisa Murkowski, in 2017, persuaded her Senate colleagues to authorize drilling in the refuge as part of a tax bill, ending protections that have been in place since the Eisenhower administration.

headline: The Coronavirus Generation
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Poverty', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Education (K-12)', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)', 'Welfare (US)', 'Food Stamps', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The virus doesn’t sicken kids as much as adults. But it can still destroy their futures. A child allowance would help.
lead_paragraph: Three decades ago, a team of researchers at Duke University set off to follow a group of schoolchildren in a stretch of rural North Carolina that happened to include a small reservation. Soon after, the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians opened a casino and began sharing the profits, about $4,000 per adult each year, with every household in the tribe — essentially creating a local version of guaranteed income.

headline: Coronavirus Limits California’s Efforts to Fight Fires With Prison Labor
abstract: Early releases of prisoners to protect them from the virus have depleted the ranks of an inmate firefighting program that some say should be abolished anyway.
lead_paragraph: VACAVILLE, Calif. — They charge into fire zones with 60-pound packs and three-foot chain saws, felling trees and hacking through brush to make wide paths of dirt around anything worth protecting. Bright orange uniforms set them apart from other firefighters — and identify them as inmates of California’s state prisons.

headline: Sister Elaine Roulet, 89, Dies; Aided Imprisoned Mothers and Their Children
abstract: Changes Sister Elaine helped bring about at the Bedford Hills prison for women in New York State allowed inmates and their offspring to bond.
lead_paragraph: Sister Elaine Roulet, a Roman Catholic nun who helped female inmates bond with their children and created innovative programs for mothers both in prison and after release, died on Aug. 13 at the Stella Maris Convent in the Rockaway Park section of Queens. She was 89.

lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — It is not unheard-of for Iowa to experience a tornado or a freak thunderstorm. It is also not unheard-of for my mother to exaggerate a story.
