lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Suddenly, the Islanders’ focus has shifted, from the confidence in a franchise record-setting goaltender, to having concerns about how Semyon Varlamov will bounce back from his worst performance of the N.H.L. postseason on Wednesday.

headline: Rev. Roxy Is Serious About Marriages and Helping Make Them Work
abstract: The Rev. Roxanne Birchfield, a celebrity wedding officiant, will tell you one thing for sure: marriage is not a fairy tale but it is absolutely a thing of hope.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Roxanne Birchfield, 36, a minister of the Evangelical Church Alliance and the founder and owner of Married By Rev. Roxy, an officiating and premarital counseling service in Brooklyn, has become a high-profile officiant, performing ceremonies on hit reality shows like Netflix’s “Love Is Blind,” VH1’s “Love & Hip Hop” and “Married at First Sight.”

headline: You’re Beginning to Look Dull
abstract: How to get a healthy glow even if you’ve barely laid eyes on the sun all summer.
lead_paragraph: It has been a weird summer, many of us cooped up indoors, and our skin has noticed. Now, in these last weeks of the season, skin care obsessives as well as the more laid-back among us are getting sick of the dull skin that has become something of a hallmark of the pandemic.

headline: Wildfires, Pandemic, Earthquakes. What’s Next for California?
abstract: Nature seems to be ganging up on the Golden State.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Every other week for the past 18 years, my wife and I have made a five-hour round-trip drive between here and Mendocino County. She has a health care practice in both places, so our rural home isn’t a retreat; nonetheless, like others who had the option, when the pandemic kicked in we opted for the country, where social distance is axiomatic and anxiety less likely.

headline: Parenting in Front of a Live Audience of In-laws
abstract: Micromanaging my husband, I realized how much I still craved my parents’ approval.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere in rural Pennsylvania, my husband and I whisper-argue on a mattress strewn across the floor. His hand gestures say, “Lower your voice.” Mine say, “I’m a big-haired Spanish woman from Jersey. Fat chance.”

headline: My Job? Telling People What Happens Next
abstract: I spend my time talking to experts, trying to envision what the future of the coronavirus crisis looks like. There aren’t a lot of rules on how to do this.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Over 100 Ex-Staff Members for John McCain Endorse Joe Biden
abstract: The group endorsement of Mr. Biden is the latest effort from anti-Trump Republicans to lure conservatives and moderates away from the president, who often clashed with the former Arizona senator.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 100 former staff members for Senator John McCain are supporting Joseph R. Biden Jr., a show of support across the political divide that they hope amplifies the “Country First” credo of the former Arizona senator.

headline: Late Housing Payments and Coronavirus
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Mortgages', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']
abstract: Landlords are negotiating payment plans, but rent and mortgage debt is rising.
lead_paragraph: Nearly six months into the pandemic, the share of American homeowners and renters who have missed or been late with their monthly housing payments is holding steady, despite government stimulus initiatives and protections including the CARES Act.

headline: Is Social Security Becoming a Pawn in the Postal Service Crisis?
keywords: ['Social Security (US)', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Elderly', 'Retirement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Most benefits are now paid electronically, but nearly a million monthly checks are still mailed out, and the post office’s delays and political controversy could clog paperwork.
lead_paragraph: Top Democrats are warning that the problems afflicting the United States Postal Service pose a threat to more than voting rights — a slowdown in services, they say, will also hurt seniors who rely on letter carriers for Social Security checks, medications and other critical mail.

headline: 3 Major Themes From Night 3 of the R.N.C.: Watch the Highlights
abstract: Two of our reporters break down the key moments from the third night of the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Adam Nagourney: The third night of the Republican National Convention took place against a backdrop of staggering tumult in the country: the demonstrations and shootings in Kenosha, Wis., the devastating hurricane approaching the Gulf Coast. The big question was whether the speakers would at last mention these issues. The answer, particularly with Vice President Mike Pence’s speech, was yes, they were mentioned.

headline: My Family’s Shrouded History Is Also a National One for Korea
abstract: Decades after the war ended, scars left by the Japanese occupation persist for millions of Koreans and Korean-Americans, including the author Alexander Chee.
lead_paragraph: In the latest article from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series by The Times that documents lesser-known stories from World War II, the author Alexander Chee looks back at the dark legacy of the Japanese occupation of Korea — and a once-unknown personal connection to it.

headline: Desperate to Leave Beirut, Young Lebanese Are Also the Ones Fixing It
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Beirut, Lebanon, Explosions (2020)', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Youth', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The young people leading the huge volunteer effort after the recent blast are bringing hope, but have lost it themselves. “I want to at least have Beirut on its feet before I go,” one said.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The scooter engines snorted out, and Sara el-Sayed swung herself down to the pavement outside the third damaged building she had visited that afternoon, two carpenters in tow.

headline: Trash Piles Up in Parks, Just When New Yorkers Need Them the Most
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Budget cuts have left some of New York City’s green spaces with unmown lawns, unemptied garbage cans and littered playgrounds.
lead_paragraph: In a playground in the Morrisania section of the Bronx on a recent afternoon, two parents kept their toddler strapped in her stroller, afraid she might pick up the hamburger wrappers,  cigarettes or hypodermic needle lying on the pavement.

headline: College Football’s Pandemic Playbook: Fewer Fans, No Tailgating, No Bands
abstract: About two dozen states plan to host college football games this season. With thousands of fans expected for many of them, organizers are trying to balance public health with tradition.
lead_paragraph: At Texas A&M, the football stadium that normally holds about 110,000 people may allow fewer than 28,000 to start this season. Alabama and Auburn banned tailgating, and so did Mississippi’s governor. Marching bands are forbidden on the Atlantic Coast Conference’s fields, suites at Texas will not have self-service buffets and from Baylor to Boston College, hand sanitizer will be more common than printed tickets.

headline: Intel Slips, and a High-Profile Supercomputer Is Delayed
keywords: ['Computer Chips', 'Supercomputers', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment']
abstract: The chip maker was selected for an Energy Department project meant to show American tech independence. But problems at Intel have thrown a wrench into the effort.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — When it selected Intel to help build a $500 million supercomputer last year, the Energy Department bet that computer chips made in the United States could help counter a technology challenge from China.

headline: Move Over, Sustainable Travel. Regenerative Travel Has Arrived.
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Eco-Tourism', 'Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings']
abstract: Can a post-vaccine return to travel be smarter and greener than it was before March 2020? Some in the tourism industry are betting on it.
lead_paragraph: Tourism, which grew faster than the global gross domestic product for the past nine years, has been decimated by the pandemic. Once accounting for 10 percent of employment worldwide, the sector is poised to shed 121 million jobs, with losses projected at a minimum of $3.4 trillion, according to the World Travel & Tourism Council.

headline: What if the First Coronavirus Vaccines Aren’t the Best?
abstract: Dozens of research groups around the world are playing the long game, convinced that their experimental vaccines will be cheaper and more powerful than the ones leading the race today.
lead_paragraph: Seven months into the coronavirus crisis, with more than 30 vaccines rapidly advancing through the rigorous stages of clinical trials, a surprising number of research groups are placing bets on some that have not yet been given to a single person.

headline: Félix Fénéon, the Collector-Anarchist Who Was Seurat’s First Champion
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art reopens with an exemplary show devoted to an essential figure who multitasked his way through the aesthetic and political ferment of Belle Époque Paris.
lead_paragraph: Every exhibition tells a story, usually about an artist or groups of them. Occasionally, however, some shows focus on non-artists: individuals who work as art dealers, curators, critics or collectors. Essential to a functioning art world, they don’t make things. They make things happen.

headline: 15 Books to Watch For in September
abstract: New fiction from Elena Ferrante, Yaa Gyasi and Marilynne Robinson, Mariah Carey’s tell-all, several deep dives into Cold War espionage and more.
lead_paragraph: When readers meet Ursula Kuczynski Burton, a.k.a. Agent Sonya, a decorated intelligence agent and colonel in Russia’s Red Army, she’s living undercover as a housewife in a small English village. All that her neighbors know about her is that she makes great scones; they don’t realize she’s funneling atomic secrets from Britain and the U.S. to the Soviet Union. Macintyre, the best-selling author of several books about spies, offers a rich portrait of Burton, who was involved in some of the 20th century’s most famous espionage operations.

headline: In Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, Some Cracks Emerge in the Pro-Trump Wall
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: President Trump is likely to win again in rural northern Michigan, a key to his surprise victory in the state in 2016. But can he pile up the same margin in 2020? Some have their doubts.
lead_paragraph: ST. IGNACE, Mich. — Michigan’s Upper Peninsula is known for many things: its enviable location, nestled among three of the five Great Lakes — Huron, Superior and Michigan; hundreds of waterfalls and vast expanses of lush forests; and pasties, a concoction of meat, potatoes and vegetables enrobed in dough that served as a portable meal for those heading into the copper and iron ore mines.

headline: Turkey Braces for Yet Another Currency Crisis
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Currency', 'Home Appliances', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Ventilators (Medical)', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: A sharp drop in the value of the lira is testing businesses and residents while they are coping with the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: When the Turkish lira plunged to a new low against the dollar and euro this month, Hakan Bulgurlu did not panic. This was not the first time that Mr. Bulgurlu, the chief executive of Arcelik, a Turkish maker of home appliances, had steered through a currency crisis.

headline: Republican Convention: Best and Worst Moments From Mike Pence Night
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Republican National Convention', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Our columnists and contributors give their rankings.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for Night 3 of the Republican National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rank the evening on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the night was a disaster for Republicans; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump for the Trump-Pence ticket. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which featured Richard Grenell, Lara Trump, Kellyanne Conway and Vice President Mike Pence.

headline: The M.T.A.’s Doomsday Budget Plan
keywords: ['Second Avenue Subway (NYC)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Subways', 'Buses', 'Transit Systems', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Surfing']
abstract: Without federal aid, the agency said, it would need to reduce subway and bus service by 40 percent to address its deficit.
lead_paragraph: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

headline: White House, Under Fire for Discouraging Coronavirus Testing, Says It Will Buy Millions of Test Kits
abstract: President Trump promised a vaccine by the end of the year. For hurricane-battered Louisiana and Texas, a confluence of disaster.
lead_paragraph: This briefing has ended. Read live coronavirus updates here.

headline: On the Ground in Kenosha
abstract: Jacob Blake, a Black man, was shot in the back several times at point-blank range by a white police officer. In the aftermath, unrest and violence have roiled the Wisconsin city.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

headline: A Perk for N.Y.’s Richest Areas: First Dibs on Top Public Schools
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Income Inequality', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: New York City gives students a shot at nearly all high schools across the city — except for a handful of top schools in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: On paper, Tiffani Torres looked like a strong candidate for one of New York City’s highest-performing, most selective public high schools. She had high test scores and excellent grades. “I was a good fit for what the school was looking for,” Tiffani said.

headline: Soon, the Kitty Litter Will Come by Electric Truck
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Delivery Services', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'E-Commerce', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: With deliveries surging during the pandemic, carriers like UPS and FedEx and companies like Amazon are renewing their push toward electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Going back years, you might have been able to spot a truck from the likes of FedEx and UPS, and more recently Amazon, that ran on electricity. But most of these were small, short test runs that left the internal-combustion status quo in place.

headline: The Growing Power of Hurricanes
abstract: And what else you need to know today.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Laura shares something in common with both Hurricane Florence, a 2018 storm that killed 52 Americans, and Hurricane Katrina, which struck Louisiana 15 years ago this week. All three changed from more typical hurricanes into severe ones in just a day or two.

headline: ‘Matthias & Maxime’ Review: Unsealed With a Kiss
abstract: A male friendship is destabilized in this overlong ponder on desire.
lead_paragraph: There are some directors you wish would never grow up, and Xavier Dolan — a man whose fire hose of emotions could at times make you giddy — is one. Before he turned 27, with movies like “Laurence Anyways” (2013) and “Mommy” (2015), Dolan seemed to have decided that restraint was a dirty word and expressiveness his guiding principal.

headline: ‘All Together Now’ Review: A Song as a Source of Hope
abstract: In this sweet and scrappy film, Auliʻi Cravalho plays a young woman torn between following her dreams and her loyalty to her mother.
lead_paragraph: There is a particular skill in presenting a character who is nearly flawless without turning her into a staid saint. In Brett Haley’s sweet and scrappy teen Netflix drama “All Together Now,” Amber Appleton (Auliʻi Cravalho) checks so many boxes of trait perfection (she volunteers at a retirement community, teaches E.S.L. classes, etc.) that a worse film would become a hagiography. But Haley’s directing has a gentility, and Cravalho (who was introduced to movie audiences as the title voice in Disney’s “Moana”) gives Amber a visceral humanity that elevates the intermittently uneven screenplay.

headline: ‘Mr. Soul!’ Review: Televising the Revolution, With Great Songs
keywords: ['Movies', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Television', 'Music', 'Writing and Writers', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: A documentary resurrects the magic of “Soul!,” a boundary-pushing public television show that celebrated the rich diversity of Black culture in the ’60s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: In one of the many remarkable archival clips in the documentary “Mr. Soul!,” a 20-something Al Green croons “Love and Happiness” on live TV. Seen in front of him in long shot are the bobbing heads of an enraptured audience. They form — as the writer Greg Tate describes in an interview — a “sea of big, bold Afros.”

headline: ‘You Cannot Kill David Arquette’ Review: Ready to Rumble (Again)?
abstract: David Arquette risks his body and his reputation to win redemption as a professional wrestler in this rough and tumble documentary.
lead_paragraph: When the admirably raw documentary “You Cannot Kill David Arquette” begins, its title subject is out of shape and recovering from a recent heart attack. His mental health and his recent sobriety both seem shaky, and his film career has not lived up to early promise. But it’s not acting that haunts David Arquette’s dreams. Instead, he fantasizes about professional wrestling.

headline: ‘The Binge’ Review: They’ll Drink to That
abstract: In this parody of the “Purge” movies, drugs and booze are banned except for one 12-hour period a year.
lead_paragraph: Here’s an equation for third-period math: Take “Superbad,” “Booksmart,” and, hell, any teen-party movie, add in a useless overarching conceit, subtract all originality. The result is “The Binge,” a new Hulu original that is only exceptional in its mind-numbing inanity.

headline: ‘Ghost Tropic’ Review: A Missed Stop and a Long Walk Home
abstract: Bas Devos captures the sleeping outer portions of Brussels in this drama about a hard-working woman who finds herself stranded.
lead_paragraph: This new movie from the Belgian filmmaker Bas Devos opens with a static shot of an apartment’s living room and its window. No one is there. The shot holds as the room goes from fully lit to completely dark. “I see the time that has gone by,” a woman says in voice-over. “How would a stranger feel here?”

headline: ‘Fatima’ Review: Blinded by the Light
abstract: The film is a plodding cinematic recounting of reported visions that the Roman Catholic Church deemed a miracle.
lead_paragraph: “Fatima” is based on the life of Sister Lucia, who, as a girl in 1917, along with two of her cousins, claimed to have seen visions of the Virgin Mary in a field in Fátima, Portugal. Throngs of the curious flocked to the site. When observers reported seeing fantastical solar phenomena — a sighting called “the Miracle of the Sun” — it was treated as corroboration. The Roman Catholic Church deemed the apparitions “worthy of belief” in 1930.

headline: ‘Epicentro’ Review: They Are Cuba
abstract: The Oscar-nominated documentarian Hubert Sauper explores vestiges of foreign presence in Cuba, from the ground up.
lead_paragraph: The Austrian-born Hubert Sauper has made two remarkable  documentaries on colonialism, each employing a powerful central metaphor. “Darwin’s Nightmare” (2005) draws an analogy between foreign plunderers of Tanzania and an invasive species of fish. “We Come as Friends” (2015) compares the investors descending on South Sudan (and Sauper’s visit) to an onslaught from another planet.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Madea’s Farewell Play’ and ‘Rising Phoenix’
abstract: A recording of Tyler Perry’s final show as Madea debuts on BET+. And a new Netflix documentary looks at the history of the Paralympics.
lead_paragraph: TYLER PERRY’S MADEA’S FAREWELL PLAY Stream on BET+. Last year, Tyler Perry threw on his gray wig, lipstick and thick, square glasses, and hit the road: He was going to retire his most famous character, Madea, but first he was taking her on a final tour. The show he presented, “Madea’s Farewell Play,” covers familiar Madea territory: wisecracks, music and a plot built on a law school graduation that brings the family back together — comfort food for fans who stream this recorded version. “That old broad has been good to me, so who knows — maybe one day I’ll tell the story of Madea in the ’70s and hire a real actress to play the role,” Perry wrote in an essay in The New York Times last year. “But the time of playing her has come to an end.”

headline: ‘Made in Bangladesh’ Review: A Quiet Power in Collective Efforts
abstract: This drama from Rubaiyat Hossain is a portrait of garment workers unionizing in Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: “Made in Bangladesh” opens with a close-up of a woman threading a sewing machine. As the closing credits begin, the sounds of a sewing machine return from that initial sequence; it may not be until that moment that you realize just how much the movie has taken you — minutely, step by step — through an arduous process.

headline: How to Watch the Republican National Convention
abstract: President Trump will accept the nomination, and the general election season will officially begin.
lead_paragraph: After eight intense nights of programming, the 2020 conventions will come to an end on Thursday: President Trump will formally accept the Republican nomination, and the general election season will officially begin.

headline: What’s That on the Met’s Roof Garden? A Big, Beautiful Wall
abstract: The artist Héctor Zamora’s “Lattice Detour” is a monument to openness over enclosure, lightness over heaviness, transience over permanence. It’s also fraught with political meanings.
lead_paragraph: A buff-and-gray stronghold of stone, steel and glass set against Central Park, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is designed to shut out pretty much everything the park represents. It’s sealed off from weather and seasons, and natural change of any kind. The one part of the museum that’s an exception is the Cantor Roof Garden. Open to the elements, it’s rain-washed and sun-washed year round.

headline: The Elephants in the Room
abstract: Mike Pence talked about the pandemic and the protests, but most G.O.P. convention speeches have seemed like holdovers from January.
lead_paragraph: Good morning and welcome to a special convention recap edition of On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics.

headline: China Fires Missiles Into South China Sea, Sending U.S. a Message
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The move was Beijing’s latest effort to assert sovereignty over disputed waters.
lead_paragraph: China has fired a barrage of medium-range missiles across considerable distances into the South China Sea, Beijing’s latest move to demonstrate its strategic dominance and sovereignty over the disputed waters.

headline: Entertainment Is Power in Push for Racial Justice
keywords: ['Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms']
abstract: Pro sports are going on strike. Will other industries follow?
lead_paragraph: Want this delivered to your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline: The Photographer Capturing Unvarnished Truths
abstract: Heji Shin’s striking, discomfiting work poses an important question for the contemporary age: What do we expect art to do, and does the artist have a responsibility to do it?
lead_paragraph: “WE PUT A kind of call out for cocks. And they brought them. They’re beautiful. I mean, they’re extremely, extremely beautiful,” says the photographer Heji Shin in the midst of her latest shoot, her first since the Covid-19 lockdown: large-format studio portraits — “very sharp, very shiny” — of bellicose roosters. Two prints from the series, titled “Big Cocks,” recently appeared in a group show at Galerie Buchholz in Berlin. Roosters have long been associated with masculinity (though, in fact, they don’t have penises, Shin informs me); in an era in which violence tends to be systemic or “tactical,” she writes to me later, “the short-lived outbursts of angry cock energy look Hellenistic and virile.”

headline: Welcome to the R.N.C.’s Alternate Universe
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conspiracy Theories', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: A meaningful percentage of Americans are living in a collaborative fiction, built one conspiracy theory at a time.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every weekday.

headline: What to Know About California’s Coronavirus Testing Expansion
abstract: Thursday: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced a deal that would more than double the state’s testing capacity and criticized federal guidelines.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: German Automotive Giant Admits It Was a Nazi Accomplice
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Forced Labor', 'Automobiles', 'Concentration Camps']
abstract: The company, Continental, is the latest to offer a detailed exposé of its wartime use of slave labor and other crimes.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The auto parts maker Continental became the latest German company to issue a confessional study of its Nazi past Thursday, saying it was “a pillar of the National Socialist armaments and war economy” that employed around 10,000 slave laborers, often in inhumane conditions.

headline: The wait for the $300 unemployment benefit can depend on a state’s computers.
abstract: Why have some states been able to move quickly to pay out the new $300-a-week unemployment benefit, while others expect the process to take weeks? In a word: technology.
lead_paragraph: Why have some states been able to move quickly to pay out the new $300-a-week unemployment benefit, while others expect the process to take weeks? In a word: technology.

headline: After months of unemployment, back at work but not feeling secure.
abstract: Kris Fusco is finally back at work. That doesn’t mean her coronavirus worries are behind her.
lead_paragraph: Kris Fusco is finally back at work. That doesn’t mean her coronavirus worries are behind her.

headline: Powell Announces New Effort to Achieve ‘Maximum Employment’
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, unveiled a plan aiming to keep unemployment low while tolerating higher inflation.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, unveiled a plan aiming to keep unemployment low while tolerating higher inflation.

headline: Hurricane Laura Sweeps Through Gulf Coast
abstract: Hurricane Laura, one of the strongest U.S. storms on record, moved north through Louisiana after making landfall as a Category 4 storm early Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Laura, one of the strongest U.S. storms on record, moved north through Louisiana after making landfall as a Category 4 storm early Thursday.

headline: Since a $600-a-week benefit lapsed, her savings have been dwindling.
abstract: Christy Miller says there are three things that shape her identity: making people laugh, making people strong and lifting heavy objects. She can’t do any of those right now, and she isn’t sure when she will be able to again.
lead_paragraph: Christy Miller says there are three things that shape her identity: making people laugh, making people strong and lifting heavy objects. She can’t do any of those right now, and she isn’t sure when she will be able to again.

headline: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Missy Robbins’s pasta provisions, crushable hats — and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: The TikTok FOMO Is Real
abstract: A teenage reader says that the video sharing app is stoking feelings of social exclusion.
lead_paragraph: As a teen, TikTok creates stress in my life. When I hang out with friends, they often ask if I want to make a TikTok with them. I never suggest it, but it nearly always comes up. I want to be nice and say yes, but then I worry that other friends will see the clip and feel excluded that they weren’t part of it. At times, TikToks have made me feel separate from my friends, and I don’t want to make anyone else feel that. How can I be polite and still respect my friends’ feelings?

headline: A Rising Women’s Team Looks Past the Pandemic
abstract: In three seasons, Bordeaux rose from obscurity to a top-three place in France. The coronavirus affected its momentum, but not its plans.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Khadija Shaw sensed opportunity.

headline: Watch live: Fed Chair Jerome Powell speaks on the central bank’s policy shift.
Fed Chair Sets Stage for Longer Periods of Lower Rates
abstract: Jerome H. Powell said the central bank would focus its efforts on fostering a strong labor market while tolerating higher inflation.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, announced a major shift in how the central bank guides the economy, signaling it will make job growth pre-eminent and will not raise interest rates to guard against coming inflation just because the unemployment rate is low.

headline: Mali’s Ousted President Is Released From Detention by Coup Leaders
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta was allowed to return to his home in the capital by the military officers who forced him to resign as president.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta, Mali’s ousted president, was released from detention and driven to his home in the West African country’s capital early Thursday, nine days after a military coup brought an end to his seven years in power.

headline: ‘I Lost Everyone’: Floods Bruise a War-Weary Afghanistan
abstract: Flooding has left more than 150 dead and 200 others injured in recent days, battering a country already torn asunder by violence and the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: CHARIKAR, Afghanistan — Hamid Agha’s family was sleeping outside when the rain began. He had witnessed torrential rain before during his two years living in Charikar, a city carved along the foothills of the Hindu Kush in northern Afghanistan, and thought little of it. Yet when the family of 13 awoke on Wednesday, having moved inside their oppressively hot three-room home during the night, it was to the sound of floodwater.

headline: ‘Nice White Parents’ Discussion Guide
abstract: This companion guide invites families, students and educators to have a conversation about the goals of public education in America … and the relationship between race, social class and a quality education.
lead_paragraph: The podcast “Nice White Parents” largely focuses on the story of one Brooklyn middle school that opened in 1968 — and how white parents have influenced the trajectory of this school over and over, even when their children didn’t attend it. But the issues the podcast raises via this one case study make it a meaningful opportunity to explore the complicated realities of race, privilege and power across all American schools.

headline: The Dual History of Poisonous Flowers
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Poisoning and Poisons']
abstract: From ancient times through today, the same blooms used to harm have also proved healing.
lead_paragraph: THE FLOWERS POINT straight down, a chandelier’s worth, turned ostentatiously away from the sun. They are Brugmansia by genus and angel’s trumpet in parlance, with elongated buds that open into blaring mouths. In South America, the tree that bears them is called el borrachero, or “the drunk-maker,” in part because of the blooms’ dizzying night perfume of fermented lemons, said to induce crazed dreams. And more: Parts of the plant, when crushed, yield scopolamine, a.k.a. burundanga, a.k.a. devil’s breath — a psychoactive alkaloid deployed by criminals, via a spiked drink or a puff in the face, to disable free will. It is said to transform victims into dutiful servants who revive hours later, bereft of all their belongings and any memory of what they’ve done.

headline: ‘The Boys’ Is Back, More Relevant Than Ever
abstract: Amazon’s irreverent take on the superhero genre is defined by depravity and violence, which makes it suited to a time when “authoritarianism and celebrity are combined,” its creator said.
lead_paragraph: It’s the penultimate episode of the new season of “The Boys,” Amazon’s superhero action series, and it’s time for a costumed champion named Starlight to give one of those rousing speeches that inspires listeners to ignore insurmountable odds and get motivated for the journey ahead.

headline: In His Own Words: Jacob Lawrence at the Met and MoMA
abstract: In 1996, the activist artist found inspiration at two of his favorite museums. The discussion that followed, with a Times critic, revealed a man of his generation, whose art is as timely as ever.
lead_paragraph: Shuttered since March by the coronavirus pandemic, the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art are reopening with limited visitorship, various admonitions about masks and social distancing, and several new exhibitions, among them “Jacob Lawrence: The American Struggle.” That show, at the Met, reunites the panels of a lesser-known series that the storied modernist painted during the mid-1950s, exploring themes from the American Revolution to the Westward expansion.

headline: Republicans have intensified their unrest-focused message, with Kenosha as a backdrop.
abstract: On the third day of the convention, Vice President Mike Pence and other Republicans portrayed Democrats as tolerant of violence and riots. And they continued to try to soften President Trump’s image.
lead_paragraph: Republicans used the third night of their convention on Wednesday to amplify warnings of violence and lawlessness under Democratic leadership, trying to capitalize on the worsening unrest in Wisconsin to reclaim moderate voters who might be reluctant to hand President Trump a second term.

headline: As young Black athletes call for a racial awakening, some N.F.L. retirees declare fealty to Trump.
abstract: On one of the most consequential nights in recent sports history — when a player-led boycott forced the N.B.A. to postpone playoff games — the Republican National Convention offered pro-Trump testimonials from a retired Notre Dame coach and a former N.F.L. player facing insider-trading charges.
lead_paragraph: On one of the most consequential nights in recent sports history — when a player-led boycott forced the N.B.A. to postpone playoff games — the Republican National Convention offered pro-Trump testimonials from a retired Notre Dame coach and a former N.F.L. player facing insider-trading charges.

headline: How Trump’s convention has become a crucial play for the suburbs.
abstract: Conciliatory messages at the Republican convention were an acknowledgment by the president’s campaign that appealing to his right-wing base will not be enough to win re-election.
lead_paragraph: It is President Trump’s clearest path to re-election: winning back the suburbs in a handful of swing states that drifted from the Republican Party in the 2018 midterms. And that imperative has been vividly apparent each night of the party’s national convention, with speakers and videos trying to recast Mr. Trump’s divisive record, which hurt Republicans two years ago.

headline: The G.O.P. argues that only Trump can stop the chaos. But he’s already in charge.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The America that many speakers described on Wednesday at the Republican National Convention did not sound like a desirable place: fractious, violent, functionally lawless in some pockets.
lead_paragraph: The America that many speakers described on Wednesday at the Republican National Convention did not sound like a desirable place: fractious, violent, functionally lawless in some pockets.

headline: ‘At no time before have voters faced a clearer choice,’ Trump will say in his convention address.
abstract: Amid an untamed pandemic that has cost more than 180,000 American lives and millions of jobs, a hurricane battering the Gulf Coast and unrest gripping another city after another police shooting of a Black man, President Trump plans to make his most direct case for re-election yet on Thursday night when he addresses the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Amid an untamed pandemic that has cost more than 180,000 American lives and millions of jobs, a hurricane battering the Gulf Coast and unrest gripping another city after another police shooting of a Black man, President Trump plans to make his most direct case for re-election yet on Thursday night when he addresses the Republican National Convention.

headline: Some of the immigrants Trump naturalized on Tuesday didn’t know they were being broadcast.
abstract: In one of the most striking moments of the second night of the Republican convention on Tuesday — both for its content and for its blatant disregard for the traditional separation between governing and politicking — President Trump held a naturalization ceremony for five immigrants.
lead_paragraph: In one of the most striking moments of the second night of the Republican convention on Tuesday — both for its content and for its blatant disregard for the traditional separation between governing and politicking — President Trump held a naturalization ceremony for five immigrants.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Check out an engrossing new documentary series, or the latest installment of a pop culture institution.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, we offer hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read the latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.

headline: Hurricane Laura in Pictures
abstract: Photographers are on the ground in Texas and Louisiana documenting the damage from the storm.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Laura made landfall near Cameron, La., early Thursday as a Category 4 hurricane, delivering a barrage of 150-mile-per-hour winds and a surge of water. The storm weakened as it moved inland but remained destructive with strong winds and heavy rain.

headline: The Billionaire Behind Hudson Yards Thinks New York Is Too Expensive
abstract: Stephen Ross, a friend of President Trump, talks about politics, philanthropy and his pet peeve: wastefulness.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Ross — the billionaire real estate developer who founded Related Companies, owns the Miami Dolphins and has an interest in brands including SoulCycle and Equinox — is a man of contradictions.

headline: Ted Cruz didn’t get a convention invite, but he still has plenty to say.
abstract: Four years ago, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas delivered the most stunning speech of the Republican National Convention, conspicuously declining to endorse Donald J. Trump, his former presidential primary rival, and urging viewers instead to “vote your conscience.”
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas delivered the most stunning speech of the Republican National Convention, conspicuously declining to endorse Donald J. Trump, his former presidential primary rival, and urging viewers instead to “vote your conscience.”

headline: Dozens of former McCain and Romney staff members back Biden.
abstract: In contrast to the Democratic convention, where three former presidents and the party’s 2016 nominee Hillary Clinton, made the case for Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Republican convention has been devoid of such standard bearers this week for President Trump.
lead_paragraph: In contrast to the Democratic convention, where three former presidents and the party’s 2016 nominee Hillary Clinton, made the case for Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Republican convention has been devoid of such standard bearers this week for President Trump.

headline: Rising Tensions Between Turkey and Greece Divide E.U. Leaders
abstract: Conflict over drilling rights to massive natural-gas deposits in the eastern Mediterranean is becoming increasingly militarized, risking a conflict between two NATO members.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — An escalating dispute between Greece and Turkey over energy resources in the eastern Mediterranean is fast becoming militarized, raising the risks of a clash among NATO allies.

headline: 250 Million Years Ago, They Hibernated at the Bottom of the World
abstract: In the tusks of creatures that lived before dinosaurs, paleontologists found signs of hibernation-like metabolism.
lead_paragraph: How to tell if something that died 250 million years ago hibernated when it was alive?

headline: ‘The Personal History of David Copperfield’ Review: A Boy’s Story
abstract: Armando Iannucci’s souped-up, trimmed-down adaptation of the Dickens novel is an exuberant, heartfelt delight.
lead_paragraph: “The Personal History of David Copperfield” — the umpteenth stab at visualizing Charles Dickens’s favorite novel — is so sincere in its telling and so innocently buoyant in its presentation that I had to do a double-take on the writing and directing credits. Armando Iannucci? The Scottish satirist and king of the blisteringly profane diatribe? Surely not.

headline: Voluminous Fashions for Dreamy Fall Nights
abstract: Ruffles, full skirts and Shakespearean sleeves make for evening wear imbued with drama.

headline: Fossil Reveals ‘One of the Cutest Dinosaurs’ Ever Found
abstract: While many fossils have been flattened by time and the elements, a titanosaur found in an egg was preserved in three dimensions.
lead_paragraph: Some 20 years ago, someone smuggled dinosaur eggs from Argentina to the United States illegally. The smuggler probably had little clue that inside one of the eggs was one of the best-preserved skulls of a dinosaur embryo ever found, which is now giving us new insights into the facial appearance of one line of our planet’s erstwhile rulers.

headline: How to Rein In a Messy Bathroom
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Content Type: Service', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']
abstract: If every item has a home, you’ll know where to find it and where to put it when you’re done.
lead_paragraph: If every item has a home, you’ll know where to find it and where to put it when you’re done.

headline: In Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, cracks emerge in a pro-Trump wall.
abstract: ST. IGNACE, Mich. — Michigan’s Upper Peninsula is known for many things: its enviable location, nestled among three of the five Great Lakes — Huron, Superior and Michigan; hundreds of waterfalls and vast expanses of lush forests; and the pasty, a dough pocket filled with meat, potatoes and vegetables that served as a portable meal for copper and iron miners.
lead_paragraph: ST. IGNACE, Mich. — Michigan’s Upper Peninsula is known for many things: its enviable location, nestled among three of the five Great Lakes — Huron, Superior and Michigan; hundreds of waterfalls and vast expanses of lush forests; and the pasty, a dough pocket filled with meat, potatoes and vegetables that served as a portable meal for copper and iron miners.

headline: Here’s how to watch as the convention wraps up.
abstract: After eight intense nights of programming, the 2020 conventions will come to an end on Thursday: President Trump will formally accept the Republican nomination, and the general election season will officially begin.
lead_paragraph: After eight intense nights of programming, the 2020 conventions will come to an end on Thursday: President Trump will formally accept the Republican nomination, and the general election season will officially begin.

headline: Putin Warns Belarus Protesters: Don’t Push Too Hard
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: He said Russia had formed a security force that could intervene if its neighbor “gets out of control.” But for Mr. Putin, that poses the risk creating another anti-Russian hotbed like Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia gave an ominous warning on Thursday to protesters in Belarus not to push too hard to topple their country’s embattled president, saying that Russia had formed a special reserve force of security officers to restore order in the event of chaos in its western neighbor.

headline: Here’s What America’s Covid-Era Classrooms Look Like
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns']
abstract: We asked educators to show us how they were preparing to teach amid the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This will be a school year unlike any other, that much is clear. Educators, parents and students across the country are returning to in-person and virtual classrooms shaped by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Watch Report: The Inner Workings
abstract: Skeleton-style timepieces that are by turns sporty and genteel.

headline: Pelosi says Biden should not debate Trump. Biden disagrees.
abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the nation’s top elected Democrat, said on Thursday that former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. should not debate President Trump, telling reporters that she believed her party’s nominee should not “dignify that conversation with Donald Trump.”
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the nation’s top elected Democrat, said on Thursday that former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. should not debate President Trump, telling reporters that she believed her party’s nominee should not “dignify that conversation with Donald Trump.”

headline: TikTok Is Said to Wrestle With Two Competing Offers
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Mobile Applications', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The sale of the video app’s U.S. operations is entering its final stages, with two groups having submitted bids.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The race to buy TikTok’s U.S. operations has entered its final stages, with two groups submitting bids for the video app, said three people involved in the deal talks. One of the bids was from Microsoft and Walmart, which have teamed up, and the other was from Oracle and could include a coalition of investors, they said.

headline: Trump Barely Mentions Kenosha in Speech, and Only Refers to Violence
keywords: ['Police Reform', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police']
abstract: The president suggested that the Wisconsin city, which has been roiled by protests and violence this week, had succumbed to “mob rule.”
lead_paragraph: President Trump made only a glancing reference to Kenosha, Wis., in his speech on Thursday accepting the Republican nomination for a second term, linking it to other American cities where protests against systemic racism and police brutality have sometimes turned violent.

headline: Citing Kenosha, a Wisconsin college cancels plans for Pence to deliver its commencement address.
abstract: The day after Vice President Mike Pence was the headline speaker at the Republican National Convention, a Wisconsin college announced on Thursday that it had decided not to have him deliver its commencement address this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The day after Vice President Mike Pence was the headline speaker at the Republican National Convention, a Wisconsin college announced on Thursday that it had decided not to have him deliver its commencement address this weekend.

headline: Dennis Williams, Former U.A.W. Leader, Is Accused of Conspiracy
abstract: The ex-president of the United Auto Workers was charged with using union funds for personal expenses. The case is part of a long federal investigation.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Thursday charged a former president of the United Auto Workers union, Dennis Williams, with conspiring to embezzle union funds for personal expenses and luxury travel. He is the 15th person accused in a broad investigation into corruption at the union.

headline: One N.B.A. Team Walked Out. A Generation of Athletes Followed.
keywords: ['Playoff Games', 'Basketball', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Strikes', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: More games were halted in basketball, baseball and hockey, and the messages from athletes reverberated beyond the sports world.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — George Hill is hardly the biggest star in professional basketball. But he was the one who took the lead when a handful of players on the Milwaukee Bucks began talking about the police shooting of Jacob Blake a few days earlier in Wisconsin.

headline: Bon Appétit’s Next Editor in Chief Is a Book-World Star
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Discrimination', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks']
abstract: Dawn Davis, who will become one of the few Black top editors in Condé Nast’s history, will oversee a brand where many workers have complained of discrimination.
lead_paragraph: Bon Appétit, the multimedia food-journalism outlet that has experienced a summer of racial strife in the workplace, has a new editor in chief: Dawn Davis, a prominent editor and executive who has been one of the few Black power players in the book world.

headline: Trump will appear at a live ‘town hall’ with undecided voters on ABC next month.
abstract: President Trump is set to appear at a live town hall with the ABC News anchor George Stephanopoulos on Sept. 15, where he will field questions from undecided voters, the network said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President Trump is set to appear at a live town hall with the ABC News anchor George Stephanopoulos on Sept. 15, where he will field questions from undecided voters, the network said Thursday.

headline: Reopened Schools Find Health Risks in Water After Covid-19 Lockdowns
abstract: A number of schools found the bacteria that causes Legionnaires’ disease in their water, and experts say more should expect to see it.
lead_paragraph: The new coronavirus is not the only illness that teachers, students, parents and staff will have to worry about as some schools attempt to reopen this fall. Legionella could lurk in the water supplies of school buildings, and some measures to keep people in schools safe from coronavirus may even increase risks from deadly illnesses caused by the bacteria.

headline: Bill Arnett, Collector and Promoter of Little-Known Black Art, Dies at 81
abstract: In the 1980s and ’90s, he traveled Southern byways to find brilliant works by self-taught African-American artists who often used scavenged materials.
lead_paragraph: Bill Arnett had spent two decades collecting and dealing antiquities from around the world — African art was his passion — when, in 1986, he had an epiphany in Birmingham, Ala.

headline: Unemployment Claims Are ‘Stubbornly High’ as Layoffs Persist
abstract: New filings again exceeded one million last week, and an extra $300 in jobless pay may not show up before mid-September in most states.
lead_paragraph: Just over one million Americans filed new claims for state jobless benefits last week, the latest sign that the economy is losing momentum just as federal aid to the unemployed has been pulled away.

headline: Deceptive robocalls try to frighten Detroit residents about voting by mail.
abstract: The calls suggest that voting-by-mail exposes personal information, a lie, in what officials said was an apparent effort to suppress vote
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Michigan said on Thursday they were investigating deceptive robocalls targeting Detroit residents in what appeared to be an effort to deter them from voting by mail.

headline: Printer Jam: Serious Supply Issues Disrupt the Book Industry’s Fall Season
abstract: Capacity issues at the two largest printing companies are among the factors creating havoc for authors and publishers.
lead_paragraph: This spring, when the pandemic forced bookstores across the country to close and authors to cancel their tours, many editors and publishers made a gamble. They postponed the publication of dozens of titles, betting that things would be back to normal by the fall.

headline: 7 Activities to Build Community and Positive Classroom Culture During Online Learning
abstract: Ideas for creating authentic connections, meaningful relationships and classroom camaraderie through the screen.
lead_paragraph: When schools transitioned to remote learning in the spring, teachers worked quickly to adapt lesson plans and curriculums for virtual classes, while also trying to maintain community and connection. This fall, not only will many educators continue that same work, but they will have the added challenge of building community with students they’ve never met.

headline: Conway says the more violence erupts, ‘the better it is’ for Trump’s re-election prospects.
abstract: Kellyanne Conway, President Trump’s departing counselor, said on Thursday that Mr. Trump stood to benefit politically from the kind of unrest that erupted this week in Kenosha, Wis., after the police shooting of an unarmed Black man, Jacob Blake.
lead_paragraph: Kellyanne Conway, President Trump’s departing counselor, said on Thursday that Mr. Trump stood to benefit politically from the kind of unrest that erupted this week in Kenosha, Wis., after the police shooting of an unarmed Black man, Jacob Blake.

headline: On ‘Smile,’ Katy Perry Finds Purpose (and Pitfalls) in the Past
abstract: The singer and songwriter is no longer at the gravitational center of American pop music. But on her sixth album, she tries to add brightness to a dark moment.
lead_paragraph: It is either auspicious, or unfortunate, that Katy Perry is releasing her sixth album, “Smile,” the same week that her titanically successful 2010 record “Teenage Dream” is celebrating its 10th birthday.

headline: Was the C.D.C. Injected With Politics?
abstract: Readers are shocked by the recommendation that asymptomatic people should not be tested.

headline: In Trump’s Gilded Beltway, Rudy Giuliani Finds a Potent Reward: Relevance
abstract: No one has seized the chance for a second act under President Trump with more gusto than Mr. Giuliani, whose epic career of ups and downs, feuds and outrages, has made him in some ways the quintessential creature of Trump’s Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No one ever asks “What happened to Rudy Giuliani?” as he hobnobs his way through the lobby of the Trump International Hotel, a few blocks from the White House.

headline: 17th-Century Dutch Painting Is Stolen. Again.
abstract: “Two Laughing Boys” by Frans Hals has been taken from a museum in the Netherlands, after having been stolen in 1988 and again in 2011.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — A 17th-century painting by the Golden Age master Frans Hals was stolen from the wall of a museum in the Netherlands early Wednesday morning.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: An outbreak in South Korea, Belarus, TikTok: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Officials reported 441 new cases on Thursday, the country’s highest daily total since early March. The government said it was facing two great obstacles in fighting the coronavirus: doctors on strike and churches obstructing epidemiological efforts.

headline: Bush’s ethics lawyer calls for an investigation of Pompeo’s R.N.C. speech.
abstract: Two law professors, including one who served as President George W. Bush’s ethics adviser, have filed a complaint to the U.S. Office of Special Counsel accusing Secretary of State Mike Pompeo of violating federal laws by addressing the Republican National Convention while on a diplomatic trip overseas.
lead_paragraph: Two law professors, including one who served as President George W. Bush’s ethics adviser, have filed a complaint to the U.S. Office of Special Counsel accusing Secretary of State Mike Pompeo of violating federal laws by addressing the Republican National Convention while on a diplomatic trip overseas.

headline: Walter Lure, Guitarist for a ‘Mythical’ Punk Band, Dies at 71
abstract: With the Heartbreakers, a shooting star in New York’s punk rock scene, he was a more proficient guitarist than many of his peers. Then came a very unpunk second act.
lead_paragraph: Walter Lure, who played rhythm guitar for the Heartbreakers, a pioneering band of the 1970s New York punk scene, and who had a most unpunk second career on Wall Street, died on Aug. 21 at in Queens. He was 71.

headline: Theater Operator Sues Insurers That Denied It Coronavirus Payments
abstract: Jujamcyn Theaters, the operator of five Broadway houses, asserts that it was wrongfully denied insurance coverage after the pandemic forced it to shut down.
lead_paragraph: Jujamcyn Theaters, the operator of five Broadway houses, has sued its insurers for denying it millions of dollars that the theater company says it deserves as payment for the losses suffered during the monthslong coronavirus pandemic shutdown.

headline: The R.N.C.’s TV ratings declined on the third night, lagging the D.N.C.
abstract: Television ratings declined for Wednesday’s installment of the Republican National Convention, which was seen by roughly 25 percent fewer live viewers than the third night of the Democratic convention last week.
lead_paragraph: Television ratings declined for Wednesday’s installment of the Republican National Convention, which was seen by roughly 25 percent fewer live viewers than the third night of the Democratic convention last week.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of evidence this week that we’re living in a boom time for thoughtful, powerful nature writing. “Vesper Flights” collects essays by Helen Macdonald, whom you likely know from her internationally best-selling memoir, “H Is for Hawk.” In “The Bird Way,” Jennifer Ackerman takes a detailed look at the lives of birds — including their parenting strategies — like the bowerbird, the cuckoo and the kea. From the sky to the sea, with another international best seller: Patrik Svensson’s “The Book of Eels,” which combines elements of memoir with an examination of the slithery creatures.

headline: G.O.P. Convention Skims Over Trump’s ‘Unfinished Business’ in Foreign Policy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Targeted Killings', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: From Iran to North Korea, President Trump has failed to achieve many of his stated foreign policy goals. He is asking for a second term to get them done.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican National Convention this week has portrayed President Trump as a strong commander in chief facing down enemies and demanding more of allies, but the boastful language has glossed over the grand ambitions of his foreign policy that he has been unable to fulfill.

headline: The Day They Didn’t Play
abstract: A walkout by pro athletes brought several sports to a halt on Wednesday night, and raised the volume on a conversation they were eager to have.
lead_paragraph: It started with empty chairs.

headline: How the Met Was Made
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is reopening, commemorating its 150-year anniversary with an exhibition that asks: How does this museum give an account of itself today?
lead_paragraph: Talk about a spoiled birthday. For years leading up to its 150th anniversary the Metropolitan Museum of Art had been planning a swell of celebratory programming: an overhaul of its British Galleries, debuts of major gifts of photography and drawing, new cross-cultural displays, an international symposium on collecting, a Great Hall photo op with the mayor and a big cake.

headline: Jared Kushner, a real estate scion, says boycotting N.B.A. players have the ‘luxury’ to ‘take a night off from work.’
abstract: A boycott by N.B.A. players over the shooting of Jacob Blake by police in Kenosha, Wis., elicited a dismissive response from members of the Trump administration on Thursday — one that dramatically diverged from the expressions of solidarity from top Democrats.
lead_paragraph: A boycott by N.B.A. players over the shooting of Jacob Blake by police in Kenosha, Wis., elicited a dismissive response from members of the Trump administration on Thursday — one that dramatically diverged from the expressions of solidarity from top Democrats.

headline: Israeli Officer Need Not Have Shot Autistic Palestinian, Commander Says
abstract: The commander testified that the man his partner killed, Iyad al-Hallaq, was not resisting and posed no danger, in a case that ignited protests against police brutality.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli police officer who gunned down a Palestinian man who had autism in the Old City of Jerusalem in May defied an order to hold his fire even though the man posed no danger to anyone, his commander has told investigators, according to people briefed on the case.

headline: Douglas A.J. Latchford, Khmer Antiquities Expert, Dies at 88
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Collectors and Collections', 'ANTIQUES', 'Art', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY']
abstract: A leading collector of Cambodian relics, he was credited with helping preserve Khmer culture. He was also charged with trafficking in looted treasures.
lead_paragraph: Douglas A.J. Latchford, a pre-eminent collector of Cambodian antiquities who earned praise for his scholarly works on Khmer Empire art, only to be indicted last year by American prosecutors for illicitly trafficking in the selfsame objects, died on Aug. 2 at his home in Bangkok. He was 88.

headline: Biden Says Trump Is ‘Rooting for More Violence’ Amid Kenosha Unrest
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Republican National Convention', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As Republicans sensed a political opportunity, the Democratic nominee sought to turn attention back to the pandemic and highlighted the president’s tendency to inflame volatile situations.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday accused President Trump of “rooting for more violence” at a moment of national unrest over racism and police brutality, offering one of his most extensive responses yet to the Republican argument that he would be a weak leader on law enforcement and criminal justice.

headline: The Elite Needs to Give Up Its G.D.P. Fetish
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “Material living standards” are not the same thing as “quality of life.”
lead_paragraph: For Americans living through the recent months of crisis, some of the latest economic data may come as a surprise. Gross Domestic Product (G.D.P.) over the past six months remained far above what we could have achieved even a decade ago. Investors have driven key stock indexes back above their February peaks. But rarely have such economic indicators been so entirely beside the point. Seriously: Who cares?

headline: Charles Cook, Ground Zero Volunteer for Months, Dies at 79
keywords: ['World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']

lead_paragraph: When the planes crashed into the World Trade Center towers on Sept. 11, 2001, most people streamed uptown.

headline: The pandemic has curbed new voter registrations, but a study suggests a reason for hope.
abstract: Despite immense interest in November’s elections, new-voter registrations have plummeted this year, thanks to a pandemic that has shut down motor-vehicle licensing offices and get-out-the-vote drives by advocacy groups at places like malls and street festivals.
lead_paragraph: Despite immense interest in November’s elections, new-voter registrations have plummeted this year, thanks to a pandemic that has shut down motor-vehicle licensing offices and get-out-the-vote drives by advocacy groups at places like malls and street festivals.

headline: The British Museum Reopens to a World That Has Changed
keywords: ['Museums', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Art', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Slavery (Historical)']
abstract: While it was closed, the museum altered several exhibitions to clarify its links to slavery and colonialism. But not everyone is happy with the changes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After being closed for 163 days by the coronavirus pandemic, the British Museum on Thursday became the last of Europe’s major museums to welcome back visitors.

headline: White House Wants Companies to Foot Payroll Tax Bill for Workers
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Corporate Taxes', 'United States Economy', 'Taxation', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Payroll Tax', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: The Treasury Department has not been willing to issue guidance making it clear that companies will be on the hook for deferred taxes, further delaying crucial information for businesses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A debate between the White House and the Treasury Department over President Trump’s payroll tax suspension has delayed crucial information about how the executive order will be carried out, according to people familiar with the matter, leaving businesses across the country uncertain about how to proceed.

headline: How Much Can 1968 Tell Us About 2020?

abstract: Drawing parallels between the riots of the 1960s and the protests of today may only be taking us further from the truth, the historian Rick Perlstein writes.

headline: Will This Be the Year Arizona Turns Blue?
abstract: Democrats, Independents and even Republicans have come together to work toward a lasting political transformation of the desert Southwest.

This is partially true, but the origins of Arizona’s evolution into a pivotal battleground state can be attributed to a longer history and a broader cast of characters.

headline: ‘Bill & Ted Face the Music’ Review: Be Adequate to Each Other
abstract: Keanu Reeves and Alex Winter travel through time to save reality and redeem the honor of Generation X.
lead_paragraph: “Bill & Ted Face the Music” sounds like more of a reckoning than it is. It would be unbearable to think that William Preston and Theodore Logan, the goofballs first incarnated by Alex Winter and Keanu Reeves more than 30 years ago, could be candidates for cancellation. And though they may be longer in the tooth and heavier in the jowl than they used to be — as so many of us are — the dudes retain their essential innocence. They are still friendly avatars of nontoxic masculinity. No serious misdeeds resurface from their various time travels that demand judgment in the harsh light of the present.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Following’ and ‘The Roads Not Taken’
abstract: Revisit Christopher Nolan’s debut feature. Or stream the latest movie from the filmmaker Sally Potter.
lead_paragraph: FOLLOWING (1998) Stream on Criterion Channel and IFC Films Unlimited; rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes and YouTube. When hardy audiences trek to theaters to see Christopher Nolan’s latest mind-bender, “Tenet,” in theaters next week, they can expect two things: masks in the movie house and puzzles on the screen. For that has been the Nolan way for nearly two decades: In 2001, Nolan’s “Memento” offered “a series of clever epistemological puzzles,” A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times. Nolan’s film “The Prestige,” from 2006, “has a satisfyingly puzzlelike structure,” Scott wrote in his review. The filmmaker’s 2010 dream-hopper, “Inception”? It “trades in crafty puzzles,” Scott wrote. “Interstellar” in 2014? “Tantalizing puzzles,” Manohla Dargis wrote. All echo “Following,” Nolan’s 1998 debut feature, which gave a taste of his knack for cinematic discombobulation. Shot on a shoestring — the cost of making “Following,” reported to be in the low thousands, was surely less than the hair gel budget delegated to the men of “Inception” — the film plays fast and loose with chronology, telling the story of a young Londoner (Jeremy Theobald), whose hobby of tailing strangers leads him to the city’s criminal underbelly. In her review for The Times, Janet Maslin called the movie “a black-and-white film noir with a difference,” writing that “the usual elements of scheming and deception are well represented here, but they are made all the knottier by shifting time frames.” And, she noted, the story “offers plenty of intriguing puzzle pieces.”

lead_paragraph: I’m so relieved that the pandemic is over! I’d somehow missed that news, but then I watched the Republican National Convention, culminating in President Trump’s big speech, and learned that with his swift, muscular action, he’d pretty much vanquished the “China virus.” I learned that the economic toll of it was fast receding and would be a blurry memory soon.

headline: Chintz Hospital Gowns and Wildflower Dresses
abstract: How Christina Lewis, Lela Rose and Bronson Van Wyck are social distancing.
lead_paragraph: Age: 40

headline: Trump Can’t Avoid Reality Forever
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: Let’s look away from the tawdry spectacle of the Republican convention.
lead_paragraph: The alt-reality show on the screen this week, a Republican National Convention without platform or ideas, mixed Dear Leader adoration with primal fear jabs aimed at the weary American voter. And it may work.

headline: These 6 Businesses Have Survived the Depression, War and Now the Pandemic
abstract: From a Staten Island bakery to a boiler factory in Queens, these mom and pops, all over 100 years old, having staying power.
lead_paragraph: The number of small businesses in New York City closing because of the pandemic — more than 2,800 since March — has been stark. But some independent family businesses in the metropolitan area — all deemed essential — not only operated throughout the worst part of the outbreak and are still going strong, but also survived 20th-century crises like the Great Depression and World War II. Here are a few of them.

headline: How a Veterinarian Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Pets have provided much-needed emotional support this year. But they need to be taken care of, too. Meet one of their doctors.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Simone McLaughlin sees up to 20 pets a day. In normal times, this would be a packed schedule. But pandemic protocols have further complicated matters.

headline: When a Film Festival Goes Virtual, What Do We Lose? Or Gain?
keywords: ['Movies', 'Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'New York Film Festival', 'Toronto International Film Festival', 'Venice International Film Festival']
abstract: With the Venice, Toronto and New York events much changed this year, a look at why the in-person experience matters to our love of movies.
lead_paragraph: We had flown thousands of miles — traveled on boats, even — to see “Joker.” To be clear, last year’s Venice Film Festival promised journalists more than just the world premiere of that Todd Phillips supervillain origin story, then only an operatically pitched trailer. There would also be Brad Pitt in the space psychodrama “Ad Astra,” Noah Baumbach’s emotionally charged “Marriage Story,” and a new film by Hirokazu Kore-eda, the Japanese master who only a year earlier had made the devastating “Shoplifters.”

headline: Remember the ‘Travel Bubble’? Here’s How It Burst
abstract: To keep tourism afloat during the pandemic, some countries formed travel alliances with their neighbors. At summer’s end, the experiment has had mixed results.
lead_paragraph: One of the strategies for keeping international travel afloat during the pandemic was the creation of “travel bubbles”: alliances between neighboring nations with low infection rates that would allow travelers from those countries to freely visit.

headline: College Is Everywhere Now
abstract: Yale students in Barbados. Michigan students in Brooklyn. Berkeley students in Las Vegas? Off-campus housing is way off-campus now.
lead_paragraph: As the fall semester begins, many college students will be attending classes from the relative safety of their family homes. Others have arrived to live on university campuses, with varying amounts of success; even schools that enforce strict social distancing guidelines are seeing outbreaks of the coronavirus.

headline: Kenosha Tells Us More About Where the Right Is Headed Than the R.N.C. Did
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Looting (Crime)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Self-Defense']
abstract: The conservative media’s embrace of Kyle Rittenhouse speaks volumes about its priorities.
lead_paragraph: The most revealing thing to happen in conservative politics this week did not involve the Republican National Convention, at least not directly. Instead, it took place in Kenosha, Wis., in the aftermath of a shooting on Tuesday night that killed two people and wounded a third.

headline: Catch Up on 4 Key Moments From a Night of Norm-Busting
abstract: Two of our reporters break down the big themes from the final night of the Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Jenny Medina: Well, there is a lot to digest. Thursday was perhaps the most polished night of the Republican convention, but the slickness was mostly used for elaborate attacks against Democrats — including some who aren’t even on the ballot this year. (Hello, bipartisan punching bag Mayor Bill de Blasio.) Of course, this is President Trump’s party. And if there were any chance you might forget that, his hourlong speech followed by a massive fireworks display — complete with “TRUMP 2020” spelled out in fireworks — was there to remind you.
