headline: You, Me and 53 Dogs
keywords: ['Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race (Alaska)', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Dog Sledding', 'Dogs']
abstract: Liz Raines met Matthew Failor, a champion dog sledder, just before the start of the 2018 Iditarod race in Alaska, where she was on assignment as a TV reporter.
lead_paragraph: Liz Raines was three years into her first on-camera job as a political reporter at KTVA, the CBS affiliate in Anchorage, when a chance to cover the Iditarod, the nearly 1,000-mile dog sled race, landed in her lap in March 2018.

headline: In Bid for TikTok, Microsoft Flexes Its Power in Washington
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Government Contracts and Procurement']
abstract: The tech giant, once an example of how not to operate in the nation’s capital, now has a successful influence operation there.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft’s quiet pursuit to buy TikTok suddenly appeared dead a month ago, when President Trump said he wanted to ban the popular social media app for national security reasons. So Brad Smith, the tech giant’s president, went to work.

headline: Crucial Battle to Keep Senate Control Gets Little Notice at Republican Convention
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: Despite its importance to the next president, the contest for the Senate majority was relegated to the background as the convention focused almost exclusively on President Trump.
lead_paragraph: A fight for control of the Senate is raging across the country, but viewers who tuned in to the Republican National Convention this week could be forgiven if they did not realize it.

headline: Pictures of Themselves: The 2020 College Essays on Money
abstract: Each year, we ask high school seniors to send us college application essays that touch on money, work or social class. Here are four from this year’s incoming college freshmen.
lead_paragraph: Consider these dispatches from the time before.

headline: God Is Dead. So Is the Office. These People Want to Save Both
abstract: Divinity consultants are designing sacred rituals for corporations and their spiritually depleted employees.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning there was Covid-19, and the tribe of the white collars rent their garments, for their workdays were a formless void, and all their rituals were gone. New routines came to replace the old, but the routines were scattered, and there was chaos around how best to exit a Zoom, onboard an intern, end a workweek.

headline: At the Met, a Promising Sign: The ‘Hot Dog King’ Is Back in Business
keywords: ['Food Trucks and Vendors', 'Hot Dogs and Frankfurters', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Museums', 'Veterans', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Small Business']
abstract: The rebound of the longtime vendor could be a bellwether for small-business owners in the city who rely on tourists and workers for sales.
lead_paragraph: When the Metropolitan Museum of Art closed in March, as the coronavirus ravaged New York, the cluster of pushcarts out front — one of the most coveted food-vending locations in the city — was left with no business.

headline: 7 Things to Do This Weekend
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Art', 'Museums', 'Theater', 'Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Mostly Mozart Festival', 'Classical Music', 'Dancing', 'Children and Childhood', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: How can you get your cultural fix when many arts institutions remain closed? Our writers offer suggestions for what to listen to and watch as well as view in person (museums are reopening!).
lead_paragraph: In March, there may have been a certain sting in seeing images of life that hadn’t been abruptly put on hold. But as the shock of our circumstances wore off, viewing photographs became the easiest way to remember the world as it once was.

headline: Is Opening a Hotel in Rockaway Beach Right Now a Good Idea?
abstract: The area is perfect for day-trippers during a pandemic, but whether New Yorkers will pay hundreds to spend the night is another question.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Thursday morning, the staff at the Rockaway Hotel was busy installing sanitation stations, arranging lounge chairs six feet apart and practicing contactless check-ins. Scheduled to open Labor Day weekend, the upscale property sits just two blocks from the Atlantic Ocean in Queens.

headline: The Brain Implants That Could Change Humanity
keywords: ['Brain', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Voice Recognition Systems', 'Paralysis', 'Sensors', 'Implants', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Touch (Sense)', 'Privacy', 'Addiction (Psychology)']
abstract: Brains are talking to computers, and computers to brains. Are our daydreams safe?
lead_paragraph: Jack Gallant never set out to create a mind-reading machine. His focus was more prosaic. A computational neuroscientist at the University of California, Berkeley, Dr. Gallant worked for years to improve our understanding of how brains encode information — what regions become active, for example, when a person sees a plane or an apple or a dog — and how that activity represents the object being viewed.

headline: For David Hallberg, a Swan Song in Pictures
abstract: Mr. Hallberg, soon to lead the Australian Ballet, was photographed in Moscow before the pandemic halted his final days as a dancer.
lead_paragraph: David Hallberg is not on a plane. He is not dashing between Moscow and Milan, London and Sydney, readjusting to time zones, settling into rented apartments, reconnecting with favorite partners and old friends. Mr. Hallberg, 38, who made ballet history in 2011 by becoming the first American to join the Bolshoi Ballet as a principal, is not rehearsing and performing in “Eugene Onegin,” “Giselle,” “The Winter’s Tale” or “Nureyev”— some of the ballets he was supposed to dance this year, with the Bolshoi Ballet, American Ballet Theater, the Royal Ballet and La Scala Ballet.

headline: Turning Your Home Into a Home School
abstract: Classes are being held in repurposed living rooms, cleaned-out barns and even tree houses.
lead_paragraph: Classes are being held in repurposed living rooms, cleaned-out barns and even tree houses.

headline: Parents Join Forces to Rethink ‘Back to School’
abstract: Instead of classrooms, some children are heading to learning pods that will be held in repurposed living rooms, cleaned-out barns and even tree houses.
lead_paragraph: During this pandemic, Leah Dela Cruz  has taken the idea of learning anywhere to heart. Ms. Dela Cruz lives with her husband and their two children, Lauren, 6, and Rocco, 16 months, in a two-bedroom, 750-square foot apartment in San Mateo, Calif. Since Covid-19 hit, Ms. Dela Cruz’s mother has been living with the family as well, meaning that Ms. Dela Cruz and her husband share one bedroom with their children while her mother is in the other.

headline: Republican Convention: Best and Worst Moments From Trump’s Big Night
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Masks', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Republican National Convention', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']
abstract: Our columnists and contributors give their rankings.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for the last night of the Republican National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rank the evening on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the night was a disaster for Republicans; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump for the Trump-Pence ticket. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which featured Ivanka Trump and President Trump himself.

headline: The ‘My Friend’ Defense, and Other Political Golden Oldies

headline: The Doctors Found Their Perfect Date

lead_paragraph: A year ago, a wedding for fewer than 300 seemed impossible to Shravani Durbhakula. “When you’re an Indian person, you don’t get to have an intimate wedding,” she said. Because, she said, tradition often dictates a multiday celebration with extended family, “it just doesn’t happen.”

keywords: ['Movies', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The star of a new “David Copperfield” film learned to see the novelist in a new light after memorizing pages and pages of dialogue, never giving up, just like his character.
lead_paragraph: “Whether I turn out to be the hero of my own story or whether that station will be held by anybody else, these pages must show.” They are some of the most famous words in all of English literature, and a riff on them also opens “The Personal History of David Copperfield.”

headline: Four Years Later, Trump Still Portrays America as Under Siege

headline: Philippine Network That Clashed With Duterte Ends Local Coverage
abstract: ABS-CBN lost its broadcast license, but a dozen regional operations kept covering local news through cable and the internet. On Friday, that stopped.

lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: The White House wants companies to pay for the payroll tax holiday.

headline: Melania in Lime Green, Ivanka in Black, Trump as Lord of All He Surveyed
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Republican National Convention', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: The president’s speech at the Republican National Convention was a model of pomp and circumstance.
lead_paragraph: It ended with a spectacle, there is no doubt. A panoply of Trumps, arrayed on a makeshift stage created on the South Lawn of the White House, fanning out around their patriarch as he officially accepted the Republican nomination for president in front of a forest of American flags. The White House glowed in the background Thursday evening, fireworks exploded overhead and a live, largely unmasked, audience rose to its feet with cheers.

headline: Keith Haring’s Personal Art Collection to Be Auctioned for Charity
abstract: This Sotheby’s sale of works by Basquiat, Warhol and other stars is expected to raise nearly a million dollars for the Center, an L.G.B.T.Q. nonprofit in the city.
lead_paragraph: Owning a private collection of nearly 140 artworks by luminaries like Jean-Michel Basquiat, Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein would be a godsend for most arts organizations, but it was a burden for the Keith Haring Foundation.

headline: The 5 Best Ways to Prevent Mosquito Bites
abstract: There are more options for handling mosquitoes than simply drenching yourself in a smelly DEET-based repellent. Here’s what the experts recommend.
lead_paragraph: With the global pandemic keeping many of us indoors for extended stretches, outdoor excursions have started to feel more like therapy than leisure. Whether you’re by the beach, camping, or in your backyard, not much can disrupt a late-summer idyll quite like a mosquito buzzing incessantly in your ear.

headline: March on Washington 2020: Protesters Hope to Rekindle Spirit of 1963
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Census', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: Thousands gathered for a protest on Friday aiming to recall the March on Washington and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours after President Trump stood on the South Lawn of the White House to rail against what he called agitators bent on destroying “the American way of life,” thousands of Americans streamed to the Lincoln Memorial, not a mile away, on Friday to deliver what frequently seemed to be a direct reply.

headline: Teaching Resources for Middle School Using The New York Times
abstract: Activities and lessons that can be employed by English, social studies, math and science educators, using Times photos, illustrations, graphs, videos, podcasts and articles.
lead_paragraph: Some teachers might think that The New York Times, with its sophisticated language and lengthy articles, is too adult or advanced a resource for many middle school students. But teachers who have used The Learning Network tell us that the array of activities we’ve created using Times content — including photos, illustrations, graphs and videos — gives students at different reading levels a chance to deepen their thinking and expand their knowledge of the world.

keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Cycling, Road', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Masks', 'Quarantines']
abstract: The coronavirus has forced a race celebrated for its accessibility to embrace social distancing. But can you take an entire country along for the ride from inside a bubble?
lead_paragraph: One rider said he worried cycling fans would ignore edicts about masks. A small-town mayor said he would do his best to abide by limits on crowd sizes. A team official expressed concerns about sweat, and spit, and at least one mechanic said he had stopped sharing his tools.

headline: Japan’s Leader Is Leaving. Here’s How It Might Pick a New One.

headline: India’s Covid Outbreak Is Now the World’s Fastest-Growing
abstract: Crowded cities, lockdown fatigue and a lack of contact tracing have spread the coronavirus to every corner of the vast country.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India now has the fastest-growing coronavirus caseload of any country in the world, reporting more than 75,000 new infections per day.

headline: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘The Sting’
abstract: Sharp clothes, sharp tunes, sharp acting. This Redford-Newman con-men picture swindles viewers, too. But so what? It’s a con that leaves us feeling richer.
lead_paragraph: Frankly, I didn’t understand “The Sting” when it opened in 1973 and I was 10. What with the movie’s manifold tricks and streetwise double-crossings, I grasped only the basics. In 1930s gangland Chicago, two handsome, sneaky crooks (Paul Newman and Robert Redford) were swindling another handsome, far more sinister crook (Robert Shaw). This they do by trying to fleece him of half a million dollars in a bogus betting parlor, populated by a mob of their associates. What I liked most were the mustaches.

headline: A Sculptural Sofa, Rereleased for the First Time
abstract: Designed by Mario Bellini, the Camaleonda was a hit when MoMA included it in a landmark 1972 show.
lead_paragraph: Several of the museum shows that set the cultural course of the late 20th century took place in a single year: 1972. In addition to the “Documenta 5” exhibition in Kassel, Germany, a wide-ranging spectacle that signaled the rise of mass media, and the British Museum’s “Treasures of Tutankhamun,” which opened not only the Egyptian pharaoh’s tomb but the floodgate for traveling blockbusters, there was the Museum of Modern Art’s “Italy: The New Domestic Landscape.” Twelve legendary Italian designers and design groups were invited to create environments in the museum’s galleries, while dozens more presented their works in the sculpture garden, among them Achille and Pier Giacomo Castiglioni’s Arco arching lamp and the Olivetti Valentine typewriter by Ettore Sottsass, who would later lead the colorful Memphis collective.

headline: The Psychiatrist Will See You Online Now
keywords: ['your-feed-science', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Telemedicine', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Depression (Mental)', 'your-feed-health']
abstract: Experts have long predicted that psychotherapy was poised to go virtual. The pandemic may prove them right.
lead_paragraph: For about two years, Michael Raymos made the drive from Modesto, Calif., to Sacramento and back for therapy, and for the therapist, who could listen to stories of childhood abuse and gently unwind their hold on the present. Those regular office sessions, at a clinic at the University of California, Davis, created a strong bond, and Mr. Raymos came to rely on them to manage symptoms of post-traumatic stress and the emotional weight of a neurodegenerative disorder that struck him in 2012, in the prime of adulthood.

headline: A Visitor’s Guide to MoMA and the Met
abstract: What you need to know before you head back to the museums, from safety precautions to the exhibitions still on view.
lead_paragraph: Before you head back to the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, there are some things you need to know: capacity will be limited to 25 percent, temperature checks and face masks will be mandatory, and the advance purchase of tickets is required. Each museum has specific guidelines, so you’ll want to visit their websites: moma.org and metmuseum.org. Our critics have reviewed some of the new shows — “Félix Fénéon” at MoMA, and “Making the Met,” “Jacob Lawrence” and Héctor Zamora’s rooftop sculpture at the Met — but they also weighed in previously about several exhibitions that are still on view. Below, you’ll find an overview of those shows, as well as a partial listing of some of the museums opening in the coming days. NICOLE HERRINGTON

The story goes that the former first lady used Gucci’s slouchy leather tote, originally named the G1244, to shield herself from the paparazzi. keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)']

lead_paragraph: Heather Boushey, who is unofficially one of the top economic advisers to Joseph R. Biden Jr., does not play to type. When the progressive economist and I arranged to meet last December in a Midtown Manhattan coffee shop, I was expecting someone buttoned up, and I couldn’t find her in the room. Then she texted and waved from just a few feet away. She was wearing a Stephen Malkmus and the Jicks T-shirt — a niche band featuring the lead singer of the beloved 1990s indie group Pavement.

headline: Today’s Chefs Are Honoring a Vital Tradition: Feeding the Revolution
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Food', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Hunger Strikes']
abstract: As Americans have taken to the streets demanding racial justice, restaurants and nonprofits have provided meals for them, building upon a long legacy of food as resistance.
lead_paragraph: THE KITCHEN IS an arsenal. Bring out the pots and pans and bang them like drums, clash lids, whack spoons. That the weapons are so humble is the point: everyday essentials, available to all. Orchestras equipped like this once paraded through medieval Europe, in the traditions of the French charivari and its English equivalent, “rough music,” descending on the homes of those believed to have betrayed social mores — what the English folk historian Violet Alford called “the beginning of popular justice.” This took on a more political tone in the mid-19th century, with housewives in Paris bashing pans outside their landlords’ windows, demanding relief from rent. Today, such disruptive noisemaking has been borrowed as a form of collective action around the world, often under the name cacerolazo (from the Spanish for “casserole”), popularized by a 1971 demonstration against food shortages in Chile in which more than 5,000 women took to the streets rattling pots, the emptiness of which gave testament to their cause.

keywords: ['Human Trafficking', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: A second man from Northern Ireland has pleaded guilty in a case that shocked Britons when the bodies of 39 Vietnamese were found in a truck trailer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A trucking company manager from Northern Ireland pleaded guilty on Friday to the manslaughter of 39 Vietnamese people, including two 15-year-old boys, whose bodies were found last year in a truck trailer in Essex, east of London.

headline: Watch Full Video: Wisconsin Officials Give Update on Blake Investigation

lead_paragraph: Several law enforcement and public officials in Wisconsin held a news conference at the Kenosha Public Safety Building about the investigation into the police shooting of Jacob Blake.

headline: Auli’i Cravalho on Her New Netflix Drama and the Smell of Wet Dog
abstract: Playing a homeless teen in “All Together Now” was taxing for several reasons, but the voice of “Moana” was happy to continue her run of strong female roles.
lead_paragraph: A lot has changed for Auli’i Cravalho since her first film.

headline: A Poignant Portrait of a Childhood Friend
abstract: A work by Tyler Mitchell speaks to the artist’s desire to expand ideas about Black masculinity.
lead_paragraph: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work into context. This week, we’re looking at a piece by Tyler Mitchell, a photographer and filmmaker who focuses on Black subjects and is invested in creating a more equitable aesthetic culture.

keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Water Pollution', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

headline: Ian McRae, Who Brought Electricity to Black South Africa, Dies at 90
abstract: As head of the state-owned utility, he defied apartheid laws by laying the groundwork for providing power to the nonwhite townships and by hiring Black people. He died of the novel coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Love Letter: Can Your Relationship Survive a Political Divide?
abstract: Plus: A son becomes a distant memory.
lead_paragraph: Some say that opposites attract, but that may not be the case when it comes to political views. It’s one thing to ignore the opposing political opinions of a friend or a co-worker, but when your spouse has drastically different political views  it can put a strain on your relationship. And, with the presidential race in full swing, politically-divided couples find themselves at odds now more than ever.

headline: In a Naked Pandemic Race, You Can Leave Your Hat On
abstract: When we can’t go outside without covering our faces, there’s a special appeal in the opportunity to uncover everything else.
lead_paragraph: In a lot of ways, the 5K I ran on Saturday was like any other race: The tall, skinny guys zipped out front, fast. Spectators rang cowbells. I heard the “Rocky” theme twice along the course.

headline: Ulcerative Colitis, Abe’s Affliction, Is a Long-Term, Debilitating Disease
abstract: The illness that has afflicted Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan is a chronic gastrointestinal disorder that can unexpectedly flare up.
lead_paragraph: Ulcerative colitis, the gastrointestinal affliction that has debilitated Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan so badly that he is resigning, is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease, which is suffered by millions and can flare up unpredictably.

headline: Kurt Andersen on ‘Evil Geniuses’
abstract: Andersen talks about his new book, and Lesley M.M. Blume discusses “Fallout.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: ‘But I Saw It on Facebook’: Hoaxes Are Making Doctors’ Jobs Harder
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Social Media', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Hospitals', 'Doctors', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: Without the support of social platforms, our efforts to stamp out viral misinformation feel futile.
lead_paragraph: The news came from a colleague — not a doctor but someone who works in the emergency room and has seen firsthand the devastation caused by the pandemic. “There is a cure for Covid-19,” he said. “It must be true because a doctor friend shared a Facebook post about this cure.”

headline: Dirk Mudge, Who Played a Key Role in Namibian Independence, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Mudge was a pro-apartheid politician who later turned toward helping lay the foundations of multiracial democracy. He died of Covid-19 complications.
lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Ted Danson Made D’Arcy Carden a Better Not-a-Robot
abstract: In a conversation, the Emmy nominees and former “Good Place” co-stars discuss their appreciation for the show, the creator Michael Schur and each other.
lead_paragraph: The 72nd Primetime Emmy Awards will be given out on Sept. 20, so we’re talking to pairs of nominated actors as we look ahead to the ceremony. (Whatever it ends up being.) For a full list of Emmy nominees and other coverage of TV’s top awards, visit nytimes.com/Emmys.

headline: At a nontraditional convention, some sartorial traditions endure.

lead_paragraph: Shirlene Ostrov was looking forward to her first convention.

lead_paragraph: Is the “WAP” hubbub over yet?

headline: Trump Extends Pardon to Alice Johnson After She Praises Him at Convention
abstract: The president, who previously commuted her sentence, said he saw her in the audience as he accepted the nomination for a second term and decided to elevate his action to a full pardon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump employed his power of clemency on Friday for the second time this week in connection with his nominating convention, issuing a full pardon for Alice Marie Johnson, a onetime drug convict, a day after she appeared in a campaign video praising his leadership.

headline: The Trump Women, Trying to Help Trump With Women
abstract: Tiffany Trump, Lara Trump, Kimberly Guilfoyle and, of course, Ivanka Trump all took a turn at promoting the family business — for all intents and purposes, President Trump — on the convention stage.
lead_paragraph: If you were to create a chart showing the hierarchical position of each of President Trump’s four adult children, judging from how often he sees, mentions or is photographed with them, you would surely place the golden child of the family, Ivanka Trump, at the very top. Next would come the two sons — Donald Trump Jr. and Eric.

headline: ‘End of the Line’: School Bus Industry in Crisis Because of the Coronavirus
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Buses', 'Education (K-12)', 'Transportation', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Coronavirus Reopenings', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Stimulus (Economic)']
abstract: Industry leaders say it will be the nation’s schoolchildren and parents who will suffer, as they alter their lives and figure out how to replace a mode of transportation that was once a certainty.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Glenn Every received notice in early March that schools in the Hudson Valley of New York would close because of the coronavirus pandemic, he parked his fleet of 20 school buses thinking they would be running again in a few months.

headline: Readers Would Add These African-American Directors to the Criterion Collection
abstract: As the prestigious archive addresses its severe lack of such filmmakers, we asked you who should be included. You had a lot of ideas.
lead_paragraph: Why aren’t there more African-American filmmakers in the Criterion Collection, the prestigious Blu-ray/DVD archive of cinema from around the world?

headline: 7 Takeaways From ‘Melania and Me,’ by the First Lady’s Former Friend
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'First Ladies (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Stephanie Winston Wolkoff was part of the Trumps’ inner circle — until she wasn’t. Her memoir is a cautionary tale.
lead_paragraph: Melania Trump was the sister Stephanie Winston Wolkoff never had — “a really confident, perfectly coiffed, ultimate older sister,”  the former senior adviser to the first lady writes in “Melania and Me,” her epic scream of a tell-all, which comes out Tuesday.

headline: After 7 Years on the Run, a Muslim Brotherhood Leader Is Caught
abstract: Egypt said that a raid in Cairo had netted the outlawed movement’s acting leader, Mahmoud Ezzat, who was thought to have fled abroad.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s interior ministry said Friday that a security services raid on a Cairo apartment had captured Mahmoud Ezzat, the acting leader of the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood, who had been on the run for seven years.

headline: House Panel Moves to Hold Pompeo in Contempt of Congress
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States International Relations', 'Subpoenas']
abstract: The House Foreign Affairs Committee cited Mike Pompeo’s defiance of subpoenas related to the State Department’s compliance with Senate Republicans’ investigation targeting the Bidens.
lead_paragraph: The House Foreign Affairs Committee announced on Friday that it would move to hold Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in contempt of Congress for defying its subpoenas related to the State Department’s participation in Senate Republicans’ investigation targeting the Bidens.

headline: Here’s What You Need to Know About Donald G. McNeil Jr.
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'Newsletters', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Republican National Convention', 'Democratic National Convention']
abstract: A Q&A with The Daily’s coronavirus expert.
lead_paragraph: Since February, Donald G. McNeil Jr. has been our go-to guide for understanding the coronavirus. He warned us in February, before the outbreak was classified as a pandemic, that it may soon become a global health crisis, and in March, when everything still felt new and uncertain, he offered essential advice on how to avoid infection. This week, he joined us again to explain four recent developments on our understanding of the virus.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: California wildfires. College football’s pandemic playbook. A family divided by politics. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. Can you believe we’re already in the last few days of August? Maybe you or your loved ones are gearing up for a return to school. This summer’s been a tough one, but I hope you’ve managed to get some moments of rest. Whatever you’re doing this weekend, be sure to make time for some great journalism.

headline: Alice Koller, Author of the Solitary Life, Dies at 94
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Her book, “An Unknown Woman,” has been compared to a feminist’s Walden and has attracted fans inspired by her self-reckoning.
lead_paragraph: At 37, Alice Koller was unsettled. She had a Ph.D. in philosophy from Harvard, a résumé of small-bore jobs in and out of academia and no fixed address. She was bright and educated, yet she had floundered.

headline: Nxivm ‘Sex Cult’ Leader Should Get Life in Prison, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Keith Raniere was convicted last year in a trial that exposed the inner workings of the group, in which women were branded and coerced into sex.
lead_paragraph: The self-help group Nxivm gained notoriety as a “sex cult” last year when its leader, Keith Raniere, was convicted of sex trafficking, racketeering and conspiracy after testimony that he had created a harem of sexual “slaves,” branded with his initials and kept in line with blackmail.

headline: Larry Pardey, Mariner Who Sailed the World Engineless, Dies at 80
abstract: With his wife, Lin, he circumnavigated the world twice on wooden boats he had built. And they always took their time.
lead_paragraph: On a perilous westerly course bound for Cape Horn near the southern tip of South America in 2002, Larry and Lin Pardey made their approach into the hazardous currents of the Strait of Le Maire aboard Taleisin, their 29-foot, engineless wooden yacht.

headline: The People You’d ‘Pay Admission’ to Know
abstract: They’re just that delightful or fascinating or brilliant.
lead_paragraph: Welcome. I recently received a message on social media from a long-lost friend. We’d been inseparable in college, co-conspirators, ecstatic with newfound freedom that manifested in what, decades on, I see in a montage from a film that could be described as a “heartwarming coming-of-age caper”: Gossipy late-night dorm-room study sessions. Swapping clothes. Dancing deliriously at an on-campus concert of the Village People. A spring break trip to New York where we bought matching wool berets and wore them to what to us was the city’s coolest nightclub, the Limelight.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
abstract: Travelers are being shamed for potentially spreading the virus.
lead_paragraph: Vacations have become a serious point of contention among families, friends and strangers on social media, who say travelers may be unnecessarily putting their health in jeopardy, or unknowingly spreading the virus to others.

headline: Movies Are Returning to Theaters. Will Audiences Follow?
abstract: Big-budget films are being released for the first time since March, but the willingness of people to sit inside a closed room with strangers for several hours is still uncertain.
lead_paragraph: HENDERSON, Nev. — The Regal Sunset Station multiplex in suburban Las Vegas reopened on Thursday night after sitting empty for five months in eerie pandemic-forced exile. One of the first people to take a center seat, popcorn and orange soda in hand, was Brian Truitt, who bought tickets to “The New Mutants,” a Marvel superhero movie, a week in advance.

headline: Trump Says Crime Is Rampant in N.Y.C. Here Are the Facts.
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: At the Republican National Convention, the president and two other New Yorkers painted a dark picture of the city. The reality is more complex.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump sought to paint an apocalyptic portrait of big-city crime as out of control at the Republican National Convention Thursday night, he turned to two fellow New Yorkers to help him make the case.

headline: Conventions Can Boost the Incumbent. Did It Work This Time?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Presidential Election of 2004', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: The Trump team’s approach to the task of pigeonholing the challenger looked less focused than those used in 2004 and 2012.
lead_paragraph: The last two presidential re-election campaigns followed a similar playbook: define the opposition early on the most important issue, emphasize a few cultural wedge issues to rally the base while appealing to a few swing voters, and reinvigorate supporters at the convention. It was enough for George W. Bush in 2004 and Barack Obama in 2012 to flip their approval ratings from negative to positive, and to win re-election.

headline: Jacob Blake, Plasma, September Books: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: With a New Leader, Conservatives Look to Unseat Justin Trudeau
abstract: Under Erin O’Toole, defeating the Liberal government may involve shifting Conservative Party policies.
lead_paragraph: In keeping with the general upheaval that has marked this year, the Conservative Party of Canada announced its new leader at an unusual time: in the middle of the United States’ presidential nominating conventions.

headline: ‘The New Mutants’ Review: Maybe All the Cool Super Powers Were Taken
abstract: This much-delayed “X-Men”-related film from Josh Boone features five teens with not-so-great powers.
lead_paragraph: How does one disavow an unruly mutant? Lock it up, says the Essex Corporation, the villain of “The New Mutants,” an “X-Men”-adjacent thriller about a detention hall for ultra-destructive kids — and 20th Century Studios, the manufacturer of this ramshackle flick, agrees. Directed in 2017 by Josh Boone (“The Fault in Our Stars”), “The New Mutants” spent three years on ice before being allowed to escape into the slowest summer season in a century. That’s fitting for a film that’s all buildup and no bang.

headline: 2 TikTok Stars Who Threw Big Parties Face Charges, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Bryce Hall and Blake Gray are accused of defying a ban against big gatherings in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The TikTok stars Bryce Hall and Blake Gray are facing criminal charges for throwing mega-parties at their Hollywood Hills mansion in defiance of a ban against large gatherings in Los Angeles, prosecutors announced on Friday.

headline: ‘We Need to Adapt’: California Unveils New Virus Reopening Plan
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom said California’s plan to reopen businesses would be based on a system of tiers, tied to positive tests and new cases of the coronavirus.

headline: After a Long Lull, Protesting Is Taking Hold Across Baseball
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Basketball', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Carlos Delgado remembered the difficulty of demonstrating alone 16 years ago. Now, he and current players are encouraged by a growing sense of solidarity with Black athletes.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Delgado, the former Toronto Blue Jays and Mets slugger, was playing basketball with his 13-year-old son at their home in Puerto Rico on Wednesday evening when he noticed a news alert on his phone: The Milwaukee Bucks players were sitting out of their N.B.A. playoff game to protest systemic racism and police brutality following the shooting of Jacob Blake, a Black man, by police in Kenosha, Wis.

headline: An American Disaster Foretold
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States International Relations', 'Voter Fraud (Election Fraud)', 'Absentee Voting']
abstract: Europeans look at “containment” as the means to deal with Trump.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Henry Kissinger this month called François Delattre, the former French ambassador to the United States who is now the secretary general of the Foreign Ministry. Kissinger was concerned about the deteriorating state of U.S.-Chinese relations and the risk that the situation could slip out of control.

headline: The Massacre That Emboldened White Supremacists
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Reconstruction Era', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Thirteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Fourteenth Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: The 1873 murders of dozens of former slaves in a flyspeck Louisiana town still reverberate.
lead_paragraph: An hour after sunset on Easter Sunday in 1873, a stern-wheel riverboat put ashore at Colfax, La., a ramshackle settlement surrounded by cotton plantations on the east bank of the Red River. Rain was falling. As passengers disembarked, they found themselves stumbling in the dark over what turned out to be the lifeless bodies of African-Americans who had been freed from slavery eight years earlier at the conclusion of the Civil War.

headline: The Conventions Hit Closer to Home This Year
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: Both the Republican and Democratic events reflected the odd mashup of our current media moment.
lead_paragraph: The faces flicker across our screens, making a pitch in speech and song to voters who may or may not be listening. To document the national political conventions in this pandemic year, Damon Winter went into ordinary people’s homes in upstate New York and projected images from the live broadcasts across bedrooms, living rooms, kitchens, basements — wherever the residents typically watch or listen to the news. The photographs he took of these projections capture the strangeness of this year’s conventions, and how dramatically they differed from the events in a typical year.

headline: TV Ratings for Biden and Trump Signal an Increasingly Polarized Nation
keywords: ['Television', 'News and News Media', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Fox News dominated ratings for the Republican convention, and MSNBC was the clear No. 1 for the Democrats’ gathering.
lead_paragraph: Americans who watched the political conventions on television opted for news networks with partisan fan bases to a degree unseen in recent years, another sign of an increasingly divided electorate as the nation hurtles toward the November election.

headline: Dead Dolphins Wash Ashore After Oil Spill Off Mauritius
abstract: The deaths have added to growing concern that the spill could be disastrous for Mauritius, a tiny island nation off Africa’s eastern coast that is highly dependent on fishing and tourism.
lead_paragraph: Environmentalists are expressing alarm over an increasing number of dead dolphins that have washed ashore on Mauritius after a Japanese ship ran aground last month, spilling oil into the famed blue lagoons off the Indian Ocean island.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Political Advertising', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']

keywords: ['Hurricane Laura (2020)', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']

headline: Generic Rivalry
abstract: Michael Hawkins leaves us stranded on a corner.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Another day, another themeless Hawkins puzzle to drive us crazy. (For a fun fact, don’t miss the Constructor Notes.) Michael Hawkins is familiar, with plenty of grids under his belt including a good crunchy Saturday back in July. Today’s puzzle has a lot of offbeat elements to it that made for a pleasant ski run for me, until I skidded on the ice in the southeast corner, flew into the woods and had to wait for a dog to dig me out, the mental equivalent of what happens when I draw enough blanks that I have to leave a puzzle alone for a while. Where does that good dog come from?

headline: ‘Black Panther’ Star Chadwick Boseman Dies of Cancer at 43
abstract: The actor also played groundbreaking figures like James Brown, Jackie Robinson and Thurgood Marshall, becoming one of his generation’s most sought-after leading men.
lead_paragraph: Chadwick Boseman, the regal actor who embodied a long-held dream of African-American moviegoers as the star of the groundbreaking superhero film “Black Panther,” died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 43.

headline: Djokovic and Other Top Men Are Creating a Players’ Association
abstract: It is not clear whether the group will operate like a union, although it was billed that way to get players to join. Women are not being included.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated by what they view as a lack of leverage in men’s tennis, Novak Djokovic and Vasek Pospisil are forming a breakaway body to represent the interests of male players outside of the current structure of the Association of Tennis Professionals, and have resigned their leadership roles in the association’s player council.

headline: Chadwick Boseman, Who Starred in ‘Black Panther,’ Is Mourned as a ‘Superhero’
abstract: Oprah Winfrey and Joseph R. Biden Jr. were among those who praised the actor, who died on Friday at 43, for his portrayals of Black leaders and his perseverance against cancer.
lead_paragraph: After the announcement late Friday that the “Black Panther” star Chadwick Boseman had died, tributes began pouring in on social media from prominent figures in entertainment, politics and beyond.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Get Duked!’ and NASCAR
abstract: Four teenagers try to escape the Scottish Highlands alive in “Get Duked!” And NASCAR’s regular season finale kicks off in Daytona.
lead_paragraph: GET DUKED! (2019) Stream on Amazon. Three troublemaking teenagers and a strait-laced loner head out on a character-building camping excursion in the Scottish Highlands — what could go wrong? In this film, from the music-video director Ninian Doff, the boys encounter trouble in the form of a homicidal couple (played by Eddie Izzard and Georgie Glen) armed and hellbent on maintaining “the integrity of the species.” In her New York Times review, Manohla Dargis wrote that “the movie is loud, busy and cheerfully glib, though at one point — after the weapons and politics have been brandished — it takes a brief turn to sincerity.”

headline: Where to Stream Chadwick Boseman’s Best Performances
abstract: The star made a specialty of playing Black heroes real (Jackie Robinson, Thurgood Marshall) and imaginary (Black Panther).

keywords: ['Basketball', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Organized Labor', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Strikes']
abstract: Professional basketball players demonstrated the enormous power of highly paid workers with rare skills, but also their caution.
lead_paragraph: Like a vintage LeBron James dunk, the pro basketball labor stoppage was remarkable both for its display of strength and for the speed with which it ended.

headline: Shinzo Abe’s Resignation Prompts Speculation About His Successor
abstract: Whoever the Liberal Democratic Party elects as its leader, probably within the next week, will almost certainly become Japan’s next prime minister. It isn’t clear who that will be.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In his resignation speech on Friday, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said that the executives of his conservative political party were finalizing plans for selecting a new leader. Speculation about who that might be was swirling even before he took the podium.

headline: Splaining How Government Works to Young Voters
abstract: Ben Sheehan runs a nonprofit that uses humor for civic education.
lead_paragraph: Name: Ben Sheehan

headline: Is Teleprompter Trump Effective?
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: Although most voters complain about President Trump’s often abrasive personality, Americans over all are actually far more likely to say they’re bothered by his personal foibles than by his politics.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.

headline: Biden’s Approval Rating, G.O.P. Recasts Trump: This Week in the 2020 Race
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Republican National Convention', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: President Trump, during his convention speech, did little to acknowledge the coronavirus pandemic, warning instead of what would become of the country’s economy and “greatness” if Joe Biden were elected.

headline: After 90 Years, Columbia Takes Slave Owner’s Name Off a Dorm
keywords: ['Names, Organizational', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Samuel Bard was George Washington’s doctor and delivered Alexander Hamilton’s first son. He was also a “pretty significant slave owner.”
lead_paragraph: Little is known about the 18th-century New Yorker described in an advertisement seeking the return of a runaway slave in 1776 beyond his given name (James), what he looked like (tall and thin, with bloodshot eyes) and that he was talkative.

headline: Christmas Time Is … Here?
abstract: On TikTok, the holiday spirit has come early.
lead_paragraph: Hannah Smith is “usually not one of those people who gets excited about Christmas in July,” she said.

headline: What It’s Like to Be an R.A. Now
abstract: Dorm life got kinda serious.
lead_paragraph: Resident advisers have always played a key role in how colleges implement behavioral policies. An R.A. will typically oversee a dormitory floor or building; they are responsible for limiting parties and helping new students settle in. At some schools, R.A.s are trained in how to help prevent sexual assault. Now, colleges have drafted them to another front line.

headline: How to Meet New People, Even at a Distance
keywords: ['Loneliness', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Quarantines', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Social Media', 'Friendship', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Online and offline platforms are helping strangers form social connections, which are crucial for our health, especially in a pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A retired teacher, a Midwestern minister and a mother of two teenagers all dial into a Zoom room. For the next 90 minutes, they do something their typical adult lives don’t usually afford them a chance to do: listen to others’ perspectives, and have others listen to them. And after three rounds of answering not-so-standard questions, like “What sense of purpose guides you in your life?”, the group leaves the room, feeling deeply connected.

headline: Wedding Presents That Will Turn Any House Into a Home
abstract: Industry experts share their favorite gifts that are sure to warm any couple’s hearts and home.
lead_paragraph: For many couples, the moment they announce their newly engaged status, questions like, “When is the wedding?” and “Where are you registered?” are sure to follow. Creating a gift registry has become an obligatory (and sometimes overwhelming) part of planning a wedding. And, for family and friends, it can sometimes feel as if there’s a fine art to picking the perfect gift that is both practical and special. We asked a few industry pros — from a celebrity planner to a celebrated fashion designer — for their favorite wedding gifts. Here are a few of them.

headline: Your Coronavirus Test Is Positive. Maybe It Shouldn’t Be.
abstract: The usual diagnostic tests may simply be too sensitive and too slow to contain the spread of the virus.
lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s leading public health experts are raising a new concern in the endless debate over coronavirus testing in the United States: The standard tests are diagnosing huge numbers of people who may be carrying relatively insignificant amounts of the virus.

headline: Intimacy in Isolation
abstract: It can be unsettling to be seen. Now I have to see myself.
lead_paragraph: I have been alone for months.

headline: Did Something Burp? It Was an Earthquake
abstract: Years of observations in central Italy show that more carbon dioxide percolates through Earth’s crust during periods of strong seismic activity.
lead_paragraph: During earthquakes, spider webs of faults open up below ground, allowing gases deep within our planet to percolate upward. Researchers have now compiled the first long-term record that shows a relationship between earthquakes and the release of carbon dioxide gas.

headline: What Is Waacking, and Why Is It All Over TikTok?
abstract: A few dedicated New Yorkers are masters of the 1970s club dance, which has become a social media sensation.
lead_paragraph: Princess Lockerooo is a whirling force with a singular focus: spreading the gospel of waacking.

keywords: ['Basketball', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

lead_paragraph: Whenever a W.N.B.A. team steps on the floor during the 2020 season, Angel McCoughtry’s influence is there.

headline: Fashion Advertisers Rediscover Black Models
keywords: ['Black People', 'Blacks', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Models (Professional)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Magazines']

lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade ago, when Precious Lee arrived for a modeling go-see, she was grilled about her ethnic background. The clients, who were representing a deep-pocketed luxury brand, were looking for a mixed-race model, Ms. Lee recalled. When she told them that she was Black, their faces fell.

headline: Trump Program to Cover Uninsured Covid-19 Patients Falls Short of Promise
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)', 'Hospitals', 'Medicaid', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: Some patients are still receiving staggering bills. Others don’t qualify because conditions other than Covid-19 were their primary diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Marilyn Cortez, a retired cafeteria worker in Houston with no health insurance, spent much of July in the hospital with Covid-19. When she finally returned home, she received a $36,000 bill that compounded the stress of her illness.

headline: N.B.A. Brings Flash to E-Sports, but Can It Hold On to Its Viewers?
abstract: Despite challenges, the N.B.A. continues to build its e-sports program, saying it generates sponsorship revenue and provides valuable data on viewing habits of cord-cutters.
lead_paragraph: Since its introduction two years ago, the National Basketball Association’s e-sports arm has struggled to draw viewers. Then, with Americans forced to shelter in place in early March, the N.B.A. had a captive audience.

headline: Enjoy That Last Gasp of Summer
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Movies', 'Content Type: Service', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Pizza', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Summer (Season)', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Tired of your routine? With the unofficial final weekend of the season on its way, here are seven ways to step up your leisure game.
lead_paragraph: Movies have always been escapist: During the Great Depression, audiences flocked to cinemas in an attempt to forget their worries, at least for a while. Today, as the pandemic continues, drive-in theaters have been popping up all over. In Astoria, Queens, the Bel Aire Diner started one in its parking lot, while Walmart has turned parking lots at 160 of its Supercenter locations into outdoor movie theaters with free showings through Oct. 21.

headline: European Leaders Weigh New Lockdowns as Cases Rise
abstract: Some in Europe fear a return to lockdowns as cases rise. Colleges struggle to rein in sororities and fraternities.

headline: Berlin Police Halt March Against Coronavirus Restrictions, Saying Protesters Risked Spreading Disease
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Neo Nazi Groups', 'Politics and Government', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Thousands had gathered in the German capital. But the march was shut down after an hour for failing to obey social distancing rules.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Thousands of Germans angered over restrictions intended to control the coronavirus marched in Berlin on Saturday, but the police dispersed them after an hour because many were violating the very social-distancing rules championed by Chancellor Angela Merkel that they say threaten their rights and livelihoods.

headline: A Python Ate the President’s Neighbor? Only in Carl Hiaasen’s Florida
abstract: “Squeeze Me,” Hiaasen’s new novel, is an unabashedly political satire full of his signature high jinks.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2016, when reality TV stars were still funny, Carl Hiaasen wrote a book, “Razor Girl,” taking aim at some. They were the Nance brothers, an ersatz crew of bayou types who actually came from a wealthy Milwaukee suburb and had to be coached to sound like Cajuns (except for the racial and ethnic slurs, which they had down pat). The book holds up even though its “Duck Dynasty” muses have moved on.

headline: Many Want to Be Japan’s New Leader. Do They Know What Awaits Them?
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Elections', 'Women and Girls', 'International Relations']
abstract: The coronavirus, a tanking economy, an aggressive China, a postponed Olympics, a U.S. election: That’s just the start. And any successor will confront those challenges without having the stature of Shinzo Abe.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese economy has taken a historic nosedive. The coronavirus could yet rage out of control and force a second postponement of the Olympics. Chinese military aggression is rising in the region just as America, Japan’s closest ally, is embroiled in a polarizing presidential election.

headline: Staying Afloat: A Pandemic Financial Guide for Millennials
keywords: ['Content Type: Service', 'Millennial Generation', 'Personal Finances', 'Mortgages', 'Recession and Depression', 'Credit Scores', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Younger people were hit particularly hard by the economic crisis. Whether or not you were greatly affected, here are ways to manage your finances during the pandemic.

headline: How the G.O.P. Stretched Hard to Defend Trump on Race and Gender
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Women and Girls', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Democratic National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Never before has a convention by a major party felt compelled to call such a diverse array of speakers to defend the character of a sitting president.
lead_paragraph: The Republican convention this week marked an extraordinary effort to recast President Trump’s image on issues of race and gender, with the party stretching to find African-Americans who would testify that Mr. Trump is not racist, and lining up women to describe him as sensitive and empathetic — qualities he rarely displays in public.

headline: Deciding Who Gets to Live in the Family Home During a Divorce
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: A long-term plan for separate lives is the wisest choice for all parties.
lead_paragraph: Q: My husband and I recently decided to separate after many years together. Because we jointly own the house and are both named on the mortgage, I believe we should each be entitled to time living alone there. (Our children are grown, so there are no custody issues.) My husband disagrees and refuses to leave our home for any amount of time. Since I own half the house, do I have the legal right to have it to myself half of the time?

headline: The Princess vs. the Portrait in Trumpworld
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The first family serves up a malarkey buffet.

headline: Compare Pages From an Uncensored Book on Investigating Terrorism
‘That Same Feeling’: Painful Memories in Kenosha Come Rushing Back
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The auto plant closed in 1988, turning the Wisconsin city upside down. Now it’s facing an even deeper existential crisis.

abstract: As summer recedes, check out a comedy show inside a Nintendo game, get teary at ‘Porgy and Bess’ and catch a Ray Bradbury read-a-thon.
lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

headline: C.I.A. Uncensors Memoir of F.B.I. Agent Who Protested Torture of Terrorists
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Interrogations', 'Torture', 'Terrorism', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Censorship', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Nine years after the C.I.A. blacked out parts of Ali Soufan’s book, the agency has finally allowed a more complete version of his story to be published.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a group of Qaeda suspects was captured in September 2002, the C.I.A. flew Ali Soufan, an experienced F.B.I. counterterrorism agent, to Afghanistan to help interrogate them. But when he arrived, C.I.A. officials abruptly sent word to keep him from the two most significant new detainees.

headline: Catching the Buzz: A Young C.E.O. on Her Lemonade Business, Which Was Inspired by Bees
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Bees', 'Lemons', 'Honey', 'Personal Finances', 'Children and Childhood', 'Small Business', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Start-ups', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Health Foods']
abstract: Mikaila Ulmer’s “Bee Fearless” is that rarest of book breeds: the middle grade memoir.
lead_paragraph: A little more than halfway through “Bee Fearless,” the 10-year-old C.E.O. Mikaila Ulmer has her first encounter with a fancy advertising agency. Its experts love the mission of her lemonade business and wonder if they can help. She takes the meeting, and a designer lets her in on a secret: “It’s not the product you sell but the story you tell.” And so we get this rarest of book breeds: the middle grade start-up memoir, by a teenager.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon draw our attention to a foible.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s excerpt is a thinker. At first, I didn’t easily reconcile its content with its author, whom I admire but know for only one reason (which proves the excerpt’s point, to get meta). After reading an expanded version, I absorbed the meaning a bit better, and I now find it very timely and profound.

headline: Conventions to Match a Surreal Year
abstract: A photographer tries to find the moments of stillness.
lead_paragraph: This year’s conventions were not typical ones for photographers to shoot. Absent the massive crowds, bustling auditoriums and balloon fanfare of conventions past, they were left staring at candidates through a screen.

headline: From Iran to America, One Epic Tale at a Time
abstract: A modern-day Scheherazade uses storytelling to survive the fifth grade.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, my bedtime stories involved great warriors and kings, the heroes of ancient Persia. Many came from the “Shahnameh,” an epic Persian poem that weaves the history of Iran like a colorful tapestry. In “Everything Sad Is Untrue,” Daniel Nayeri weaves an equally rich history of his family’s journey from Iran to America.

headline: Humans Take a Step Closer to ‘Flying Cars’
abstract: A Japanese company said it had completed a manned flight of its electrical vertical takeoff and landing machine. Experts say the technology needs work and that it will be expensive.
lead_paragraph: In the 1880s, the first automobile was developed and about two decades later, the Wright brothers in North Carolina invented the first successful airplane. Today, the world is closer to combining those two concepts as a Japanese tech company said it completed a manned test flight of a “flying car.”

headline: Film Crew Spent 3 Years in Remote Balkan Hamlet. Will They Ever Leave?
abstract: Nominated for two Oscars, “Honeyland” charted the tensions between a hermitic beekeeper and her disorderly neighbors. Now the filmmakers are struggling to disentangle themselves from their subjects.
lead_paragraph: BEKIRLIJA, North Macedonia — When the producer and two directors of “Honeyland” returned to the setting of their documentary in North Macedonia for the first time since it earned two Oscar nominations in February, something fundamental had changed.

headline: Now Is the Time to Start Keeping a Journal
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: It can be like therapy, only cheaper, and provides a chronicle of our times.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a way to relax in these tense times? A way to know yourself better? To improve your writing and the stories you tell others about yourself? To create something that outlasts you? And for psychotherapy, on the cheap? What better time than now to start writing a journal.

headline: How to Forge a Solid Parent-Teacher Relationship
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Education', 'Content Type: Service', 'Parenting', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: This year is ‘almost like a full reset. A horrible reset, but a full reset.’
lead_paragraph: During a usual school year, Maria Davis-Pierre is one of those parents who regularly reach out to their children’s teachers. A mother of three in Lake Worth, Fla., and the founder of the parenting organization Autism in Black, Ms. Davis-Pierre checks in monthly via email and requests meetings upon receiving progress reports, working with her kids’ teachers to make sure that her eldest daughter especially — who is 8 and on the autism spectrum — is meeting her goals and getting the most from her schooling. “Especially for Black parents, we have to let them know that we’re involved,” Ms. Davis-Pierre said. “We want to know what’s going on.”

headline: Ideas for Better Political Debates
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Get rid of moderators? Use a chess clock? Hold them virtually? Eliminate debates altogether? Readers offer their suggestions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.K. Braces for School Return Amid Fears of Virus Spike
abstract: Can Britain reopen its schools safely? The Tory government is confident it can, but after an exam grading fiasco, trust in the government is running low.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When pupils return to Southend High School For Boys next week, the cafeteria will serve takeout food only and lunch will be eaten outside. Lessons will stretch to two-and-a-half hours to reduce the need to switch classrooms. And new equipment has been bought to spray the sports changing rooms with disinfectant.

headline: In One Louisiana City, a Police Shooting, a Pandemic and a Hurricane
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Hurricane Laura (2020)', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)']

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Republican National Convention', 'Race and Ethnicity']

lead_paragraph: President Trump and his party are entering the nine-week stretch until Election Day with their success riding on a hope that enough voters come to the following conclusion: You’re not as bad as we thought.

headline: Have a New Address? Don’t Lose Your Mail
keywords: ['Quarantine (Life and Culture)', 'Content Type: Service', 'Delivery Services', 'Moving and Moving Industry']
abstract: If you’ve decided to temporarily relocate, make sure your essential correspondence and eagerly anticipated packages can find you.
lead_paragraph: With many employers allowing staffers to work remotely well into 2021, you may be considering a temporary move. Perhaps you have relatives who need help with child care, or elderly parents to look after. Or maybe, if you’re going to be all alone for the next few months anyway, you’ve decided having deer as neighbors in a tiny house in the woods sounds better than communing with the roaches in your apartment.

headline: TikTok Deal Is Complicated by New Rules From China Over Tech Exports
keywords: ['Social Media', 'International Trade and World Market', 'E-Commerce', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Mobile Applications', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: In an 11th-hour twist, Beijing raised a potential hurdle for a sale of TikTok, further roiling the race to buy the Chinese-owned app.
lead_paragraph: As the sale of TikTok enters its final stages, Beijing is saying it wants the last word.

headline: College Football Is Not Essential
abstract: Why are some schools pressuring student-athletes to play a game that could expose them to the coronavirus?
lead_paragraph: For more than six months now, many workers deemed essential have had to strap on face masks for shifts at meatpacking plants, Walmarts, grocery stores, hardware stores and restaurants. It is a necessary sacrifice for the nation’s well-being. But at universities across the country, while scores of professors, staff and students start the academic year remotely to curb the spread of the coronavirus, another class of worker will be asked to strap on protective gear to do their job — without the face coverings: college football players.

headline: The Rent Eats First, Even During a Pandemic
keywords: ['Evictions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Unemployment', 'Quarantines']
abstract: Threatening to turn families out of their homes during the coronavirus fight isn’t just morally suspect; it’s dangerous.
lead_paragraph: A year and a half ago, Jhon Loaiza and his wife, Sugey Bedoya, moved with their three daughters — now 12, 5 and 3 — from a two-bedroom apartment in New York City to a compact brick ranch house in San Antonio. They loved that house — its fenced-in backyard and four whole bedrooms, each with soft tan carpet — and their new city. They would walk by the river with ice cream or ride bikes after Sunday church. At night, Mr. Loaiza would put on salsa or reggaeton, twirling his girls around the living room and laughing. His broad smile forced his dimples to crease in.

headline: The Lawbreakers Trump Loves
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Hatch Act (1939)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']

headline: Denying Alex Rodriguez, Mets Avoid a Risky Presence in the Owner’s Box
abstract: There’s no denying his charm and genuine passion for baseball. But his habit of overstepping boundaries would have made him an uncomfortable presence if he had succeeded in purchasing the Mets.
lead_paragraph: From the very start, Alex Rodriguez has been an achiever. He was the first overall draft pick at 17 years old and a batting champion at 21. He was the richest player in baseball at 25 and a three-time most valuable player at 32.

headline: All Aflutter
abstract: Olivia Mitra Framke’s puzzle has subtle and unpredictable ramifications.
lead_paragraph: *Important note for electronic solvers: The center box of this puzzle, which falls between 62- and 63-Across, is notably shaded gray in the print version, which makes it stand out from the beginning of the solve. This small difference alters the whole feel of working the puzzle, which is kind of confusing but appropriate, as you will see.

headline: Biden, Speaking to National Guard Group, Takes Aim at Republican Criticism on Crime
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Democratic presidential nominee hit back at attacks delivered at the Republican National Convention.

headline: Bison Are On the Run After 125 Escape a Nebraska Feedlot
abstract: So many people have been chasing the 50 stragglers that the animals got spooked and split off into singles and pairs, complicating efforts to catch them, a sheriff said.
lead_paragraph: After more than 100 bison escaped from a feedlot in southern Nebraska, local residents hopped into pickup trucks and onto horses and four-wheelers to try to catch the fleeing animals.

headline: What to Know About Colon Cancer
keywords: ['Colon and Colorectal Cancer', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Age, Chronological', 'Colonoscopy', 'Content Type: Service', 'your-feed-science', 'your-feed-health']
abstract: The cancer that killed Chadwick Boseman is the second-leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States, and rates are rising among younger people.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of Chadwick Boseman’s death from colon cancer at age 43, many people have questions about the disease, especially about the risk of colon cancer in younger people. Here’s what is known and what experts recommend.

headline: ‘Something Broke Inside Belarusians.’ Why an Apolitical People Rose Up
abstract: Comfortable urban elites long tolerated the eccentricities of the country’s ruler, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko. Then came the coronavirus and a blatantly falsified presidential election.
lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — Denis Dudinsky, the longhaired and mustachioed host of “Good Morning Belarus!,” can still hear the producer’s nervous voice in his ear any time his banter approached something remotely political.

headline: It’s Hard to Make Dignity Interesting. Chadwick Boseman Found a Way.
abstract: The actor, who died Friday at 43, exploded the parameters of what biographical moviemaking ought to be.
lead_paragraph: The problem with dignity is that there’s not much an actor can do with it. Not when he’s playing Jackie Robinson or Thurgood Marshall, not when you’re the leader of a made-up African kingdom, like Wakanda.

headline: No More In-Person Election Briefings for Congress, Intelligence Chief Says
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Lawmakers in both parties worry the move will block their ability to question and test intelligence assessments that can be crucial to ensuring that foreign powers do not undermine election results.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s top intelligence officials moved on Saturday to tighten control over the flow of sensitive intelligence about foreign threats to November’s election, telling Congress that they would no longer provide in-person briefings about election security and would rely solely on written updates instead.

headline: ‘Enough Is Enough’: New Racial Justice Leaders Rise in Kenosha
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement']
abstract: A new crop of activists has joined the ranks of protesters in Kenosha, Wis., as police killings across the country spur ordinary people into the streets. Jacob Blake’s family spoke at a rally on Saturday.

headline: The Milwaukee Bucks Are Back, but They’re Not Leaving Activism Behind
keywords: ['Basketball', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Playoff Games']
abstract: “This group wants to do both,” Coach Mike Budenholzer said of pursuing a championship without abandoning the team’s efforts to combat police brutality and systemic racism.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — It is bound to be forgotten with time that the Milwaukee Bucks, determined as they were in their pursuit of social justice, merely wanted to forfeit a basketball game Wednesday. The Bucks initially believed that they could stage a one-game, spur-of-the-moment walkout, even during the N.B.A. playoffs, without far-reaching consequences.

headline: Phoenix Settles With Black Family After Police Drew Guns Over Reported Doll Theft
keywords: ['George Floyd Protests (2020)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'Black Lives Matter Movement', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The settlement, which is for more than $470,000, comes after an episode last year in which officers responded to a shoplifting complaint at a Family Dollar store.
lead_paragraph: The city of Phoenix has reached a settlement with a Black family for more than $470,000 after a widely viewed video last year showed police officers drawing their weapons and shouting expletives at the family while responding to a shoplifting complaint.

headline: How to Build a Catapult From Newspaper
abstract: With a few folds and some tape you can soon be launching soft projectiles.
lead_paragraph: The use of catapults can be traced to the Greeks, Romans and Chinese more than 2,000 years ago. They were particularly popular during the Middle Ages as a way to launch projectiles over the walls of forts and castles. The catapult mechanism, also known as a lever, was, and still is, used to lift and move objects. If you have ever tossed a ball or played on a seesaw you have experienced the power of a lever.

headline: Amid Tennis’s Swirling Storms, a Stubborn Djokovic Claims a Title
abstract: “It has been challenging mentally and emotionally for me to stay sane,” said Novak Djokovic, who beat Milos Raonic on Saturday while working to create a controversial new players’ association.
lead_paragraph: After a six-month break from the tour, you might have expected tennis stars to look fresher than ever as they returned to playing in earnest.

headline: Quotation of the Day: District by District, a Plan for In-Person Schooling Falls Apart
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 30, 2020.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve been to student funerals. I would prefer not to go to any more.”

headline: With a Wary Eye on China, Taiwan Moves to Revamp Its Military
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: The self-governing democracy is taking steps to bolster its armed forces in order to deter or defeat an invasion from China — with or without American help.

headline: Shinzo Abe Is Quitting, and Leaving a Trail of Scandals Behind
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Will he ever face the Japanese people’s calls for accountability?
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s announcement on Friday that he would resign because of poor health was a rather abrupt end for a supposedly strong leader. Mr. Abe has ruled Japan, most recently, for a record seven years and eight months: He is the country’s longest-serving prime minister.

headline: One Person Dead in Portland After Clashes Between Trump Supporters and Protesters
abstract: A man affiliated with a right-wing group was shot and killed Saturday night. A caravan of supporters of President Trump had driven into downtown Portland.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — A fatal shooting during a night of political conflict in Portland, Ore., has yet again escalated tensions in the city and further inflamed the issues of crime, protest and race that President Trump is trying to make a focus of presidential politics.

headline: Looking to Reopen, Colleges Become Labs for Coronavirus Tests and Tracking Apps
